HEADLINE: 2,250 Layoffs Set at Chase, Or 3% of Staff

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
The Chase Manhattan Corporation, the nation's largest bank, said yesterday that it planned to lay off about 2,250 employees, or about 3 percent of its work force, as it consolidates administrative and business functions.
About half of the layoffs, or 1,125 jobs, will be in the New York metropolitan region and New York State. The cuts are part of a plan to eliminate about 4,500 of the bank's 69,033 positions over the next 18 months by laying off workers and by not replacing others who depart. 
 When Chase and the Chemical Banking Corporation agreed to merge in 1995, the two banks employed about 75,000 people. The completion of the merger in 1996 brought the elimination of about 12,000 jobs. But the number of employees subsequently grew, in part because of smaller acquisitions Chase pursued, such as last year's purchase of the credit card business of the Bank of New York Corporation.
Chase employees have been aware for some time that layoffs were on the way and a climate of uncertainty has pervaded the bank -- an uncertainty that will now be prolonged as Chase carries out the layoffs.
An internal memo circulated to employees in January indicated that layoffs were coming. At the time, Chase said it was freezing hiring in its corporate and business-support units. Chase also said it planned to trim $70 million a year from its budget by declaring a "moratorium on the use of all management consultants," reducing its sponsorship of events and other measures. Chase said yesterday that many of the cuts would affect the company's back-office operations, though it said the rest would be proportionally shared among the bank's other operations.
"The uncertainty is nothing new," said one employee who insisted on anonymity. "Now we just know what the exact numbers will be."
Chase said it would take an after-tax charge of $320 million against its earnings for the first quarter, related to the layoffs and administrative consolidation. No further layoffs are envisioned for the immediate future, the bank said.
Chase's president, Thomas Labrecque, said that the broad outlines of the layoffs were decided only this week and that he had consulted Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani about them. Mr. Labrecque said annual savings from the moves would be about $460 million.
"It's a meaningful chunk of change that will make investors feel better about the company's earnings outlook," said Diane Glossman, an analyst at Lehman Brothers.
The bank plans to reinvest the savings in highly profitable businesses like cash management, high-yield debt, advising on mergers and acquisitions, stock research and underwriting, originating and servicing mortgages and credit cards.
Mr. Labrecque said the moves would assure that revenue growth would rise to 10 percent annually in the next two years from current rates of 8 percent. He also said the cutbacks would help achieve a goal of an 18 percent return on equity -- a key measure of profitability.
"Where we're really looking for the push is not that the expense base will go down, it's that the revenues will rise," Mr. Labrecque said.
As part of the reorganization, Mr. Labrecque also said that Chase would create a unit, Chase Business Services, that would perform functions common to all of the bank's businesses, like marketing, benefits administration and property management.
Chase also announced that it would raise its quarterly dividend to 72 cents from 62 cents and that it planned a 2-for-1 stock split, pending shareholder approval. On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Chase shares rose $6.4375, to $134.75.
Despite the reaction of the market, some analysts said that yesterday's announcement failed to allay some of their concerns about Chase, such as its continued exposure to economic uncertainty in Southeast Asia and the soundness of some of the bank's loans.
"This was a very narrow restructuring announcement and didn't get to some of the more meaningful issues like credit quality," said Judah Kraushaar, an analyst with Merrill Lynch & Company.

HEADLINE: Developer Seeks to Build Another Hotel in (Where Else) Times Square

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
The developer Bruce C. Ratner is negotiating with city and state officials to build a 450-room hotel behind his entertainment center now rising on 42d Street in what would be a major revision of the redevelopment plan for Times Square.
The proposal is yet another sign of both the continuing resurgence of Times Square and of a booming hotel industry. Mr. Ratner's hotel is the seventh such project planned for the area and would sit less than a block from another developer's 860-room hotel, which has already received state approval. 
 Mr. Ratner has signed a tentative deal with Doubletree, a hotel chain owned by the Promus Hotel Corporation, to build the moderately priced hotel tower on 41st Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, according to real estate executives and city and state officials. The hotel would loom over the developer's 335,000-square-foot entertainment and retail complex -- which includes a Madame Tussaud's Wax Museum and a 25-screen movie theater -- that is under construction on 42d Street.
But to go forward with the project, Mr. Ratner is also seeking tax breaks from the city and the state's approval to amend the master plan for the redevelopment of Times Square, the once-sorry neighborhood that has become the address in Manhattan most sought after by retailers and office tenants. The plan originally envisioned four new office towers at the intersection of Seventh Avenue and 42d Street; two office buildings are under construction, and the remaining two development sites on Seventh Avenue are up for sale.
The plan also called for the restoration of six theaters in smaller buildings at the center of the block. But Mr. Ratner is proposing a tower for that location.
The Municipal Art Society, a longtime critic of overbuilding in Times Square, says that the once desolate streets are now in danger of being overshadowed by tall buildings.
"The rebirth of entertainment and retail has been so successful that Times Square's sidewalks and streets are congested," said Brendan Sexton, president of the Municipal Art Society. "We're looking at two more office towers with deep public subsidies and God knows how many hotels. I think we're straining the limits of credible urban planning."
Mr. Ratner declined comment, as did city officials. But Charles A. Gargano, the chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, confirmed that negotiations were under way with Mr. Ratner.
Mr. Ratner's pending hotel deal has not come without the kind of high drama worthy of the theater district. In 1995, he was selected to build the entertainment complex. More recently, he decided to add a hotel, striking a deal with the city's Economic Development Corporation. But three weeks ago, according to people involved on both sides of the negotiations, City Hall scuttled the hotel deal, thinking it was too favorable to Mr. Ratner. The developer then began talking with another set of city officials who are now close to a new deal. If approved by the mayoral administration, the proposal would then go to the state.
"If an agreement is reached," Mr. Gargano said, "a hotel on 41st Street would not only be a perfect complement to the rest of the block, but would bring life and foot traffic to the western end of the street. We all know New York City needs more hotel rooms."
There is no question that the hotel industry is booming, after suffering through a devastating recession in the early 1990's. Most hotels are operating at or near capacity, and the average room rate has jumped 38.5 percent, to $187, since 1991.
"In today's climate, you could do a hotel anywhere in Manhattan," John Fox of PKF Consulting, a lodging consultant, said. "The occupancy numbers are still extraordinarily high, and nothing on the horizon makes me think that's going to change."
Still, the proposed Doubletree hotel would be going up against six other hotels comprising 2,338 rooms planned or under construction in the Times Square area. There are currently more than 4,200 hotel rooms; the largest hotel, the Marriott Marquis, has been running at about 90 percent occupancy. Mr. Ratner is so bullish on hotels in Times Square that he recently submitted a proposal to build a hotel over the Port Authority Bus Terminal at 42d Street and Eighth Avenue.
"More critical mass in Times Square, be it retail, office or hotel, is good news for everyone," said John Livingston, president of the Tishman Urban Development Corporation. "It means more people, more tourists, more consumers will come to this street."
Mr. Livingston's company plans to begin construction next year on a 45-story hotel on the east side of Eighth Avenue, between 42d and 43d Streets. In the meantime, Tishman is building a retail and entertainment complex on 42d Street that will include a Sony cineplex, cafe and retail store, as well as a Museum Company store, restaurants and an arcade.
Across the street, Mr. Ratner is building a $160 million complex that would include, in addition to Madame Tussaud's and the 25-screen theater, an HMV record store alongside the newly restored Liberty, Empire and Harris theaters.
Planet Hollywood International plans to build a 564-room hotel at the southwest corner of Broadway and 47th Street, while Sofitel is putting up a 400-room hotel on 44th Street, near the Avenue of the Americas. Marriott is building a 244-room Courtyard hotel on 40th Street, between Broadway and the Avenue of the Americas. Philip Pilevsky is building a 170-room hotel in the American Radiator building on 40th Street, and Homestead Village is building a 150-room hotel next door.

GRAPHIC: Map showing sites of planned hotels in the Times Square area: A developer has signed a tentative deal to build a hotel on 41st Street.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. FISCAL PLAN REJECTS PROGRAMS SOUGHT BY CLINTON

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 17

 BODY:
The chairman of the Senate Budget Committee today proposed a Republican fiscal blueprint for next year that rejects nearly all of President Clinton's calls for increased domestic spending but provides smaller tax cuts than sought by many Republicans.
The proposal from Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, is the first detailed Republican budget plan this year and appeared likely to be adopted more or less intact by the committee this week over Democratic opposition. If approved by the full Senate, it would serve as the chamber's broad tax and spending guideline as it confronted the first Federal budget surpluses in a generation and began grappling with the long-term financial crises facing Social Security and Medicare. 
 The plan calls for Federal spending of $1.73 trillion, an increase of 3.6 percent over this year, but turns aside the White House's proposals for new education, child care and health care initiatives.
It provides for tax cuts worth $30 billion over five years, about half what the Republican Party's more ardent tax cutters have been demanding. And it goes along with the Administration's insistence that any budget surpluses be set aside until the nation agrees on a way to shore up Social Security, which will run short of money in coming decades as the enormous baby boom generation retires.
White House officials said that Mr. Domenici's plan attacked the core of their plan to help families by improving public schools and providing more assistance with day care expenses.
"This budget squeezes out education and squeezes out children," said Gene Sperling, the White House's economic policy adviser.
One of the Domenici proposal's main features is the earmarking of any proceeds from a legislated settlement with the tobacco industry over the illnesses caused by smoking to help Medicare, the health insurance program for the elderly.
Although there is no assurance that Congress and the industry will come to terms on a deal, Mr. Clinton's budget proposal allocated $65 billion in anticipated proceeds from any settlement largely to his new spending plans, including $21 billion in new financing for child care over five years and $7.3 billion to reduce the size of classes.
Mr. Domenici said that since 14 percent of Medicare's expenditures -- about $30 billion a year -- go to treat smoking-related illnesses, any tobacco settlement should go to averting the financial problems that Medicare will face as the population ages.
The proposal was criticized by some Republicans, who want to use any tobacco money for tax cuts, as well as by Democrats, who said it would gut their spending agenda. But Mr. Domenici defended it as the most prudent use of the money.
"That's the program that's most justified in having that money," Mr. Domenici said in releasing his plan at a budget committee hearing.
Mr. Domenici also took on the White House in his approach to paying for the lone piece of major legislation passed by the Senate so far this year, a $214 billion highway construction and mass transit bill that exceeds by $23.5 billion the spending limits set by last year's bipartisan balanced budget agreement.
He said that the increased spending should be covered by spending cuts that Mr. Clinton had proposed to help finance his social programs. The proposed cuts include curtailing health benefits given to veterans who have smoking-related illnesses unconnected to their military service and administrative cost reductions in the Medicaid program of health insurance for the poor.
Senate Democrats have been working on an alternative proposal that keeps intact Mr. Clinton's main spending proposals. Senator Frank Lautenberg of New Jersey, the senior Democrat on the budget committee, said the Republican plan would not help families as the Democratic plan would. And Mr. Lautenberg said that by allocating the proceeds from any tobacco settlement to Medicare rather than to a variety of other popular proposals including anti-smoking programs, Mr. Domenici's plan risked destroying any chance of a deal with the tobacco companies.
With midterm Congressional elections coming in November, members of both parties said they looked forward to the debate over their differences, with Democrats happy to run as supporters of the social programs backed by Mr. Clinton and Republicans arguing in favor of a less expensive, less powerful Federal Government. The differences between the parties are likely to be even more pointed in the budget proposal that House Republicans plan to introduce late next month, which may call for deeper tax and spending cuts than Mr. Domenici's plan.
"By passing this budget, we will move powerful and effective programs forward while forcing the Federal Government to live within its means," said Senator Gordon H. Smith, Republican of Oregon.
But Senator Patty Murray, a Washington Democrat, said the Republican plan endangered the nation's long-term economic and fiscal health by shortchanging children and education. "If our children don't get a good education," she said, "they won't get good jobs and the economy won't be strong."
For all their differences, though, the two parties are much closer in agreement on fiscal policy than they have been in years. Both Democrats and Republicans have pledged to keep the budget balanced and to live within the spending caps set out in last year's balanced budget deal. Republicans no longer seem intent on forcing showdowns over eliminating entire Cabinet departments or slashing spending on entitlement programs, and appear willing to allow overall spending to grow.
Some of the most contentious debates are likely to be within the Republican Party. Senator Rod Grams of Minnesota told fellow Republicans on the budget committee today that the tax cuts in Mr. Domenici's plan were not big enough, and that surpluses ought to be used for cutting taxes and reducing the national debt.
Republicans are also divided over how quickly to begin backing proposals to rescue Social Security. A growing number of them want to use any surpluses to finance private retirement accounts to augment or partly replace Social Security, while others are fearful of embracing any fundamental change to the system unless Mr. Clinton and the Democrats are also willing to sign on.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

2 Top S.&L.'s Will Merge, Creating Formidable Giant
The nation's two largest savings and loan companies, once intense rivals in the takeover game, agreed to merge in a $9.9 billion stock swap that would create a West Coast behemoth capable of competing with the new giants of consumer banking.
The deal, in which Washington Mutual of Seattle agreed to buy H. F. Ahmanson of Los Angeles, would make the new company triple the size of the nearest competitor among savings and loans. Page A1. 

Big Merger in Steel
Ispat International, a London-based steelmaker that has grown rapidly through global acquisitions, will buy Inland Steel of Chicago for $888.2 million plus $538.6 million in assumed debt. Inland's shares rose 18.4 percent on the news, and stocks of several other domestic steelmakers rose as well on speculation that they too could become acquisition targets. D3.
 
Panel Approves I.M.F. Funds
A Senate panel approved $18 billion in financing for the I.M.F., but only if the fund formally voted to make major changes in the way it lends money. A8.
 
Oil Prices Fall Below $13
Crude oil prices slid further, falling beneath $13 a barrel for the first time in nine years before recovering slightly. Prices have been eroding on the diminished likelihood that OPEC will reduce the global oversupply. D7.
 
Mixed Day on Wall Street
After a big run-up the previous day, stocks were mixed, buoyed by merger news but hurt by sagging oil prices. Even so, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 31.14 points, to 8,749.99, beating the record set Monday. The Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 1.18 points, to a record 1,080.45, but the Nasdaq composite index fell 8.88 points, to 1,779.30. D7.
 
Bond prices rallied early in the day but ended lower, hurt by mixed signals on the economy's strength. The 30-year Treasury's yield rose to 5.89 percent from 5.86. D7.
 
Starts of Housing Soar 6 Percent
The nation's housing market boomed in February, with starts rising 6 percent, but industrial production was unchanged, signs that domestic demand was offsetting whatever ill effects the economy suffered from Asia's crisis. Manufacturing output also held steady last month. Factory utilization fell to 82.7 percent. D5.
 
S.E.C. Sees Pyramid Scheme
The S.E.C. charged International Heritage, a North Carolina company that calls itself a direct sales organization, and three of its founders with luring 155,000 investors into a $150 million pyramid scheme. D6.
 
Vornado-Barney's Talks Reported
Vornado Realty Trust, an aggressive real estate investment trust, was said to be in talks to purchase Barney's, the upscale retailer now operating in Chapter 11. Vornado, which has acquired other high-profile properties, would join a list of other potential investors in Barney's. D3.
 
Construction Materials Deal
The Lafarge Corporation, a construction-products supplier, agreed to buy three construction materials businesses in North America from its major shareholder, Lafarge S.A. of France, for $690 million. D3.
 
Beardstown Ladies Admit Flaws
The Beardstown Ladies, the grandmotherly investors who wrote best-selling books, admitted that their returns fell far short of the market-beating numbers reported. They cited a computer error and apologized. Price Waterhouse audited their books after Chicago magazine questioned their claims. D2.
 
Drug Wholesalers To Fight F.T.C.
Cardinal Health and Bergen Brunswig plan to contest the Federal Trade Commission's attempt to block the proposed $2.62 billion merger of the two big pharmaceutical wholesalers. D4.

HEADLINE: Biggest S.& L.'s In Merger Deal Of $9.9 Billion

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
The nation's two largest savings and loan companies, once intense rivals in the takeover game, agreed yesterday to merge in a $9.9 billion stock swap that would create a West Coast behemoth capable of competing with the new giants of consumer banking.
Washington Mutual Inc., a once-sleepy Seattle concern that in a very short time has become the largest savings and loan association in the country, said it would buy the second-largest savings unit, H. F. Ahmanson & Company of Los Angeles, to create a new company with $149.2 billion in assets. That would not only make it three times the size of its nearest competitor in the savings and loan business, but would also make it the seventh-largest company in the entire banking industry, far surpassing such West Coast rivals as Wells Fargo & Company, but trailing the BankAmerica Corporation. 
 Nationally, Washington Mutual would come after the Chase Manhattan Corporation, Citicorp, Nationsbank, J. P. Morgan & Company, BankAmerica and the First Union Corporation.
But how long the rankings will remain is far from certain. A wave of mergers and consolidations has swept the once-staid banking industry in the last three years -- among the mega-mergers is First Union's $17.1 billion deal for Corestates and Nationsbank's $15.5 billion purchase of Barnett Banks. Institutions have sought to build national franchises and redefine how they serve customers' needs, with some, like Washington Mutual, focusing on individuals and small businesses, while others like J. P. Morgan and the Bankers Trust New York Corporation seek to compete with Wall Street houses in serving big business.
"Washington Mutual is taking the Wal-Mart approach to consumer banking where they sell simple products like mortagages and checking accounts and don't try to nickel and dime you with fees," said Kenneth A. Posner, an analyst with Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company. "The thrift industry is dead because mortgages alone aren't enough anymore. Consumer banking has expanding margins and that's where Washington Mutual is heading."
Mortgage lending has traditionally been the savings and loan industry's bread and butter. But even though industrywide profits have been rising, and the economic landscape is more favorable than it was earlier in the decade, savings and loan associations have had difficulty in the increasingly competitive mortgage business.
Now, savings and loan associations are merging to make themselves more attractive takeover targets -- as did the Golden State Bancorp Inc., parent of the Glendale Federal Bank, when it agreed to acquire First Nationwide Holdings Inc., the parent of the California Federal Bank, in February. They are also using acquisitions to broaden their products and services, as Washington Mutual is doing.
In trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, Ahmanson's shares soared $12.375, to $77.875, while Washington Mutual's shares rose $1.1875, to $72.9375, on the Nasdaq stock market.
The transaction, which is subject to regulatory approval, is expected to result in the elimination of 3,000 to 3,500 jobs, or at least 10 percent of the merged company's work force, mainly through layoffs.
Asked if the deal posed any antitrust problems, a spokesman for the Justice Department said the department could not comment until it had studied the agreement. Wall Street analysts, however, said such problems were unlikely.
Washington Mutual and Ahmanson were on opposite sides in a bitter takeover battle last year for the Great Western Financial Corporation, a Los Angeles savings and loan association. Ahmanson made a hostile bid for Great Western in early 1997; it failed when Washington Mutual emerged as a so-called white knight. Washington Mutual proved to be the winning bidder, and the acquisition vaulted the company into the savings and loan industry's top spot.
Although Charles R. Rinehart, Ahmanson's 51-year-old chairman and chief executive, plans to leave the company when the merger is completed in the third quarter, both companies said yesterday that once the battle for Great Western ended, there was little enmity between them.
"It was hard fought, but we're big boys, and we had to get on with running our companies," Mr. Rinehart said.
For his part, Kerry Killinger, the 48-year-old chairman and chief executive of Washington Mutual, said that the merged operation would be able to offer cheaper and more personalized services to small depositors, who were overlooked or shunned by retail banking giants.
"There's a strong opportunity for consumer banking when you focus on consumers and small businesses more effectively than larger commercial banks can," he said.
Washington Mutual, which three years ago had only about $20 billion in assets, will enjoy a formidable presence on the West Coast, assuming the merger is completed. In California alone, it would rank second to the BankAmerica Corporation in terms of deposit share, and it would be the largest mortgage originator in the state.
Washington Mutual entered the California market in 1996 when it doubled its size by acquiring the American Savings Bank. The new merger will enhance its presence there, while also expanding its mortgage franchise nationally and giving it a foothold in Texas.
Washington Mutual and Ahmanson currently have assets of $96.9 billion and $52.5 billion, respectively. The new company is expected to serve 5.9 million households in the West, Texas and Florida, have pro forma profits for 1997 of $896 million, and have a market capitalization as of March 16 of about $27.6 billion.
Under the terms of the deal, Ahmanson shareholders would get 1.12 shares of Washington Mutual for each Ahmanson share they own. Based on Washington Mutual's closing stock price on Monday, that values Ahmanson at $80.36 a share, a 33 percent premium to Ahmanson's closing stock price on Friday.
Washington Mutual was advised in the transaction by Lehman Brothers Inc., while Ahmanson was advised by Credit Suisse First Boston.

HEADLINE: Population Of New York Rises Slightly

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 17

 BODY:
More than a million New Yorkers moved out of the city during the 1990's, but new immigrants and children born to them have more than replaced those who left, according to Federal Census figures released today.
The city's total population in 1997 reached 7,342,636, half a percentage point higher than the lowest point of the decade, in 1991, the Census figures show. 
 But the mostly static total figures for the 1990's mask huge flows of people: 1.07 million New Yorkers left the city; 677,000 foreigners moved to New York; there were 937,000 births and 516,000 deaths.
The slight growth, in large measure, helped push New York State's population to 18 million last year, giving it a 0.8 percent growth rate since 1990. Neighboring New Jersey saw the greatest growth in the region, with its population expanding by 4 percent, taking it slightly over eight million.
Overall, states in the Northeast and Midwest continued to lose ground to the booming growth centers of the South and West, the Census report showed, sustaining the steady trend that is inexorably shifting the nation's political and economic might toward the Sun Belt and Rocky Mountains.
"What we're seeing is the Northeast and Midwest losing its political clout," said Richard Munson, executive director of the Northeast-Midwest Institute, a bipartisan research organization for members of Congress. "The leadership of this Congress is decidedly Southern. And they are doing a pretty good job of getting dollars for their states."
The survey of population changes in the country's 3,142 counties showed that while the country grew by 0.9 percent last year, the Northeast's population increased by only 0.2 percent and the Midwest by 0.6 percent. At the same time, the West's population grew by 1.6 percent and the South by 1.3 percent.
 The one-year increase in New York City's population was small according to the Census Bureau's estimate: 7,812 people, or barely a 0.1 percent increase over 1996. But it was symbolically important for the city and its Mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, who has been trumpeting the city's revival across the nation.
But demographers said the rapid turnover of New York City residents documented in the Census Bureau report could also create problems for the city. New immigrants are likely to need more services, taxing overstretched city resources. They will also be unable to vote, leaving them with little voice over government. And the swift in-and-out migration of people does little to bring stability to city neighborhoods.
"It makes New York look more like a jumping-off spot," said Andrew A. Beveridge, a professor of sociology at Queens College. "Turning over a seventh of your population in seven years is a very big shift."
The figures were part of a survey of population changes in the nation's counties that were based on estimates and not an actual accounting of the nation's population.
 The changes were most starkly evident in a roster of the country's fastest growing larger counties between 1990 to 1997. The first three slots were held by communities just south of Denver, where the sprinting growth of high-technology industries and the charm of Rocky Mountain living has attracted a flood of transplants from California and the East.
 But at the other end of the spectrum, the list of counties that lost the most population since 1990 was laden with Northeastern urban areas, including Philadelphia, which was at the top; Hartford, Brooklyn, and the Bronx. New York City's population grew overall because of growth in Manhattan, Staten Island and Queens.
 The political implications of the Census Bureau's new report, which was based on estimates of population growth, are potentially immense. A broad range of Federal policies are based on census statistics, from apportioning seats in the House of Representatives to allocating Federal money for hundreds of programs.
 Since today's report offers the closest thing to a preview of the Census in 2000, which is intended to be the most accurate accounting of the nation's population, it also foreshadows losses in Federal aid and Congressional seats for the Northeast and Midwest come the new millennium.
 The statistics also have broad implications for each state's internal politics. Significant growth in the metropolitan region's suburbs will give them increasing power in state legislatures and over gubernatorial elections.
 Demographers and economists cited a host of reasons for the national trends in the new population figures, including a tide of immigrants from Latin America and Asia to the South and West, stronger economic growth in those regions and the continued allure of warm climates for retirees from the frigid North. They also said that rapid growth in rural areas of the West and South has created a demand for new jobs building roads, sewers and houses, which in turn has attracted even more people to those regions.
 "It's sort of a chicken-and-egg thing," said Rae Rosen, the senior economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. "If there were jobs, counties wouldn't lose population. And on the other hand, a growing population also creates more jobs."
 Between 1990 and 1997, New York State's population increased by 0.8 percent, or 146,448, to 18.1 million. New York City grew by 0.3 percent in that time, with Manhattan, Staten Island and Queens all growing while the Bronx and Brooklyn lost people.
 Ms. Rosen noted that population growth in New York City seemed in large part fueled by the booming stock market, which has brought thousands of new jobs to Wall Street. But the upstate region saw significant population losses, a result, she said, of a shrinking industrial base and the continued exodus of people from farm regions.
 New Jersey, which was the first state in the region to have replaced all the jobs lost during the last recession, showed the strongest population growth in the New York metropolitan region, according to the report. The state's population increased by nearly 4 percent, or 305,099, to just over eight million between 1990 and 1997. That was still below the national average of 7.6 percent, and far below such rapid-growth states as Georgia.
 Only two counties in New Jersey lost population between 1990 and 1997: Hudson, which dropped 0.3 percent, and Essex. Essex includes New Jersey's largest city, Newark, where the population dropped 3.5 percent to 750,842.
 The national pattern of cities losing people to the suburbs was particularly pronounced in Connecticut, where the population declined by 0.6 percent, or 17,258, to 3.3 million.
Modest growth in most of the state's counties was completely offset by the shrinkage of three urban areas: Hartford, New Haven and New London.

HEADLINE: Mississippi Reveals Dark Secrets of a Racist Time

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: JACKSON, Miss., March 17

 BODY:
After a 21-year court fight, the state of Mississippi today unsealed more than 124,000 pages of secret files from a state agency that used spy tactics, intimidation, false imprisonment, jury tampering and other illegal methods to thwart the activities of civil rights workers during the 1950's, 60's and early 70's.
Like an eerie journey into a shadowy past, the files of the agency, the Mississippi State Sovereignty Commission, provided a profoundly unsettling reminder of the state's determination to maintain Jim Crow segregation, as reporters and individuals named in the commission's files began to review the computerized records. 
 While some of the commission's methods have been known for years, the full files released today demonstrated the scope of its work. Investigators made note of the skin color, associations, religious beliefs and sexual proclivities of the civil rights workers they tracked. They jotted down the license plate numbers of cars parked at civil rights meetings and peeked into bank accounts. Informants, many of them black Mississippians, reported to the commission about plans for marches and boycotts.
In some cases, the potential for using violence against civil rights workers is discussed in commission memorandums. Although none of the documents reviewed to date show a direct state hand in the numerous deaths of rights advocates in Mississippi in those years, they clearly reflect the mindset of the state's white supremacists: to maintain segregation at all costs.
In one 1959 memorandum, for example, Zack J. VanLandingham, a commission investigator, tells of a conversation he had with a Hattiesburg lawyer, Dudley Connor, about Clyde Kennard, a black man who tried to desegregate Mississippi Southern College in Hattiesburg in the late 1950's.
"If the Sovereignty Commission wanted that Negro out of the community and out of the state they would take care of the situation," Mr. VanLandingham quoted Mr. Connor as saying. "And when asked what he meant by that, Mr. Connor stated that Kennard's car could be hit by a train or he could have some accident on the highway and nobody would ever know the difference."
In another memo, this one written by Mr. VanLandingham to Gov. J. P. Coleman in 1959, the investigator related a conversation he had with John Reiter, a campus police officer.
"Reiter had several weeks ago told me that when Kennard was attempting to enter Mississippi Southern College in December, 1958, that he had been approached by individuals with possible plans to prevent Kennard's going through with his attempt," he wrote. "One of the plans was to put dynamite to the starter of Kennard's Mercury. Another plan was to have some liquor planted in Kennard's car and then he would be arrested."
On Sept. 15, 1959, Mr. Kennard was in fact arrested on charges of illegal possession of whisky, after police officers claimed to have found five half-pints of whisky and other liquor under the front seat of his car. His problems did not end. He was sentenced to prison after his arrest for possession of five bags of stolen chicken feed. He died a short time later of cancer.
The release of the Sovereignty Commission files here comes as the South is making fresh efforts to disinter the history of some of its most tortured times.
After years of silence, the family of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. is encouraging efforts to discover whether James Earl Ray really was responsible for the 1968 assassination of the civil rights leader. Federal investigators in Birmingham, Ala., have reopened the case of the 1963 bombing of the 16th Avenue Baptist Church, which killed four little girls.
Last week in Little Rock, Ark., former members of the Women's Emergency Committee to Open Our Schools held a news conference to release its membership roster for the first time. Because members feared for their physical and economic well-being, the group largely worked underground between 1958 to 1963 to reopen schools that had been closed by Gov. Orval Faubus to deter court-ordered desegregation.
Here in Mississippi, several civil rights advocates who were the subjects of Sovereignty Commission investigations said today that they may use their newly released records to file lawsuits against the state. Prosecutors said that it was also possible that information found in the files could be used to press criminal charges against suspected perpetrators, if they are still alive.
"Certainly, if there's evidence that comes to light regarding any crime that occurred in our jurisdiction, then we'll certainly investigate that, take a look at it to see whether it's prosecutable, just like we did in the Beckwith case," said Bobby DeLaughter, a Hinds County assistant district attorney here in Jackson, where the mayor is black.
In 1994, Mr. DeLaughter won conviction of Byron De La Beckwith for the 1963 assassination of the N.A.A.C.P. leader Medgar Evers after learning that the Sovereignty Commission had aided Mr. Beckwith's defense in two previous trials in which the juries deadlocked.
A new trial was ordered after Jerry Mitchell, a reporter for The Clarion-Ledger, Jackson's daily newspaper, used information leaked from Sovereignty Commission files to write in 1989 that the commission had secretly aided in Mr. Beckwith's defense by helping to screen potential jurors to weed out Jews and civil rights sympathizers.
The unsealing of the Sovereignty Commission files ended a two-decade legal battle that began in 1977, when the state Legislature voted the commission out of existence but sealed its records for 50 years. The American Civil Liberties Union and several individuals filed suit to keep the records open, and in 1989 Judge William H. Barbour of Federal District Court here ordered that they be released.
It took nine more years to satisfy appeals and to establish a process to allow subjects of the commission's investigations to exert their rights to keep their own files private. Some of the commission's files have been reportedly destroyed, and about 7,700 pages out of a total of 132,000 pages of files remain secret because 42 people claimed privacy rights, said Katie Blount, a spokeswoman for the Mississippi Department of Archives and History, which has maintained and indexed the files.
The commission, which was created in 1956 with a $250,000 budget, formally existed until 1977. It was the model for similar agencies that fought desegregation in other states.
The opening of the Sovereignty Commission files has generated a debate here between those who believe that the ugliness of the past should remain buried and those who believe that only a full airing can bring healing. Some civil rights advocates have fought the opening of the files because they believe their release could hurt the subjects of Sovereignty Commission investigations once again by releasing unsavory, and possibly untrue, details about their personal lives.
"It will probably bring forth some memories of a bad time in the state, which we all acknowledge was a bad time now," said former Mississippi Gov. William F. Winter, a member of the President's Advisory Board on Race. "I hope it'll be the basis for understanding that we can't ever lapse back into the kind of intolerance we once had in this state."
One of the few living members of the Sovereignty Commission, Betty Long, 69, said today that she, too, was pleased that the files had been opened. "I want facts to be known instead of innuendo and rumors," she said, adding that she did not believe that the commission had been involved in murder or other acts of violence. "At the time, everyone in the state was gung-ho to keep things segregated and that was tied in with the idea of the communists taking over. It's something I wish had never happened."
For those who have waited for decades to see what information the state had collected about them, their family members and their friends, the day provided a long-awaited moment of revelation and relief.
"Twenty-one years is a long time to wait to see what is in here," said Ellie J. Dahmer, clutching a packet containing the file on her husband, Vernon Dahmer, who was shot to death in 1966 while fending off a Ku Klux Klan firebomb attack on his house in Hattiesburg.
Mrs. Dahmer, who spoke outside the archives building in front of a memorial to the Confederate dead, said she hoped that her husband's file may help prosecutors retry Sam Bowers, an Imperial Wizard of the White Knights of the Ku Klux Klan who was acquitted in 1968 of ordering the firebombing. That trial, for arson, ended when the jury deadlocked 11-to-1. A second trial, for murder, also ended with a deadlocked jury, this time 10-to-2.
The Clarion-Ledger published an article by Mr. Mitchell last week saying that notes taken from F.B.I. files suggest that Klan members had contacted jurors in the first case.
"When it came up 11-to-1 one time and 10-to-2 the next time, we thought something might be wrong, but we didn't have any way of proving it," Mrs. Dahmer said. "It shows what kind of state we lived in, what kind of environment there was, what they really thought of black people."
A review of Mr. Dahmer's file today revealed no evidence of Sovereignty Commission involvement in Mr. Bowers's trials.
The commission files also show that the commission's director, Erle Johnston Jr., ordered one of its investigators, A. L. Hopkins, to look into the facts surrounding the 1964 murder of three civil rights workers -- Andrew Goodman, Michael Schwerner and James Chaney.
Mr. Hopkins reported first that some of the local law enforcement officers on the case had assured him that they were working hard to solve it. But by his last report he was noting that some of the officers had themselves been arrested and charged in the deaths and were headed for trial.

HEADLINE: Costs Are Seen On Target To Meet Goals In Curriculum

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: TRENTON, March 17

 BODY:
State education officials said today that estimates on the amount of financing needed to meet new curriculum standards adopted in 1996 were largely on target and that only a slight increase in spending would be necessary to continue to meet those standards in the next few years.
Since Gov. Christine Todd Whitman adopted the curriculum standards in 1996 as part of her school financing plan, opponents have contended that estimates of the financing needed to meet the standards were inadequate. But state education officials said today that their review proved that the estimates were accurate and that spending to meet the curriculum standards has been equitable for all school districts. 
 Today's announcement came as the New Jersey Supreme Court was weighing a judge's recommendation to spend $312 million a year more on supplementary programs in the 28 urban districts. The Whitman administration has urged the court to reject the recommendation, saying the state is already spending more than enough to insure that urban schools meet the constitutional requirement.
In recommending only a slight increase in spending for the 1999-2000 school year, the state is trying to convince the Supreme Court that its financing plan is equitable, said Lynne Strickland, a spokeswoman for the Garden State Coalition of Schools. "They are in the middle of a court case," she said, "so they need a consistent argument to prove their original plan was valid."
The Governor's plan requires education officials to adjust the spending level every two years. The officials announced today that the recommended spending level would increase to $7,827 in 1999, on average, from $7,426 this year.
Peter Peretzman, a spokesman for the New Jersey Department of Education, said education officials based the spending adjustments on a report that studied the spending habits of 103 "high performing" school districts. The report recommends that districts spend an average of $7,083 per pupil in elementary schools, $7,933 per pupil in middle schools and $8,500 per pupil in high schools in 1999-2000. New Jersey spends more per pupil than any other state.
"The increase that we are recommending is sufficient and appropriate to provide a thorough and efficient education," Mr. Peretzman said.
By setting curriculum standards and a spending limit, Mrs. Whitman intended to end the decades-old court battle over the disparity between the richest and poorest school districts. The standards sought to insure that all of the state's 1.23 million public-school children received the "thorough and efficient" education guaranteed by the State Constitution.
But the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled last spring that the plan was unconstitutional, because the recommended spending level was not necessarily enough to assure that poor districts can meet the standards. The court required Mrs. Whitman to send an extra $248 million to the 28 poorest urban districts this year, so they could spend as much as the 120 wealthiest districts. Since the Supreme Court has not yet ruled on the judge's recommendation, the spending levels recommended today do not apply to those 28 districts.
A spokesman for the New Jersey School Boards Association, Frank Belluscio, said the increase recommended by state officials today was insufficient because it only kept up with the inflation rate.
"There has never been a clear link between this spending level imposed by the state and what actually goes on in the classroom," he said.

HEADLINE: Polls Are Split On Credibility Of Key Figures

BYLINE: By MARJORIE CONNELLY 

 BODY:
In the aftermath of newly detailed accusations of sexual misconduct against President Clinton, the American public continues to approve of his job performance, but is divided on whether to believe Mr. Clinton or his latest accuser, Kathleen E. Willey, three national polls have found.
More than 60 percent of respondents said they approved of the way Mr. Clinton was handling his job, according to polls conducted by ABC News, CBS News and by the Gallup Organization for CNN and USA Today on Monday night, after Ms. Willey appeared on the CBS News program "60 Minutes" on Sunday evening. 
 The polls found that most assessments of Mr. Clinton had not substantially changed since the interview, in which Ms. Willey, a former White House aide, said the President made a sexual advance in November 1993 in the Oval Office. The ABC News poll found that evaluations of Mr. Clinton's honesty and ethical standards remained low, while a majority continued to approve of his leadership qualities and economic accomplishments.
Americans are split on whether they believe Ms. Willey's claim or Mr. Clinton's denial. In the poll conducted by CBS News, for example, 48 percent say they believe Ms. Willey and 44 percent believe Mr. Clinton -- a statistical tie.
The polls did reveal some negative opinions about the President. Almost half of the public professes to have "lost respect" for the President "since the start of this year" in the Gallup poll.
CBS News found 52 percent who say they believe Mr. Clinton "has engaged in reckless sexual conduct while President."
According to the ABC News poll, 60 percent say he has engaged in a "pattern of sexual misconduct."
Mr. Clinton may continue to get high marks for his job performance because of the robust national economy and because most of the public -- 58 percent of those surveyed in the ABC News poll -- considers the accusation about Mr. Clinton's sexual conduct to be a private matter. Only a quarter of those polled consider the accusation to be of great importance to the nation, according to the CBS News poll.
On the other hand, the possibility of perjury on the part of the President remains of greater concern. Seventy percent in the ABC News poll said that based on what was known right now, Mr. Clinton should remain in office. But, if it is shown that the President lied under oath, 63 percent said he should resign; 53 percent said that if he did not resign, he should be impeached.
While men and women are equally likely to support the way Mr. Clinton is handling his job, they differ in their assessment of Ms. Willey's accusation. Men are more likely to believe Ms. Willey's account of the incident; women are more inclined to believe the President.
CBS interviewed 529 adults who had been previously polled, while ABC and Gallup each called a new random sample. The ABC poll is based on 655 adults, and the Gallup poll was conducted with 651 adults. All three polls, conducted by telephone, have a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.

HEADLINE: Clinton Pushes Plan for Medicare at Age 55

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 17

 BODY:
President Clinton went to Capitol Hill today and, at a rally with three dozen Democratic members of Congress, pushed his proposal to open Medicare to millions of people 55 to 64 years old.
Hundreds of supporters, lobbyists and labor union members cheered the President, who clearly relished the opportunity to show that he was doing business, undistracted by any sex scandal or grand jury investigation. 
 Mr. Clinton also expressed alarm at reports that some insurance companies had found ways around a 1996 law intended to make coverage available to people who change jobs or lose their jobs. "These practices have to be stopped," he said.
He ordered the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Donna E. Shalala, "to conduct a thorough review of the options for strengthening the protections" of the 1996 statute, known as the Kassebaum-Kennedy law. "We intend to enforce it vigorously," Mr. Clinton said.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat who was a co-author of the law, said he would introduce legislation this week to set limits on the premiums that can be charged to people exercising their rights to buy individual health insurance coverage under the law. The insurance industry adamantly opposes Federal regulation of rates.
The General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, found that people with medical problems, though theoretically guaranteed access to insurance under the 1996 law, could be "priced out of the market" because they were charged premiums far higher than the standard rates.
Representative Nancy L. Johnson, Republican of Connecticut, said: "This is an outrage. It makes a farce of the Kassebaum-Kennedy bill. If the G.A.O. report is accurate, the industry is circumventing the spirit of the law and may be circumventing the letter of the law."
Charles N. Kahn 3d, chief operating officer of the Health Insurance Association of America, said: "You can regulate rates all you want, but if you have a few million-dollar cases, premiums for everybody will still go up. It would be much better to have broad-based subsidies for the insurance premiums of high-risk individuals, rather than regulating rates."
Republicans have generally been cool to the President's proposal to expand Medicare. But Democrats said they would take the issue directly to the Senate floor, bypassing the Finance Committee and forcing Republicans to vote on expansion of Medicare in this election year.
The President said his proposal "presents no threat to the integrity of the Medicare program or the security of the trust fund."
Mr. Clinton would offer Medicare coverage to two groups: people 62 to 64 who cannot get health benefits through an employer and unemployed people 55 to 61 who lost insurance coverage along with their jobs.
Under the proposal, people 55 to 64 years old could buy Medicare coverage by paying premiums of $300 to $400 a month. People ages 62 to 64 who chose this option would also have to pay surcharges on their regular Medicare premiums after they reached the standard eligibility age of 65.
The premiums and surcharges, combined with measures to crack down on Medicare fraud, would pay for the coverage, Mr. Clinton said. He observed that people 55 to 64 were often unable to find affordable insurance in the current market.
Legislation to carry out the President's proposal is being introduced by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, the ranking Democrat on the Finance Committee, and Representative Pete Stark of California, the ranking Democrat in the House Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health. Cosponsors include Mr. Kennedy and Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader.
Representative Bill Thomas, the California Republican who headsthe Subcommittee on Health, said, "We first need to fix the current shortfalls in Medicare and Social Security before we consider the President's proposal to increase Government spending and expand yet another Government program."

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY;
Even With More Jobs, Unemployment Rises

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
New Jersey's unemployment rate rose a tenth of a percentage point in February -- to 5 percent -- even as the number of jobs in the state increased by 12,500, the State Department of Labor announced yesterday.
Although the figures may seem contradictory, they are not, said Kevin Smith, a department spokesman. Because the unemployment rate incorporates the number of residents who are both unemployed and seeking jobs, the rate can rise simply because jobless people who had not been looking for work have resumed their search, Mr. Smith said. That is probably what happened in New Jersey last month, he added, due to optimism about the economy. 
 The creation of new jobs, although still a positive economic indicator, may not reduce the unemployment rate, Mr. Smith said, depending on how many of those jobs are filled by unemployed residents seeking work. Last month's new jobs were concentrated in the retail, construction and transportation industries, Mr. Smith said.

HEADLINE: Suburbs' Mass-Market Mansions;
Baby Boom Luxury: Huge Home, Often on a Tiny Lot

BYLINE: By DEBRA WEST 

DATELINE: IRVINGTON, N.Y., March 16

 BODY:
When Evan and Susan Ratner were shopping for a new home, they looked for a community like the one where they grew up in Smithtown, N.Y.: a development with young families, where children skated on cul-de-sacs and called to neighbors over backyard fences. They also wanted, and could afford, more luxury than their parents would have dreamed possible.
It didn't take them long to find both. 
 Much as the generation that grew up with a family station wagon has shown an appetite for even bigger sport utility vehicles, the children of suburbia who were raised in three-bedroom ranches, where elegance meant a basement rec room, are now buying luxury estate houses in subdivisions.
These are not sprawling estates, but instant neighborhoods of supersized tract houses, built on relatively small lots. They are luxurious Levittowns, and they represent a new kind of suburban dream.
"My Dad just dragged my Mom out of Brooklyn," said Mr. Ratner, 35, a vice president of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, the investment firm. "It was 1968 and he wanted grass and trees in the backyard. When he got it, he felt like he had achieved the American dream.
"For us it's a little different," said Mr. Ratner, a father of three. "We grew up there. We're kind of going on to the next step, in size and process. My parents had no choice in the house they bought. It was there, take it or leave it. We could say, 'Here is what we want and this is how we want to do it.' "
In June, the Ratners will be moving from West Orange, N.J., into their new home, a 7,000-square-foot white clapboard colonial on 1.7 acres, among 55 luxury homes here overlooking the Hudson River. The house has six bedrooms, seven baths, a mudroom as big as a kitchen, a library and a blue stone patio. It sits on a cul-de-sac with five other mansions. Prices in the development start at $799,000 and exceed $1 million.
In 1996, the most recent year for which figures are available, nearly 14 percent of new houses built nationally were 3,000 square feet or larger, said Gopal Ahluwalia, director of research at the National Association of Home Builders.
The trend is seen mostly in the suburbs of big cities. Nearly 18 percent of new houses built in the Northeast, 15 percent in Texas and Florida and 12 percent in the West are larger than 3,000 square feet. The measurement itself is a reflection of how houses have changed in the past decade.
"Ten years ago they didn't even have that category," Mr. Ahluwalia said. In 1986, the largest category measured was 2,400 square feet or larger and it included 18 percent of new house construction nationally. At last count, 30 percent of new houses were at least 2,400 square feet.
It is not only size but luxury that makes the subdivisions of estates stand out, said Alexander Garvin, a professor of architecture and planning at Yale University.
"They call them McMansions," Mr. Garvin said. "Mass-produced large homes that sell for three-quarters of a million dollars. You haven't seen anything until you see what they are doing in Texas, where they build these homes on one-fifth of an acre. The house takes up the whole property."
The sheer mass of these houses has already caused a backlash.
The Town of Eastchester, in Westchester County, passed a law in September restricting home size based on the size of the lot. The largest house that can now be built on a 100-by-100-foot lot is 4,725 square feet, said Joseph C. Vohnought, the town engineer. Similar measures have been passed in Newton, Mass., a suburb of Boston, and Hinsdale, Ill., a suburb of Chicago.
Estate developments are being squeezed onto available land in expensive suburbs like Rye and Roslyn, N.Y., and Wayne, N.J., and spreading out in more modest towns like Yorktown, N.Y., Southbury, Conn., and Jackson Township, N.J.
The new luxury houses have features that were once found only on true estates, like columned entrances and two-story foyers with marble floors and dramatic curving staircases. They often include a "great room," an oversized eat-in kitchen that opens into a family room; and bathrooms with "his and her" dressing rooms, double-sized whirlpool tubs and steam showers. Three-car garages are standard.
What they don't have is a lot of land. The buyers want a lot of house instead. Often, they don't want the chores and the sense of isolation that go with a big piece of property.
Mammoth houses lined up on neat half-acre lots seem like a lost opportunity to Mr. Garvin, who criticizes the real estate industry for selling false French facades and heavy-handed Mediterranean styles in place of better design. "All that money could have been spent for a much better environment and much more beautiful buildings and still sell at the same price," he said.
Two factors have made the houses appealing and affordable, said Kira McCarron, vice president of marketing for Toll Brothers of Huntingdon, Pa., the country's largest developer of luxury homes.
One is the increasing wealth of the middle class. In 1996, 8.2 percent of households nationally had annual incomes of $100,000. In 1970, only 3.2 percent had equivalent incomes, based on 1996 dollars, Ms. McCarron said.
The other factor is that the cost of luxury has dropped with the mass manufacturing of items like Palladian windows, porticos and curved staircases. "We have perfected a method of customization that allows for incredible houses and economies of scale," Ms. McCarron said.
Toll Brothers built 2,488 luxury houses in 16 states last year. Its average home is 3,500 square feet and costs $400,000. Like most luxury developers, Toll Brothers offers hundreds of custom options.
Of the 40 million people born in the baby boom years from 1954 to 1964, many have outgrown their starter homes and have enough equity and income to afford trophy houses. In addition, a significant number of empty nesters are defying conventional real estate wisdom and trading up.
K. Hovnanian Enterprises, the largest residential developer in New Jersey, made its reputation building affordable housing. A decade ago, people camped out overnight and entered lotteries by the thousands for the chance to buy one of the company's modest homes in Jersey City, starting at $97,500.
But since 1990, Hovnanian has responded to the desire for more opulence, said Ara Hovnanian, president and chief executive. Now, 20 percent of Hovnanian's new homes are larger than 2,800 square feet and cost $280,000 to $600,000, he said.
"In the 80's there was a surge of first-time home buyers that led to tremendous growth," Mr. Hovnanian said. "What we're seeing today is the second- and third-time move-up buyers. We've made a shift in our focus and emphasis, and a lot of it has to do with demographics. It's definitely consumer driven."
Who are the consumers leading the charge?
"I think it is a super-middle class," said Emanuel Tobier, a professor of economics and planning at New York University. "In income terms, they are upper income. But in class terms, they are middle class. There may be too many of them to live in that characteristic estate manner of 20 years ago. They live differently. They don't want to be that isolated and they don't need to be. They are not celebrities."
Many new mansions have a home office and a nanny's suite, reflecting busy working couples, but rarely do they have a traditional maid's quarters off the kitchen, Mr. Garvin said.
"The rich don't have kitchens that open into family rooms," he said. "They have help prepare the meals."
Yet the new mansions do have celebrity-sized kitchens. "The kitchens and bathrooms have become the most important rooms," said Arlene C. Travis, an interior designer in Glen Cove, N.Y. Her company, Mansions and Millionaires, started out restoring old mansions on Long Island back in 1973, in the age of diminished expectations, when people looked at huge homes as energy-wasting anachronisms.
"The kitchens, not because you cook, but because it shows you appreciate good food," she said. "The bathrooms, they don't even call them bathrooms anymore. They have become more of a spa."
Nikki van der Vord, 29, has a whirlpool tub. She and her husband, Andrew, and two preschool daughters live in the Park Lane Reserve, a development of 306 luxury homes on 396 acres in Harrison in Westchester County. At 3,700 square feet and $659,000, the van der Vords' cream-colored colonial is among the development's more modest homes.
The couple, who are British, were transferred to the United States four years ago by Mr. van der Vord's employer, Schroder & Company, a British investment bank. They plan to stay, partly because of the housing opportunities.
"You couldn't get this in the U.K.," Ms. van der Vord said, gesturing to an expanse of window that brightened the great room, and beyond to the neighbors' mansions, visible from each room in the house. "They don't build estates like this so close to the city."
Developing luxury homes makes economic sense, Mr. Ahluwalia said. Profit on a subdivision house is typically 5 to 10 percent, regardless of style, he said. Therefore, costlier homes mean higher profits.
"They charge for every upgrade you get," Mr. Ratner said. "They'll say: 'A two-car garage is standard. Oh, you want a three-car garage? That's another $10,000.' But what are you going to do? Who wants a two-car garage?"

An article on Wednesday about the baby boom generation's buying of luxury estate houses in suburban neighborhoods referred to the baby boom years incompletely. They began in 1946, not 1954, and lasted until 1964.

HEADLINE: DOWNTIME;
For Fanatics, Sports Webcasts

BYLINE: By MATT RICHTEL 

 BODY:
IT'S not quite like being there. It does not even approximate television. But if you are in Fresno, Calif., or Chippewa Falls, Wis., and your favorite team is in Chicago or Denver, it's the next best thing. And for some sports junkies, that is a great leap forward.
Meet the Internet simulcast, the newest medium for live sports, and its fan: the Web potato. 
 "It's obviously not TV, where you can get all excited, but for my options, it's as good as it gets," said Chris Grusz, a Seattle software salesman who uses the browser in his cubicle at work to tune into Chicago Bulls basketball games.
To some, the idea of "watching" games unfold in simple text is a likely sign of lunacy. But Mr. Grusz is among thousands of point-and-click fans who are happily tuning into ESPN Sportszone, CBS Sportsline and a handful of smaller operations that seek to simulate games as they happen, using animation or text updates fed from the sidelines.
ESPN is set to begin its first full season of Web-based baseball coverage, while CBS is embarking on a second full season. Each offered football games last season, and ESPN recently started Gamecast for the National Basketball Association. Last season, CBS Sportsline's Baseball Live was its most popular on-line offering, attracting hundreds of thousands of viewers each game, the company said.
Perhaps more impressive, the Total College Sports Network, a division of Total Sports, based in Raleigh, N.C., was viewed by at least several hundred thousand viewers during the first weekend of the NCAA tournament. The 10-month-old network has provided real-time play-by-play, charts and digital photos for hundreds of college basketball, football and baseball games in the last year.
Make no mistake, the experiences are not even a distant cousin of television. CBS provides animation based on Java, an Internet language for interactive and multimedia programs. For football, an image of a football helmet moves across the field as a team marches on a drive; for baseball, animated figures round the bases as a running box score keeps a tally.
The network promises an elaborate upgrade for this baseball season. CBS is using a program called Shockwave, a multimedia application for a browser, to make the action look like an arcade baseball game.
ESPN focuses more on statistics, providing running play-by-play text, rosters, box scores and shot charts.
These Webcasts may be a harbinger of what is called convergence, the melding of television hardware and content with home computer hardware and content. In the case of sports, that means fans will be able to use one screen to get access not only to broadcasts but also to mountains of statistics -- chocolate and peanut butter for fans.
The signs of convergence are already evident in radio, where technology that permits broadcasts to be carried over the Internet makes hundreds of games and events available to anyone with a connection, speakers and a copy of audio-streaming software like Microsoft's Netshow or Real Network's Real Player. In baseball, at least 13 major league baseball teams, two dozen college teams and a handful of minor league teams were set up for doing audio feeds as of February. And you thought you had to be at the park to follow the Winston-Salem Warthogs or Durham Bulls.
The Internet now provides audio access to many other sports: hockey, soccer, golf, auto racing, college basketball, horse racing and rodeo, among others. Audio Net, a Dallas-based Internet broadcaster, even offers play-by-play for contests broadcast exclusively for the Internet, like events at some small universities.
There is even access to sports talk radio, which is where sports fans can go after they have seen the game and the highlights (twice) and they need to find the deeper meaning.
Eventually, Web simulcasts should begin to incorporate not just audio but also video streaming and still shots to create a much richer experience, said Ross Levinsohn, vice president for programming and executive producer at CBS Sportsline.
"We've just built the Edsel," Mr. Levinsohn said. "This is the forebear to the Rolls-Royce, which is still three to six years away."
The early incarnation is apparently welcomed by displaced fans like Louis Crandall, an economist with R. H. Wrightson & Associates in New York, who cannot wait for the baseball season. During the summer, two of the computers on Mr. Crandall's desk are devoted to work and one to the Pittsburgh Pirates. A native of Pittsburgh, Mr. Crandall said he loved to keep the Webcast on in the background; he said it was less intrusive than radio. Last season, he used his browser to watch a no-hitter that Pittsburgh won in extra innings. "It was great when Mark Smith's home run came across" the Internet, said Mr. Crandall, his voice rising as if he had actually been there.
The Webcasts are also attractive to gamblers, their creators admit. "We have no idea how many, but a pretty significant number of people are looking at this because they have an interest in gambling," said Geoff Reiss, senior vice president for sports at ESPN Interactive.
Other competitors may soon get into the Cybercast game, too, said Rick Alessandri, vice president and general manager of Sports Ticker Enterprises, an ESPN-backed venture that provides real-time statistics to more than 100 on-line services. Mr. Alessandri said Yahoo, Fox and America Online were among the companies considering more elaborate real-time coverage.
CNN/SI, the Web site representing CNN and Sports Illustrated, already carries live video of sports-related press conferences. There is just one catch: it runs at 10 frames per second, pokey slow.
Indeed, Web-based live sports are primitive enough to be the domain of die-hard fans. Basketball may be the ultimate example. It is a game that is so fast-paced, it sometimes does not even lend itself to television commentary, let alone to text-based updates. To wit, from a recent ESPN Gamecast of a contest between the Houston Rockets and Minnesota Timberwolves:
"Hou: Charles Barkley defensive rebound
"Hou: Clyde Drexler 3-pointer (Hou 55, Min 43)
"Time remaining, 3:33
"Min: Kevin Garnett layup, assist Stephon Marbury (Hou 55, Min 45)
"Time remaining, 3:17
"Hou: Charles Barkley 3 second violation
"Hou: Mario Elie for Clyde Drexler
"Min: Stephon Marbury miss"
Even David Stern, the Commissioner of the N.B.A., would have trouble selling the experience as Fan-tastic. ESPN gurus do not dispute that.
"This medium cannot and does not replace visual satisfaction in terms of covering Kobe Bryant taking an alley-oop pass and dunking it," said Mr. Reiss, of ESPN Interactive. "What we can do is provide a far greater level of understanding of what is happening in that event. For the hardest-core fans, it's the greatest augmentation that they've ever seen."
Technology aside, the Webcasts will probably face some opposition from other media in the not too distant future, legal experts say. The courts may have to decide whether the Internet functions more like a newspaper or like a broadcast medium, which would put it into direct conflict with television licensing.
But the Webcasts are a godsend to a self-admitted sports junkie like Joseph Pilar, a retired courier in Baltimore. Rather than watch games from his couch, as he used to, Mr. Pilar sits at his desk. That way, he can still watch games on the 21-inch television, then swivel to the 17-inch monitor to get text-based play-by-play updates on the Internet for other games.
"This way, I don't have to wait for the CBS announcer to say, 'Let's go to New York for an update of other scores,' " Mr. Pilar said. "I know everything as it happens."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Household Savings Rate Declines in Japan

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 18

 BODY:
Japan's average household savings fell in 1997 for the first time in four years, signaling that the nation's slump has spread to one of the pillars of the economy.
Average savings per household fell to 16.35 million yen, or $125,769, in 1997, a decline of 1.3 percent from the year before, the Management and Coordination Agency said. The decline was a result of higher taxes and falling wages. 
 To be sure, the Japanese are still the world's biggest savers, with a national savings rate about 2.5 times that of the United States as of 1996, according to the Bank of Japan. Japanese have about 1,200 trillion yen ($9.2 trillion) in savings.
The average savings of a salaried worker's household fell 2.3 percent, to 12.50 million yen, the survey showed. That was the first decline in three years.
The Government raised taxes three times last year, including a two-percentage-point increase in the national sales tax, the elimination of three years of special income tax rebates and a jump in medical insurance premiums. That cost the average household 200,000 yen ($1,538) in lost income, according to the Japan Research Center.
The higher taxes, as well as concern over job security, led consumers to spend less. Declining sales of autos, homes and other big-ticket items prompted companies to cut wages and hiring, further dampening sentiment.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Issues Fall on Report Of Tightening Labor Markets

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities finished lower yesterday after a Federal Reserve account of business conditions around the nation said that labor markets were stretched to the limit.
The Fed's "beige book" report asserted the economy was growing so vigorously that demand for labor was generating substantial wage demands and hampering production. 
 Prices moved in very narrow ranges for most of the session and were barely changed just ahead of the beige book's release.
But prices went to the lowest levels of the day after the report came out. Within a half-hour of the release, the 30-year Treasury bond was down 8/32, yielding 5.91 percent. But by the end of the day it was down only 3/16, to 103 3/16, for a yield of 5.90 percent -- up one basis point, or hundredth of a percentage point, from Tuesday.
"With labor markets stretched to the limit in many areas, there have been reports of rather large wage increases," the anecdotal summary of regional economic activity said.
The market was also edgy ahead of today's reports on February consumer prices and January trade data.
Chris Rupkey, vice president and financial economist at Bank of Tokyo/Mitsubishi, said that the market's movements, while small, were not random.
"We rallied overnight on the dollar going above 130 yen, and they sold it at the opening," he said. "It came back, and then right after 11 o'clock, they priced the $1.6 billion Raytheon deal. That's when we saw the highs of the New York trading day."
Raytheon sold $1.6 billion in debt in a four-part offering that included 3-year, 7-year, 12-year and 20-year debt securities.
Bonds retreated a bit as oil rallied from nine-year lows after Venezuela called for an agreement among both the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and non-OPEC producers to cut oil output.
But bonds mostly meandered until the small selloff that ensued after the Federal Reserve released its beige book report.
The market trimmed its losses after the Treasury announced the size of its monthly two-year and five-year note auctions.
The Treasury said it would sell $14 billion of two-year notes on March 24, $1 billion less than it sold in February. The Treasury also said it would sell $11 billion of five-year notes on March 25.
"We're still in an uptrend from the rally we've had since March 6 when we hit 6.09 percent," Mr. Rupkey said, "but I don't sense a lot of people want to try and join the rally here -- not at this level."
