LENGTH: 993 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Foreign Investors Start Return to Thailand

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 18

 BODY:
Fresh investment has begun flowing into Thai companies and banks for the first time since the financial system started to crumble eight months ago, raising hope that foreign investors are starting to acquire assets made cheap by severe currency and market losses.
Thai financial institutions have gotten a much-needed lift from a spate of deals in recent days, including one announced today under which the Dutch banking giant ABN AMRO will assume majority control of the medium-sized Bank of Asia. The investments do not amount to a rush, and some analysts remain skeptical that Thais are prepared to sell property and companies at prices foreigners are willing to pay. 
 "Strategic buyers are beginning to come into this market, and that is very good news," said Nikhil B. Srinivasan, a Morgan Stanley vice president based in Bangkok. "But anyone who flies in here thinking fire sale is going to be disappointed."
In fact, long-term foreign investment has remained elusive, not only for Thailand but for nearly all damaged Asian economies. Potential investors say that even some overly indebted local companies, determined to save face for their founding families, choose to default on loan payments rather than part with prized possessions at bargain prices.
Legal restrictions have also been an obstacle. Thailand recently adopted a Western-style bankruptcy law that will allow creditors to foreclose on debtors, but the law remains untested in court. The Government continues to ban outright foreign ownership of land, a restriction many see as a strong deterrent to investment here.
Still, officials concede that the country cannot recover on its own, and they have urged foreign investors to bail out banks and finance companies. Prime Minister Chuan Leekpai recently completed a visit to the United States, where he sought to stir the interest of business executives. "We have to admit frankly that we do not have the money in Thailand" to revitalize local companies, Mr. Chuan said in a recent interview. "We will depend on foreigners for some time to come."
A few Western companies are taking up the offer, as seen in ABN AMRO's deal to acquire a 75 percent interest in the Bank of Asia, Thailand's 11th-largest commercial bank. Under a letter of intent, the Dutch bank will make an initial purchase of shares and inject $184 million into the bank.
But in a concession that illustrates the difficulty of reaching investment agreements amid the current economic turmoil, ABN AMRO agreed to determine the final purchase price in 2000, when the Thai market will presumably have strengthened. The Dutch bank also used the word "alliance" to describe its purchase, though it will have a dominant position and control management.
Although many foreign banking companies, including Citicorp and the ING Group of the Netherlands, have scouted potential Thai and other Asian partners, ABN AMRO's deal marks the first significant investment by a Western bank since the Asian financial crisis began last summer. DBS Bank of Singapore took a controlling interest in Thai Danu Bank late last year, but that was seen as a government-to-government arrangement.
Foreigners have also begun to acquire some of Thailand's nonbank finance companies. The Taiwan-based China Development Corporation announced earlier this week that it would spend about $20 million to buy a 40.5 percent stake in Bangkok First Investment and Trust, a finance company now owned by Bangkok Bank, Thailand's largest.
Societe Generale of France last week raised its holding in Asia Credit, a Thai finance company, from 25 percent to 51 percent, an increase valued at $156 million. ABN AMRO also recently bought a large stake in Asia Securities Trading.
Big industrial companies are also getting foreign help. The financier George Soros and a consortium of other foreign investors last week agreed to channel $650 million into the Nakornthai Strip Mill, by far the biggest investment in a Thai company during the crisis. The consortium plans to reorganize and expand the steel plant, a unit of the debt-ridden NTS Steel Group, and replace local managers with foreigners.
Although those deals are substantial, analysts doubt that they will lead to a slew of foreign takeovers. A key reason is that Thai company bosses still have a strong antipathy to selling their holdings.
Indeed, some companies wary of selling big stakes to foreign strategic partners and risking the loss of control are rushing to take advantage of improved market sentiment and to raise funds in a way that protects the existing management. For example, Thai Farmers Bank, the country's second largest, just began a worldwide share subscription drive to raise $1 billion.
"We think this will be enough to tide us over into the next century," said Banthoon Lamsam, the bank's president, in a recent interview. He said the offering was intended to limit foreign share ownership to 49 percent and to preserve family control over the bank. "We do not foresee the need to bring in a strategic partner," he added.
Moreover, potential investors are hesitating to take stakes in Thai companies willing to accept foreign control, largely because the economy is still weakening. The Government thinks that output will shrink 3.5 percent this year.
Even the largest Thai companies have suspended payments owed to banks, putting them in technical default and raising tricky legal questions for potential foreign suitors. Companies are already posting big losses, but most analysts expect that the worst is yet to come. For that reason, many foreign investors are likely to wait until late this year before committing themselves to big deals, analysts say.
"Thailand is still on its way down," says Russell Kopp, research chief at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson here. "Until Thais become more realistic about their prospects and set prices accordingly, I don't think we're going to see many bailouts."

HEADLINE: Accra Journal;
African Hospitality No Match for Clinton's Hordes

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: ACCRA, Ghana

 BODY:
The last time this country received a visitor of such note, it was nearly four decades ago, and the guest was a young Queen Elizabeth. Newly independent and lacking the kinds of accommodations typically reserved for royalty, the Government hurriedly built an extension to a whitewashed old fort that still serves today as State House.
Ghana's Government is again frantically preparing for a special guest, President Clinton, who is to stop here on March 23 on the first leg of a six-nation African tour. Mr. Clinton's visit will be the first by an American President to sub-Saharan Africa in 20 years. 
 But in a sure sign of changing times, in the weeks since Mr. Clinton's visit was confirmed, no amount of rushing seems to have sufficed to meet his logistical needs.
Though Queen Elizabeth arrived here with an entourage of a couple of dozen royal handlers and aides, Mr. Clinton, the President of the world's only remaining superpower, is bringing a super-sized delegation of about 800 people, including the press. After much hand-wringing and planning sessions by advance teams and Ghanaian officials that even resulted in a trimming of the delegation size, it was decided that Mr. Clinton could simply not stay overnight in Ghana.
There were just not enough hotel rooms.
In its own way, the mismatch between an American Presidential delegation and the available hotel space in a West African capital like Accra sums up in miniature the gap between rich and powerful America and a largely poor Africa.
With the possible exception of South Africa, each stop on Mr. Clinton's itinerary, from Ghana to Uganda, and Botswana to Senegal and Rwanda, will serve up reminders of just how rarely the United States accords Africa this kind of attention. There will be reminders, too, of how unequal the discussion can be whenever the Americans do come.
Whether the subject is Washington's current emphasis on commerce in its policy toward the continent -- summed up in the phrase, "trade not aid" -- or something as simple as traffic and security arrangements during each of Mr. Clinton's various stops, African officials may soon discover that with a guest this important, having the last word is next to impossible.
Many Ghanaian officials broach the topic of Mr. Clinton's impending visit with distinct pride in the fact that the White House has chosen their country at all, not to mention that it will be the President's first stop.
"Anytime the first family of the United States comes to your country, 98.7 percent of the world's media will be looking at your country for at least some portion of the day," said Kwame Peprah, Ghana's Finance Minister. "We will be doing everything we can, of course, to put on our best face."
Others involved in the nitty-gritty of making sure the visit comes off successfully, however, are already well versed in scarcely imagined difficulties in the details.
First, of course, was the hotel issue. Ghana's bustling capital has over 500 top-flight hotel rooms, putting it within the ballpark of the Clinton delegation's needs, but it turns out that the largest and perhaps best hotel, the Golden Tulip, is owned by Libyan investors, thus placing it out of bounds for official American guests.
Even though Mr. Clinton will not be spending the night, his advance team, security people and assorted aides and guests will be scattered across 24 hotels, prompting one diplomat to remark, "You can imagine the logistical nightmare involved in keeping everything clicking."
With a mixture of amused wonderment and slight irritation, Ghanaian officials tell stories of White House inspection visits that resemble a cross between a bomb squad sweep of a public building after a scare and a health department inspection of a neighborhood diner.
"I'll never forget watching one of these people, a lady, walking through the Castle with a clipboard saying: 'This will have to go. That's fine right there. And, oh, is there any way you could move this furniture?' " said one assistant to Ghana's President, Jerry Rawlings. "When we reached the outside, they took one look at the huge generator we have and said that it wouldn't do.
"The woman actually asked if we could replace it," Mr. Rawlings's assistant said, referring to a large, multimillion-dollar piece of heavy equipment. The same official reportedly asked if the Government could set up an international press center with hundreds of direct dial international lines, to accommodate the estimated 250 journalists traveling with Mr. Clinton.
Ghana is in a financial squeeze, made worse by a severe energy shortage that has lately forced tight rationing of electricity. So when the Government politely declined to replace the generator at the State House, Mr. Clinton's assistants began planning to fly in one of their own for use during his planned eight-hour stopover here.
As for the press center, in a country where placing even a local call can require persistence, the Ghanaian official said the visiting press would have to make do.
Besides logistics, Ghanaian officials are finding out that wherever policy and communications intersect, Mr. Clinton's visit will be tightly scripted, with each country on the African trip assigned its own special themes. In Ghana, the accent will be on shared historic bonds between the United States and West Africa, democracy and what Mr. Clinton will call Africa's continuing economic renaissance.
One leading Ghanaian businessman said that he had approached senior Government officials here and urged them to appeal to Mr. Clinton for emergency help in finding a solution to the country's energy crisis, but was rebuffed.
Other Ghanaian officials say they have urged that Mr. Rawlings, a fiery populist leader, make the most of the occasion by promoting "a new global economic order," and denounce the perceived hypocrisy of telling Africans to open their economies while Western countries remain protectionist.
"We've been told that Clinton is coming to change the way Americans think about Africa, from a continent of despair to a place of opportunity and hope," said a senior Ghanaian official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "I guess if you want the President of the United States to come, you've got to let him give his message."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Market Continues Its Climb, With Indexes Hitting Highs

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
The stock market soared further into record territory yesterday, sending all the major indexes to all-time highs.
The Dow Jones industrial average, rising steadily for almost two months, gained 25.41 points, to 8,775.40, its third consecutive record.
In a year when few Wall Street analysts expected to Dow to gain double-digits, the blue-chip average is already up 11 percent, one of its best starts this decade.
After three spectacular years of share price gains, the market is once again strengthening against a backdrop of solid economic growth, heavy cash flows into mutual funds and speculation that more and more companies will merge, pushing share prices even higher.
The brokerage industry -- one of the prime benefactors of this bull market -- has been both a source of tremendous profit growth, driven by an increasingly investment-hungry populace, and heavy speculation about new banking combinations.
Yesterday, for instance, talk that the Chase Manhattan Corporation might merge with Merrill Lynch sent Merrill's shares up more than 9 percent, despite denials among industry insiders that a deal was pending. Chase and Merrill declined comment.
Shares of Chase also rose a day after the nation's biggest commercial bank said it would cut 4,500 jobs, by laying off 2,250 employees and not replacing the others, in the next 18 months.
In the last three years, brokerage stocks, as calculated in the American Stock Exchange's security and broker-dealer index, are up about 500 percent, partly because of new combinations such as Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter and the merger of Salomon Brothers and Smith Barney, which is part of the Travelers Group.
Shares of several regional telephone companies also rose yesterday after Edward Whitacre, Jr., the chairman of SBC Communications, said he might be interested in buying another local phone company.
It has been that kind of a market. Earnings growth may be eroding, but analysts say investors believe the economy will remain strong, and the eagerness to own stocks is greater than ever.
Since the Dow fell 554 points last Oct. 27 to hit 7,161.15 on fears of a deepening economic crisis in Southeast Asia, the average has risen 1,614 points, or 22.5 percent. Even ardent bulls are wondering whether the market has risen too fast.
"The momentum unleashed in the last few weeks means we're going to go to the extreme on the greed side," said Alfred Goldman, director of market analysis at A. G. Edwards Inc. "People have lots of money and they don't want to leave a winning game."
Shares of energy companies gained after oil prices rebounded from a series of declines. Exxon and Chevron were among the leading Dow component stocks. Investors also bought up technology shares despite recent profit warnings. The Nasdaq composite index rose 8.98 points to close at a record 1,788.28.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 5.07 points to close at a record 1,085.52. The Russell 2000 index of small-company stocks rose 1.07, to a record 427.18.
Richard Eakle, an analyst and president of Eakle Associates in Fair Haven, N.J., said the market has been buoyed by middle-aged investors who see stocks as the fountain of wealth.
"The primary catalyst is the baby- boomer generation liquidity situation," he said. "That generation is going to invest as much as they can."

HEADLINE: 3 Top Cabinet Members Lobby Congress for I.M.F. and U.N.

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18

 BODY:
Three senior Cabinet members warned today that American economic and security interests would suffer badly if Congress failed to approve new financing for the International Monetary Fund and pay its back dues to the United Nations.
Speaking in near-apocalyptic terms, Defense Secretary William S. Cohen, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin went to Capitol Hill to plead for $18 billion for the monetary fund, nearly $1 billion for the United Nations and $2.5 billion for military costs in Bosnia and the Persian Gulf and for disaster relief. 
 "Our national security, and war and peace, are at risk by not having appropriate payment of U.N. arrears," Mr. Rubin said at a news conference. "The financial stability of the world is at risk."
The House and Senate are considering the requests, but the emergency spending bills have become entangled in partisan Congressional bickering, anti-abortion riders and many Republicans' deep distrust of international organizations.
Without quick approval of the spending bills, Ms. Albright said, "we're in danger of shutting down U.S. national security policy."
Emphasizing that American economic and security goals are interlocking, especially in countries like Thailand and South Korea, Mr. Cohen said, "We need to move on the I.M.F. funds as quickly as possible."
The rare appearance of the three powerful members of the Cabinet reflects a growing unease at the White House that two of President Clinton's top foreign policy priorities -- financing for the monetary fund and payment of the United Nations dues -- face formidable obstacles.
The House Republican leadership today postponed for the second time in a week a vote on a House-Senate conference report that would authorize payment of the United Nations dues. The leadership was unable to win backing from conservative Republicans, many of whom oppose paying the dues. House leaders are expected to try again on Thursday.
Separately today, the House rejected, by a vote of 225 to 193, a resolution that would have required Mr. Clinton to withdraw American troops from Bosnia.
The Administration initially asked Congress to consider the emergency spending for the military operations, disaster aid, the monetary fund and the United Nations in one large bill.
But House Republicans split the requests into two bills, one for the military and disaster spending, which could be approved quickly, and another addressing the more contentious issues of I.M.F. financing and back United Nations dues. The Senate followed suit.
On Wednesday the Senate Appropriations Committee approved the $18 billion for the monetary fund -- $3.5 billion for a new emergency credit line and $14.5 billion for reserves -- but attached strict conditions that must be met before most of the money could be spent. It dropped the requested $921 million in United Nations dues.
Mr. Rubin today praised the Senate committee for approving the $18 billion but said the conditions "could create a situation that could require six months, a year, perhaps indefinite time" to reach agreement with each of the 182 nations in the monetary fund.
In response, three Republicans from agricultural states that could lose exports if the Asian crisis deepens broke ranks and introduced a bill to modify many of the conditions.
"Passage of workable I.M.F. funding is critical to stem the Asian financial crisis before it spreads and overwhelms the rest of the world," said Senator Pat Roberts of Kansas, who sponsored the bill with Senator Rod Grams of Minnesota and Senator Charles Hagel of Nebraska.
The situation with the spending bills in the House is even murkier. The House Republican leadership has held up its I.M.F. financing bill until the White House agrees to a provision to prohibit the State Department from giving aid to international organizations that lobby foreign governments to change their policies against abortion. Mr. Clinton opposes that provision.
With the monetary fund's coffers depleted by bailouts for three Asian countries, Mr. Rubin said, "there is a very real risk that if there were another major crisis, the I.M.F. would not have sufficient funds to deal with that crisis."
"If that were true," he said, "that could significantly affect our workers, our farmers and our businesses."

HEADLINE: Lockheed Seeking a Way To Save Its Northrop Deal

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 18

 BODY:
The Lockheed Martin Corporation is scrambling to salvage its proposed acquisition of Northrop Grumman, now that the Government has rejected a new proposal the company made in an effort to allay antitrust concerns.
But the chances that the deal may collapse appear to be growing as the Government and the company seem far apart, and indeed the Justice Department may sue to block the transaction. 
 "It would appear that the Government has constructed a scenario that's impossible to satisfy without making the deal unattractive economically," said Howard A. Rubel, aerospace analyst with Goldman, Sachs & Company. He estimated there was a 70 percent chance that the takeover would not be completed as currently configured.
Reflecting that, Northrop Grumman's shares fell $2.50, or nearly 2.3 percent, today to $107.50. Lockheed Martin lost 81.25 cents, to $115.5625.
The Justice Department might go to court to block the deal as early as Thursday, some industry and Government officials said. But others, including Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen, suggested that negotiations would continue.
The Defense and Justice Departments said last week that they were worried that the deal would stifle competition, in part because Lockheed Martin, a major aircraft manufacturer, would own a leading supplier of radar and other electronic systems used in those planes.
Lockheed on Tuesday proposed to sell part of Northrop's electronics business with more than $1 billion a year in sales, industry officials said. This was twice as much as the company had been willing to sell before the Government expressed its concerns. The company also offered to enter into consent decrees to insure that it would not discriminate against outside suppliers.
But the Government is pushing Lockheed Martin to sell all of the Northrop electronics businesses, with about $4 billion in sales.
That accounts for nearly half of Northrop's roughly $9 billion in revenue and would be a deal-breaker, industry officials said, because the electronics business is the main reason Lockheed wants Northrop. But it is not yet clear how much Lockheed would be willing to sell to win Government approval.
A Lockheed spokesman said the company was continuing to talk to the Government. A spokesman for the Justice Department also said the matter remained open, while a Pentagon spokesman said it was in the Justice Department's hands. Northrop Grumman had no comment.
Under the agreement announced last July for the $8.3 billion stock acquisition, either company can walk away from the deal if it is not completed by March 31. But the companies have told the Justice Department they will not close the deal before April 24.
Mr. Rubel of Goldman, Sachs said he did not think Lockheed and Northrop would want to fight the Pentagon, the main customer, in court. "I think they gave it a good college try," he said. "And if their customer says, 'Sorry,' they are better served by moving ahead and working on their own respective businesses than by having lawyers fighting each other."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Trade Surplus Soars in Japan

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, March 19

 BODY:
Japan's customs-cleared trade surplus for February climbed 88.7 percent from a year earlier to 1.28 trillion yen, or $9.8 billion, the Finance Ministry said today.
The surplus with the United States, Japan's biggest trade partner, rose to 539.03 billion yen, or $4.14 billion, in February, up 32.9 percent from a year earlier, it said. The figures were not adjusted for seasonal factors. 
 The overall surplus was near economists' average forecast of around 1.202 trillion yen, or $9.2 billion. Economists said the trade surplus was likely to continue rising because of a declining trend in imports, caused by weak domestic demand, a weaker yen and falling oil prices.
The growth in the surplus may heighten Washington's repeated calls on Tokyo to take decisive steps to revive its ailing domestic economy in the face of Asia's economic crisis.
A White House economic adviser, Gene Sperling, said earlier this week that the Administration was hopeful Japan would adopt a fiscal stimulus worth up to 10 trillion yen, or $77.5 billion.

HEADLINE: Strong Economy, No Inflation in Fed Survey

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18

 BODY:
Despite a decline in export sales, the economy in all regions of the United States remains strong -- yet inflation seems "eerily calm," the Federal Reserve said today.
"Industrial activity is on the rise in most parts of the country, with orders and production up," it said in its "beige book" survey of regional economic conditions. "Most districts, though, are experiencing a decline in exports to Asia." 
 American consumers continue to spend strongly on most items except cars, the report said. It was based on information collected through March 9.
"Retail sales are generally up in most districts, exceeding retailers' expectations in many of them," it said. "Auto sales, however, are generally down, although demand for pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles remains high."
Before the Asian crisis emerged in full force this fall, the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, and his colleagues had been warning that labor shortages in the United States could eventually lead to increased inflation.
Since then, they have been counting on the impact of the Asian turmoil to dampen growth and ease labor shortages in the United States. So far, though, that does not seem to be happening, the beige book said.
"The demand for labor remains strong, with nearly all districts reporting shortages of workers at the entry level and in certain skilled categories," it said. "Widespread labor market tightness appears to have increased the degree of wage pressures."
Despite that, "pressures on product prices remain eerily calm," it said, adding, "Domestic competition, productivity gains and the Asian situation help to constrain production costs."
The beige book, named after the color of its cover, was prepared for the March 31 meeting of the Fed's policy-making Federal Open Market Committee. The panel sets short-term interest rates through changes in the overnight rate on loans between banks.
A year ago, it nudged the rate up by a quarter percentage point, to 5.5 percent, citing excess demand in the economy. Since then, it has left the rate untouched, watching nervously to see if strong growth and scarce labor would produce increased inflation.
In other developments, the beige book said that mild weather in many parts of the country, the product of the El Nino current in the Pacific Ocean, had created "unseasonably hardy" housing markets and healthy commercial real estate markets.
But conditions on the nation's farms are mixed, it said.
"An abundance of precipitation has harmed crop prospects and delayed field preparation activities," it said.

GRAPHIC: Chart/Map: "Economy Tempers in Places, but Remains Vigorous"
A roundup of regional economic conditions in recent months for the Federal Reserve's 12 districts, according to the beige book report issued by the Fed yesterday.
 
Minneapolis -- Growth continued at a steady pace led by the construction, manufacturing and retail industries.
 
Chicago -- Growth increased modestly, led by gains in consumer spending and housing. Manufacturing operated near capacity and new orders showed no signs of slowing.
 
Cleveland -- The economy continued to grow at a moderate pace. Labor markets were strong and price pressures light. Real estate flourished.
 
Boston -- Retail sales picked up while manufacturing had mixed results. Many companies reported hiring difficulties.
 
New York -- The economy grew briskly in the first two months of 1998 with better-than-expected retail sales. The housing market retained momentum.
 
Philadelphia Manufacturers saw continued strength in shipments and orders, while retail sales were rising. Car sales eased.
 
Richmond Retail sales rose above last year's level. Manufacturers said shipments and orders rebounded sharply and real estate picked up.
 
Atlanta -- The Southeastern economy continued to grow at a moderate pace. Retail sales met expectations; home sales rose as mortgage rates declined.
 
St. Louis -- The economy continued to generate business growth with few signs of rising prices. Retail sales met expectations while manufacturers experienced strong sales and orders.
 
Kansas City Labor markets remained tight, with intensifying wage increases. Retail prices held steady, sales dipped slightly and construction slowed.
 
Dallas -- Economic activity expanded at about the same pace or a little slower as before. Manufacturing prices were flat to down while the service and construction industries saw higher prices.
 
San Francisco -- The economy continued its vigorous growth although with signs of moderation in certain areas, including retail sales. The effects of Asian economic turmoil were evident in several sectors.

HEADLINE: U.S. Weighs Deal to Halt Missile-Gear Sales by China

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18

 BODY:
The United States is weighing whether to allow American satellite manufacturers to buy launching services from China, a senior Government official said today. In exchange, China would have to create a system to stop sales of Chinese missile technology to nations like Iran.
The move would waive sanctions imposed after the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre. It would allow President Clinton to take an attractive proposal with him when he visits China this summer. But it is far from clear that China can or will curb its sales of missile technology. 
 In this foreign policy stratagem, human rights policies are being shaped by expanding markets as well as strategic concerns. The Clinton Administration has made it known that it believes China's human rights record has improved in recent years. Last week it said it would neither propose nor support a United Nations resolution censuring China for human rights abuses.
That stance allows the Administration to propose a policy that is intended simultaneously to remove some of the stain of the Tiananmen Square massacre, help control the spread of weapons of mass destruction and increase commercial ties between the United States and China.
Critics of the evolving policy toward China contend that Beijing has never kept its promise to play by the rules of the Missile Technology Control Regime, an international agreement that China never signed but has pledged to follow.
In January the Congressional Research Service reported that China "may be continuing to violate its commitment to abide by the M.T.C.R. guidelines."
United States intelligence services regularly report that China may be selling military technology to nations including Iran and Pakistan. The State Department says some of these reports are inconclusive.
The biggest potential stumbling block for the new proposed policy is that the United States does not know what system, if any, the Chinese Government has for controlling sales of missile technology. China has never established export controls that would meet the international standard established under the missile control regime.
The proposed policy resembles an offer that the United States made to Russia last week. During meetings in Washington between Vice President Al Gore and Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, United States officials offered to increase Russia's opportunities to launch American satellites. In exchange, Moscow would have to clamp down hard on the sale of missile technology to Iran.
The new proposed policy toward China is solely about expanding commercial and scientific space cooperation, said the senior Government official, who would not be quoted by name. It contains "no consideration about helping China's military," he said. He strongly disputed a report by The Washington Times today that said the policy would permit China access to United States missile technology.
"The emphasis is on peaceful space cooperation," he said; for example, efforts to use satellites to study the climate, topography, agriculture and development of nations. "This is an area where we can engage in additional scientific cooperation with the Chinese in ways that are purely peaceful," he said.
He also said United States satellite manufacturers are pushing to open up China, exerting "a lot of pressure to find new opportunities for launch services," he said. "They are in favor of ways to take advantage of foreign launch services."
The interplay of politics, commerce and strategy between Washington and Beijing was underlined again today by the opening of a huge potential nuclear power market in China for American companies like General Electric.
In December the Clinton Administration certified to Congress that China is reining in its sales of technology that can be used in nuclear weaponry. Congress let that certification stand today. That means it is now legal for United States companies to sell nuclear reactors to China.
The market is potentially worth billions of dollars for the American nuclear power industry, which has not built a new plant in the United States since the 1979 accident at Three Mile Island. Until today the United States was the only country in the world that imposed restrictions on peaceful nuclear cooperation with China.

HEADLINE: French Jobless Find the World Is Harsher

SERIES: HELP UNWANTED: First of two articles.

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, March 18

 BODY:
Like the more than three million other French workers who cannot find a job, Yves Hell is angry. He lost his job as a clerk in Marseilles in December, and now, at age 35, he has had to give up his small apartment there and move in with his retired parents.
What he is angry about is not so much the difficult job market or being let go as the unexpected inability of the vaunted French welfare system to provide him with a decent standard of living. 
 "You can't live as well on unemployment today as you could 10 years ago," he complained. When unemployed workers took to the streets in Marseilles this winter to demand a year-end $300 bonus payment to help them start the new year, he joined them.
Thousands of unemployed workers on welfare have marched on welfare offices around the country demanding large increases in benefits and making a few gains. Last month, the Government increased welfare payments, but protesters still want 10 times as much and plan to continue demonstrating into the spring.
The pattern of worker entitlement, protest and Government capitulation is deep-rooted here, and has swollen the French welfare state into one of the most comprehensive and costly in Europe. But now, with French unemployment running at more than 12 percent since 1996, with a mandate to cut spending for the introduction of Europe's common currency and with growing international business competition, this pattern is near the breaking point.
This year, the French economy is expected to post a healthy 3 percent gain -- its best growth in nine years -- but it will not produce many new jobs. The job shortage in the face of a gradual recovery is a problem bedeviling not just France but all of Western Europe, where entrenched expectations that the state will look out for its workers are colliding with the pitiless challenges of global competition.
As economic growth picks up, the unemployed French feel as though they are being left behind, and that is putting the country at the epicenter of a collision between Europe's new order and the old. For generations the French have generally assumed that their rich farmland and their proud industrial base would provide either the jobs or the "decent means of existence" promised in the preamble to the Constitution.
Financed by some of the world's highest tax rates, the growing welfare system flourished. It elevated 300 million people in Europe to some of the world's highest living standards, provided affordable medical care, public swimming pools and a superb educational system.
But much of that is financed by payroll taxes on employers that are among the steepest in the world. Now, many business leaders argue that the price of social protection is too high in a world of intense competitors from Asia to the United States. Taxes and benefits are the main reasons employers say they are not creating jobs in Europe and especially in France.
Lionel Jospin, the Socialist Prime Minister who was elected last June on promises to make jobs his first priority, recently found a little extra money for social measures thanks to higher-than-expected economic growth last year. He raised welfare payments 8 percent, instead of the 2 percent plan that had brought demonstrators to the streets. But he took pains to say, "I am for a society that works, not a society of assistance."
But where Britain's Prime Minister, Tony Blair, has proposed cutting business taxes and giving people on welfare tax incentives to look for jobs, Mr. Jospin is placing his hopes for job creation on continued economic growth and a much-debated plan to reduce the work week from 39 hours to 35 hours, without cutting pay.
 
Will It Be New Jobs Or Even More Layoffs?
Shorter weeks will create hundreds of thousands of jobs, he maintains. But employers say that without strong growth, the change could drive up costs and create even more layoffs.
In the United States, corporate America cut tens of thousands of jobs in the last decade or so, but unemployment eventualy declined to record lows thanks mostly to a surge in new jobs in services. But like France, the United States Government repeatedly had extended jobless benefits and created programs for the long-term unemployed during its period of transition until the American economy began creating hundreds of millions of new jobs -- a trend that is barely beginning now in France.
Many of the long-term unemployed feel "excluded," a word that in French means being outside normal society and carries the connotation of alienation and poverty.
Most had assumed that they lived in a society that would never leave them to fend for themselves. Believing that even France's labor unions do not represent their interests, many of the "excluded" have formed militant groups like the ones that led the sit-ins at welfare offices.
One example is A.C.! -- an organization formed in 1994 whose initials in French (pronounced ah-SAY) signify "Act Together Against Unemployment," and are pronounced like the French word assez, or enough. It grew out of the traditional union movement and was one of the instigators of the demonstrations this year to occupy welfare offices around the country.
Jacqueline Maman helped open a self-help storefront office for the unemployed in the 20th arrondissement of Paris, a working-class neighborhood heavily populated by North African immigrants.
Her National Movement of Temporary and Unemployed Workers, a group similar to A.C.!, concentrates on the problems of working women like herself, many of them single or divorced mothers with children.
She opened the office after finding, much to her astonishment, that the temporary jobs she was lucky enough to land occasionally required her to contribute part of her pay to unemployment insurance. But even with those contributions, she could not get benefits after her job ended.
"The unions and the employers administer the unemployment insurance and pension system, but people who are permanently out of work have no voice in how the money is spent," said Ms. Maman, a 49-year-old former secretary.
"The unemployed should sit on those boards," she said. "But the union leaders don't even want to know about the likes of us."
Jean-Jacques Leclerc, an 47-year-old single father in Marseilles who is unemployed, volunteered to help in the A.C.! campaign to occupy welfare offices in December.
"I felt I had to do something," he said. "I couldn't just stay at home doing nothing."
Mr. Leclerc, who uses a cane because of abuse he said he suffered as a child, said his last job, as an accountant, ended five years ago when his employer went bankrupt.
 
'Look at Fortunes On Stock Market'
He is still looking for work, he said, and lives on a disability pension of about $400 a month. He also gets a rent allowance that pays for the apartment in the center of the city for him and his three sons and family allowances that average about $150 a month for each of the boys.
"That money belongs to them, not me," Mr. Leclerc said. "The boys like to have home-cooked Sunday lunch at home just like any other French family, and I try to make them a good Provencal meal."
His family health insurance is free, as it is for people on welfare, and it would pay, Mr. Leclerc said, for psychiatric counseling for the boys to help them get through the problems they experienced after their mother abandoned the family four years ago, for reasons he said were not connected with his losing his job.
"Look at the fortunes being made on the stock market," he said. "I can't even afford a basketball for my oldest."
Mr. Hell, the 35-year-old clerical worker who moved into his parent's apartment in Marseilles, nodded in understanding. He is attending classes at the tuition-free St. Charles University in Bordeaux to get his French secondary-school diploma, the baccalaureat. "I want to show that it is possible to escape this unemployment trap," he said.
In an office above a garden center, Philippe Parrot, runs a state employment branch office in the western Paris suburb of Velizy. It is a cheerful place with big windows and bulletin boards bearing fresh printouts of job offerings from local companies, a large number of which are in the computer and information-processing business. There are also telephones for arranging job interviews. "As a rule, people have the best chance of finding a job in the first three months after registering with us," Mr. Parrot said.
"About 20 to 40 people a day come in here, sometimes as many as 800 before we close," he said. "Not all of them are young people, of course. Some have held jobs already for 10 or 15 years, and come in here for the first time in their lives after their company has closed or let them go, and look absolutely shellshocked," he said.
"Others have been through this before," he said. "They know that nowadays it's easier to find short-term contracts than it is to find permanent jobs."
Gerard Decout, a counselor who interviews applicants when they first come in, said: "A few years ago, not everyone was willing to accept a short-term contract. They preferred to wait for a permanent job to turn up."
"Now," he said, "temporary and part-time jobs are more numerous than they used to be."
 
Fears From Employers And Even Some Unions
Employers have been almost universally hostile to Mr. Jospin's plan to cut the work week, mostly because they fear that it will cost more. Even some union groups have been opposed.
"Reducing the work week is not a remedy for a period of crisis," said Nicole Notat, leader of a centrist union, the French Democratic Labor Confederation. Greater growth should give employers and unions leeway for finding more flexible ways of organizing work that, she said.
One company that has added workers and reorganized the work schedule is a subsidiary of the Galeries Lafayette department store. It is in the business of marketing and credit card services from a sparely decorated headquarters in the Paris banking district and a processing center near Bordeaux that employs 1,600 people.
Thierry Berge, the long-haired, bespectacled chief executive of the company, said it opted for a 35-hour week a year ago after the Government began subsidizing half the cost of new hires made necessary by a shorter week.
"Our customers wanted service at night and on Saturdays, and we couldn't provide that with all our employees working between 8 and 5 and only five days a week," Mr. Berge said.
"So we went to our unions and said, 'We'll give you shorter working hours for equal pay if you'll give us more flexible schedules.' "
At first, the unions were skeptical but gradually both sides agree that workers could control some scheduling, and the company could eliminate overtime payments by averaging hours worked over an entire year.
"With this system, we created 140 new jobs," Mr. Berge said, and a Government subsidy cut the cost of the new workers by half.
"But we never would have done this if the unions hadn't agreed to give us flexibility on scheduling, and we couldn't have hired extra workers if our business hadn't been growing by 15 percent a year," he said. "Not all companies are so lucky."
Indeed, as much as Mr. Jospin wants employers and workers to figure out how best to use a 35-hour law, there are obstacles.
For one thing, the measure, which is still being debated in Parliament, would reduce incentives established by the previous conservative Government that helped Mr. Berge's company go ahead. Mr. Jospin's Government does not believe in paying such subsidies to business.
 
Profit Margins Already Stretched Thin
There is the problem of growth. Jean-Yves Bloquert, the peppery head of the family-owned Kindy textile company in Moliens, a tiny, windswept farm village in northern France, said profit margins in his business were already stretched thin.
The town's single main street is lined with brick houses and barns, but it has become a parking lot for the factory workers who come from miles around to run machines that knit 55,000 brightly colored pairs of socks every day, Monday through Saturday nonstop.
Mr. Bloquert did not lay off a single worker when France cut the workweek from 40 hours to 39 in 1988, he said. But he already pays workers $16.45 an hour after adding $6.83 in 18 separate payroll taxes.
So a Government requirement to cut the work week to 35 hours without a pay cut means, he says, that every employee will now cost him even more.
During the cold war, he said, there were few ways to cut labor costs. But now in Eastern Europe, the going wage in the textile industry is only $2.21 an hour in the Czech Republic, $2.39 in Poland and $3.18 in Hungary, including payroll taxes. And all of those factories are just a day away by truck.
Would he adopt a 35-hour week? "It will depend on what exactly is in the law when it finally passes," Mr. Bloquert said. "But if the law doesn't give companies some flexibility in implementing it, we will have to consider moving about 25 percent of our production to Eastern Europe."
"It would break my heart to do it," he said, "but we owe it to our shareholders to keep increasing profits, and we'll have to do something."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Once Behind the Pack, Adidas Vies for the Lead

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: MUNICH, Germany

 BODY:
When Robert Louis-Dreyfus was tapped five years ago to run Adidas A. G., he was taking over the weakest franchise in the global sporting goods league.
For years, Adidas was synonymous in many parts of the world with sneakers and athletic apparel. But as one more example of a family-run company that stumbled when the founding family died out, Adidas had been badly beaten by agile new competitors like Nike and Reebok. When Mr. Louis-Dreyfus took over in early 1993, the company had just reported an $82 million loss for 1992, after eking out an $8 million profit the year earlier. Business in the huge American market, where Adidas had established its three-striped brand as a trendy item a decade earlier, had all but dried up. 
 But that was before Mr. Louis-Dreyfus, a skilled turnaround artist, began his make-over. Now Adidas is sprinting back into contention even as Nike, the industry Goliath, is stumbling.
Adidas closed out 1997 with record net income of $255 million, 48 percent more than the year before, on revenues of $3.6 billion. In the process, it overtook Fila U.S.A. as the No. 3 athletic shoe supplier in the United States and has set its sights on passing Reebok for the No. 2 slot. Mr. Louis-Dreyfus even plunked down $1.4 billion last September to acquire Salomon S. A., the French sporting goods giant best known in the United States for Taylor Made golf clubs and Salomon skis. Adidas-Salomon, as the merged company is called, is the world's second-largest sporting goods group, behind only Nike itself, which has been struggling with bloated inventory and faltering demand not only in the United States but also in Asia.
"We're going in the right direction now," Mr. Louis-Dreyfus said in an interview here, not far from Adidas's headquarters in the German town of Herzogenaurach.
 The reversal of fortunes was evident this week. On Wednesday, Nike announced disappointing third-quarter earnings, though its stock rose $1.625, to $46.50, because the results were not as bad as had been forecast. Adidas stock closed at a record high on Tuesday of 319 marks, or about $175; it finished Wednesday at 310 marks.
Mr. Louis-Dreyfus has turned things around in several ways. He poured large sums into creating a cooler image for Adidas with young people tired of Nike's in-your-face style. To challenge Nike's design flamboyance, Adidas took a contrary stance with its "feet you wear" concept, maintaining that built-up sneakers can be unstable. And while holding on to its strength in soccer, Adidas gained ground in more popular sports in the United States by signing up big-name athletes like Kobe Bryant of basketball's Los Angeles Lakers and Keyshawn Johnson of football's New York Jets in sponsorship deals.
Nike, which is planning a counterattack on Adidas's home turf, says it is not too worried. Stefano Caroti, who took over last year as Nike's general manager for Central Europe, accuses Adidas of building its recent success by using Nike's winning formulas.
"They're copying us, from our ads to our products," he said. "You put a swoosh at the end of their commercials, they're ours."
True, the 51-year-old Mr. Louis-Dreyfus still has a long way to go just to catch Nike's shadow. Nike may have its problems, but it continues to control 47 percent of American sneaker sales, compared with 15 percent for Reebok and just 6 percent for Adidas.
Yet what Mr. Louis-Dreyfus has already accomplished has won him high marks on both sides of the Atlantic. "It is a great company, and Robert is a fabulous manager," said Faye Landes, senior footwear analyst at Salomon Smith Barney in New York. (The securities firm has no connection with Salomon S. A.)
Investors clearly agree. After Mr. Louis-Dreyfus took Adidas public in 1996, selling 40 percent of its equity on the Frankfurt exchange, the initial price was 68 marks, a fraction of what it trades for now. Once he assimilates the Salomon purchase, Mr. Louis-Dreyfus plans to sell Adidas shares directly on Wall Street or as American depository shares, perhaps as early as next year.
Mr. Louis-Dreyfus is a total break in style as well as substance for Adidas. A Frenchman in a company with deep German roots, he lives in Switzerland and has assembled an international team to run Adidas, including Christian Tourres, a French executive often described as his alter ego, and an Australian banker, Dean Hawkins, whom he made chief financial officer. "Diversity brings creativity," he said.
Fast talking and cigar smoking, he is an avid skier and soccer fan who once personally bought a French team, Olympique Marseille, to keep it from falling into Nike's hands; at work, he eschews collars and ties for sweatshirts and jeans. A graduate of the Harvard Business School, he is equally comfortable in English and his native French.
In 1993, a group of French banks and insurance companies was saddled with Adidas, which the maverick French financier and politician, Bernard Tapie, had acquired in 1990. Although Adidas, whose founder, Adolf Dassler, is generally considered the father of athletic footwear, had been making athletic shoes as early as the 1920's, it was on the ropes. Mr. Dassler's son and heir, Horst, died in 1989 at 51, and the family had sold out to Mr. Tapie. Management was disoriented, and Nike and Reebok were parlaying a lethal combination of glitzy sneakers made cheaply in low-wage countries and promotions with American sports superstars into dominance of a market Adidas once ruled uncontested.
Enter Mr. Louis-Dreyfus.
In 1988, he had just finished turning around IMS International, a leading United States pharmaceutical market research company, when he sold it to Dun & Bradstreet for $1.7 billion and decided to retire.
Not a bad idea for the scion of one of France's wealthiest families, the owners of giant S. A. Louis-Dreyfus & Compagnie, the traders and real estate magnates. (The family is large and far-flung; Julia Louis-Dreyfus, best known as Elaine in the comedy series "Seinfeld," is a distant relation.) Yet there was a hitch. Mr. Louis-Dreyfus was only 42, and when he sought a skiing or golfing partner, no one was around. "The problem with retirement," he said, "is that your friends are working."
So when Charles and Maurice Saatchi asked him to help right their foundering British advertising agency, Mr. Louis-Dreyfus bit. After three years, in which he cut costs, dismissed staff and bolstered profit margins, he achieved his second major turnaround.
Now he is five years into his third effort, one that he almost did not get.
In 1992, the British sporting goods group Pentland agreed to buy Adidas from Mr. Tapie, then backed out after due diligence disclosed what it called "fundamental problems."
But French banks behind Mr. Tapie had already installed Gilberte Beaux, a retired French banker, to begin the job of cleaning up Adidas for the next owner. In the United States, she lured hot-shot young executives from Nike to revive sales; she increased the advertising budget and hired the young British agency, Leagas Delaney, to design an aggressive TV and print campaign.
Some experts say that Mr. Louis-Dreyfus really only carried out a turnaround set in motion by Mrs. Beaux. "A lot of people think that Louis-Dreyfus changed things overnight," said Eugenio Di Maria, editor of Sporting Goods Intelligence Europe, an industry newsletter that is published in Paris. "But it was more a question of timing -- he came at the right time, and helped influence some strategic decisions."
Still, he executed masterfully, and the results have been substantial.
When Mr. Louis-Dreyfus replaced Mrs. Beaux in 1993, he looked over Pentland's study of Adidas, then decided that two crucial problems were easily fixable: Adidas's ad budget should be inflated substantially, and an overreliance on independent distributors should end.
"They had been losing since Horst Dassler's death," he said in Munich. "And when you're on the losing side, it's difficult to get off."
In the United States, he went on the offensive. To get toeholds in baseball and football, he signed deals with the New York Yankees and the National Football League. He raised global advertising outlays to 13 percent of Adidas sales, compared with 6 percent when he took over. He says the figure will go even higher.
And he has played off Adidas's rich history. Adolf Dassler made the running shoes Jesse Owens wore at the 1936 Berlin Olympics. So at the 1996 Olympics, Adidas plastered Atlanta with its slogan, "We Knew Then; We Know Now . . .," recalling greats like Owens and Emil Zatopek, the Czech long-distance runner and four-time Olympic gold medal winner, who also ran in Adidas shoes.
Mr. Louis-Dreyfus says his top priority now is to accelerate growth in the United States by continuing to whittle away at the market shares of Reebok and Fila. His second goal, growing out of the first, is to integrate Salomon to give Adidas economies of scale and a leg up in such trendy sports as in-line skating and snowboarding.
"I have a belief," he said, "that while my generation was into team sports, our sons with their in-line skates and snowboards are going to be into individual sports."
Many analysts say the key question now is how Nike will react. Mr. Caroti, the Nike general manager for Central Europe, says Nike plans to take on Adidas in Germany with a combination of blanket promotions and high-profile sponsorships. To go after sports that Germans favor, Nike is sponsoring Borussia Dortmund, the German soccer team that was the 1997 Champion's Cup winner, and Michael Schumacher, the race car driver.
Now it's Adidas's turn to appear unruffled. Mr. Louis-Dreyfus notes proudly, for example, that he's no Phil Knight.
"He's the Disney of sports, into the marketing of sports at the entertainment end," he said dismissively of the Nike chairman. Despite its deal with Kobe Bryant, Adidas, he added, is less centralized than Nike and, with its strong focus on soccer, the world's No. 1 growth sport, less dependent on American superstars. "We try," he said, "to be more cosmopolitan."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Economy Remains Strong, Fed Says in 'Beige Book'
The economy in all regions of the United States remains strong, despite a decline in export sales to Asia -- yet inflation seems "eerily calm," the Federal Reserve said in its "beige book" survey of regional economic conditions.
"Industrial activity is on the rise in most parts of the country," it said, and demand for labor is strong. Retail sales are strong, the Fed added, but auto sales are down. Page D4. 

Stock Market Topples Records
All major stock market indexes reached new highs, with the Dow industrials climbing 25.41 points, to 8,775.40. But Treasury securities prices fell after the "beige book" report, with the yield on the 30-year bond rising to 5.90 percent from 5.89. D7.
 
Crude Oil Rebounds 8.6 Percent
Crude oil prices rebounded 8.6 percent with the market encouraged by news that there might soon be a special meeting of big oil-producing countries to discuss cutting output. Tuesday's late price of $13.21 had been the lowest in nine years, reflecting oversupply in the world market. D7.
 
Utility Raises Bid
Western Resources, a major Midwest utility, announced that it had raised its $32-a-share bid for Kansas City Power and Light. The rise to about $34.50 could end a long drama. D4.
 
Lockheed Scrambles to Save Deal
Lockheed Martin is scrambling to salvage its proposed acquisition of Northrop Grumman, but analysts said the chances the deal might collapse appeared to be growing. D2.
 
Ian Schrager Hotels to Expand
Ian Schrager, creator of the Royalton and Paramount hotels, formed a partnership with Northstar Capital and plans to expand. B8.
 
Union Pacific Safety at Issue
Union Pacific's plans to avoid accidents like those that killed 11 people last year are being hampered by resistance from the railroad's middle managers and field supervisors, union leaders contended at a Federal safety hearing. Executives of the giant line, while stressing a commitment to safety, agreed that their programs were far from complete. D4.
 
A Move to Goldman From Lazard
Kendrick R. Wilson, one of Wall Street's best-regarded investment bankers, will be leaving Lazard Freres & Company, which was plagued by management turmoil last year, to join the financial institutions group at Goldman, Sachs as a managing director. D8.
 
Joblessness Strains French System
Although the French economy is expected to grow a healthy 3 percent this year, unemployment continues to strain the country's vaunted welfare system. A1.
 
Japanese Household Savings Fall
Japan's average household savings fell 1.3 percent, to an average of $125,769 in 1997. The drop, the first in four years, signaled that the nation's slump had spread to one of the pillars of the economy. D5.
 
Optimistic Signs in Thailand
Investment has begun flowing into Thai companies for the first time since the financial system started to crumble eight months ago, raising hopes that foreign investors are starting to acquire assets made cheap by severe currency and market losses. D5.

INTERNATIONAL A3-10
 
India's New Government May Add Nuclear Weapons
India's new Hindu nationalist Government, led by Atal Bihari Vajpayee, said that it would review the country's nuclear weapons policy and might "induct nuclear weapons" into its military arsenal. The declaration seemed likely to set off a new round of anxiety about an arms race between India and Pakistan. It also provided a striking counterpart to the main thrust of the national agenda put forth by Mr. Vajpayee. The agenda omitted virtually everything in the nationalists' program that had caused anxiety among India's Muslims and lower-caste Hindus suspicious of the upper-caste origins of Hindu nationalism. A1 

Senate Debates NATO Treaty 
The Senate held a second day of debate on admitting Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic to NATO, but only after chaotic scheduling short-circuited a debate on education. A1
 
Space Deal With China Weighed
The United States is considering allowing American satellite manufacturers to buy space-launching services from China, a senior Government official said. But China would have to create a system to stop sales of missile technology to nations like Iran. The move would waive sanctions imposed after the Tiananmen Square massacre in 1989. A20
 
Report on Religion in China
Three prominent American religious leaders recently returned from China issued a cautiously optimistic report that cited an improvement in religious freedom in China during the last 20 years, but they said the country still needed to make significant changes in order to meet acceptable international standards. A8

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk

HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DERIDES G.O.P. BUDGET PLAN AS ILL-CONCEIVED

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 18

 BODY:
President Clinton today firmly rejected the current Republican budget proposal, declaring that it "shortchanges our nation's future" by eliminating nearly all of his planned Federal programs for education, job training and child care.
Employing sharply partisan language and speaking to a cheering crowd of union members of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., Mr. Clinton set out on a collision course with the Republican-controlled Congress over taxing and spending at a time when the nation will have its first projected surplus in 30 years. 
 "If the Republican budget says no to new teachers and smaller classes, no to modernizing our schools, no to investing in higher education for our children, the American people should say no to that budget," Mr. Clinton declared to whoops and cheers from a largely blue-collar audience here.
He added: "I need your help. This ought not to be a partisan political issue."
Hours later, the Senate Budget Committee approved the Republican tax and spending plan on a party-line 12-to-10 vote, after turning aside efforts by Democrats to restore Mr. Clinton's initiatives. If the Republican plan is approved on the Senate floor, it will serve as the blueprint for the bills authorizing spending programs and tax cuts.
With the entire House and a third of the Senate up for election this year, and Democrats harboring hopes of regaining control of the House, both parties appear eager to turn their tax and spending plans into campaign issues. Democrats believe their spending plans will be popular with middle-class families, while Republicans are happy to run as guardians of the nation's new-found fiscal health.
In attacking the Republicans' proposal one day after it was introduced in the Senate, the President moved quickly to exploit what White House advisers in Washington described as a political misstep by Republicans.
"If the Republicans want to have a fight about education, we stand ready to defend our schools, our parents and our children," said Rahm Emanuel, one of the senior advisers.
It was clear this evening that this was a welcome fight, with the White House searching for distractions from the independent counsel's investigation into Mr. Clinton's relationship with a White House intern. Mr. Emanuel suggested, with evident enthusiasm, that the budget dispute might well last the entire year.
The President's remarks came today in the course of a relatively quick trip out of Washington, to attend a meeting of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. executive council. He seemed buoyed by the tumultuous reception he received from the moment he walked into the Carpenters Joint Apprenticeship Training Center at the outskirts of this city.
"Every now and then, you just got to get out here in the country," Mr. Clinton said, his voice husky, draping a hand over the front of the Presidential lectern. "It helps a President to remember why he ran, what he's trying to do, and for whom he is really working."
But even outside Washington in friendly territory, there were reminders of the events back home. An effort by an audience member to signal support for Mr. Clinton turned confusing when the President apparently assumed he was being badgered about Monica S. Lewinsky, the White House intern at the center of the current investigation.
"To hell with Monica!" the supporter yelled from the back of the audience.
"Shut up!" someone else shouted, and the President grinned broadly.
"Couldn't have said it better myself," Mr. Clinton said to laughter. "You ought to run for office!"
An aide later said Mr. Clinton was apparently not wearing his hearing aid, and thus misheard the shout.
For most of his 28 minutes on stage, the President gave an enthusiastic accounting of the state of the nation, taking credit for improvements in employment, inflation, crime and the economy. He then noted that the central budget dispute is how to spend a surplus that is now being projected.
"You don't have to be a carpenter to know that you don't fix the roof when it's raining," he said. "You fix the roof when the sun is shining. The sun is shining on America."
"I'm telling you: we've got the money, it's time to invest in the future of our country," he said.
Mr. Clinton scored the Republicans for opposing his call to hire 100,000 teachers to reduce class size to 18 students for kindergarten through second grade. He restated his initiatives, largely rejected by Republicans, to spend money on rebuilding dilapidated school buildings, provide grants and low-interest loans for college, and to keep schools open so students have a place to stay until their parents finish work.
Gene Sperling, head of the President's National Economic Council, said Mr. Clinton was proposing $7.5 billion in child care spending over five years, $7.3 billion over five years to reduce class size and $5 billion for school construction.
The Senate Republican plan calls for a total of $1.73 trillion in Federal spending next year, an increase of 3.6 percent over this year. It allows room for $30 billion in tax cuts over five years, far less than many Republicans want.
House Republicans will take up their budget proposal next month, and are considering bigger tax cuts and deeper reductions in domestic spending than envisioned by the Senate plan.
Over Democratic opposition in Congress today, the Senate Budget Committee left in place the proposal by its chairman, Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, that any proceeds from legislation imposing a settlement on the tobacco industry over the health damage from smoking be earmarked solely to shore up Medicare, the health insurance system for the elderly. Both parties are working on legislation that could yield tens of billions of dollars in coming years through taxes or fees on sales of cigarettes, but there is no assurance a bill can be passed this year.
"The President is way premature in his comments," Mr. Domenici said. "We can't give the President $124 billion and not get a nickel for Medicare. We're not going to just bow to him."
Democrats had argued throughout the day that any money from the tobacco deal should go to anti-smoking programs, health insurance plans for children and Mr. Clinton's other spending initiatives. And they said that by apportioning any tobacco money exclusively to Medicare, the Republican plan would end any chance of assembling broad bipartisan support for a tobacco bill.
Republicans said that if Mr. Clinton was going to attack them over his domestic initiatives, they would strike back by suggesting that Democrats were not doing enough to address the problems Medicare would encounter as the population ages. For years, Democrats used much the same strategy with great success against Republicans, accusing them of supporting cuts in one of the nation's most popular entitlement programs.
Mr. Domenici said the White House was "turning its back on Medicare and reneging on its commitment to America's seniors."
He said that without relying on any tobacco money his plan included an expansion of anti-smoking programs, increased funding for child care and a sharp rise in spending for the National Institutes of Health. And he said a tobacco deal should not become a new pool of money for Democrats to use to increase the size of the Federal Government.
"We shouldn't be running around trying to invent things to spend money on from this giant piggy bank," Mr. Domenici said.

HEADLINE: Slain Shop Owner's Generosity Is Remembered

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

 BODY:
During James Lee's eight years as the owner of a gift shop on St. Marks Place, his tireless work habits and outgoing demeanor made him a popular fixture in the East Village trinket market.
While running a business that catered largely to tourists, Mr. Lee went out of his way to help the neighborhood's less fortunate residents, frequently buying coffee and lunch for the homeless and giving his old clothing to the needy. 
 But Mr. Lee, 61, had little tolerance for shoplifters, his employees said, and on Monday when he tried to stop two teen-agers he apparently thought were stealing a wool baseball cap, he was felled by a punch from one of them and suffered fatal head injuries when he collapsed on the sidewalk.
"I heard the sound of the punch, a loud punch," said Salahuddin Ahammed, 37, who has worked at the shop for four years. "Right away he can't talk. I held his head. I tried to hold his head together. There was lots of blood."
Mr. Lee was taken to Bellevue Hospital, where he later died of head injuries, said Detective Robert Samuel, a police spokesman.
A police officer from the Ninth Precinct captured two suspects a block away.
One, Sean Lynch, 17, of the Bronx, was charged with murder and robbery. The second suspect was detained, then released for lack of evidence, Detective Samuel said.
A police investigator who spoke on condition of anonymity said that Mr. Lynch had prior arrests on charges of defacing property with graffiti and possessing stolen property.
Mr. Lynch was dumbfounded to learn that Mr. Lee had died, the investigator said. "He thought we were kidding," the investigator said.
Police officials declined to discuss the contents of Mr. Lynch's videotaped statement.
The hat had the insignia of the Grays, a baseball team in the now-defunct Negro leagues of the 1940's, said Richard Torres, 34, who has worked at the store since 1992.
"It's very hot these days," Mr. Torres said. "Very popular."
Employees described Mr. Lee as the kind of boss who always asked how their wives and children were doing, and even occasionally lent money to workers in a financial crunch. Mr. Lee, a native of Korea who moved to New York more than 20 years ago, lived on 34th Street with his wife. He had four children, Mr. Torres said, including a son in dental school.
His employees said he was trying to earn enough money to pay for his children's education, and hoped to retire in five years.
So he spent most of his waking hours hawking hats, T-shirts, bags, jewelry and sunglasses at the First Rich Gift Shop on St. Marks near Third Avenue.
"If they had eight days in a week, he'd work eight days," Mr. Torres said.
"He kept it open every day, even on Christmas, to make money to take care of his family. A hard-working man, never took a day off."

HEADLINE: When Citizenship Is Leadership;
Our Celebrity President

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Do President Clinton's high approval ratings primarily reflect American economic satisfaction, policy savvy or emotional maturity? Perhaps none of the above.
As Richard Norton Smith (Op-Ed, March 12) suggests, there is a less flattering reason.
Until they tire of a celebrity's act, Americans hold him to extremely low moral standards. So far, Mr. Clinton has traded successfully on his celebrity status. 
Respect for the office of the Presidency has eroded even as celebrity Presidents have become more adept at weathering scandals. Whether this lost authority can be recaptured in a true national crisis is a question no one should be too eager to test.
 
LEIF WELLINGTON HAASE
Greenwich, Conn., March 17, 1998

HEADLINE: Freedom for Schools

To the Editor:
Sue Halpern's fantasy about sending her daughter to a "well-financed, energetic, successful local public school" like those in Scarsdale (Op-Ed, March 13) got me thinking.
As a teacher in the Bronx public schools for 19 years, I have seen many attempts to democratize education, including the current notion that equal opportunity for students can be gained by raising the standards in our public schools.
