SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 33; Column 3; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 1333 words

HEADLINE: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;
Capturing the City At a Vanishing Point

BYLINE: By VICKI GOLDBERG 

 BODY:
It is the nature of cities to change and the nature of city dwellers to regret the sacrifices made along the way, even in the name of progress. Our cities are extensions of ourselves, and their streets open up to memory like family albums of all the lives lived in them. The past of city and self tends to seem ever more important and precious as time and memory threaten to bury it.
In the 19th century, as cities swelled and were reconfigured, photography was called on to record the present before it became the past, and then to point out where things were going so the future would be able to contemplate its past as well. When Baron Haussmann rebuilt Paris in the 1850's and 1860's, he hired Charles Marville to document what was being destroyed as well as what was being built so that both the city's history and his own achievement would be clear. 
 Late in the century, the Society for Photographing Relics of Old London commissioned several photographers to depict buildings that expansion would soon overrun. At the beginning of this century, Eugene Atget, making documents for artists, photographed a Paris he thought would disappear under the impact of modern life. In the 1930's, Berenice Abbott, who had saved Atget's archive after his death in 1927, photographed old New York, which she suspected was very fragile, as well as the strong new city. Her book "Changing New York," published in 1939, almost instantly became a famous document.
The Museum of the City of New York, which helped sponsor Abbott's project and owns a set of her exhibition prints, her negatives and her research files, currently has on view 126 vintage photographs, plus reproductions of some variants and a few of her discards, in a show called "Berenice Abbott's Changing New York, 1935-1939."
Some of these photographs are little known; the 1939 book had fewer images. A book by the show's curator, Bonnie Yochelson, "Berenice Abbott: Changing New York, the Complete W.P.A. Project" (The New Press/Museum of the City of New York), reproduces all 305 images from Abbott's original undertaking.
New York transforms itself too fast for people to keep their bearings or hold on to their history in it -- I once told a child to meet me at a restaurant and temporarily lost him because he had left when all he found there was an excavation. Abbott did a real service by catching the place in transition.
A strong photographer, she was especially adept in the narrow confines of Wall Street and among the ethnic stores and antique details of Greenwich Village, where she lived. Her images will fascinate anyone who remembers the El, or knew some avenue before it became a thoroughfare, or could not imagine horse-drawn milk trucks on these streets. One of the show's real virtues is that the labels note what has become of this building and that one. Also on view is a charming nine-minute video by Douglas Levere of Abbott's images and Levere's contemporary rephotographs of the exact same scenes from the exact same positions she once stood in.
Abbott's photographs add up to a cool record of a hot city. She is measured, dispassionate, "objective." She avoids the Depression and its effects. The dynamic of her city lies not in human relations to one another or to the surroundings but in the architecture and in occasional contrasts between tenements and commercial giants, quirky old buildings and muscular new ones, ethnic neighborhoods and imperial realms of business. She often looked at the city from a distance above it, though not at too steep an angle, as she was afraid of heights. What with New York's ambitious skyline, some worm's-eye, bird's-eye and tilted-building views, and the naked evidence of engineering, the city's energy and jazz come through almost despite her deliberate pace and attraction to emptiness.
I rather miss a sense of electricity at street level. There are few reminders that people live, work and hurry in and between the stone behemoths that jostle the sky. Abbott worked with a large, heavy 8 by 10 camera and a large, heavy tripod, which she sometimes had to set up in the middle of the street. The equipment was too slow to catch movement readily. She wanted a fast, hand-held camera but received one only in 1938, shortly before the money for her project ran out.
She had gone to Paris as a sculptor in 1921, worked as Man Ray's darkroom assistant when he wanted someone who knew nothing about photography, and become a superb portrait photographer on her own. She met Atget and after his death arranged for the publication of a book of his work and reprinted some of his negatives. (Ultimately she sold her Atget Collection to the Museum of Modern Art in New York.) When she returned to New York in 1929 and was seized with a passion to photograph the city, Atget was clearly in her eye and mind. His Paris was entering one modern world and her New York another, but their different personalities and goals were as crucial to their styles as the times they lived in.
Atget had even fewer people in his pictures (except for the peddlers he had pose for him), having accosted Paris at dawn before it moved too fast for his poky camera. Yet the poetic melancholy of his scenes implies an absence, implies that someone has just left or may soon appear. Abbott's city is largely self-sufficient, a great machine that runs on commercial energy and nourishes itself on the more old-fashioned, invisible mechanics of its neighborhoods. Atget wrote poetry in his images; Abbott wrote impersonal, reportorial prose, sometimes vigorously, sometimes not. Her photographs do not imply so much as declare.
She borrowed from Atget an occasional lone, lorn figure or two posing in a doorway, looking out a window at the photographer, tiredly buying a movie ticket. They tend to be as unsettled as the times, like the barber and his assistant waiting for customers outside his shop. Now and then, mostly when she got the small camera, she took the pulse of the city via the movement of pedestrians, and would have taken more had she had the camera sooner.
Interested as she was in shops -- food shops, cheese stores, bakeries, hardware stores, pawn shops, antiques shops -- she took not one picture of a clothing store, not even a surrogate human being like the mannequins Atget portrayed so tellingly and often. She photographed shop fronts as often as Atget did but never with his interest in complex reflections, though the reflections in glass windows play an enormous role in the shifting nature of modern city experience.
A document at the level of Abbott's work seeks a precarious balance of art and information. She knew a great deal about contemporary art and liked a long lens that flattened the field and compressed distances or a wide angle lens that distorted perspective. But she did not aim for the stark Cubism and Expressionist versions of Mondrian that gripped the urban art photographers of the time. Mostly she kept her modernism in check, seeking clarity above all. In fact, she was singularly self-effacing, never insisting on a distinctive signature style.
These photographs might never have existed if Abbott's work had not been financed through a Government agency. Sponsored by the museum, she was employed by the Federal Art Project of the Works Progress Administration, a relatively small organization that helped unemployed artists during the Depression and attempted to prove that art could benefit the community. Conservatives, fearful or contemptuous of left-wing artists, shrilly criticized the Federal Art Project; by 1939, a hostile Congress had gutted the agency, and Abbott was laid off. (The organization was disbanded in 1943.) Cities change, but certain political issues outlast brick and stone.
"Berenice Abbott's Changing New York, 1935-1939" is at the Museum of the City of New York, 1220 Fifth Avenue, at 103d Street, through June 21. It will travel to the National Museum of Women in the Arts in Washington.

HEADLINE: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Technology and Design;
G.M. Speeds Up Car Development

BYLINE: By NOELLE KNOX 

 BODY:
IN a feat of competitive catch-up, the General Motors Corporation says it has cut the the time it takes to design and build new cars and trucks by six months. Further, it promises another six-month improvement by the end of this year, matching its domestic competitors.
G.M. executives have confirmed that the company moved a new vehicle concept from the design studio to the factory floor in just 30 months, beating its previous record of 36 months. And G.M. says it will soon match its smaller American rivals, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation, with a 24-month development cycle.
 
 Every auto company is trying to speed up the development process to respond faster to changes in consumer tastes and demand. For G.M., which has long been the laggard in product development, as well as the most inefficient auto producer, the quicker cycle demonstrates that the company's global restructuring and investments in new technology are starting to pay off. The company would not disclose the development times for any specific vehicles.
"We are not stopping at 24 months," said William G. Poulos, a director of G.M.'s vehicle development process center in Detroit. "We will continue to look for ways to take time out" of product development.
The first G.M. cars built for the United States market on the 30-month cycle will be introduced next year, Mr. Poulos said. Although he would not identify the models, the company is expected to bring out in late 1999 an all-new Pontiac Bonneville and Buick LeSabre, as well as a new Chevrolet Impala (which replaces the Lumina) and Monte Carlo, according to J. D. Power & Associates, an automotive consulting firm.
While G.M. is making progress, the company remains far behind Japanese competitors. The Toyota Motor Corporation, for example, designed and started building the new Lexus RX 300 sport utility vehicle, which went on sale two weeks ago, in just 18 months. And Toyota's chairman has set a new-product goal of just 14 months.
Some analysts are also skeptical that G.M. can deliver on its promises.
"It doesn't matter if your product cycle is that fast, if you can't make a decision about what to build," said Michael L. Schmall, managing director of Planning Edge, a consulting firm in Troy, Mich. "They are just so late to the market. The company keeps telling us how wonderful everything is, and their market share keeps going down."
 Nearly everyone in the industry agrees that faster development times provide a critical advantage. The speedup is good news for consumers, who won't have to wait the traditional four or five years for a new car or truck design. For the companies, the results are mixed. Shaving time off the development cycle saves money, but big profits from a hot-selling model can soon be siphoned away by a quick competitor that rushes out a similar product. As a result, auto makers are trying harder to shield future products from rivals' spying eyes.
The chairman of G.M., John F. Smith Jr., told Wall Street analysts this month that the company may have blundered by showing a prototype of a European-market mini-van, the Opel Zefira, at the Frankfurt Auto Show in September, a year before the van was to go into production.
In a recent meeting with Wall Street analysts, Mr. Smith said his "concern was that they've given the competition, including Ford and others, a lot of lead time," said Joseph S. Phillippi, an auto stock analyst for Lehman Brothers. Mr. Smith conceded that if G.M.'s competitors scrambled, "We will only have six to nine months on the market before they answer our product."
For G.M. and most other auto makers, the key to saving time has been a switch to computer-aided design and holographic models from paper-and-ink drawings and clay models. Now, companies can make more design changes, and they can make them faster. Computer designs are also more precise than hand-crafted models. A more accurate and complete design means fewer costly, last-minute changes to equipment in production plants.
"You can actually deliver a higher-quality, lower-cost product with a more effective development process," Mr. Poulos said. He estimated that reducing the cycle to 30 months shaved about 12 percent off the cost of developing a new vehicle, which translates into tens of millions of dollars.
G.M. has also tried to speed the process by harmonizing designs among subsidiaries in different countries. For example, it plans to introduce small cars based on a single platform around the world starting in 2000, analysts say.
"Shortening the development cycle is important because there is a lot more input from other organizations in other regions," said Michael Robinet, managing director of CSM Forecasting, an auto-industry consulting firm in Southfield, Mich.
G.M. has also eliminated layers of management that delay decisions by consolidating divisions and putting one person, known as a vehicle line executive, in charge of taking a new design to the factory floor. "It's getting better," said Mr. Phillippi of Lehman Brothers. But there is "still too much of a bureaucratic labyrinth products have to wind their way through."

SECTION: Section A; Page 4; Column 3; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 893 words

HEADLINE: Budapest Journal;
Hungarian Fingerprints All Over the 20th Century

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: BUDAPEST

 BODY:
He was a man of brilliant and diverse intellectual energy who discovered the nuclear chain reaction, went on to help develop the atom bomb and then tirelessly campaigned against it.
He soaked in the bath three hours a day, thinking up incredible inventions, needled his scientific colleagues with puckish humor and refused to flush the toilet in his room at the University of Chicago in the 1940's, insisting that it was "maid's work." 
 So it was with ambivalent pride and a sense of lost glory that Hungary celebrated the centenary of Leo Szilard, who died in 1964. Szilard (pronounced SIH-lahrd) was perhaps the most quixotic of the renowned physicists and mathematicians who were born and educated here but who fled, often, like Szilard, under the shadow of anti-Semitism, to the United States.
Hungarian scientists have had a deep impact on the 20th century. John von Neumann made fundamental contributions to quantum theory as well as the development of the atomic bomb and the high-speed electronic computer. Albert von Szent-Gyorgyi was credited with first isolating vitamin C. For a country of its population (10 million), Hungary has produced an immoderate number of Nobel Prize winners. Hungarians who became American citizens, including Szilard, Eugene Wigner and Edward Teller, played a major part in the Manhattan Project in World War II.
But few in this pantheon of Martians -- a nickname spun from the scientists' superhuman intelligence and their unearthly Hungarian language -- so keenly felt that the pursuit of science also carried political and personal responsibilities.
"The Hungarians have plenty of first-rate scientists and Nobel Laureates to celebrate," said Szilard's American biographer, William Lanouette, who was among those at the ceremonies in February. "Yet Szilard alone personifies the moral and ethical responsibilities of science. He had the drive to foresee the social and political consequences of discovery."
Mr. Lanouette records in his book "Genius in the Shadows" how Szilard, at the start of the war, drafted the letter signed by Albert Einstein that urged President Roosevelt to speed up work on the nuclear bomb before the Germans developed it; after the war he spent much of his time trying to ease the arms race that he helped create.
With a combination of banter and logic, Szilard persuaded Nikita S. Khrushchev, the Soviet leader, that a hot line between the Kremlin and the White House was a good idea. During the Eisenhower and Kennedy years, he flooded the State Department with nuclear disarmament programs that were mostly rebuffed.
A tubby figure who loved to eat fatty Hungarian delicacies, Szilard was often thought of as maddeningly eccentric. Sometimes this eccentricity produced breathtaking flights of fancy: He came up with the idea of electrifying barbers' chairs so that a man's hair would stand on end, allowing the barber to do a fast mowing job.
For Hungarian intellectuals who remained in Hungary, Szilard and his emigre colleagues represent a bittersweet phenomenon. On the one hand, there is pride that Hungary has produced so many important minds. Yet there is also sadness that so many fled -- and that the new generation of best brains continues to leave.
Now, instead of being enticed by the ferment in German and American universities as their elders were between the two world wars, young Hungarian scientists are wooed abroad by Western companies.
"Today the most gifted Hungarians leave the country while they are graduate students," said Gabor Pallo, the deputy director of the philosophy institute at the Hungarian Academy of Sciences.
After more than 40 years of Communism and a rough transition to a market economy, Hungary lacked the financial resources to keep them.
In the popular mythology, this crew of geniuses are shadowy figures in Hungary. For most of the cold war, they were considered soldiers in the enemy camp and banned in the media and school texts. Then in the early 1980's, when the Hungarian leader Janos Kadar was eager to improve his nation's profile in the West and wanted to pump up sagging intellectual morale at home, the emigre scientists were dusted off.
Mr. Pallo said that by 1983, he was allowed to publish some of his research on the scientists and in 1985 he was asked to give a lecture at the prestigious Academy of Sciences on Hungarian-born Nobel Prize winners. Some of the scientists came back in their old age for short visits before the collapse of Communism; the fiercely anti-Communist Mr. Teller waited until after 1989.
But like Andrew Grove, who as a young science student fled Hungary after the failed 1956 uprising and is now chairman and chief executive of the computer giant Intel, Szilard showed little interest in Hungary, Mr. Pallo said.
Even so, Szilard is now buried here. At least, part of him.
Szilard's ashes, kept in a California crematory after his death, were reburied in a cemetery during the centenary ceremonies. According to his family's wishes, half of his ashes were sent to Budapest. The other half were dispatched to upstate New York, where his wife is buried.
This is not quite what Szilard had in mind. Before he died in La Jolla, Calif., he said he wanted his ashes tied to a helium balloon and sent into the sky. People, he said, should look up rather than down.

HEADLINE: Indonesia-I.M.F. Talks Show Flexibility on Ending Impasse

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 19

 BODY:
Indonesian officials began meetings today with officials of the International Monetary Fund, with both sides offering signals of flexibility on the deadlock that has caused a halt in disbursements of international aid.
The officials sat down in five working groups to tackle separate aspects of the economic crisis, including Indonesia's huge burden of corporate debt, a problem the I.M.F. had not previously addressed. 
 "We talked about the debt, but we have no concrete proposals yet," Hubert Neiss, the chief I.M.F. delegate, said today.
Indonesia is seeking an easing of requirements that it remove subsidies for fuel and basic food items, and I.M.F. officials have said they might agree to this, given the hardship and social unrest that could result from further price increases.
The increases have spurred a series of anti-Government protests on university campuses in recent weeks. Today the police used tear gas, clubs and high-pressure water hoses to subdue thousands of stone-throwing student protesters at Lampung University in Bandarlampung on Sumatra. At least 60 people were detained.
Students also confronted the police at Airlangga University in Surabaya, 370 miles east of Jakarta. And several thousand students staged peaceful anti-Government rallies today on at least three campuses in Jakarta and at a university in the city of Bandung, 75 miles east of the capital.
In addition to their opposition over the removal of subsidies, Indonesian officials have also complained about requirements that they disband cartels and monopolies, an issue on which the fund has voiced less flexibility.
For its part, Indonesia is seeking a quick way to strengthen the value of its currency, the rupiah. It is so weak now that corporations are unable to pay off more than $65 billion in foreign debt, in effect stalling the economy.
Mr. Neiss, who is the Asia-Pacific director of the I.M.F., indicated that a decision might not come before mid-April on whether the fund would release a second $3 billion disbursement from its $40 billion economic assistance package.
That disbursement was withheld last week because Indonesia has been slow to carry out economic reforms and also because its leadership was preoccupied with the re-election of President Suharto a week ago.
Mr. Suharto, 76, announced a new Cabinet on Saturday, and officials of the I.M.F. began arriving immediately for talks, along with envoys from the United States, Germany and Japan.
On his arrival Wednesday, Mr. Neiss said the fund's executive board in Washington would discuss the pending disbursement two weeks after he had completed his visit here. He said he would stay in Indonesia "as long as necessary" to reach an agreement.
Indonesian officials repeated their commitment to the reforms agreed to by Mr. Suharto in January, although outside analysts say they have yet to demonstrate that commitment in action.
The officials also repeated the priority they set on strengthening the value of the rupiah, but in recent days they have avoided mention of the creation of a currency board, which the I.M.F. strongly opposes.
"We are in the process of formulating a policy which will stabilize the rupiah exchange rate," said Fuad Bawazier, the new Finance Minister. "We cannot wait until the price of basic commodities rises again." He spoke after a meeting Wednesday with David Lipton, an official of the Treasury Department who is the latest in a series of American envoys to visit Jakarta.
Indonesian officials said today's working group discussed various possible measures to strengthen the rupiah or at a minimum to subsidize a stronger exchange rate for the import of medicine and staple foods.
On a visit to Tokyo today, Vice President B. J. Habibie was quoted as saying that Indonesia hoped to put into effect all 50 points of the January agreement but that the greatest difficulty would be in removing the price supports that subsidize basic commodities.
The first two working groups that began meeting today will focus on monetary policy and banking reform, Mr. Neiss said. The third will analyze the state budget and seek to find ways to pay for continued price supports. Fourth, he said, is the sensitive issue of structural reforms. The fifth group will seek to find ways to deal with Indonesia's private debt burden.

HEADLINE: A Wildcatter On the Tame Side;
Replacing Roughnecks With Computers

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: HOUSTON

 BODY:
Designed for the world's hungriest, damn-the-expense devourers of data, the Auspex NS7000 computer server, costing more than $1 million, can store the equivalent of a million 400-page novels for instant access. The first one in this area went to NASA in 1995 for guiding space shuttles into the heavens. The next year, another was installed, at the Zilkha Energy Company, for exploring under the Gulf of Mexico, miles into the earth's crust.
For Zilkha, such bets have paid off, proving that technology is taking the wildness out of wildcatting. Its success in finding oil and natural gas on the gulf's already intensively drilled continental shelf was certified beyond a doubt in January. Zilkha, just 12 years old, was sold to Sonat Energy for $1 billion. 
 Not bad for a company with just 65 employees, most of them on a single floor of a downtown building here. The casual, college-dorm camaraderie, the open setting with no private offices and the huge monitors on most desks are more typical of a software start-up. Geologists, concentrating so intently that they seem about to step inside those monitors, talk of entering the zone.
It's a petroleum company, all right, but without roughnecks, rigs or corporate bureaucrats. It is, in other words, a virtual energy company.
Zilkha Energy's virtual invisibility suited the family that ran it. The company has never issued a press release, and its owners, father and son, have said nothing about it publicly until now. "People didn't know how real we were," Michael Zilkha, the son, said in an interview.
He persuaded his father, Selim, to let the company make a flickering appearance in cyberspace by starting one of the industry's first Web sites. But nowhere at that site are the owners' names mentioned.
For the Zilkhas, the company's triumph is proof of the returns possible from bringing a new approach to what seems like a mature business. Buying huge volumes of digitized data covering most of the gulf's shelf, they hired the best geologists they could find and gave them the latest computerized tools for turning all that data into drilling strikes.
While many competitors, large and small, have taken similar steps, Zilkha's success stands out in speed and scale. "It's dawning on people that the high value added is information technology, to locate hydrocarbons 10,000 feet below the surface of the earth," said Bill White, a former Deputy Secretary of Energy. Because Zilkha recognized this, he said, "They're making more money than anyone else in the business."
Drilling success rates are stable or rising even as companies explore in places they would not have risked a few years ago. They are finding new oil and gas reservoirs in areas they thought were uneconomical or tapped out, like the North Sea, East Texas and the Gulf of Mexico.
This technological progress has created a new balance of economic power. After years of decline, oil production by non-OPEC nations began rising in 1995. Instead of cringing at OPEC threats, the rest of the world can now impose its own embargo, on Iraqi oil. Oil prices, even before adjusting for inflation, have fallen to the lowest levels in almost a decade, while natural gas prices have been stronger.
To others in the industry, the Zilkhas' success is all the more surprising because they are outsiders, Iraqis whose fortune has its origins in banking, retailing and even rock music. Khedoury Zilkha, Selim's father, opened a one-room bank in Baghdad in 1899, in the days when reaching Istanbul to do business first required a monthlong caravan to Aleppo, Syria.
In 1927, a month after Selim was born, the Zilkhas, with the business expanding, went first to Lebanon, then Egypt, then, in 1941, to New York.
"Baghdad Banker Reaches Wall Street," read the headline in The New York Times on April 17, 1955. To manage his operations, Khedoury Zilkha, by then known as the Rothschild of the Middle East, deployed his four sons around the world, with Selim drawing Paris, then London.
After his father died in 1956, Selim decided banking was not for him. He founded the Mothercare retailing chain, offering everything for mother and child. Catching on to the value of technology, he bought an I.B.M. 440 mainframe to manage his inventory.
In 1983, after selling that chain, he paid $28 million for 44 percent of a company called Towner Petroleum.
"What attracted me was, I was very ignorant," Selim Zilkha said. At age 70, he can afford to joke about himself, with an accent and a measured delivery that suggest his urbane origins. "I didn't know what a depleting asset was, for one thing," he said. "Because I've been in retailing, and in retailing you don't have a depleting asset. You have a good store, and if you do your job right it becomes a more valuable store."
In 1984, after the company had taken a detour into bankruptcy, Selim Zilkha paid $11 million more to own it all.
He renamed the company and turned it from an investor to an explorer and producer in its own right, hiring executives who, given the collapse of oil prices, were often readily available. He sent in Michael, now 43, first as a trainee, eventually as second-in-command. Selim Zilkha owned 62 percent of the company, his son the rest.
Michael, with his father's slight build and heavy, eloquent eyebrows, bobs his head with such animation as he talks that he seems about to get up and dance. Raised in London, he took his Oxford degree to the American rock business.
His ZE Records and its zesty roster of bands like Kid Creole and the Coconuts caught the industry's attention. Thomas D. Mottola, president of Sony Music Entertainment, calls him "a talented visionary," adding, "It comes as no surprise to me that he's been a success in other fields."
But Michael Zilkha did not see the record business as a lifetime occupation. "I didn't want to be twice as old as my groups," he said.
In the energy business, the Zilkhas' challenge was finding a niche, even as that business was heading into a depression. The opportunities they discovered began just an hour's drive south of Houston, in the Gulf of Mexico -- by then known as the Dead Sea. Major oil companies concentrated on drilling in foreign countries, with a few exploring the deep water of the gulf. They had all but abandoned a continental shelf extending an average of about 150 miles from shore.
Federal leases and geological data had become exceptionally cheap. By the early 1990's, said John B. Holmes Jr., an Exxon veteran hired as Zilkha's president, "The economics for exploration were the best I had seen in my career."
Zilkha concentrated on buying up enough 3-D seismic data to cover almost the entire shelf, from the barrier islands of South Texas past Louisiana, Mississippi and Alabama to the Florida panhandle. To generate the data, ships bounce sound signals off underground formations. Computers translate the responses.
Other companies first decided roughly where to drill, then bought patches of data for pinpointing. Zilkha offered companies that collect the data a deal: sell us your every bit, byte and number, but at wholesale. Zilkha could then scan for the best prospects, and either gain leases on the cheap or strike exploration agreements with other leaseholders.
The result, from 1992 through September of last year, was a 66 percent success rate on 79 wells, more than double the industry's average. Through the end of 1996, production grew at a 68 percent annual rate.
It remained a risky business, however. Zilkha's drilling program had a 90 percent success rate in the first nine months of 1996, but only 50 percent in the corresponding period last year. But it's a strong enough record overall for Selim Zilkha to boast of making a venture that often seems as unpredictable as movie making into something far more stable. "We developed a factory for generating prospects," he said.
In recent years, as others caught on to the gulf's potential, Zilkha has stayed ahead with technology investments that reached $5 million last year, or about $75,000 per employee -- plus more than $35 million for data. Upgrading its Auspex server and adding a second unit, Zilkha can now store nearly three times as much data as two years ago.
When new seismic results become available, usually to several buyers at once, Zilkha can often analyze them quickly enough to capture the choicest opportunities. And while petroleum companies tend to seek partners to share exploration risks, Selim Zilkha, confident in his company's prowess, never tires of saying, "If it's worth drilling, drill it all."
The financial rewards, besides the billion-dollar sale price, have been more typical of technology ventures, too. With pay tied to performance, even for receptionists, about 10 of the 65 employees each made more than $500,000 last year. In the merger, a long-term executive compensation plan rewarded the top four officers with a total of $73.7 million.
Among them was Joseph J. Romano, the chief financial officer. Whenever anyone asked how to pay the huge technology and exploration expenses, Selim Zilkha's stock answer was, "That's Joe's problem." One solution was a pioneering agreement with Enron to sell natural gas still in the ground at fixed prices.
What about going public? Not a chance. "I didn't want pimply-faced analysts to come and tell me what to do," Selim Zilkha said.
But beginning last July the Zilkhas had investment bankers shop their company around. Selim Zilkha's explanation for selling Mothercare -- "I love the journey; I don't like the arrival" -- apparently went for his energy company as well. Ronald L. Kuehn Jr., Sonat's chief executive, adds that developing Zilkha's prospects was taking more capital than Zilkha by itself could command.
Though the Zilkhas wanted cash, Mr. Kuehn flew from his Birmingham, Ala., headquarters to argue that they were better off with his stock. He cited Sonat's plans to rise from ninth to third among the nation's independent petroleum companies, and its willingness to retain or promote Zilkha Energy's managers. "They liked the story," Mr. Kuehn said later. "They liked the price, too."
Judging only by Zilkha's petroleum reserves, Mr. Kuehn says, his $1 billion expense, not counting the assumption of $280 million in debt, was more than double the fair price. But those reserves are only a third of the value, he said recently at what is now the Sonat GOM (for Gulf of Mexico) office. The vast, though unproven, prospects on Zilkha's leases are worth another third, he says, with Zilkha's management and technical abilities making up the rest.
In practice, it's not so clear who's taking over whom. Brad Juneau, Zilkha's exploration chief, is taking command of Sonat's exploration. The Zilkhas, Sonat's largest shareholders at 21 percent, each have a seat on the board.
How to finance Sonat GOM's further ambitions? "That's Ron's problem," they said in laughing unison.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Prices Mixed as Economic Signals Remain Unclear

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, after several economic reports provided no clear signals for investors.
The price of the 30-year bond was up 6/32, to 103 9/32. And the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 5.89 percent, from 5.90 percent the previous day. 
 Among the economic reports yesterday, the Government said that the United States trade deficit in January rose more than expected, amid hints that the difficulties in Asia are beginning to play a role in widening the United States trade imbalance.
But Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said seasonal adjustment problems also seemed to contribute to the increase, and he said it was still not possible to definitively separate out the Asian impact from other forces.
Also yesterday, the Government said that the Consumer Price Index rose by one-tenth of 1 percent in February, in line with expectations. The year-over-year increase was only 1.4 percent, the lowest level in more than a decade. That might have been expected to encourage bond investors, but some were apparently alarmed by a gain of three-tenths of 1 percent in the so-called core index, which eliminates the volatile food and energy prices.
In another report, the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia said its regional business survey showed that the demand for manufactured goods remained strong in the mid-Atlantic region while inflation had not accelerated. The index rose to 16.1 points in March from a 12.8 reading in February.
Mr. Fine said yesterday's reports suggested that interest rates would remain steady for some time. "Taken as a whole, there is nothing in today's data, or for that matter the entire recent gamut of economic statistics, that would suggest any change in Fed policy anytime soon," he said.
"Indeed, the Federal Open Market Committee is very likely to keep monetary policy unchanged and maintain its neutral stance at its meeting on March 31. Futhermore, this could well be the case for quite some time."
After the recent gains in bond prices, some investors apparently saw yesterday as an opportunity to take profits. Others apparently sold securities short, or sold borrowed shares, expecting to profit from a drop in prices.
Next week the Treasury will be adding supply pressures by auctioning $25 billion of new two-year and five-year notes Tuesday and Wednesday, so it is likely dealers will be trying to make yields as attractive as they can -- by lowering prices -- to insure decent demand.
In when-issued trading ahead of next week's Treasury note auctions, the new two-year issue was offered at a price to yield 5.47 percent, just slightly higher than the previous day, while the five-year note, also up slightly, was offered at a price to yield 5.53 percent.
In corporate debt, despite a surge in new issues because of low interest rates, the market remains solid.

HEADLINE: New York Taxes Poor Whom U.S. and State Exempt

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
In a discrepancy affecting almost 100,000 poor New York families, the city is assessing income tax on people whose incomes are low enough to exempt them from Federal and state taxes, according to a study by the city's Independent Budget Office.
The study, conducted by the city-financed independent watchdog group at the request of the Public Advocate, Mark Green, concluded that the city's tax system was contributing to the broad gap in incomes between rich and poor New Yorkers. 
 Typically, it said, the poor families affected make less than $20,000 a year, and pay slightly more than $100 in city income tax.
The report recommended a system of income tax credits, particularly for families with children, to raise the threshold for city income taxes to roughly that of the state and Federal governments.
"Because we have failed to keep pace with state and Federal reforms, New York City is taxing families that live just above the poverty line," said Mr. Green, a Democrat who has announced his intention to seek the Democratic nomination to run for the Senate seat held by Alfonse M. D'Amato. The poverty line for a family of four, as defined by Federal guidelines, is $16,276.
The study found that of 99,500 households affected by the discrepancy, 71 percent were headed by single parents. It said 153,000 children were affected.
At City Hall, officials said the findings released yesterday provided a detailed appraisal of a problem that has been evident for years, and has not escaped the attention of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani or the City Council.
A proposal for a system of low-income tax credits that would have lifted the city's income tax threshold was made jointly last year by the Mayor and Peter F. Vallone, the City Council Speaker, but it was rejected by legislators in Albany.
Any adjustment in the city's income tax system must first be approved by the State Legislature, and then by the City Council.
Yesterday's report attributed the disparity between city, state and Federal income tax assessments to varying types of tax credits that have been introduced over the last decade to protect the poor. The main culprit, it said, was a system of credits that the city began offering in 1989 that paralleled those offered by Washington and Albany but, unlike the others, were not indexed for inflation.
As a result, as the inflation-adjusted thresholds at which low-income people begin paying state and Federal income taxes have risen since 1989, the city threshold has remained constant, the report said.
An expert on state and city fiscal policies, Donald J. Boyd, of the Rockefeller Institute of Government in Albany, said yesterday that similar discrepancies may exist elsewhere but would probably not be considered as severe a problem for taxpayers outside New York City because their tax rates -- and their tax bills -- were lower.

HEADLINE: Trade Pact Brings Drug Searches and Traffic Jams

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: LAREDO, Tex.

 BODY:
It was a trip of four and a half miles, to haul a trailer of Mexican-made air-conditioner parts from a warehouse in Nuevo Laredo, Mexico, to a freight forwarder just across the border in Texas. For Salvador Romero, the driver, the journey took 29 hours, door to door.
First came a four-hour backup on the Mexican side. Then, once Mr. Romero made it across the Lincoln-Juarez Bridge over the Rio Grande, his truck got flagged for a random, intensive search by United States Customs agents and their drug-sniffing dogs. A paperwork mistake meant the trailer had to stay parked at Customs overnight. More inspection backups meant the search was not finished until the next afternoon. 
 "It's a constant traffic jam out here," said Mr. Romero, who earns 80 pesos -- about $9.30 -- for every round trip he makes between the two nations. "On average, I can make one trip a day, maybe two or possibly even three if I'm lucky. And then there are days like this."
More than four years after the North American Free Trade Agreement took effect, many crossings along the 2,000-mile border between the United States and Mexico are increasingly jammed with trucks, as the roads and bridges simply cannot keep pace with the booming growth of trade. While the congestion affects entry points from Southern California to the Rio Grande Valley of Texas, it is at its worst in Laredo, the busiest cargo crossing on the border, with lines sometimes stretching for five or six miles in either direction from the Rio Grande here.
A decade ago, 185,000 trucks a year crossed the two bridges at Laredo, while now nearly one million trucks cross three bridges each year, with at least a doubling of that figure projected by 2010. The heavy traffic causes tie-ups that have added to the cost of shipping goods all along the border and that periodically set off tensions between the two nations.
In recent months, the tie-ups have been compounded by lengthy searches ordered by the Customs Service, an agency caught between conflicting mandates to help speed the flow of commercial goods between the two countries and to stem the flow of illegal drugs.
"We've got a big drug problem at the border, and we're not going to turn our eye away from that," said Leonard C. Lindheim, special agent in charge of investigations at the Customs Service's South Texas division. "If it causes long lines, that's a price we'll have to pay."
Here in Laredo, the trade agreement has brought some economic activity, evident in the warehouses that have sprouted all over town. But there is also a nagging sense that the pact's benefits to Laredo were overstated while its drawbacks -- pollution, traffic and other problems -- are overwhelming this city of 150,000 people. The unemployment rate here remains above 10 percent, more than twice the national average.
Despite their obvious frustrations at the system, most Mexican drivers seemed resigned to the process as they gathered at a waiting area in the Customs lot here. Although it was only March, temperatures hit the 90's by midday, and many drivers said they were already dreading the nightmarish heat of summer.
"You have to stay near the truck at all times, so what can you do?" said Jorge Campos, 42, a driver based in Nuevo Laredo who was waiting as crates of elevator parts he was taking to Laredo were removed from his truck by forklifts, searched by Customs officials and sniffed by the dogs. "Of course we are mad, but you can't blame them," he said, gesturing toward the agents and their dogs. "They're just doing their jobs. They didn't make the law."
The searches are part of Operation Brass Ring, a six-month program started by Customs in February that includes roving teams of inspectors and intensive random inspections, like the one Mr. Romero's truck underwent, that are all aimed at sharply increasing the amount of drugs seized at the border.
Customs already seizes more drugs than all other Federal agencies combined, including more than 607,000 pounds of marijuana and 46,000 pounds of cocaine in its border regions alone last year. But with some law-enforcement officials estimating that 90 percent or more of all drugs that cross the border go undetected, the agency is under constant pressure to step up the pace and scope of its searches.
Some drugs still enter the country in backpacks carried by smugglers across remote stretches of desert. But with border crossings overwhelmed by commercial traffic, many dealers have become increasingly brazen about trying to hide the drugs inside shipments aboard 18-wheelers and other big trucks. Recent searches by Customs agents have turned up cocaine and heroin in the doors, walls, axles, fuel tanks and tires of the big trucks, and inside cargo pallets and even the hollowed-out cores of a load of vegetables.
Sgt. 1st Class Richard Rodriguez of the Texas National Guard's anti-drug task force, who was assisting Customs agents with truck searches here recently, said it could take up to six hours to complete a thorough inspection. Many trucks are given a cursory inspection and waved on at the bridges.
Local transportation planners say they are trying to ease the tie-ups, which tend to be at their worst in the late afternoons. Trucks are increasingly using the six-year-old Colombia-Solidarity Bridge, about 20 miles northwest of here, which had initially been considered something of a Government white elephant because drivers balked at making the detour from major highways. That diversion can take two hours or more on either side; but the eight-lane bridge has dozens of inspection docks and the crossing procedure is much quicker. The sister cities are also embarking on construction of another bridge later this year.
Customs officials also have long-range plans for easing the congestion. The agency already uses three huge X-ray machines along the border, two in California and one in the Rio Grande Valley of Texas, that look a bit like mammoth car washes and that can inspect a truck's contents in minutes. But prospects for their widespread use are uncertain, since the machines cost $3.5 million each. Customs officials are also considering use of high-tech devices that can "sniff" cocaine vapors and are pressing plans to streamline paperwork by putting truck manifests on computers that would be linked to Customs agencies in Mexico, Canada and the United States.
"There is no question that the infrastructure limits what you can do," said Noel Sanchez Jr., the Customs Service's director of passenger operations and vehicular traffic here. "But we can still do a good job at both things, helping to move goods across the border and stopping drugs. Just give us the resources, and we can do the job."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Customs agents used drug-sniffing dogs recently to check the cargo of a truck entering Laredo. A trade pact and intensive drug searches have led to nightmarish traffic jams like this one on a bridge linking Laredo and its sister city in Mexico. (Photographs by Greg Spaulding for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
A Family Circle Breaks: Murdoch Owns Dodgers

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

DATELINE: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 19

 BODY:
The father yanked them out of Brooklyn 40 years ago to capture the wealth of the West. Now the son has severed them from the family for the wealth $311 million will bring.
The Los Angeles, formerly Brooklyn, Dodgers left the O'Malley family today after nearly half a century of ownership when Major League Baseball club owners approved their sale to the Fox Group of Rupert Murdoch. It marks the end of family ownerships in baseball. 
 The sale, which needed 12 of the 16 votes from National League owners and 8 of 14 from American League owners to pass, was approved by a vote of 27 to 2 with one abstention.
Ted Turner of the Time Warner Atlanta Braves and Jerry Reinsdorf of the Chicago White Sox voted no. The Mets abstained because their co-owners were split in their positions. Fred Wilpon favored the transaction; Nelson Doubleday opposed it.
Peter O'Malley said he could not compare his feeling of selling the Dodgers with the feeling his father, Walter, had in moving them before the 1958 season. But he said at a news conference following the meeting at the Renaissance Vinoy Resort:
"I remember my dad talking about the move. It was a tough move for the family. Before he concluded it was best thing to move that franchise, he strongly tried to build a stadium in Brooklyn at the corner of Atlantic and Flatbush Avenues. Only when that became impossible did he move."
Old-time Dodgers fanatics would most likely dispute that motive for moving, believing that Walter O'Malley engineered the trip west because of the promise of riches the untapped West Coast held. The two Fox executives who will be in charge of the club for Murdoch followed a similar route.
Peter Chernin, 46, and Chase Carey, 44, are the co-chief operating officers of News Corporation, parent company of the Fox Group. Like the Dodgers, they grew up in New York. Chernin has been in Los Angeles for 19 years, Carey for 16.
"I'm a lifelong Dodger fan," Chernin said. "I saw my first baseball game at Ebbets Field."
Turner is not a Murdoch fan, and he made that clear in comments he made at sessions Wednesday and today. But others who attended the meeting credited Turner with acting with class and avoiding personal vitriol.
"I thought Ted Turner showed an extraordinary amount of class," Bud Selig, a relieved acting commissioner, said. "Just the way he handled himself. The way he spoke. What he said. When he said it."
Another person who was at the meeting said that after the vote, Turner made some conciliatory remarks, saying the majority had spoken and they all would work together to make baseball a better game. He also congratulated the Fox executives.
Murdoch, whose television entities hold national rights to major league games and local rights to games of 22 of the 30 teams, was not present for the occasion. Chernin and Carey were, and they were summoned into the meeting at one point to answer questions from some concerned owners.
Two of those owners, Peter Magowan of San Francisco and John Moores of San Diego, were so satisfied with their answers that they changed what might have been "no" votes to yes.
"They did a good job of answering the questions," Magowan said. "The biggest question was whether it was a conflict of interest having a financial investment in local media rights of 22 clubs. Would owning the Dodgers hurt the financial interests of those clubs? They made very strong statements that they would operate each of these businesses separately."
Another concern that had been expressed was the prospect of Murdoch's spending money madly for players and escalating the salary scale.
"We've had enough salaries escalating without him coming into the game," Magowan said, "so it would be hard to blame him for that."
Reinsdorf declined to say why he voted no, but officials said his vote stemmed from a dispute he had with Murdoch years ago.
Selig said Fox's presence as an owner was good for baseball economically.
"They are our national TV partner and they have been an excellent partner," he said. "They have cooperated and worked with us in a number of things. They have an economic arrangement with 22 clubs. I believe the synergism all the way around is very useful."
Is he satisfied that there is no conflict of interest?
"We are satisfied," he said. "We spent a lot of time going over a myriad of details and we are satisfied."
For Fox's part, Chernin said the purchase was important because the Dodgers are "one of the crown jewels of American sports and life." In addition, he said, "The Dodgers are one of the great unifying features of the city of Los Angeles."
The $311 million purchase price is the largest paid for a baseball team, but it includes other properties as well, including Dodger Stadium, real estate surrounding it, the spring training complex in Vero Beach, Fla., and the club's complex in the Dominican Republic.

HEADLINE: Prices Paid By Consumers Up Just 0.1%

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
Inflation remained subdued last month, thanks in large part to falling energy prices.
The Labor Department said today that consumer prices rose only one-tenth of 1 percent in February. Excluding the cost of food and energy, which can move sharply from month to month, February's prices increased at a faster three-tenths of 1 percent, led by the largest increase in tobacco prices in nine years. 
 Separately, the Labor Department said the number of new jobless claims rose by 9,000 last week, to 308,000, exceeding analysts' expectations. The level of new claims suggested that job creation was strong.
Economists expect inflation to stay tame because competition among American companies will force them to hold the line on prices, while the Asian crisis will help keep import prices down.
Energy prices, which account for about one-tenth of the Consumer Price Index, fell 2.2 percent in February on the heels of a 2.4 percent decline in January.
Earlier this week, crude oil prices fell to a nine-year low because of expectations that the major producing nations would leave the world awash with oil. Still, oil company executives expect the downturn in oil prices to be temporary. "What has happened in the last several months is really just a hiccup and is not sustainable," Archie Dunham, chief executive of Conoco Inc., said in an interview.
Food prices, which make up about one-fifth of the price index, were unchanged in February even though the price of fresh fruits rose 5.8 percent, the biggest gain since July 1988. Fresh vegetable prices fell 7.2 percent, the largest decline since June 1993.
Food prices may climb as a result of El Nino, the global weather phenomenon driven by unseasonably warm water off the coast of Peru. Record rainfall in the southern United States and California has flooded fields and ruined some crops.
The price of tobacco and other smoking products rose 2.9 percent in February, the largest monthly gain since January 1989. That suggested "retailers have taken the opportunity to widen their margins while blaming the manufacturers," said Ian Shepherdson, economist with HSBC Securities Inc. in New York. "Tobacco companies are clearly squeezing their price-insensitive consumers in order to fund impending legal deals."

HEADLINE: U.S. TO EASE CURBS ON RELIEF TO CUBA AND MONEY TO KIN

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
At the urging of Pope John Paul II, President Clinton will ease American restrictions on aid to Cuba, direct flights to the country and money sent to relatives by Cuban-Americans, senior American officials said today.
The President is expected to announce the changes on Friday, said the officials, who stressed that he would keep the economic embargo on Cuba. 
 The officials said Mr. Clinton wanted to respond to a plea from the Pope for help in carrying out religious and relief activities that do not benefit the Communist Government of Fidel Castro. Restrictions on tourism will not be relaxed.
The moves do not convey any approval of Mr. Castro's Government or policies, a senior official said, but are based on the conclusion that the Pope's visit to Cuba in January "created space for people to act in opposition to Castro."
For the first time since 1994, Mr. Clinton will allow Cuban-Americans to send money directly, and legally, to relatives in Cuba through licensed agencies. Cuban-Americans will be able to send up to $300 every quarter to each household.
Mr. Clinton will also allow certain organizations, like the Roman Catholic Church and the Catholic agency Caritas, to charter flights directly to Cuba from the United States. These flights might carry goods for relief purposes or passengers in emergencies, like funerals.
The President will also announce a streamlining of the licensing procedure that allows nonprofit organizations to export and sell pharmaceuticals to Cuba, while letting the organizations themselves insure that the drugs go to the proper recipients, and not the state.
And Mr. Clinton will say he is willing to work with Congress on legislation to ease the export of needed food to Cuba.
Some Congressional criticism was immediate. Representatives Lincoln Diaz-Balart and Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, both Florida Republicans, issued a joint statement accusing Mr. Clinton of seeking "to unilaterally relax sanctions on the Castro tyranny." They said the Pope's visit "should not be used as a pretext to soften sanctions."
Ms. Ros-Lehtinen said permitting flights and the payment of money to relatives reduced the price Mr. Castro is paying for shooting down two unarmed civilian aircraft, flown by Cuban exiles testing the Cuban Government, in international waters on Feb. 24, 1996.
But others in Miami cheered the decision and said it was another sign of needed change. "It was overdue," said Armando Garcia, vice president of Marazul Charters, the biggest Miami retailer of flights to Cuba. "Miami's not the same as it was two or three years ago. People are losing their fear of speaking up."
Larry Birns, director of the Council on Hemispheric Affairs, a research group based here, said he thought the Administration's decision would find general approval.
"There will be some gnashing of teeth in Congress, but with the Pope sanctioning such assistance and excoriating those who don't help, it seems to me the Administration will emerge relatively unscathed by its actions," Mr. Birns said. "It will also win points with the European Union and the rest of Latin America, which has been caustic in its criticism of U.S. policy to Cuba."
At Mr. Clinton's request, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and Samuel R. Berger, the national security adviser, developed the recommendations. Ms. Albright went to Miami in late February to talk to church leaders and Cuban-Americans, including the families of the pilots killed in 1996.
On March 7, in a conversation with the Pope at the Vatican, Ms. Albright discussed Cuba and the importance of the Pope's 1979 visit to Poland to ending Communist rule there. His visit to Cuba could be a similar "point of departure," she told him.
After the meeting, Ms. Albright wrote Mr. Clinton a memo. In it she drew an analogy to what happened in Poland after the Pope's visit and said Cuban-Americans had given her the impression that the Pope's visit to Cuba had provided encouragement to opponents of the Government. She said the Catholic Church -- with its four million adherents, its uncensored sermons and its access to the people -- represented an important opening for Washington.
But what Mr. Clinton will do, officials say, is mostly revert to practices that existed when he took office. In August 1994, he responded to an organized outflow of Cuban boat people by banning Cuban-Americans from sending money to relatives.
Even so, Mr. Birns said, some $700 million a year in illegal payments get through to Cuba.
Mr. Clinton suspended direct flights to Cuba on Feb. 26, 1996, two days after the downing of the planes. Both the economic embargo and the ban on direct flights were included in the Helms-Burton bill, which Mr. Clinton signed in March 1996.
One Congressional staffer said today that it was not clear whether Mr. Clinton had the authority himself to allow direct flights, since the ban is covered under the legislation, which does allow special waivers. But officials said that while the details were still being worked out, the intention is to cut the costs to the church and charities of flights they were sending anyway, through third countries.
After the Pope's visit, Senator Jesse Helms, the Republican from North Carolina who heads the Foreign Relations Committee, announced that he would introduce legislation designed to increase aid to Cuba and allow direct flights to deliver it. Today, his spokesman said he had been offended by Mr. Clinton's unilateral actions.
"This is a major mistake," said Mr. Helms's spokesman, Marc Thiessen. "It seriously complicates our ability to get through legislation to provide increased humanitarian assistance to the Cuban people."
The move to ease the Cuban sanctions had been gathering strength, even before the Pope's visit. The end of the Soviet Union made the idea of a Cuban threat to America seem implausible, and the recent death of Jorge Mas Canosa, whom Mr. Birns called "the most forceful and politically influential Cuban-American figure, with the key to back door of White House," took some political sting from the Cuban-American lobby.
John Howard, director of international policy for the United States Chamber of Commerce, said an end to the embargo would bring quicker benefits of freedom, the same argument the Europeans make.
In January, the chamber joined groups like the National Association of Manufacturers in advocating an immediate lifting of restrictions on the sale of food, medicine and medical equipment. "But that's only a first step," Mr. Howard said. "When you end these embargoes, free markets and free societies follow."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Cablevision Official Offers To Buy a Stake in Yankees
George Steinbrenner, the controlling owner of the New York Yankees, acknowledged talking with Charles Dolan, the chairman of Cablevision Systems, about Mr. Dolan's buying a piece of the club.
 
 Even so, a member of the Steinbrenner family and baseball officials warn that any thought of a sale of part of the Yankees is extremely premature. They also point out that offers to acquire a portion of the club are quite common. Page A1.
 
Cablevision would love to add the Yankees to its media empire. The company owns a portion of Madison Square Garden, the Knicks, the Rangers and six regional sports cable services, and already shows Yankee games on them. C8.
 
Fidelity Is Closing Three Funds
Fidelity Investments plans to close three of its stellar performers, its Growth and Income, Contrafund and Low-Priced Stock funds, to new investors after April 3. D6.
 
Sunbeam Stock Falls on Estimates
An announcement by Sunbeam that it might not meet sales estimates for the first quarter because of a decline in orders from retailers sent shares of the stock plummeting 9.4 percent. Analysts had not expected that news from the consumer appliance maker, which recently said it would buy Coleman outdoor equipment, Mr. Coffee machines and First Alert smoke alarms. D4.
 
Indonesia and I.M.F. Meeting
Indonesian and International Monetary Fund officials are meeting to resolve a deadlock that has caused a halt in disbursements of international aid. A8.
 
Consumer Prices Increase Slightly
Consumer prices rose only one-tenth of 1 percent in February, keeping inflation subdued. Though the Labor Department said the number of new jobless claims rose by 9,000 last week, that level still suggests that job creation remains strong. D5.
 
Coke Marketing Guru Departs
Sergio Zyman, a hard-charging and innovative marketing executive who rejuvenated Coca-Cola's advertising over the last four and a half years with a zestful multibillion-dollar campaign, will resign May 1 to spend more time with his family and write a textbook on marketing. "Life After Sergio" could mean a more local orientation by Coke in its soft-drink marketing. Advertising. D4.

Internet Tax Deal Reached
An agreement was reached by state, city and county government leaders on a bill to mediate the thorny issue of taxing Internet services and commerce. It is expected to be voted on by the House of Representatives in the next few weeks, but it differs significantly from a Senate version. A21.
 
BBC and Discovery Form Alliance
The BBC and Discovery Communications signed a deal to form a $565 million alliance to create new programs and new cable channels around the world. D2.
 
Dow Records, Day 4
Major stock market indexes rose to records again despite new warnings from several companies about earnings weakness. The Dow industrials surpassed 8,800 for the first time, up 27.65 points, to 8,803.05, the fourth consecutive day that the blue-chip index has closed at a record. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also rose to its fourth consecutive all-time high. The Nasdaq and Russell 2000 indexes increased to records for a second consecutive day. D6.
 
Treasuries Little Changed
Treasuries ended little changed. The yield on the benchmark 30-year bond fell to 5.89 percent from 5.90 percent. D6.
 
$6.15 Minimum Wage Proposed
The Democrats formally introduced a plan to raise the minimum wage by 20 percent, to $6.15 an hour. Unions praised the plan but even some supporters expressed concern that the higher level could cost jobs. A14.

HEADLINE: January Trade Deficit Soared, as the Asia Crisis Hit Home

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit surged in January to its highest level in a decade as the financial crises in Asia depressed demand for American goods in that part of the world, the Commerce Department reported today.
It said the deficit in the trade of goods and services expanded to $12 billion in January from $10.9 billion in December. This was the widest gap since the department began using its current monthly measurement system in 1992 and was last exceeded late in 1987 under a system that measured trade on a quarterly basis. 
 The deficit in goods alone rose to $18.8 billion, the highest level on record, from $17.7 billion in December.
Economists have predicted for months that Asia's woes would begin slowing the robust American economy, and today's figures provided the first clear evidence that the process was under way.
"This is the beginning of Asia kicking in, and it is the harbinger of wider deficits to come," said Joel L. Naroff, an economist at the First Union Bank in Philadelphia.
With American exporters feeling the bite, the Clinton Administration stepped up efforts today to press Japan into reviving its moribund economy to help pull Asia out of its crisis. For the first time, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury Lawrence H. Summers specified how much the United States wanted Japan to increase public spending and cut taxes: 2 percent of the country's gross domestic product. That is roughly equivalent to $77 billion.
Mr. Summers acknowledged that Japanese officials were becoming increasingly angry at American criticism of how their economy was being managed. But, he said, "Just as our Japanese and European friends appropriately criticized U.S. budget deficits, we think it is appropriate" to specify how Japan should stimulate its economy for the good of its trading partners.
Analysts said they expected widening trade deficits in coming months to exert more of a drag on growth in the United States.
But they said it remained unclear whether the otherwise strong economy would slow sufficiently to avoid inflation pressures that would lead the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates -- or whether the economy might slow so much that an interest-rate cut would be justified.
Inflation statistics released today provided few clues to which way the economy might tip. The Labor Department said the Consumer Price Index for February rose one-tenth of 1 percent, held down by falling oil prices, leaving the inflation rate for the last year at 1.4 percent. Excluding food and energy, the Consumer Price Index rose three-tenths of 1 percent, its biggest jump since last April. Most of the rise, though, came from one-time increases in items like cigarette prices and rent, rather than broad-based price increases.
Falling oil prices also made the trade deficit look smaller, since the value of energy imports would otherwise have been much higher. As it was, the trade figures showed how the difficulties among some of the nation's fastest-growing export markets were being felt at home.
The most compelling evidence was in the figures for trade with the four original "Asian tiger" economies. The combined deficit in those markets -- South Korea, Hong Kong, Singapore and Taiwan -- jumped to $2.2 billion for the month, up from $841 million in December and $783 million a year earlier.
The deficit just with South Korea, one of the nations hit hardest by financial crisis, rose to $856 million from $341 million. In January 1997, the United States had a trade surplus with South Korea of $181 million.
The deficit with Japan, one of the most politically sensitive indicators of American trade performance, narrowed to $4.4 billion, from $5.1 billion in December, when the gap was particularly high.
The deficit with China, which now rivals that of Japan in economic and political significance, rose in January to $3.7 billion from $2.7 billion.
While considerable attention has been focused on how Asian financial problems are hurting trade, economists said the overall impact on the United States was mixed. The currency devaluations across Asia have made imports from there into the United States less expensive, dampening inflation and forcing domestic competitors to hold down prices.
Low inflation and a flood of investment from Asia into United States Treasury bonds have pushed down interest rates, reducing borrowing costs for American businesses and consumers and setting off mortgage refinancing that has left more money in the pockets of many people.
While the slowing of exports to Asia could significantly cut growth in this country, the slowdown will be partly offset by the reduction in interest rates and by low oil prices, analysts said. While many economists still expect growth to slow from its 3.9 percent pace in the fourth quarter, few predict that it will slow in the current quarter to what has been considered a sustainable pace of 2.5 percent or less.
"The domestic part of the economy is really on fire," said Stuart G. Hoffman of the PNC Corporation. "If the trade deficit held at its current level through February and March, it could knock one and a quarter percentage points off the growth rate, but that would leave real G.D.P. growth at 3 or 3.5 percent."

HEADLINE: Smoking Budgets in Washington

 BODY:
After two months of soap-opera diversions, Congress has returned to the familiar task of squabbling over how to spend money that does not exist. President Clinton and the Democrats want to apply funds from a tobacco settlement to hire teachers, build classrooms and expand health coverage. Republicans reject that approach but are divided over the alternatives. Whichever side prevails, the budget makers are courting trouble by counting on a tobacco settlement, and that may cripple their ability to craft one that does not give too much away to the industry.
Even so, such familiar budget tangles can be a comfort for those weary of scandal. Also, thanks to a booming economy and surpluses projected over many years, these disputes center on how to deal with abundance. In January Mr. Clinton proposed to set aside the surplus for the financially ailing Social Security system. So far he appears to have won the day from Capitol Hill on that point. But to generate resources for his additional spending programs and tax cuts, Mr. Clinton wanted to reduce spending in other areas, close tax loopholes and, most important, tap $65 billion in tobacco-related revenues over the next five years. 
 The most helpful Republican response would have been to wait until there is a tobacco deal before spending the money from it. But the Republicans, too, are eyeing all that tobacco money for their own purposes, especially tax cuts. The climate in Congress thus favors some kind of settlement that would include payments from the industry to the government, a sharp cigarette tax hike, or both.
Any tobacco deal should not immunize the industry from lawsuits or bar the Government from regulating tobacco. Tobacco proceeds would also best be used for victims of diseases relating to smoking, as the Administration wants.
This week the Senate Budget Committee called for the rest of the tobacco money to be set aside to prevent future cuts in Medicare. That proposal would be preferable to the push by House Republicans to use it for tax-cut schemes and highways. But the Medicare trust fund is not in any immediate danger of insolvency, and the White House's idea of spending the money on education, job training and child care deserves consideration.
Whatever happens will probably be decided in conference later this year. The President, looking relieved to be talking about tax and spending policy, took to the road this week and got a predictably supportive response from the A.F.L.-C.I.O. What he left out is that it all deserves to disappear in a puff if the right tobacco deal is not reached.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Tory With Juice

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
The journalistic sense of mission to visit London that seizes American columnists each springtime can be fulfilled only with commitment to specific duties. Walks in parks alive with daffodils must be undertaken; also seeing a couple of plays, dinner at an excellent club, and breakfast at the Ritz.
 My breakfast was with a man I had met far from here but wanted to see in this city, on the record.
 
 The two times I had talked with Christopher Patten were in Hong Kong, when he was the British Governor there. With the island tense approaching the Chinese takeover, what he said was not for publication. But what this politician-diplomat learned from experience with the Chinese struck me as increasingly important to be read in Europe and America.
So, on the record, this sums up what he said in both cities:
-- China needs Western business hugely more than the West needs Chinese. Britain's exports to China are 0.4 percent of the British total. Britain sells 15 times more to the Benelux countries than to China.
 -- China's economic power against the West is no more than the power of blackmail against the fearful, which vanishes when confronted.
-- But Western business and governments act as if it were the other way around. Through fear of loss of Chinese trade they make business and political concessions that are against their interests, economically and morally.
-- The Chinese not only know this fear-driven Western weakness but incorporate it in their international business and political policies. When China wanted to show its economic muscle, it canceled some contracts with a suitably small country. It chose Denmark in punishment for the Danish stand against Chinese human rights abuse. For all the talk of Continental unity, Europe did nothing and neither did the U.S.
-- Vastly stronger economically and technologically than China, the West must divorce its political, strategic and moral needs and principles from business deals with China. Only then will the Communists treat the West with any respect, not the contempt it has earned.
As Mr. Patten talked, I thought of what had happened in the past few days that showed how hypnotized Washington had become by the fake watch of profit that the Chinese keep swinging before its eyes.
President Clinton pushes forward a visit to China. He cancels Washington's yearly attempt to get the U.N. Human Rights Commission to criticize China's human rights brutalities. America's diplomatic spin doctors sell the story that China is improving its human rights behavior -- as Beijing again rounds up suspected dissidents. The Clinton Administration considers canceling missile-technology sanctions against China imposed after the massacre at Tiananmen.
And I have just received a copy of a report on religious rights in China by three U.S. clergymen, Catholic, Protestant and Jewish.
They were dispatched by the President of the United States and received by the President of China, and did not permit U.S. journalists to accompany them. The report has all the passion and compassion of a telephone directory. In tone and language it treats the Chinese Government, warden of the Chinese gulag and persecutor of Chinese Christians who disobey Beijing's "patriotic" religious regulation, as if the clergymen were bowing themselves in and out of an emperor's presence.
Mr. Patten is a Conservative, a Tory with juice -- phrase stolen from conversation with Warren Hoge, who enriches The New York Times with his reporting from Britain.
Mr. Patten squirts some juice on Rupert Murdoch. HarperCollins, a Murdoch publishing house, canceled Mr. Patten's book, "East and West," for fear the Chinese would take their anger out on Murdoch holdings in China. Bottom line: Mr. Patten got a settlement from HarperCollins, contracts from Macmillan in London and Times Books in New York, and mountains of free publicity.
The press in Britain and America jumped all over Mr. Murdoch. That was fine, except when the attacks came from journalists and academics who have been silent about Mr. Clinton's sellout of Chinese and Tibetan human rights.
They fit the Patten definition of the publisher who would not publish: "China's useful idiot."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed
