HEADLINE: Auction Ends 5-Year Dream in 5 Minutes

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

 BODY:
It was over in just five minutes. Yolanda Garcia, who had fought for five years to restore the old Bronx County Courthouse, a hulking monument to the city's abandonment of her neighborhood, was simply outbid.
The building, a 1914 Beaux-Arts landmark at 161st Street and Third Avenue that was shuttered in 1978, was sold for $300,000 at a city auction yesterday to two men from Brooklyn who plan to renovate it as medical offices or stores. 
 With that, a community's dream seemed to have fizzled.
Since 1993, Ms. Garcia and other members of Nos Quedamos (We Stay), a grass-roots group that is slowly beginning to revive the ravaged Melrose section of the Bronx, had worked with a succession of city and nonprofit agencies and philanthropies to turn the courthouse into a town center of sorts.
Nos Quedamos, which became an international model for community-led planning when it took control of the Melrose Commons urban renewal project in 1992, envisioned a school, museum, library and other groups sharing the courthouse's cavernous lobby, marble staircases and terrazzo floors.
This would be no easy task. A 1992 estimate put the cost of restoring the courthouse at $43 million. But Nos Quedamos developed a plan to fix it up piecemeal as funds materialized. It raised $900,000 to begin the job and began talks with the city about a lease.
But in 1996, the city abruptly ended those negotiations and put the courthouse up for sale. It was sold at auction in 1996 to an electrical contractor from Queens, who defaulted on his payments last year.
At the previous auction, Ms. Garcia watched, helpless, as the courthouse sold for $130,000. She resolved not to let it be sold a second time without putting up a fight.
"Give up?" she said yesterday morning, amid the hubbub of the auction, attended by several hundred people at One Police Plaza. "That's where we live. What do we do, continue to let it decay? Continue to live in a ghetto?"
This time, Ms. Garcia had financial support: Robert Garcia (no relation), an electrical contractor who grew up a block from the courthouse and played in its entrances as a child, and Shelly Fox, a general contractor who is building three-family homes in the Bronx.
Over lunch, the men worried how high the bidding might go, how high they would be willing to go.
Parcel No. 146, the courthouse, went up for sale at 3:40. Across the auditorium, half a dozen people quickly bid the building up to $100,000. Ms. Garcia was still in it, her friends nodding along in agreement. A red-haired woman joined the fray, and the price was at $250,000. Ms. Garcia's friends nodded, and she went to $260,000. Then two men in the front row offered $270,000. Ms. Garcia went to $280,000. Someone else bid $290,000. Ms. Garcia raised her hand, but the men in front were recognized first, at $300,000.
The next bid, the auctioneer said, would have to be $325,000. Ms. Garcia's friends slumped in their seats. So did she.
"Sold," the auctioneer shouted at 3:45.
The winning bidders, Henry Weinstein and Benjamin Klein, said they fell in love with the courthouse when they drove past it one night three weeks ago, after seeing it in the auction catalogue.
Mr. Weinstein, who owns a furniture store and has built condominiums in Brooklyn, and Mr. Klein, a mechanical engineer, said they expect to spend about $12 million to fix up the courthouse as a department store or mall, or perhaps medical offices. They said they knew nothing of Nos Quedamos or its plans. They scoffed at the $43 million estimate for restoring the building, saying they could do it for far less.
Ms. Garcia tried to contain her bitterness, and failed. "At least you can tell us, 'Thank you for the new roof that's keeping the rain out,' " she said, referring to $300,000 in repairs the city made in response to her group's efforts.
Taken aback, the men told Ms. Garcia and her friends that they are willing to meet with her. "If there's some way we can help you people, we'd like to," Mr. Weinstein said.
He and Mr. Klein said goodbye, and Ms. Garcia took the measure of the day. "I'm crying inside," she said. "But we were close. It tells you the kind of people that live in Melrose. The kind of a commitment that's there. I just wish we could get a break."

HEADLINE: Black Youths' Rate of Suicide Rising Sharply, Studies Find

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 19

 BODY:
Suicide among black teen-agers, once quite rare, has increased dramatically over the last two decades, a troubling rise that might reflect the strain some black families feel in making the transition to middle-class life, according to a study released today by the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
The study found that the rate of black suicide for youths ages 15 to 19 had more than doubled, to 8.1 per 100,000 in 1995, from 3.6 per 100,000 in 1980. It found a similar pattern, with far smaller numbers for ages 10 to 14. 
 Researchers also found that the gap between black and white teen-age suicides was narrowing -- in 1980 the white rate for ages 10 to 19 was more than twice the black rate, but in 1995 the white rate was 42 percent higher.
And a 1995 study of high school students across the country found that black students were as likely as whites to try suicide.
Suicide is now the third leading cause of death for black 15- to 24-year-olds, matching the rate in the general population.
The leading cause of death for black youths is homicide, followed by accidents.
Dr. Tonji Durant, the author of the centers' study, said the researchers hypothesized that one factor in the increase might be the growth in the black middle class.
"One theory," Dr. Durant said, "is that upwardly mobile families may experience some stress with their social environments and for some reason they may, in the process of adapting to a new class, adopt some of the behaviors of the larger society, including the ways of dealing with hopelessness and depression."
Several experts on black youth suicide said today that the move to middle-class life might be accompanied by a splintering of community and family support networks, a weakening of bonds to religion, and the pressure of trying to compete in historically white-dominated professions and social circles.
The centers' study did not look at the economic status of the suicide victims, and Dr. Durant said more research was needed to better understand the patterns. But a 1995 study at Columbia University of teen-age suicides in the New York metropolitan region found that unlike white and Hispanic teen-agers, black teen-agers who committed suicide tended to come from higher socio-economic backgrounds than blacks in the general population.
"What we figured is that the greater economic and educational advances that blacks were able to make, the less protection they were able to give their children from the stresses that lead to suicide," said Dr. David Shaffer, a professor of child psychiatry and pediatrics at Columbia who conducted that study, which looked in detail at each of 140 teen-age suicides in New York City and its suburbs from 1984 to 1986. "One theory is that when you live in poorer circumstances, there is a kind of stress inoculation. If you're exposed to a lot of stress then you're able to deal with many problems. It's a bit like being immunized."
Les Franklin, who formed a foundation to help black teen-agers after his 16-year-old son shot himself in the head in 1990 in their affluent Denver neighborhood, said his own experience and others he knew of supported that analysis.
"You don't find a lot of gang members committing suicide," Mr. Franklin said. His son Shaka grew up in a large house with a swimming pool out back and a Porsche in the four-car garage, a life style Mr. Franklin, then working for I.B.M., said was a huge step up from his own upbringing in an apartment crowded with aunts and grandparents.
"His mother and I were divorced -- he never forgave us for that," Mr. Franklin said. "I know that he had low self-esteem. He was a kid living in pain." But, Mr. Franklin added, "he didn't have the hard life. He didn't have the preparation that I got to learn how to survive."
At a time when young black males are murdered at an alarming rate -- 111 per 100,000, according to 1995 figures -- the suicide numbers are especially troubling, people who work with black youths say.
The centers' study of the 3,030 suicides of blacks ages 10 to 19 between 1980 and 1995 found a stark increase in the suicide rate among black males between the ages of 15 and 19, which jumped 146 percent from 1980 to 1995. Suicide among white males in that age group increased 22 percent during that time. Suicides among black teen-age girls increased also, but, like whites, those rates were much lower than for boys.
Nearly three quarters of black male teen-agers who killed themselves used guns, the most common weapon for white males as well.
David C. Clark, a professor of psychiatry at Rush Medical College in Chicago, who is working on a study of all Chicago suicides for ages 15 to 19 from 1991 to 1996, said preliminary findings had suggested that "black adolescents are more likely to kill themselves in the presence of somebody else, in the presence of a girlfriend or in the presence of someone who they hang out with."
That means, Professor Clark said, that "for every black adolescent suicide we have a greater likelihood that there are other teens that are exposed to the shock."
Some experts said that in urban neighborhoods with a lot of guns, some young men, feeling hopeless or depressed, might indirectly commit suicide by putting themselves in situations where they are likely to be shot. The centers' study did not include these kinds of deaths.
Professor Clark said the increase in black teen-age suicide might also reflect the paucity of mental health services in many black communities and a cultural distrust of mental health professionals.
"It certainly has been a taboo in the African-American community to talk about suicide," said Kenya Napper Bello, president of Free Mind Generation, a nonprofit organization in Atlanta dedicated to preventing suicide and depression among blacks. "It is often viewed as a sin."
Ms. Bello's husband, Razak, killed himself at the age of 27 by jumping out the 32d-floor window of a downtown Atlanta hotel. Mr. Bello, a rising young executive at Coca-Cola, had been told by doctors that he had manic-depressive illness, but was so uncomfortable with the idea that he needed help that, two months before his death, he stopped taking medication and seeing a counselor.
"It was unfortunate that he suffered from a condition that he felt he had to hide, including from me," said Ms. Bello, who also started a newsletter called "Black Men Don't Commit Suicide," after a myth that she said some people still subscribe to.
"We have prided ourselves as a community in being resilient and being able to deal with adversity," Ms. Bello said. "The white community seems to be far more advanced in talking about it, getting psychological support and coming up with answers. We're just not there."

HEADLINE: In Deal to Sell Bus Depot, The Post Would Get a Plant

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

 BODY:
A committee of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted yesterday to make a bus depot in the South Bronx available to The New York Post for a new color printing plant, in a move that critics say could cause service disruptions and force scores of buses to be quartered in residential neighborhoods.
State officials say the deal was necessary to keep The Post's printing operation -- and the 500 jobs that go with it -- in New York City. But critics in Manhattan and the Bronx and even some transit officials assailed the deal, saying it put the needs of The New York Post, and its owner, Rupert Murdoch, ahead of those of city neighborhoods. 
 The measure, which will be considered by the full M.T.A. board on Thursday, would authorize the sale of an eight-acre parcel, which includes the Walnut Depot, to the Empire State Development Corporation for $11.5 million. The corporation would then lease or rent the property to the Galesi Group, which would develop the site, and an adjacent parcel it already controls, and rent it to The Post for a new $150 million printing plant.
Home to 220 buses, the Walnut Depot on 132d Street was scheduled to close down in two years, when another depot in the Bronx is to open. Critics inside and outside the transit agency said that shutting down the depot now, at a time when ridership is booming and when the agency plans to buy hundreds more buses, would tax the M.T.A.'s other depots.
"To be closing down a bus depot now, when they are scrounging every month to find space to park buses, doesn't make sense," said Beverly Dolinsky, a non-voting member of the authority's board who is also the Executive Director of its Transit Riders Council. Lawrence G. Reuter, the president of New York City Transit, the transportation authority's bus and subway subsidiary, said that the early shutdown of Walnut would cause only minimal inconvenience. And Caroline Quartararo, spokeswoman for the state development corporation, praised the authority for stepping aside to help bring jobs to a blighted industrial area of the Bronx.
"This project will help us create jobs and economic opportunity in a community that desperately needs them," she said.
To accommodate the early shutdown of the Walnut Depot, a former warehouse that the authority bought for $1.2 million in 1979, the M.T.A. is relocating its 220 buses to five depots in the Bronx and Upper Manhattan that are at full capacity. Yesterday's real estate committee agenda contained four requests from New York City Transit for extra parking spaces for buses in Upper Manhattan.
Ms. Dolinsky of the Transit Riders Council also criticized the way the vote was taken. The question was not on the real estate committee's regular agenda and was approved on a 1-0 vote. Daniel Scannell, one of only two members of the five-member committee to attend the meeting, voted in favor, while Alan Friedberg, the other member, abstained because the item was added at the last minute and he still had questions about it.
"Keeping business here, taking a blighted spot and making something of it, that's all good," he said. "But we're entitled to be memoed appropriately with the appropriate memorandum about all the costs related to this item."
Christopher P. Boylan, an Executive Deputy Director at the M.T.A., said that measures that come before the agency's committees need not be approved by a majority before they are passed on to the full board.
Mr. Reuter said it was costing the agency between $1.6 million and $2 million to speed the completion of a new depot along the West Side Highway that will open the day Walnut closes -- scheduled for March 29.
Mr. Reuter also acknowledged that running Bronx buses out of Manhattan depots would increase the time that it takes drivers to bring empty buses back to the start of their routes and back to the depot at the end of the day, which would increase fuel and labor costs. But he declined to say what those costs would be.
The union representing bus drivers said the extra distance that buses would have to travel to reach their runs increased the likelihood of delays for passengers.
"We're going backwards," said Jimmy DeLong, vice president for buses of Transport Workers Union Local 100. "On the Bx5," -- now slated to move its base from Walnut to the Gun Hill Depot, an extra 12 minutes from the start of the route -- "we went from 8-, 10- and 12-minute headways to 2-, 3- and 4-minute headways by putting extra service out there. We virtually wiped out competition from the private vans on that line. If we don't get these buses out on schedule people are going back to the vans."
Peggy Shepard, the executive director of West Harlem Environmental Action, assailed the proposal. "Rupert Murdoch's need for the Walnut Depot should not outweigh the health of half a million residents of northern Manhattan," she said, "but that looks like what's happening."
Howard Rubenstein, speaking for The Post and Mr. Murdoch, said:
"From every public policy perspective, it was a good decision and the right place for the printing plant. The Governor, Mayor, Bronx Borough President, and the N.R.D.C. all support it."
While Ms. Shepard and other critics wondered why The Post could not move to one of the many industrial sites in the South Bronx, Martin Singerman, the paper's president and publisher, said the Walnut site, which will be next door to a paper recycling plant, was the only suitable one it had found. "This location is a hub for all of New York City," he said. "You're right on the Major Deegan, you've got the Triborough Bridge, you've got all those highways to Westchester or Long Island nearby."
Mr. Boylan said he did not understand why the deal had attracted so much criticism.
"People complain about government not being able to get out of its own way," he said, "and here we're speeding things up for the sake of the state and the city and the M.T.A. and people complain about that, too."

HEADLINE: New Democrat Enters Race For Governor

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 19

 BODY:
Completing a transformation that began when she quit the Republican Party last year, Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross announced today that she would seek to unseat Gov. George E. Pataki, her one-time running mate. She repeatedly urged voters to make her the state's first female governor.
Taking the stage to the brassy thump of prerecorded military marches, Ms. McCaughey Ross assailed Mr. Pataki and her former political benefactor, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, presenting her candidacy as a break from politics as usual. Now a Democrat, Ms. McCaughey Ross said she would campaign against abuses by health maintenance organizations and address deep economic difficulties that she said were turning New York into a "Charles Dickens tale of two economies." 
 "I entered this race not to run against one man, but to put forward new ideas and fresh approaches to solve the problems facing working families in New York," Ms. McCaughey Ross declared. "Too many good ideas have been ignored because of politics and games. Too many fresh approaches have been left untried because of the same old thinking."
With her announcement swing through Buffalo, New York City and Albany, Ms. McCaughey Ross apparently completed the field of Democrats seeking to run against Mr. Pataki this fall, a contest that many Democrats view as daunting, at best.
But as a political phenomenon, Ms. McCaughey Ross's candidacy is highly unusual, and has attracted extraordinary attention to someone who has been in elective office for less than four years.
For one thing, many Democratic leaders have already expressed a deep distrust of her, questioning how someone who campaigned comfortably as Mr. Pataki's running mate in 1994 could now present herself as an advocate of Democratic values. At the same time, many Democrats say they believe Ms. McCaughey Ross may well win the primary, if only because she is a woman in a field of unknown men.
Accordingly, the latest gubernatorial candidate was met by something less than a cheerful welcome by her opponents.
When she appeared this evening at the Federal Hall Rotunda in lower Manhattan, an aide to one of her opponents, Peter F. Vallone, the Council Speaker, gave reporters a detailed critique suggesting contradictions between her announcement speech and her past record.
And Richard A. Kahan, a developer and former chairman of the State Urban Development Corporation, released a television advertisement that portrayed her as a conservative Republican, taking note, for example, of her initial defense of the nomination of Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court. In a standard political gambit, Mr. Kahan did not buy any significant time on the air, but by releasing the advertisement to reporters he produced newspaper stories that helped set the backdrop for today's announcement.
Ms. McCaughey Ross was repeatedly asked today to account for her shifting political loyalties. Asked to describe what kind of Democrat she was, Ms. McCaughey Ross responded: "I believe I'm the most socially progressive Democrat in the race. I'm unequivocally pro-choice. I've stood up for the rights of gays and lesbians. I've stood with tenants for rent protections."
But when she was then asked what kind of Republican she had been, Ms. McCaughey Ross appeared momentarily flustered. "You're dealing with labels, and I'm dealing with issues that are important to working families," she said.
At a news conference in Albany, Ms. McCaughey Ross disputed the suggestion by some Democratic leaders, including the state party chairwoman, Judith Hope, that she should perhaps pay some dues before seeking such a high office.
"I respect their concerns about paying dues and working my way through the Democratic Party," she said. "But you know, to most New Yorkers, if you ask them what it means to pay your dues, they think it means putting food on the table for your children, going to your children's P.T.A. meetings, making a contribution to the community. They don't think about it as running for one elective office after another."
Ms. McCaughey Ross for the most part avoided attacks on her opponents. But in a hint of what may lie ahead, she repeatedly linked the names of Mr. D'Amato and Mr. Pataki, as she asserted that it was the state's two most powerful Republicans who betrayed her.
"I've stayed true to the issues from the beginning," she said. "I was very impressed with the promises that the D'Amato-Pataki organization made four years ago. Unfortunately, there's a big difference between what they said and what they actually did."
Mr. Pataki's communications director, Zenia Mucha, said the Governor would not comment on any of his Democratic opponents until after the primary in September. As for Ms. McCaughey Ross's specific criticisms of Mr. Pataki's record, Ms. Mucha responded: "Look, irrational statements by irrational people warrant no comment."
Ms. McCaughey Ross went to some lengths today to distance herself from affiliation with any party. She talked in detail about health maintenance organizations that deny benefits to patients. She said her top priority would be passing legislation that would require insurance companies to pay for experimental treatments for diseases, a measure Mr. Pataki has opposed. She said that she would push for wider state funding of prekindergarten programs.
More than anything, though, she sought to frame her candidacy in historical terms, taking advantage of the fact that she would be the only woman in the race. Besides Mr. Vallone and Mr. Kahan, the other candidates are James L. Larocca, the former state Transportation Commissioner, and Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn District Attorney.
Ms. McCaughey Ross filled her speeches with references to herself as a "working mom." She was introduced in New York City by Lois Shapiro-Canter, head of the New York branch of the National Organization for Women. The campaign leaflets listing her announcement in Albany -- which, like the one in New York, was sparsely attended -- declared: "Be a part of history!"
At the conclusion of her speech, she said, "I believe New Yorkers are ready to elect the first woman governor in New York State history."

HEADLINE: Better Pay vs. Job Stability in Wage Debate

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
The Democrats today formally introduced President Clinton's plan to increase the minimum wage, drawing praise from unions but raising concerns even among supporters that the proposed new level, $6.15 an hour, might cost jobs.
With a ceremonial flourish, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the principal Congressional proponent of a higher minimum wage, introduced a bill to raise the minimum by 20 percent. That could be high enough, economists say, so that employers might decide to automate or to hire fewer but more skilled and more expensive workers. 
 Such an acknowledgment of a potential job loss is central to the debate over whether Congress should raise the minimum wage again, so soon after the last increase, in 1996. In 1996, most labor economists insisted that the higher minimum wage would not cost any jobs. It was an argument that carried the day, and it turned out to be true.
Now several of those same economists say $6.15 an hour may be close to some "tipping point" at which two or three minimum wage workers in a group of 100 may have trouble keeping a job or finding one. But such potential difficulties, the same economists say, are far outweighed by the financial gains for the 97 or 98 who get the raise and keep their jobs.
The Labor Secretary, Alexis M. Herman, acknowledged the new concern today, saying in an interview, "I want to put the emphasis on the gainers and not the few potential losers, if there were to be any."
The bill would raise the minimum to $5.65 an hour on Jan. 1, 1999, from the current level, $5.15, and to $6.15 on Jan. 1, 2000.
At a hearing on Capitol Hill, Mr. Kennedy avoided mentioning job loss. Instead, he and Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the House Democratic whip, spoke of the need to pay a survival wage to the workers who care for "our aging parents and our children." Five such workers described their hardships.
Mr. Kennedy acknowledged the shift in the debate, saying in an interview: "I am not ready to grant the job loss argument. But it is an argument that needs serious evaluation."
In an election year, raising the minimum wage is a bread-and-butter issue. A majority of Americans favor increasing the minimum, according to polls, and that was a reason many Republicans voted for the increase in 1996. It raised the minimum to $4.75 on Oct. 1, 1996, from $4.25, then to $5.15 on Sept. 1, 1997. About 12 million people, or nearly 10 percent of the work force, are paid $6.15 an hour or less.
But the pros and cons of the debate are more complicated than in 1996. The $6.15 hourly wage, adjusted for inflation, would still be well below the inflation-adjusted minimum in the 1960's, but it would bring minimum wage workers closer to the wage level of more skilled workers than at any time since 1979.
The comparison point used by most economists is workers earning 10 percent below the median hourly wage, a group that in skills is clearly a step or two above those earning the minimum. By the year 2000, that group is likely to be making just over $10 an hour, and the $6.15 would be roughly 60 percent of this amount, about the same ratio as in 1979, says Jared Bernstein of the Economic Policy Institute.
Mr. Bernstein argues that closing the gap is all to the good, because it would help reduce the issue of wage inequality and help "insure that low-wage workers get a fairer share of the economic growth."
But other economists wonder whether the higher minimum would squeeze some unskilled Americans out of jobs, or make their search for jobs harder and longer. That question came up in the 1970's but has never been resolved. Two labor economists in particular have drawn attention to this concern: Alan Krueger of Princeton University and David Card of the University of California at Berkeley.
They were big advocates of raising the minimum in 1996, and they favor the bill introduced today on the ground that the pluses would faroutweigh the minuses. In a study several years ago centered on Pennsylvania and New Jersey, Mr. Krueger and Mr. Card had found that lifting the minimum, far from causing job loss, actually increased the employment of minimum wage-workers. That study played a featured role in passage of the 1996 bill.
Other economists argue that passing the tipping point can help the economy by forcing employers into efficiencies they can ignore when labor is relatively inexpensive. Even opponents of another increase in the minimum wage agree that employment would rise, with the minimum at $6.15 an hour, as long as the economy remains as strong as it is today.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Unemployment Rate Rises in New York

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
The unemployment rates in New York City and the state continued to rise in February, state labor officials reported yesterday.
The statewide unemployment rate last month was 6.8 percent, up from 6.6 percent in January. It was lower than the 7.1 percent recorded in February 1997. 
 In the city, the unemployment rate of 9.2 percent in February was up from 8.9 percent in January, but down from 10.2 percent in February 1997. Outside New York City, the state's jobless rate held constant at 5.2 percent, the same as in January and in February 1997.
Officials noted that private-sector jobs throughout the state grew by 126,800, or 2 percent, between February 1997 and last month. That increase marks the third-highest year-to-year growth in more than a decade, officials of the State Labor Department said.
Stephen Kagann, the state's chief economist, said the latest data demonstrate "more of the same, solid, reliable job growth that has been occurring in recent months, only better."
Mr. Kagann said that upstate New York is showing a continued strength in durable goods manufacturing. Downstate, job growth has been fueled by retailing and business services along with finance and tourism, he said.
But New York's jobless rate was still well above the national unemployment level of 5.0 percent, down by 0.2 percentage points since January.

HEADLINE: Rowland Asks $350 Million In Aid to Rebuild Hartford

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, March 19

 BODY:
In a step toward delivering on the urban agenda he promised two years ago, Gov. John G. Rowland today proposed a $350 million package to revive downtown Hartford.
The proposal calls for the largest package of state money to any Connecticut city in a series of urban development projects that Mr. Rowland has announced over the last year. It comes as leaders of this beleaguered capital, which was the nation's fastest shrinking city in the early 1990's, contend that it is about to turn the corner on its economic problems and begin a renaissance. 
 Although downtown Hartford still lacks amenities like supermarkets, commercial movie theaters and department stores, the Governor and top business executives today painted a picture of hundreds of middle-class professionals and college students flocking there, ending the area's reputation as a business district that is often empty after 5 P.M.
Mr. Rowland, a Republican, released a report that pinpointed six projects that would serve as a blueprint for downtown's growth. The projects would use state money to attract Federal, city and private money for a total of $1.3 billion in development money.
"It is now Hartford's time," Mr. Rowland said. "The city has been stagnant too long. Companies are hiring again. We're going to take this opportunity and run with it."
The proposal, which depends on the State Legislature for approval, was developed by an eight-person advisory committee of Mr. Rowland's aides, top business executives and civic leaders. It calls for the following projects:
*$50 million for a higher education center that would move two community college campuses to downtown and would provide space to a consortium of local universities for graduate programs;
*$155 million for a convention center and sports megaplex, which might include a domed stadium for college football and other events;
*$105 million to improve parking and to develop 1,000 housing units in the downtown area, which currently has little residential space;
*$25 million to encourage improvements in the downtown area bordering the Connecticut River;
*$15 million to spruce up the Hartford Civic Center, a complex that includes a 15,000-seat arena and a food and shopping complex.
Mr. Rowland first highlighted the importance of revitalizing the state's cities in his 1996 budget address, but he did not immediately take action. At the time, the mayors of several Connecticut cities wondered whether his talk of an urban agenda was more political posturing than a serious commitment.
In the last year, as the state's economy has rebounded and its coffers have grown, Mr. Rowland has established redevelopment projects in Bridgeport, New Haven, Waterbury and New London.
The proposal for Hartford is not entirely new. There has been talk of a convention center for months. The effort to improve the riverfront has been going on for a few years.
What sets apart today's announcement is that for the first time all of the projects have been rolled together into one blueprint.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
Simply Living His Life, Trying to Be Honest And Solve Some Crimes

BYLINE: By WILL JOYNER 

 BODY:
One of the many strengths of Walter Mosley's mystery novels is that his hero, Easy Rawlins, is an anti-detective, negotiating the blind alleys and smoky back rooms of Los Angeles not so much as a solver of cases but as an illuminator of the moral ambiguities of the post-World War II era. Socrates Fortlow, the primary character in a collection of Mosley short stories, follows a similar path across the burned-out, paved-over landscape of contemporary South-Central Los Angeles, but in the film "Always Outnumbered," he's portrayed in such compelling fashion by Laurence Fishburne that he becomes something other than just an Easy Rawlins for a less romantic time.
The movie, which will have its premiere on HBO tonight at 9, was directed by Michael Apted ("Coal Miner's Daughter," "Gorillas in the Mist") from a mostly eloquent screenplay by Mr. Mosley. Its cast also includes notables like Bill Cobbs, Natalie Cole, Laurie Metcalf, Bill Nunn and Cicely Tyson. It has the assured feel of a project on which everyone was working from the same page, with a common degree of commitment, and that's some accomplishment given that the narrative is driven by a series of ethically charged situations rather than one clear-cut plot. 
 Socrates is an intensely focused, physically imposing ex-convict who awakes each morning, carefully tends to the maintenance of the hovel in which he lives alone, then sets out after that almost impossible dream known as an honest living. This means he collects bottles and soda cans to redeem for a few dollars while fruitlessly applying for supermarket jobs. Along the way, he nurses his identity by confronting petty managers with an angry articulateness and by standing up for, and advising, an assortment of characters less able than he -- most prominently, Right Burke (Mr. Cobbs), an ailing pensioner; Lula (Ms. Cole), who serves food out of the shell of a school bus; Darryl (Daniel Williams), a wayward boy who has witnessed a murder, and Howard and Corina (Mr. Nunn and Brigid Coulter), an ambitious couple whose marriage is being ruined by unemployment.
In less skillful hands, the situations presented by these secondary characters would be dominated by liberal bromides or predictable acts of vigilantism. While there are small examples of each of these pitfalls, "Always Outnumbered" for the most part is surprising in the ways that it resolves its moral predicaments or allows them to remain unresolved.
As the viewer is regularly reminded through grisly flashbacks, Socrates is a man who was convicted of manslaughter and must, above all, try to decipher his own flawed nature, not only society's. (Much is made of the name he has been saddled with, in a wry, self-debunking manner.) Mr. Fishburne is uncanny in his ability to come across both as a real, all-too-troubled person and as a larger-than-life presence whose observations, however homespun, are stabs at truth. After Socrates catches Darryl in the act of stealing and killing a chicken, for example, he rather brutally forces the boy to pluck and dismember the body, but then also gives a lesson in how to cook a nourishing meal. "A boy should be hungry," Socrates says. "It means something's missing. And hungry tells you what it is."
Although "Always Outnumbered" wanders across a range of contemporary social concerns by intention, it is fortunate that the film is integrated not only by Mr. Fishburne's fine performance but also by a voice-over, in Mr. Cobbs's deep, jazzy bass, that reflects on Socrates's odd place in the world. "Rich men would never have that power," the older man says of Socrates's attempt to lead a loving, dignified life. "And precious few lovers would be that satisfied."
 
ALWAYS OUTNUMBERED
HBO, tonight at 9
 
Directed by Michael Apted and based on the Walter Mosley book "Always Outnumbered, Always Outgunned." Laurence Fishburne and Walter Mosley, executive producers; Anne-Marie McKay and Jonathan Ker, producers; Jeff Downer, co-producer. Produced by Palomar Pictures and HBO NYC.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
The Cultural Revolution

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
China may soon let out a few dissidents to appease the U.S. before President Clinton's June visit. This should be taken with a grain of salt, because more dissidents can just be arrested. Fortunately, though, the dissidents are not the only agents of change here. In fact, they aren't even the most important ones. The most important ones are those whom the Government doesn't know, and can't arrest, but who represent powerful trends that, over time, will force the Chinese Government to either loosen its grip or risk instability.
Xu Guilan is a 56-year-old schoolteacher from Heng Dao. In her village, like others, you find many successful peasant farmers' families living in three attached houses: The first is a small mud-brick hovel where the family lived under Mao, the second is a larger red-brick structure, built under Deng Xiaoping, and the third is a white-brick home with painted tiles around the front door, built in the Jiang Zemin era. 
 "Because of Deng Xiaoping we are getting richer," Mrs. Xu explained. "Both my sons work in the town now, one in a bank, one as a teacher. The big change for my family is that we have a color TV. My mother died 10 years ago. She liked to watch TV. If only she had lived 10 more years, she would have seen the color TV."
There are millions of Xu Guilans in China today. As long as the economy soars, the Government can get away with just liberalizing the economics and not politics. But sooner or later this economy will slow. There will be pain. That's when China will need a government that is legitimate and can say to its people, "We're all in this together," and will allow people to let off steam. Democratization is critical for managing the down cycles. God help Beijing if Mrs. Xu's sons lose their jobs in the town and have to return to the village. They'll be as dangerous as dissidents.
Zhu Zhuohong is the village chief of Zhen Zi, a fishing village. He won re-election with pure pork-barrel politics. Using income from the town's factory, which processes seaweed and scallops, he was able to pave the road into the village, build a new village center, set up a kindergarten, remodel the school, get tap water into everyone's home and provide a stipend for everyone over age 60. "Almost 95 percent of the money for these projects comes from the sea," he said, referring to the town's profitable fishery.
Well, the longer Mr. Zhu gets 95 percent of his income from the sea and 5 percent from Beijing the more independent he becomes from Beijing. That is the beginning of decentralization, and it's going on in villages all over China.
Wang Hongzhe is a 49-year-old farmer in the village of Hou Shi. His house is small, but he has a stereo and television. I asked him if he wouldn't like a telephone. "You only need a phone if you're going to be a leader," he said. "But I hope I will have one in five years, after my son gets married." Every Chinese villager we met had a television -- which is one-way communication from the Government to the people. But many, like Mr. Wang, would like phones and are getting them. Phones are two-way communications -- from people to people. When China's 900 million villagers get phones, and start calling each other, this will inevitably become a more open country.
Lastly, there is my friend's cook. His salary is $200 a month. And every morning before work he goes down to the Beijing stock exchange to buy and sell stocks. Some 25 million Chinese now own stock. The Chinese stock markets are poorly regulated and casino-like. Unless the Government installs some real regulatory systems, one day they are going to crash. The biggest urban riots in China in the past few years have been led by disgruntled stockholders.
These four people, and the trends they embody, are dots on the Chinese landscape -- dots that will create pressure for a more open, law-based society. They raise two questions: When will a Chinese leader decide that to maintain the stability of China he has to connect these dots with lines that constitute a framework for democratic transition? And even if someone connects the dots, and makes a framework for a more democratic China, who will fill in the contents?
Ultimately, you can't have democracy without democrats. But where will they come from? One of the most striking things about China today is the ideological vacuum left by the death of Communism. Some Chinese are trying to turn to religion or superstition; others opt for the most crass, unrestrained materialism. Talk of making money is everywhere (partly because that's all people are allowed to talk about). China also never had a British colonial administration, a la India or Hong Kong, or American neocolonialism, a la Japan and South Korea, that could leave behind an elite and a bureaucracy steeped in liberal constitutionalism.
China has gone from Mao to Milken, without ever stopping at Madison. That's going to be a problem.

HEADLINE: BRIDGE;
Lazard Is Overtaken At Open Pairs

BYLINE: By Alan Truscott 

DATELINE: RENO, March 20

 BODY:
For 3,000 players, today is the start of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring National Championships, which will last for 10 days. But for 56 players, it is the end of the North American Open Pair Championship, which began at the local level in the fall. The winners, in a close finish Thursday night, were Ron Sukoneck of Annandale, Va., and Bill Cole of Beltsville, Md.
The standings were: Sukoneck and Cole, 407.37 match points; Marshall Tuly and James Cunningham, 397.32; Roger McNay and Troy Horton, 394.84; Steve Cohen and Beverly Rosenberg, 390.05. 
Leading into the final two sessions were Sidney Lazard Sr. and Iype Koshy, both of New Orleans, but they suffered a setback on the diagramed deal against Henry Lortz and Wyen Ohlrich of Seattle. Four spades was bid and made at many tables. But in third seat, Lazard opened four diamonds, which was a transfer to hearts. Now Koshy had to suffer in four hearts and received a spade lead. He is sure to lose one diamond trick, and the contract hinges on the number of trump losers.
He won in dummy with the ace and led a low trump. This was inferior to the lead of the king or queen, but the result should have been the same. It would have been all over if East had played low, allowing his partner to score the ten, but he put up the jack, fearing that South held the ten.
But the defense still had a winning path, and they found it. East played a second spade, won in dummy. He ducked when the heart king was led, but captured the queen on the next round. Then he underled his diamonds, and West was able to win and give his partner the crucial spade ruff. That proved to be the only plus score for East-West.
Peter Mallela, a retired professor of economics at Northern Illinois University, was kibitzing and noted an elegant communications-cutting play maneuver that the players had overlooked. If South plays a diamond at the second trick, removing West's diamond entry before he can make good use of it, he cannot be defeated, provided he plays the king and queen of hearts to kill the ten. The defense will be limited to one diamond and two trump tricks. This was one of the rare occasions in which "the onlooker sees most of the game."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
The Dow Tops 8,900 to End Solid Week

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Investors paid some attention to bad news yesterday, but not much.
The Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500 index each rose to their fifth consecutive records. Technology shares, however, faltered amid new alerts about quarterly earnings. 
 The Dow average rose 103.38 points, or 1.17 percent, to 8,906.43, its first close above 8,900. The S.& P. 500 gained 9.42 points, to 1,099.16.
Volume was extremely heavy, partly because of increased trading from the expiration of options and futures. More than 717.3 million shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange, the fourth-highest level this year and the seventh highest ever.
Investors "just don't want to quit," said Alan Ackerman, a senior vice president and market strategist at Fahnestock & Company. "Many stock buyers believe that 1998 may be the third consecutive year for 20 percent-plus gains despite a slowing corporate earnings outlook."
The Dow average finished the week with a gain of 303.91 points, or almost 4 percent. The S.& P. 500 ended the week with a gain of 30.57 points, up almost 3 percent.
The Dow set five consecutive daily records in several weeks during the last few years, said David Stevens, an analyst at Birinyi Associates, an equity research firm in Greenwich, Conn. The last time was the week that began June 9, 1997. Other such gains came in November and February 1996, May 1995 and in two consecutive weeks that ended Jan. 16, 1987, Mr. Stevens said.
But after those record-breaking runs, the Dow settled into a less sanguine mode. On average, in the weeks after such gains, the Dow was "generally neutral with a positive bias," Mr. Stevens said.
Ending two consecutive days of setting records, the Nasdaq composite index fell 10.82 points, to 1,789.16. Although it finished lower yesterday, the Nasdaq composite index was up 17.5 points, or 1 percent, for the week.
Contributing to the malaise in technology, Dallas Semiconductor fell more than 10 percent. Investors were reacting to disclosures by the company, a chip manufacturer, that first-quarter earnings and revenue would fall short of expectations because of weak demand in Asia.
The warning, announced after the market closed on Thursday, helped drag down other semiconductor shares yesterday, including Intel and Micron Technology. The announcement was the latest in a round of warnings from technology companies and others about unexpectedly weak earnings this quarter.
Jabil Circuit and Arrow Electronics both warned investors this week that profits would be disappointing. Also, Sunbeam and Rockwell International said that profits could fall short of forecasts.
"The semiconductor group keeps blowing up," said Steven Milunovich, a computer analyst at Merrill Lynch. "I think there's been surprise among investors that the stocks have held up as well as they have."
The worst may not be over for technology investors, Mr. Milunovich said. "I believe there are more" companies that will warn of disappointments before the quarterly earnings reporting period begins in late April, he said.
Despite the declines in technology issues, investor optimism buoyed oil, financial and telecommunications stocks, which provided the lift for the Dow and the S.& P.
While oil prices ended little changed yesterday, investors were encouraged by the price rebound this week from nine-year lows as expectations grew that further declines were unlikely.
"The stocks are telling you the price is not going to stay low," said Andrew M. Brooks, vice president in charge of equity trading at T. Rowe Price Associates.
Mobil led oil stocks higher. Others that gained included Chevron, British Petroleum, Exxon, Royal Dutch/ Shell and Amoco.
Investor optimism was also reflected in the broader market's gains.
"Cash flow, the economy, Asia is covered," Mr. Brooks said. "Put whatever spin you want on it. People are believers."

Treasury Prices Up a Bit
 (Bloomberg News) -- The prices of Treasury securities rose slightly yesterday amid optimism that inflation would not accelerate soon, even as the economy grows at a brisk pace.
The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose 4/32, or $1.25 for a $1,000 bond, to 103 13/32, yielding 5.88 percent, down from 5.89 on Thursday.
Bonds also got a lift as the dollar rose against the German mark amid expectations that German interest rates will not rise, traders said. Higher German rates would tend to draw international investment to mark-denominated securities.
The yield on the 10-year Treasury note, at 5.56 percent, is 69 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, higher than the 4.87 percent yield on the benchmark German 10-year bond.
This week's favorable news about inflation also helped Treasury securities. The Government said on Thursday that consumer prices rose just one-tenth of a percent last month, and only three-tenths of a percent, excluding food and energy. For the 12 months through February, prices rose 1.4 percent -- the slowest pace since 1986.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Defying Pressure, Tokyo Scrimps on Budget

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 20

 BODY:
Japan's lower house of Parliament passed the nation's budget today, approving a $600 billion plan that could squeeze money out of the economy just as it is careening toward recession.
But the approval today also creates a basis for politicians to discuss more openly their long-awaited plans to spend more money to strengthen the economy, which forecasters say is likely to record its worst annual performance in nearly a quarter-century when the fiscal year ends this month. Despite criticism from the United States and other countries, Japan has insisted on tightening its fiscal belt. 
 Now that the budget has passed, officials will be more free to push for a supplementary budget that presumably will include stimulants. There is still uncertainty, however, whether the stimulants can revive Japan's economy, bolster the rest of Asia and deflect complaints from the United States.
The budget passed today symbolizes the austerity that has so antagonized the United States. Recent data show that prices, wages and corporate profits are declining, that business confidence is at a record low and that the economy is expected to register near-zero growth, or possibly shrink, this fiscal year.
Many economists say Japan must spend more on the economy or offer tax cuts to encourage consumers or corporations to spend more. But Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto and other senior leaders have at least created the impression that they are dithering and say that drastic measures are inappropriate.
"It may look like we are taking a long time, but the economy is a living creature, and it is complex," Taku Yamasaki, the top policy maker in the governing Liberal Democratic Party, said in an interview today. "We have to be cautious."
"Even if you remove the cancer cells in an operation, it would be no use if the patient dies," Mr. Yamasaki said. "If people judge that this doctor cannot cure the illness, then they can change the doctor, which is currently the Hashimoto administration."
Mr. Yamasaki, however, also said any change in the administration could damage the economy by creating a "political vacuum."
The budget is slightly larger than the budget for the previous year, but in fact, the budget will be a force for contraction, withdrawing as much as $30 billion from the economy, according to several economists.
The tightening, for instance, might be felt immediately by construction companies, which may see their orders for new projects drop, as the Government's spending on public works declines by 7.8 percent from the previous year. Such a decline siphons funds from the economy.
That makes the supplementary budget more important, but it could not be openly debated until now. A draft of stimulus measures, anticipated next week, is expected to include spending of perhaps $78 billion, or about 2 percent of the nation's economic output. Even this may not be enough, however.
Economists are concerned that the package will include loans and other items that represent about half of the $78 billion total but do not actually inject money into the economy. That would mean the supplementary budget might add only $30 billion to $40 billion.
"First they pass the initial budget, which takes money out of the economy, and then they pass a supplementary budget that puts it in," said Jeffrey D. Young, head economist in Japan at Salomon Brothers Asia Ltd. "It all adds up to a neutral stance."
The bulk of the spending is expected to go into infrastructure projects in telecommunications, like fiber optic cables. But other projects could include a national sewage system, homes for the aged, and programs for industrial waste, education and the multimedia industry.

HEADLINE: Geography Redux: Where You Live Is What You Are

BYLINE: By PATRICIA COHEN 

 BODY:
Pick up a geography textbook from the first half of this century and you can discover a simple rule-of-thumb explanation for the varying fates of the human race: the weather.
"As a rule, people do their best thinking and planning, their minds are most alert and inventive, and they have the best judgment when the thermometer out of doors falls toward freezing at night and rises toward 50 degrees or 55 degrees by day," declares Ellsworth Huntington in "Principles of Human Geography." "In an invigorating climate" -- like that of Europe and the northern United States -- "it may also be easier to be honest and sober and self-controlled than in a more enervating one." 
 Such pronouncements ultimately made geographers seem like phrenologists who pondered the size of bumps on a person's skull. Most serious scholars shunted geography aside and forgot it.
Yet after decades of neglect, geography is being rediscovered. The study of how location affects the way people live is not only drawing in new students, it is also attracting the attention of scholars in other fields. Historians, economists and political scientists are using it to explain everything from why some nations are rich and others poor, to why Brazil and Nigeria are rising as regional powers, to why Africa produces so many superior distance runners. It's as if New York City real estate agents were suddenly given the job of explaining some of the globe's most elusive questions and chorused: Location, location, location.
The geographic renaissance, propelled in part by new advances in science and computers, is significant, scholars say, because it is generating a new intellectual dialogue. "It is a wonderful bridge among disciplines," David Landes, professor emeritus of history and economics at Harvard University, said in an interview. "It compels people to put together ideas they might not otherwise."
Most unexpected, however, is that the very field that had a racialist taint is now being used to knock down theories that define achievement in racial terms. Geography, once employed to justify colonialism and the innate superiority of whites, is brought in to undermine works like "The Bell Curve," which argues that racial differences in intelligence are inherited and linked to differences in performance and economic success.
The gradual eclipse of geography began 50 years ago when Harvard University eliminated its geography department. The decision had less to do with discomfort over screwball theories (which weren't necessarily seen at the time as screwball) than with academic infighting and weak teaching. "Geography is not a university subject," declared James B. Conant, who was then the president of Harvard.
In the next decades, other universities followed Harvard's lead: Stanford, Yale, the University of Michigan, Columbia, the University of Chicago. According to a report in the Chronicle of Higher Education on the 1987 meeting of the Association of American Geographers, department chairmen organized a seminar "to find out what they could do to avoid finding their departments on a university hit list."
Saul Cohen, a political geographer and former president of the geographers' association, says: "Very few people were exposed to geography who went to college after the 1960's. What they knew about it goes back a half century."
 
Quietly Wiped Out As a Discipline
French historians like Fernand Braudel and other members of the Annales school did look at geography, climate and land use. But in the United States, said Mr. Landes, geography was "a kind of outcast among intellectual disciplines." He continued: "More than any other field I can think of, geography was wiped out kind of quietly. I can't think of another discipline that suffered this sort of erasure."
Geography was fine if you worked at Rand McNally or played Jeopardy (Moroni. What is the capital of Comoros?). But when American scholars tackled persistent questions like why industrialization first took root in Europe instead of China or India, geography was played down. "If you look at most works on global development," Mr. Landes says, "there is very little on geography."
That has been changing. Jared Diamond, a physiologist at the University of California at Los Angeles, combines epidemiology, sociology, zoology, anthropology and botany to conclude that geography is the key to the pace and timing of economic development.
In his book "Guns, Germs and Steel" (W.W. Norton, 1997) he goes back 13,000 years to explain how food production is the starting point for success. Because farming communities produce more food and domesticate animals, they can feed non-food producers like professional soldiers, bureaucrats, writers and craftsmen.
Mr. Diamond argues that the east-west axis of Eurasia's land mass meant a shared latitude and similar growing conditions, which enabled one of the first domesticated crops, einkorn wheat, to spread relatively quickly from the Fertile Crescent to Europe; more than twice as fast, for example, as corn and beans spread from Mexico northward to what would become the eastern United States.
Fewer ecological barriers like mountains also made it much easier for livestock and, eventually, writing, the wheel and other inventions to spread than in the Americas or Africa, which both have a north-south axis. For example, cattle, sheep and goats, first domesticated in the Fertile Crescent, stopped short for 2,000 years at the northern edge of the Serengeti Plains, with their deadly, disease-carrying tsetse flies. And of the 14 large mammals domesticated before the 20th century, Eurasia had 13 of them, including sheep, goats, cows and horses, which provided meat, fertilizer, wool, leather, transport, plowing power and military assault vehicles.
Domesticated animals also served as the petri dish for nasty epidemics like smallpox and measles to which Europeans over time developed immunity. So when the Europeans arrived in the New World, up to 99 percent of the unexposed native populations were killed -- instead of the reverse. It wasn't virtuosity but viruses that helped paved the way for conquest.
 
Setting the Stage For Growth
Building on Max Weber's "The Protestant Ethic and the Spirit of Capitalism," Mr. Landes believes that Western culture based on Judeo-Christian and Enlightenment values is the single most important reason for the West's economic success. Still, maintaining that geography is "terribly important," he has titled the first chapter of his new book, "The Wealth and Poverty of Nations" (W. W. Norton, 1998) "Nature's Inequalities," and describes how a nation's geography -- its rainfall, its suitability for food production, its indigenous animals and the deadliness of its pathogens -- helps set the stage for economic success.
Europe was lucky. He, too, argues that the temperate climate and relatively even rainfall, a gift from the Gulf Stream, allowed Europeans to grow crops all year round. In addition to the other advantages, larger and stronger animals like the European battle steed instead of the Mongolian pony provided richer fertilizer than, say, the human night soil used in East Asia.
 
A Great Windfall Of Gold and Silver
James Blaut, who wrote "The Colonizer's Model of the World: Geographic Diffusionism and Eurocentric History" (Guilford Press, 1993), also takes a geographical tack, but comes to a completely different conclusion. He declares Europeans got rich because they were closest to the Americas and able to plunder it first.
In the 16th century, says Mr. Blaut, who teaches at the University of Illinois at Chicago, other maritime societies like those of "the Chinese, the Indians, and the East Africans were at the same level of development, but the Europeans were much, much closer to the New World."
Through a combination of looting and mining, the amount of gold and silver in circulation probably doubled between the years 1500 and 1600, says Mr. Blaut, and Europe got it all free. That tremendous windfall meant that the emerging middle class could buy off the ruling land-owning powers, enabling capitalism to take root and allowing the Europeans to outcompete Asia and East Africa. A shorter commute made all the difference.
Geography's sudden comeback is due in part to technological advances. Sophisticated mapping computers known as geographical information systems have generated new research areas for freshly minted geographers and raised the discipline's profile. A report last year by the National Research Council estimated that the number of undergraduate geography majors increased by 47 percent between 1986 and 1994. At the same time, advances in molecular biology, radiocarbon dating and archeology are providing new information about where cultivated crops, domesticated animals and diseases originated and where they spread. And economists are exploring statistical correlations between such things as poverty and distance from the equator.
Geography also complements the turn to interdisciplinary studies that is catching on at universities across the country. "Geography is the integrating field par excellence." Mr. Blaut observed.
Another trend has coincided with geography's comeback: using genetics to explain behavior. Geography provides a new wrinkle to the nature vs. nurture, or biology vs.culture debate. Some scholars are using geography to help provide a counterweight to what they see as a crude biological determinism implying, for example, that Europeans won out because of some inbred superiority.
In his introduction, Mr. Diamond offers this one-sentence summary of his 480-page book: "History followed different courses for different people because of differences among peoples' environments, not because of biological differences among people themselves." At its publication, "Guns, Germs and Steel" was praised for rebutting "racist theories" of history.
 
The Making Of Marathoners
Historical questions aren't the only ones that have enlisted geography to balance genetic explanations. The Swedish physiologist Bengt Saltin, for example, has studied Kenyan distance runners to find why so many excel at the sport. He found they have a muscle composition similar to that of Nordic athletes who train in similar conditions, at high altitudes and in hilly regions, according to a recent article in the New Yorker. Geography may be the critical variable, not genes.
With all the new attention on geography, some scholars warn against crediting it with too much. "I think there are societies in which geography is very formative and times when it's not," says the economic historian Robert Heilbroner. "I wouldn't make it a very high priority."
So geography is not destiny any more than genetics or culture is. But after years of neglect, it offers a useful reminder: Location matters.

HEADLINE: Boeing to Cut 8,200 Jobs By Year 2000

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
The Boeing Company said yesterday that it would eliminate 8,200 jobs by the turn of the century as it consolidates its North American operations in the wake of two recent multibillion-dollar acquisitions that have transformed it into the world's largest military and civilian aerospace company.
More than two-thirds of the cuts, or 6,200 jobs, will be in Southern California at the operations of the former McDonnell Douglas Corporation, which Boeing bought for $16.3 billion last year. An additional 1,700 jobs will be eliminated at Boeing operations in Philadelphia and Toronto, with additional, smaller cuts around the United States. But Illinois and Texas will see the creation of 550 new jobs as a result of the reorganization. 
 The cuts are in addition to 12,000 jobs Boeing previously said it would begin eliminating this year at its civilian airplane division in the Seattle area.
Investors and Wall Street analysts were pleasantly surprised by yesterday's announcement because Boeing said that it would not take a charge against earnings to cover the cost of the cuts, something many analysts had assumed. Boeing shares rose $2 yesterday, closing at $53.4375 on the New York Stock Exchange.
But yesterday's news also came at a time when a number of analysts are predicting that Boeing will fall short of its plan to deliver 115 commercial jets in the quarter ending this month, a sign that the company may not be as close as it says it is to overcoming production problems that have plagued it since last fall. Those difficulties resulted in the announcement of $2.6 billion in charges and the company's first annual loss in 50 years.
Since it acquired McDonnell Douglas and the aerospace and military operations of Rockwell International, Boeing now makes not only the 747 jumbo jet and other commercial airliners, but also the space shuttle, the F/A-18 fighter plane, Delta rockets and more. The new job cuts will result from an attempt to streamline these disparate operations and deliver the $1 billion in savings that the company said would result from the acquisitions. By consolidating various operations, Boeing hopes to shed 18 million square feet of real estate by 2000.
The company said it was difficult to tell how many of the jobs would be eliminated by layoffs rather than attrition.
Most of the jobs that will be eliminated do not involve production lines of airplanes for which Boeing has had bottlenecks. The bulk of the cuts in California will result from Boeing's previously announced decision to stop producing the MD-80 and MD-90 jets, which it inherited from McDonnell Douglas, next year.
News of the cuts comes on the heels of the loss of thousands of other jobs in California as a result of cutbacks by the Raytheon Corporation and of the acquisition of H. F. Ahmanson & Company by Washington Mutual Inc., two of the largest savings and loans in the region. But California's economy has recovered strongly from a deep recession in the early 90's and is now producing new jobs at a rate of 105,000 a month, according to Jack Kyser, the chief economist at the Economic Development Corporation of Los Angeles County.
"Announcements like these are never good news," he said. "But the irony is that our high-tech sector has been growing recently."
Boeing will continue to assemble the new 100-seat 717 jet, formerly the MD-95, in Long Beach and has said it will also continue to produce the wide-body MD-11 there as well, if it can drum up enough orders. A Boeing statement said the company would have "a clearer picture" of the plane's future later this year.
"Right now we are only building one a month," said Larry McCracken, a Boeing spokesman. "We are going to need to do better than that."
Stopping production of the MD-11 would probably result in the loss of another 3,000 jobs in California and 1,900 in Toronto, where the plane's wings are made.
Meanwhile, Boeing is still struggling to overcome its production problems. A spokeswoman for Southwest Airlines said Boeing notified it about two weeks ago that delivery of one of the three new 737's it promised to provide in March would slip into April. Production of the planes, which Boeing calls the 737 Next Generation, has been backed up by parts shortages and design changes requested by American and European regulators. Several planes are sitting outside a plant near Seattle waiting to be completed.
Boeing delivered only 61 planes in January and February. That means 54 planes must be delivered in March for the company to meet its estimate.
"It is going to be a real push," said Byron K. Callan, an aerospace analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company. Missing the target would send yet another negative signal to Wall Street, he added. "You have investors who would like to see them overshoot what they have been promising rather than undershoot it."
A Boeing spokesman said the company often rushed to meet production at the end of the quarter. The company plans to discuss the status of its production problems during a monthly conference call on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Taking the Pope's Cue on Cuba

 BODY:
The Helms-Burton law limits President Clinton's power to modify the American economic embargo on Cuba. But yesterday Mr. Clinton made good use of his executive authority to help religious and charitable groups, as well as Cuban-Americans, deliver more humanitarian aid to Cuba's people. Any easing of the outdated and increasingly counterproductive embargo is welcome, especially in humanitarian areas. Relief from abroad helps the independent sectors emerging in Cuban society distance themselves from the Castro Government.
The President's actions restore charter relief flights, simplify licensing for donations of medicine and medical devices and permit Cubans here to send up to $1,200 a year to relatives on the island. They come in direct response to Pope John Paul II's January visit to Cuba. The Pontiff, while deploring Communist tyranny and Cuban restrictions on Catholicism, condemned the American embargo for reinforcing the harmful isolation of the Cuban people. Yesterday's moves are designed to help the Catholic Church ease that isolation by making it easier and cheaper for Catholic relief agencies and other organizations to dispense humanitarian assistance to Cuba. 
 The steps the Administration has taken are modest. They simply restore humanitarian provisions that were in effect when Mr. Clinton took office but were later suspended in response to Cuban actions. Yet partisans of the embargo condemned the restoration of these provisions as an unwarranted favor to Fidel Castro. But a bipartisan group of lawmakers would take the further, useful step of allowing American companies to sell food and medicine to Cuba.
There is at last positive movement in America's Cuba policy, spurred by the Pope's pilgrimage. Barring fresh provocations by Havana, the Administration and Congress should look for further ways to ease the embargo. That would help people in need and encourage forces trying to promote political change within Cuba.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

COUNTRY: CUBA (99%); UNITED STATES (97%);

HEADLINE: G.M. Pulls Out the Stops in Fight for Market Share

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 20

 BODY:
Surf through prime time television and you can count on many shows having one thing in common: they'll be interrupted by a lot of advertisements for General Motors' cars and trucks.
The company is trying to reverse a sharp decline in its market share this year and is hoping the onslaught of ads, some offering fresh rebates and heavily discounted financing, will lure buyers. 
 But as G.M. tries to improve sales, Wall Street is beginning to question whether the company's goal of expanding is merely wishful thinking. G.M. could have trouble even holding its current slice of the market if it suffers strikes this year, an increasing possibility with tensions now rising at several G.M. factories.
"It is going to get harder and harder and harder to rationalize this decline in market share," said Maryann N. Keller, an auto analyst at Furman Selz L.L.C., a New York investment banking and brokerage firm. G.M. ended the year with 31.3 percent of the car and truck market in the United States, down from 31.5 percent in 1996. In February, its share slid to 28.7 percent, a near-record low for a company that in its heyday in 1962 sold 51 percent of all new cars and trucks on American roads.
After February's dismal sales results, G.M. seems to be at a crossroads of sorts, having watched its market share slip below the psychological barrier of 30 percent. At issue is a simple question: Is the nation's largest company destined to shrink permanently? And if G.M. cannot manage to turn itself around and grow in today's strong economy, are its workers -- and its profits -- in jeopardy in the long run? The company's factories have the capacity to build about 33 percent of the nation's cars and trucks, considerably more than G.M. is now selling.
Executives insist the company will reverse course. "We fully expect our share to get better," said Ronald L. Zarrella, a vice president in charge of G.M.'s sales, service and marketing group. "We think we can still make money and still improve our share." G.M.'s lost sales have been picked up by a number of other auto makers: the Chrysler Corporation, foreign auto makers selling popular sport utility vehicles and Korean auto makers offering heavy discounts on their small cars have all benefited.
G.M.'s sales have been pulled down in part by the maker's many entries in the weak small-car market, so G.M. has increased discounts. "We can't lose any more share in small cars," Mr. Zarrella vowed.
Several G.M. divisions have recently scrambled to increase their sagging sales. Chevrolet executives rushed to market last week with heavily discounted financing rates and on Monday began heavy advertisements, instead of waiting until April for both as planned. "We thought it was time to get more aggressive," said John G. Middlebrook, general manager of the Chevrolet division. "We've got to tell people we've got the deals."
G.M.'s Pontiac/GMC division did the same. Oldsmobile this month is promoting interest rates as low as 1.9 percent. Buick added rebates for two models in March. Saturn began in mid-February to offer leases as low as $129 a month.
G.M. said it increased its overall ad spending in March compared with February, heavily advertising during the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament and highlighting G.M. vehicles during nearly every commercial break in the USA network's hit movie this week, "Moby Dick." Nielsen Media Research said network television advertisements from G.M. and all of its divisions reached 910.6 million households during the first week of March, the most recent period available, up 25.6 percent from the corresponding period a year ago.
Even if the advertising and discounting onslaught help the company's sales this month, workers are worried about whether G.M. can keep it up. Even at Saturn, which can normally be counted on for labor peace, there was turmoil early this month.
G.M. is facing labor strife elsewhere. Workers at three parts factories in Michigan have authorized strikes unless negotiators can resolve their concerns. A strike at one of the factories, a metal fabricating plant in Grand Blanc, Mich., would halt production of most Cadillacs. A strike at a metal factory in Flint, Mich., would halt production of G.M.'s mini-vans and five large cars. G.M. refused to disclose what production would be halted by the potential strike at its Delphi subsidiary in Flint, Mich.
Last week, the head of G.M.'s North American operations, G. Richard Wagoner Jr., told Wall Street the company could face strikes soon because of the labor tensions, according to some auto analysts. G.M. disputed that account.
A G.M. spokesman said G.M. was facing labor troubles when the union was at peace with other auto companies because many of G.M.'s factories remained less efficient than the competition's. "We clearly have the greatest competitive gap to close and therefore we have some issues," said William J. O'Neill, executive director for G.M.'s North American communications.
So far, investors have not penalized G.M., despite its poor sales this year. In fact, G.M.'s stock has risen more than 20 percent this year, hitting a high two weeks ago of $74.25 and since trading down slightly to close yesterday at $70.8125, up 75 cents.
G.M. insists that it will soon grow again. Michael C. DiGiovanni, G.M.'s director of market research and forecasting, points to the 20 new cars and trucks the company plans to introduce in the next 18 months as reasons for optimism.
But G.M. has used that argument before. Two years ago, G.M. promised that it would halt its decades-long decline by replacing its least popular cars with new models -- 16 in the last 18 months. It pleaded with shareholders to be patient, and said G.M.'s market share would increase as soon as the new models had a chance to catch on.
Investors have been waiting, and waiting. But last year, after the new models finally reached the market, G.M.'s share edged down anyway.
