HEADLINE: Head of Financial Control Board for District of Columbia Resigns Under Fire

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 20

 BODY:
After months of public criticism about his management style, Andrew F. Brimmer said today that he would step down in June as chairman of the control board that has restored the financial stability of the District of Columbia over the last three years.
Mr. Brimmer, 71, a former member of the Federal Reserve Board, notified President Clinton of his decision in a letter, saying that, despite improvements throughout the city government, "the end of my term in June is the appropriate time" to leave. 
 "I indicated exactly the areas I was asked to concentrate on, finances and budget," Mr. Brimmer said of his one-page letter at an afternoon news conference. "I worked hard at it, and I'm very pleased. If you assess the city, it not only has turned the corner, but it has made genuine progress."
Congress created the control board in 1995 in response to the city's growing deficit and mounting problems with delivering services. President Clinton appointed its five members and named Mr. Brimmer chairman for his long and distinguished career as an economist.
But the timing of Mr. Brimmer's announcement today reflected the bumpiness of progress in Washington under the control board's direction. Mr. Brimmer told reporters that he had first broached the subject of his departure several months ago with Franklin D. Raines, the Federal budget director who, among Cabinet members, is most involved in District matters. Mr. Brimmer said he notified his board colleagues about a month ago.
But public disclosure came only after an article appeared today in The Washington Post, which said three other board members -- Vice Chairman Steven D. Harlan, Constance B. Newman and Joyce Ladner -- had decided to resign if Mr. Brimmer was appointed to another three-year term as chairman. The fifth member, Edward A. Singletary, has said he will step down under any circumstances.
Mr. Brimmer would not acknowledge the article at his news conference, and declined to discuss any friction with his colleagues, who stood silently behind him. They refused to take any questions.
But for more than a year, board members have periodically clashed with Mr. Brimmer, sometimes in public, saying that his decision-making was often too autocratic. He also drew fire from Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. and other elected officials, who gradually lost their power over most city agencies to the control board.
Since the control board began operating, Washington has had a chief financial officer who answers to the control board, rather than to the mayor. The public school system is run by an appointed board, rather than the elected school board. And a chief management officer accountable to the control board runs nine major city agencies that had been run by the mayor.
To many local officials, and residents who objected to the secretive nature of the board's decision-making, Mr. Brimmer came to personify the loss of home rule, which Congress granted the city in 1974.
In a statement thanking Mr. Brimmer for serving, Mr. Clinton made a veiled reference to the friction, saying that his service "at times, has been a difficult undertaking."
Despite any contentious relationships, the nation's capital has dramatically improved since the control board took over. Crime rates, while still higher than national averages, are falling. City agencies have been overhauled to improve service. And last year, for the first time in a decade, the city posted a budget surplus, $185 million. A $300 million surplus is projected for the current fiscal year.
By law, the control board goes out of operation after the city has balanced its budget four consecutive years.
"They should give him the key to the city," said Anthony Williams, the city's chief financial officer.
Acknowledging that Mr. Brimmer has taken "brickbats, spears and arrows," Mr. Williams described him as "the central architect of the District's financial recovery."
In his letter, Mr. Brimmer urged the President to persuade Ms. Newman, Ms. Ladner and Mr. Harlan to serve another term.
Mr. Clinton is not expected to nominate board members for the next three years until April or May.

HEADLINE: From Highflier to Downer;
Transformation Plans at Hoechst Are Losing Thrust

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, March 20

 BODY:
Until recently at least, Jurgen Dormann came as close as any German business executive to being a Wall Street darling.
Since taking charge of Hoechst A.G. in 1994, Mr. Dormann has won rave reviews for putting Hoechst, the huge chemicals conglomerate, through a breathtaking alchemy. He has been selling off the chemical businesses as fast as he can. He has spent billions to buy his way into the more profitable fields of pharmaceuticals and biotechnology. And he has slashed thousands of jobs and overhauled the bureaucracy. 
 Analysts repeatedly praised the strategy as bold, brilliant and fundamentally "Anglo-Saxon" in its hard-headed focus on profits. "Hoechst probably provides the prime example of changing corporate attitudes in Germany," wrote Peter Blair of Salomon Smith Barney last fall, praising the "Dormann revolution."
But now the revolution is sputtering. Investors hammered Hoechst shares last week after Mr. Dormann reported a big slide in profits and warned that this year will also be difficult. Meanwhile, managers in many divisions are demoralized and workers are draping flags with black crosses out their windows.
More embarrassing, Hoechst is being upstaged by unrevolutionary rivals like Bayer and BASF. Both have held onto their chemical businesses, and both reported big jumps in sales and profits this week. As the European bull market rages on, the shares of Hoechst lag woefully behind.
Most experts still contend that Mr. Dormann's strategy is sound. The question, though, is whether he can pull it off.
At the moment, Hoechst is caught, like a caterpillar trying to turn itself into a butterfly, between two worlds. It is well on his way out of the chemical business. But its future as a pharmaceuticals giant rests on a company cobbled together from three also-rans that desperately need a few blockbuster drugs.
The tribulations mark a uniquely cross-cultural business experience. Perhaps more than any other German executive, Mr. Dormann epitomizes the "new" European manager who has not only embraced American ideas about shareholder value and restructuring, but actually tried to carry them out. If he falters, it is only likely to add to the European backlash against the more ruthless, market-driven approach favored in business circles in the United States.
Indeed, Mr. Dormann's biggest fans have been Wall Street firms. Salomon Smith Barney; Goldman, Sachs, and Morgan Stanley have been among the most bullish enthusiasts on Hoechst in recent months, and all have scrambled to lower their estimates. Yet Hoechst has been far less popular with many German analysts.
At the heart of the storm is Mr. Dormann himself. An economist by training who was previously Hoechst's chief financial officer, he is a quiet and, some say, shy man. His office is nearly empty: a glass top desk, a glass conference table, chairs, a bookshelf in the far wall. "It's a cold office, a very cold office," one senior executive remarked.
Lately, Mr. Dormann has gone out of his way to emphasize bad news and deflate expectations. But when it comes to his strategy, he doesn't budge a smidgen.
"We said to ourselves, what is the most important business we have," Mr. Dormann said in a recent interview. "The value driver for Hoechst was and is the pharma business, and we had to decide whether to give these businesses priority."
Mr. Dormann is not alone in that strategy. Monsanto sold most of its chemical businesses to focus on life sciences. DuPont has been resisting pressure to do the same.
Yet the sheer scale of Mr. Dormann's attempted revolution dwarfs them all. In the last three years, he has sold or spun off companies worth billions of dollars, several of which have proved very successful in their new lives. SGL Carbon, once the loss-plagued subsidiary that made graphite chemical products, was floated as an initial public offering in 1995 and has seen its stock quadruple since then. Hoechst sold its remaining shares in a 1996 public offering that fetched about $1 billion.
Last year, Mr. Dormann orchestrated the sale of the specialty chemicals business to the Swiss company Clariant, which assumed more than 4 billion marks in liabilities and gave Hoechst a 45 percent stake in itself. Clariant's stock has also soared, and the Hoechst stake is worth about 3 billion marks, or about $1.6 billion. In the next year or two, he plans to sell or spin off most of the other chemical companies, including Celanese, the American supplier of basic chemicals.
Mr. Dormann's most significant move was to buy Marion Merrell Dow, a large but mediocre pharmaceutical company based in Kansas City, Mo., for $7.1 billion in 1995. He combined that with Hoechst's own drug business and the French manufacturer Roussel Uclaf, in which Hoechst had owned a majority stake since the 1970's.
But the newly merged company, Hoechst Marion Roussel, is a hodgepodge of old products and declining volumes. No one has said this more bluntly than the company's chief executive, Richard J. Markham.
"In 1997, we were the only company in the top 10 whose sales declined in real terms," he said as he presented results on March 11. "Our product line is older and more of our sales are of off-patent products than our competitors'."
Hoechst Marion Roussel's biggest product is Cardizem, a drug to relieve heart disorders, which had sales of $780 million last year. But Cardizem's patents are expiring and generic rivals will be on the market no later than mid-1999. Its other big product, a new allergy drug called Allegra, is booming but is largely replacing a similar drug called Seldane, which the company took off the market because of its side effects.
Those problems are not new. Mr. Markham, in hopes of emulating other successful pharmaceutical companies, has been rushing to refocus the company's research on developing a handful of drugs with blockbuster potential. But only two of those drugs are expected to receive approval from the United States Food and Drug Administration in 1998, and the company has been conservative about predicting their sales potential.
Meanwhile, the drug unit is fighting high costs and $6.1 billion of debt. Despite slashing 8,000 jobs worldwide last year, the company said in January that it would cut more than 1,000 research jobs this year. That move outraged workers and managers, who staged loud demonstrations at Hoechst and later began hanging black crosses out their windows.
But what rattled investors was Mr. Markham's warning about the year ahead. Acknowledging that the drug company's costs were still too high, he announced plans to set aside about $400 million next year to pay for another round of restructuring costs. After grilling Mr. Markham and other executives, moreover, many analysts concluded that the drug company would not meet its long-stated goal of generating a 20 percent profit margin in 1999.
In hindsight, it is now clear why Hoechst abruptly canceled its plans a year ago to spin off Hoechst Marion Roussel. Analysts say that it was simply in no shape to go public.
"I have had some of the most negative predictions of anybody, but even my estimates have been high," grumbled Jurgen Trojan, chemicals analyst at Deutsche Girozentrale, which supplies investment research to Germany's publicly owned banks.
Mr. Dormann acknowledged that Marion Merrell Dow had lackluster research, but he defended the acquisition. "Marion was never famous for research," he said. "We didn't buy Marion Merrill Dow because it had great products. This was an investment in infrastructure."
More specifically, Marion Merrell Dow had a huge United States marketing organization, as well as expertise in shepherding new drugs through the complex F.D.A. approval process.
Mr. Markham, an American who shuttles between New Jersey and Frankfurt, says the company's tough moves to focus on a handful of key drug projects will turn the company around.
"We are not doing as well as we should be," he said. "But I do know we have the building blocks to build a competitive firm."
Aside from pharmaceuticals, the other pillar of Hoechst's strategy is agricultural products developed through biotechnology. Four years ago, Mr. Dormann merged its various agrichemical operations into a 60-40 joint venture with Schering that is now called Agrevo. Agrevo, based on the Hoechst industrial complex, fortified its own research by buying a Dutch biotechnology company called Plant Genetic Systems, for about $600 million.
Revenues have climbed steadily from 3.6 billion marks in 1996 to 4 billion marks last year and profits are up to 194 million marks. But the real excitement is in genetically engineered crops, where Agrevo still lags. Its first big line of biotechnology products, a line of herbicide-resistent crops called Liberty Link, will face stiff competition from Monsanto's Round-up Ready products line.
Mr. Dormann argues that his company would be worse off if it had stayed the same. Unlike BASF , which has resolutely committed itself to chemicals, Hoechst has always had to buy the chemicals used to make plastics and resins.
"Believe me, if I were running BASF, I would do exactly what they are doing right now," he said.
To stay competitive, Mr. Dormann has argued, Hoechst would have had to spend billions of dollars on huge chemical crackers at a time when petrochemical companies have entered the industry from the other end of the production chain. So, while Mr. Dormann was a prime mover behind buying Celanese a decade ago, he is now engineering its sale.
"Yes, I admit it," he said with a smile. "I was the one behind buying Celanese. But what was right 10 years ago is not necessarily right today."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Austere Japan Budget Stirs Recession Fear
Japan's lower house of Parliament approved a budget that could squeeze money out of the economy just as the nation is careening toward a recession. Despite pleas from the United States and other trading partners of Japan, the budget provides no additional spending or tax cuts. 
 Economists have called such stimulants necessary for Japan's economy to escape prolonged stagnation. But Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto and other members of the dominant Liberal Democratic Party have said drastic action is inappropriate. There is also concern that a supplementary budget now under discussion may not help. Page D2.
 
Japanese workers will be getting raises but not as much as last year, based on negotiations that took place this week, revealing another sign of Japan's economic distress. D2.
 
Schlumberger Makes Russian Deal
Schlumberger, one of the world's leading oil service companies, will form a five-year alliance with Yuksi Oil, Russia's largest oil producer. The partnership, expected to be announced next Tuesday, will give Schlumberger management control over some Russian oilfields and could signal an end to Russia's historical resistance to outside management of its petroleum industry. D2.
 
The Clinton Administration is said to be backing away from imposing sanctions on European, Canadian, Russian and Asian energy companies that are investing in Iran, despite a law requiring such sanctions. A1.
 
Currency Plan Called Unrealistic
Indonesia's Finance Minister acknowledged that a plan favored by President Suharto to peg the country's currency to the dollar was not realistic. That appeared to remove one of the chief obstacles in discussions with the I.M.F. over disagreements that have stalled the release of $40 billion in economic assistance. A4.
 
Hewlett-Packard Plans Java Version
Hewlett-Packard will release its own version of Sun Microsystems' Java software, putting its stamp on -- but also possible creating another hurdle for -- the fledgling technology that aims to let programs run on any operating system. D3.
 
Treasury Prices Up a Bit
Treasury prices rose, with the 30-year bond yield slipping to 5.88 percent from 5.89. D3.
 
Porsche Thrives, Not Its Workers
Six years after flirting with bankruptcy, the renowned sports car maker Porsche has surged back into prosperity and its snappy new two-seat Boxster is a hit. But the company's fortunes have not trickled down to Porsche's workers, an example of the most striking economic trend in Germany: growth without jobs. A1.
 
Big Japanese Derivatives Loss
Yakult Honsha, a household name in Japan for its yogurt drink and professional baseball team, reported an $813 million loss on derivatives and other asset management transactions. The company's major creditor, Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank, said Yakult had the financial strength to absorb the losses. D2.
 
DePuy Buys Maker of Implant
DePuy, a maker of orthopedic devices and supplies, will buy privately held Acromed in a $325 million deal that will make the combined company one of the leading spinal implant manufacturers. DePuy's shares rose sharply on the news. D3.
 
Aftermath of Dodgers Sale
By voting so overwhelmingly to let Rupert Murdoch's Fox Group take possession of the Los Angeles Dodgers, major league baseball owners may have opened their clubhouse door even wider to less controversial media companies like Cablevision Systems, which has held discussions with the Yankees' principal owner, George Steinbrenner, about buying all or part of the club. C6.
 
New Cancer Treatment, in a Pill
Women whose advanced breast cancer has defied treatment may soon be able to take a pill called Xeloda, manufactured by Hoffman-La Roche, that promises to help shrink their incurable tumors. A11.

HEADLINE: CLINTON HESITATES TO PUNISH NATIONS FOR IRAN OIL DEALS

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 20

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is backing away from imposing sanctions on foreign energy companies that are investing in Iran, despite a law signed with great fanfare by President Clinton in 1996, senior American officials say.
The Administration hopes that the Asian financial crisis and the recent drop in oil prices will cause the two major deals at issue to collapse, and that the sensitive foreign policy problem will simply go away. 
 Even if that does not happen, the Administration is negotiating with the European Union to find enough cause under the law to waive the sanctions if they are imposed.
So Mr. Clinton has decided that he will make no decisions at least until he and the European Union conclude their summit meeting in mid-May, the officials say. Even if Mr. Clinton then imposes sanctions, he is expected to waive them, officials said.
The countries involved in the two deals at issue are France, Russia, Canada, Malaysia and Indonesia.
The United States wants to avoid an open confrontation with its European allies and with Russia, all of whom oppose Washington's efforts to punish their companies for doing business with Iran.
For the past six months, some of Washington's closest European allies have been pressing the Administration to drop or waive the sanctions, which they regard as illegal. They have threatened to challenge the legislation in the World Trade Organization.
Mr. Clinton is also courting European and Russian assistance to counter Iraq and to contain the crisis that has erupted in Kosovo, in Serbia, officials say. The Administration also wants Russia to ratify the second strategic arms reduction treaty.
Mr. Clinton, in seeking to improve relations with a changing Iran, wants to avoid any action that might undermine its new President, Mohammad Khatami. Mr. Khatami offers the prospect of a less confrontational Iran, and has said his country will stop supporting radical Islamic groups opposed to the Middle East peace talks.
Mr. Clinton is said to have been very impressed with a letter President Khatami sent, via the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, promising that Iran would respect any Middle East solution that the Palestinians accepted.
While American officials say they want proof that Iran has changed its policies on terrorism, on developing major weapons systems and on opposition to Mideast talks, they are also trying to bring Teheran into a Government-to-Government dialogue.
The law at issue is the 1996 Iran-Libya Sanctions Act, which was sponsored by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, and signed live on CNN by President Clinton. It was intended to reduce Iran's income, thus hindering Iran's support of terrorism and its weapons program. The law imposes sanctions on foreign companies that invest more than $20 million in Iran's energy sector, and is being challenged by two accords announced last year.
The larger and more provocative is a $2 billion contract to pump natural gas, signed by the French company Total and two partners, Gazprom of Russia and Petronas of Malaysia. Petronas has been hit hard by the Asian crisis, and an American official is currently investigating whether it may have to pull out of the deal, senior officials said. Total, for its part, vows to go ahead and seek further contracts in Iran.
The other deal, worth $180 million, was signed by a Canadian company, Bow Valley Energy Ltd., and its Indonesian partner, Bakrie Minarak. There have been reports that Bakrie Minarak wants to pull out and that Bow Valley is seeking new partners.
It has been six months since the State Department began an investigation into whether the companies are liable for sanctions under the law. But senior Administration officials say the investigation is not complete, which means that legally Mr. Clinton has not had to make a decision.
Even Congressional staff members who monitor the law are not pressing very hard for a decision.
"It would not be an unhappy outcome if all this were to fall of its own weight," one key congressional staff member said, echoing the fervent hope of the Administration.
At the same time, Washington wants to discourage large new investments into Iran. It is pressing for a Turkish route for a pipeline for Caspian Sea oil and gas, which would bypass Iran. And it wants to reduce Western dependence on Persian Gulf pipelines and to reduce the reliance of the newly independent Central Asian states on Russian pipelines.
It is President Khatami himself who holds out the prospect of better Iranian behavior on the very issues the sanctions law is meant to highlight: Iran's development of major weapons and its support for radical groups that oppose Middle East peace.
"This is still a very tough one," a senior Administration official said. "There are a lot of competing interests, and the coherence of our Iran policy is at stake."
While senior officials say they will carry out the law, they note that it has two kinds of waivers built in.
The first, known as a 9c waiver, which many senior American officials favor, invokes national security to waive sanctions against particular projects or companies. Using a 9c waiver, the officials say, will allow the law to retain a lot of its deterrent power because big foreign companies who want to invest in Iran -- like British Petroleum and Shell -- have too many assets in America to risk sanctions. Total, Gazprom and Petronas, by contrast, have few assets here.
Applying this waiver, the narrower of the two, would also help prevent complaints of unfair competition by American companies, which are barred from investing in Iran by a separate American law.
The European allies favor a second waiver, known as a 4c, which provides a blanket waiver for a country and its companies if that country takes "substantial measures, including economic sanctions, that inhibit Iran's abilities" to develop weapons or undermine the peace effort.
While senior European diplomats argue that Iran gets no help from Europe for its weapons programs, they are negotiating with the Americans about how to tighten up their controls over the export of dual-use products, which can be used for benign projects or for nuclear or missile programs.
Senator D'Amato has written to Mr. Clinton opposing any 4c waiver because European countries have not imposed any economic sanctions. But a senior American official said some steps by the Europeans to deny dual-use products to Iran could have "a substantial economic impact."

HEADLINE: Among Young Of Immigrants, Outlook Rises

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER 

 BODY:
A multiyear survey that is the largest ever of the children of immigrants -- who now account for almost 1 in 5 American children -- found that they overwhelmingly prefer English to their parents' native tongues and have higher grades and steeply lower school dropout rates than other American children.
While a majority of those surveyed, adolescents who were of predominantly Hispanic, Asian and black descent, said they had personally experienced discrimination, an even larger majority of them said they still believed that the United States was the best country in the world to live in. 
 The lead researchers on the study describe these findings as reassuring indications that the children of immigrants are unlikely to form a new multi-ethnic underclass, as some experts fear, cut off from the mainstream by academic failure and an inability to speak English.
But the researchers also say it is still an open question how well these young people will do in college and the job market, a caution shared by other experts. The researchers said the survey brought into sharp relief the extraordinary diversity of the children of immigrants, not only by national origin, but also by social class. It reaches from the young of Chinese and Indian couples from highly educated, upper-middle-class backgrounds to Mexicans and Dominicans from the humblest origins.
"What can certainly be predicted now is that the destinies of these youth will diverge," said Prof. Ruben G. Rumbaut, a sociologist at Michigan State University. "Some will go up, and some will go down."
The survey, which shows that the children of immigrants outperform their American peers and that those from more advantaged backgrounds do better than poorer children, will inevitably become fodder for the larger debate about the nation's immigration policy.
Supporters of the current high levels of immigration will cite the achievements of these young people, while critics may find reinforcement for their view that national policy should be tilted to favor more highly skilled and educated immigrants.
The research team, led by Professor Rumbaut and Prof. Alejandro Portes, a sociologist at Princeton University, first interviewed 5,200 youngsters in Southern California and South Florida in 1992 when the youths were in the eighth or ninth grades and tracked down 82 percent of them for a second interview in 1995 and 1996 when most were high school seniors.
This fall, another team of sociologists will begin a large-scale survey of the grown children of immigrants in New York City and its suburbs, focusing on adults 18 to 32 years old, rather than adolescents.
The number of children who are either immigrants or the American-born offspring of immigrants grew to 13.7 million last year, from 8 million in 1990, making them the fastest-growing segment of Americans under the age of 18, according to a new analysis of census data by Professor Rumbaut.
The $1 million survey of the children of immigrants was financed by the Russell Sage, Andrew W. Mellon, Spencer and National Science Foundations. The researchers provided their findings to The New York Times.
Among the most striking findings of the bicoastal survey of children from San Diego and Miami-Dade and Broward Counties in South Florida have to do with the contentious issue of language. While 9 out of 10 of the youths surveyed spoke a language other than English at home, almost the same proportion, 88 percent, preferred English by the end of high school.
Professor Rumbaut wrote, "The findings suggest that the linguistic outcomes for the third generation -- the grandchildren of the current wave of immigrants -- will be no different than what has been the age-old pattern in American history: the grandchildren may learn a few foreign words and phrases as a quaint vestige of their ancestry, but they will most likely grow up speaking English only."
And the professor also pointed to the ascendancy of English as evidence of the irrelevance of a California ballot initiative that could end bilingual education, which has been depicted as an impediment to the acquisition of English.
"English is triumphing with breathtaking rapidity," he said.
The study presents a generally upbeat portrayal of the children of immigrants as ambitious, hopeful and resilient in the face of discrimination. In San Diego, the children of immigrants had better grades than their American peers in every grade. The gap narrowed over time, largely because the poorly performing children of immigrants were more likely to stay in school than their peers who were not the children of immigrants, the researchers say. In South Florida, the school districts were unable to provide the researchers with grade point averages for the district as a whole.
But when the researchers analyzed how the children of immigrants were faring by national origin, they found that levels of scholastic success diverged sharply. Generally, the children whose immigrant parents had better educations and jobs and who came from stable, two-parent families were predictably more successful, with a few startling exceptions.
The children of Chinese, Indian, Japanese and Korean parents had the highest grade point averages, A's and B's. English-speaking West Indians had lower grades, C's and C+'s. Latin American and Haitian youths performed poorest, with averages that were slightly higher or lower than a C.
But a few groups defied what would have been expected, based on their socioeconomic status. The children of Southeast Asian refugees, who came from the most impoverished backgrounds and whose parents were among the least educated, were also among the least likely to drop out of school and had above-average grades. They did it by studying for longer hours and watching less television than many of the other children of immigrants, the study found.
And the children of Cuban immigrants, who were from average to above-average socioeconomic backgrounds, had the highest dropout rates and among the lowest grades (an average of C or C+), the survey reported. The Cuban children, who belonged to the dominant group in metropolitan Miami, faced less discrimination than any other group in the survey, the researchers said.
The children of Cubans did worse academically than the children of Mexicans, who are one of the poorest immigrant groups in the United States and by far the largest immigrant group.
The findings about Cubans were among the survey's most startling to Professors Rumbaut and Portes and their colleague, Lisandro Perez, director of the Cuban Research Center at Florida International University. All three are Cuban immigrants themselves.
Professor Portes had hypothesized that Cuban youths would use their economically powerful ethnic enclave as a springboard to higher education and the middle class, much as Eastern European Jews did in an earlier wave of immigration.
He said that the new survey data showed that while some Cuban youths, especially those in private schools, were continuing on an upwardly mobile path, the ones in public schools were facing more difficulties.
And Professor Perez said that for some, "the enclave may not be a springboard, but a cushy net that means you don't have to depend exclusively on education for a job."
"It may be that Cubans are right, and will do better going to work at an uncle's factory in Hialeah," he said. "We're not certain how it will translate economically."
The survey also found some intriguing changes in the way the children of immigrants identified themselves, possibly reflecting their altered relationship to the rest of American society or perhaps just adolescent rebelliousness.
When the youths were first interviewed, more than half labeled themselves as hyphenated Americans or as plain Americans. That sounded like old-fashioned assimilation, and it might have been expected that, three years later, even more of the youths would have chosen an American identity.
But the results of the second interview, conducted in the months after California's passage of Proposition 187, the initiative that called for restricting social and educational benefits to illegal immigrants, turned those expectations on their head.
Only a third of the youths in Southern California picked an American identity the second time around, while almost half identified themselves by their national identity, especially youths of Mexican and Filipino descent, who belong to the two largest immigrant groups in the United States.
The researchers interpreted the change as part of a backlash among these youth against what they perceived as immigrant bashing that surfaced in the campaign for Proposition 187.
In South Florida the pattern was different, but equally striking. The proportion identifying themselves by some kind of American label dropped to about a third, while the share who chose ethnic identities like Hispanic or black doubled to 38 percent, mainly among Latin Americans and Jamaicans.
The more militant, nationalistic identities assumed by Mexicans and Filipinos in California, and the minority identities chosen in Florida, Professor Rumbaut wrote, reflected the youths' rising awareness "of the ethnic and racial categories in which they were persistently classified by mainstream society."
In one of the more troubling findings of the study, the researchers said, the young people who identified themselves by ethnic categories like Chicano or Latino in junior high had lower grades and somewhat higher dropout rates than the other children studied.
This finding, they said, lends support to analysts who have suggested that children of immigrants who come to identify with American minorities may take on "oppositional" identities and see doing well in school as "acting white."

HEADLINE: Journal;
The Liars' Club

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
So many women who may be lying on TV, so little time. How else to explain the scant attention paid this week to the unmasking of the Beardstown Ladies, a gang of Middle American grandmas caught in the biggest media hoax since Joe Klein denied writing "Primary Colors"?
The Beardstown Ladies, you may recall, are 14 photogenic small-town Illinois women, median age 70, who became a cottage industry once they extolled the virtues of their investment club on CBS's morning show. Their high annual return of 23.4 percent -- which "puts many professionals to shame," as People magazine marveled -- spawned best-selling books (800,000 copies of their first investment guide alone), daytime talk-show stardom, lecture tours and a video titled "Cookin' Up Profits." ABC's "20/20" attributed their Wall Street prowess to their "heartland" virtues of hard work and churchgoing; the equally credulous Times ran their recipe for Stock Market Muffins ("guaranteed to rise"). 
 But in three years of cookin' up profits and hype, no journalist bothered to check if the ladies might be cooking their books until a reporter named Shane Tritsch challenged their numbers in this month's Chicago magazine. After much buck-passing, stonewalling and disparagement of the press, the Beardstown Ladies apologized this week. A Price Waterhouse audit uncovered a yearly return of 9.1 percent that not only underperformed the extravagant claim on their book jackets but underperformed the market.
The story that buried the Beards town Ladies' apology in much of the same media that had made them superstars was, of course, Kathleen Willey. Then again, the stories are the same. Both show how image, often created or enhanced by show-biz packaging, counts for everything on the public stage. The Beardstown Ladies were, literally, a G-rated Disney package -- archetypes from Main Street, U.S.A., published by Disney's Hyperion -- so the public and reporters alike threw skepticism aside. Ms. Willey offered another set of appealing cliches -- lovingly air-brushed by a "60 Minutes" that didn't want to let tough-minded journalism cast any ambiguous shadows on a heroine whose credibility promised big ratings.
As Katie Roiphe writes in the Web magazine Salon, Ms. Willey's attributes included her "sensible hair and high cheekbones," her upper-middle-class background and her general aura of "Not Likely to Steal Your Husband." And as Ms. Roiphe points out, the whole political spectrum, "from Newt Gingrich to Anita Hill," rushed to judge her credible as a result. "She looks more like Betty Crocker than she does like Betty Boop," said the conservative commentator Tony Blankley. The liberal pundit Bill Press echoed: "Kathleen Willey has 100 times more credibility than the lounge singer Gennifer Flowers." Or as The Economist summed up the received wisdom in a headline: "You can't call this one a bimbo."
But as the week went on, we learned that Ms. Willey's account was at odds with both a friend's affidavit and some of her own sworn statements. Though she may yet prove to have been truthful in describing a Presidential assault, her veracity is hardly a slam-dunk. Whoever she is, she's certainly far more complicated than the two-dimensional image merchandised and stage-managed by "60 Minutes."
If Ms. Willey did lie on "60 Minutes" -- and fool the audience as she did so -- she is hardly alone. We now know that the Clintons also got away with exceedingly disingenuous image-mongering in their famous '92 appearance on the show, during which the soon-to-be President responded to a question about a 12-year affair with Gennifer Flowers by saying "That allegation is false." This year, in a sworn deposition, Mr. Clinton conceded having an affair with her, disputing only its duration.
This means that in this entire saga the only female Presidential accuser we now know for certain to be telling the truth is one of the Betty Boops who was being trashed even as Ms. Willey's now-disputed account was being universally accepted as gospel. This tells us something about our class prejudices, certainly, and about our insistence on judging women by their hair. But it's also another example of how the priorities of show business override reality in the pageant we call "news." Crowd-pleasing star performers, however contrived, get the free ride that vulgar lounge acts, however genuine, do not.

HEADLINE: Germans Cut Labor Costs With a Harsh Export: Jobs

SERIES: HELP UNWANTED: Second of two articles on Europe's job drought.

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, March 20

 BODY:
It would be hard to find a more vivid example of the revival of German industry than the renowned sports car manufacturer Porsche AG. Six years after the company came perilously close to bankruptcy, sales and profits are booming and its snappy new two-seater, the Boxster, is a hit.
But that is cold comfort for its workers. Having stretched its plants to their limit, Porsche has vowed not to build any more assembly plants and to farm out work to contractors. 
 Last September, in an unprecedented move for Porsche, it hired a Finnish company to start building some Boxsters. Though the move does not save Porsche much in costs, it frees the company from the expense of building a factory, hiring workers and laying them off if Boxster falters.
Porsche is one small example of the most striking economic feature in Germany: growth without jobs.
Europe is enjoying its best economic growth in years. But employers are not hiring many people. After years of layoffs and cost cutting, unemployment remains at record rates -- 11.6 percent in Germany and more than 10 percent across the European Union. Though there are signs that the problem has peaked, nobody expects the rate to drop to single digits before late 1999, if then.
More and more, economists say, Europe's economies are growing without creating many jobs. Reasons vary from country to country but high labor costs -- fringe benefits, plentiful vacations and holidays, rigid work rules -- and high payroll taxes discourage companies from adding workers. The main exceptions are Britain, Ireland and the Netherlands, which have more liberal work rules and lower taxes.
The labor costs are pushing companies to invest elsewhere. Last year German companies invested $25 billion abroad -- 10 times as much as foreign companies invested here, the biggest investment gap ever.
The political implications are potentially explosive. Unemployed workers have staged loud protests across France and Germany. Anger about joblessness in France was central to last summer's election victory by the Socialist Party, and it is a major threat to Chancellor Helmut Kohl in an election this September.
The upheaval is almost a mirror image of the American experience. In the United States, Rust Belt manufacturers shed hundreds of thousands of jobs in the 1980's. But in the 90's the unemployment rate has declined, partly because millions of jobs have been generated in the service economy. One price for those jobs has been workers' income, which declined in real terms through throughout the 1980's and up to 1996.
In Europe, by contrast, wages and fringe benefits have remained high. The pain has come from a steady increase in unemployment.
The trends are particularly stark in Germany, Europe's biggest economy and most powerful exporter. Though exports are soaring, the domestic economy remains anemic. Retail sales actually declined a bit last year. After an acquisition binge, German banks are cutting jobs to improve profits. The dominant telephone company, forced into competition for the first time, is shedding 60,000 jobs.
 
A Case Study: Hugo Boss Apparel
The divided world of renewed dynamism and fewer jobs is on display in Metzingen, a southern German city that is home to Hugo Boss AG. Originally known for its avant garde casual clothing, the company is branching into more conservative upscale apparel, including its first women's line. Boss brands and its stores are now familiar worldwide, and the company recently opened a high-profile store in Beverly Hills.
Sales climbed 14 percent last year, and the company surprised investors last month by announcing a 27 percent jump in profits.
Part of Boss's success stems from shifting production outside Germany, mostly to Poland, Romania and Slovenia. Only about 20 percent of the clothing is produced in Germany now, down from about 40 percent five years ago.
"It used to be that if you wanted workers who cost $2.50 an hour, you had to travel 10,000 miles to Asia," remarked Joachim Vogt, the chief executive. "Now you just have to go 15 miles across the Oder River," to Poland.
Indeed, the main reason that Hugo Boss produces any clothing at all in Germany is to retain the technical expertise to supervise suppliers and insure quality. Company officials in Metzingen select the production equipment, develop procedures and even train many managers and workers from other countries.
The result is impressive. "A few years ago, our quality-control experts could look at the color of a jacket and tell what factory it came from," Mr. Vogt said. "Today, not even the quality-control people can tell."
Thus the size of Boss's German work force has remained the same for several years and it has cut back on German suppliers.
 
Where the Jobs Are: On the Managerial Level
The one silver lining is that within Hugo Boss, the decline in textile workers has been offset by an increase in better-paid managers.
"Our core competence is to bring products to market and create brands on an international level," Mr. Vogt said. "Our industry doesn't need to produce in Europe. Europe's core competence comes from its highly educated and highly skilled people, and over the last 20 years there has been migration to jobs that are more brain-oriented."
Across Europe, corporate restructurings have put thousands of people out of work, but they have helped revitalize laggard companies.
For example Moulinex, a French company that makes coffee makers and other kitchen ware, lost hundreds of millions of dollars between 1993 and 1996. Under new management, the company closed two factories, announced plans to eliminate 2,600 jobs over three years and refocused on new products.
Today Moulinex has fewer workers but a slew of new appliances. Its annual sales stabilized at $1.3 billion last year, and the company earned its first profit in four years.
Porsche, on the other hand, got into trouble when recession hit the United States, then its largest market, and a plunge in the dollar pushed up sticker prices there. That would have been bad enough, but Porsche's production had slipped woefully behind the times. Cars took too long to design and build.
After a revolving door of executives, Wendelin Wiedeking was hired as chief executive in 1993 and quickly shocked workers by hiring Japanese to re-engineer the production system. The number of hours it took to assemble a Porsche was cut in half and many workers were laid off.
Today Porsche's German workforce has actually increased to 7,100 people, from its low of 6,350 in the mid-1990's. But when Porsche began running out of assembling capacity in late 1996, thanks largely a surge in demand for the Boxster, Mr. Wiedeking had to make a choice between building a new plant and hiring more workers, or farming out the work.
It was not an easy decision. Though other German car companies had long since started building vehicles overseas, Porsche had always been a small, independent manufacturer with an rock-solid German identity.
Valmet of Finland, which has long run assembly lines for Saab and the Opel division of General Motors, offered to start assembling Porsches within nine months, using the same assembly lines used to make Saabs. It did not even need to hire new workers, because it was just reaching the end of a contract with Opel.
And if demand for Boxsters fell, Porsche could simply shut down production in Finland and let Valmet worry about layoffs. In the end, Mr. Wiedeking decided the advantages were overwhelming, and 300 Finnish workers are now assembling about 5,000 Boxsters a year.
"This was not a decision taken against Germany," Mr. Wiedeking insisted. "This was a decision because we couldn't increase the production any faster."
But the decision did have to do with flexibility, and Porsche executives say they have made a firm decision not to build new plants for any future needs.
"It is our clear policy not to build any additional capacity," said Manfred Ayasse, a Porsche spokesman. "Porsche's view is that there is enough capacity around the world. We have almost no investment to make and we have almost no risk. If Boxster sales declined, we can stop production at Valmet within a year."
Economists here and abroad say the combination of high wages, high taxes and tight regulations have created a major barrier to hiring and investment.
The Institute for the German Economy, a business-backed research organization in Cologne, estimates that labor costs in most European countries remain far higher than in the United States. The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development has calculated that the return on business investment in Europe has consistently been much lower than in the United States.
German business executives blame much of this on high labor costs and taxes. German workers pay about half their gross income in taxes and mandatory social security contributions, and employers have to match many of those payments.
The burden infuriates Arend Oetker, a fourth-generation business executive in Cologne who controls Schwartau, a producer of jams, snacks and other sweets. Mr. Oetker recently bought a controlling stake in a similar Swiss company called Hero and folded his non-German businesses into it because Swiss tax laws offer him savings compared with German laws.
"I am a German, and I want to keep employment here as much as possible," Mr. Oetker said. "But the more the labor costs rise, and the more that taxes rise, the more difficult it is to remain in Germany. No one can be astonished that unemployment is going up."
In a report to the Government, Germany's top economic research institutes echoed that view. "Stronger growth alone will certainly not be sufficient to improve the labor market situation," the institutes said. The American example, the report continued, shows that greater flexibility in wage costs and regulation can help boost employment.
 
A Bit of Change May Be Too Late
Some change is coming, slowly.
Last year at the huge Opel facility in Russelsheim, local union negotiators agreed to wage concessions in exchange for a commitment by Opel to cut jobs only through attrition and voluntary retirement incentives for the next five years.
But many German experts say the pace of change is far too slow.
A major tax-reform plan championed by Chancellor Kohl was blocked by opposition parties in Parliament. Labor unions, after grudgingly accepting negligible wage hikes in the past two years, are now demanding bigger increases.
The Government is trying to funnel more money toward job-creation programs and seed capital for new companies.
Gerhard Schroder, who will lead the opposition party in the fall, remains vague on what he would do if his party wins the elections. But he has talked about pumping more money into the economy to stimulate consumer demand.
Many union leaders continue to press for a shorter work-week, an idea the French Parliament is weighing, on the theory of dividing the current jobs among more people.
But economists say that such measures will not do the trick, and that both major political parties are too divided to force deeper changes.
"We all know what is to be done," said Klaus Friedrich, chief economist at Dresdner Bank. "But they can't get it done. Why? Because we don't have a Government in a position to do very much."

LENGTH: 1609 words

HEADLINE: You Want to Be a Star? Then Get in Line

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL 

 BODY:
"And now you want to be an actor," said Michael Kahan. It could have been a question or a statement.
The young man across the table took it as a question. He nodded eagerly at Mr. Kahan and two other drama judges in a rehearsal room of the Juilliard School at Lincoln Center. He said his name was Richard; he was 21, and a Massachusetts Institute of Technology graduate in economics. He said he would perform a scene from "Julius Caesar" and something by August Wilson. 
 "You're on," said Mr. Kahan, arching an eyebrow almost audibly. "Whenever."
Scenes like this have been playing around the country for weeks now as drama schools go through their annual admissions ritual for the fall. This year, however, the intensity is unusual. Acting is hot, And not just because of the "Titanic" idol Leonardo DiCaprio. For years now, increasing numbers of young people have been taking to the boards, assuring the acting mecca of New York an inexhaustible supply of waiters and waitresses.
"There's a definite glamour attached to the profession," said a bubbly Victoria Ross, 17, of Dayton, Ohio ("Call me Tory, because I'm British"), who came to audition last month at Juilliard.
Michael Ellis, 17, of Chatham, N.J., who also auditioned there, cited "the coolness aspect" as well as issues of personal growth. "I used to be modest, shy and reticent," he said. "It made me flower." His friends were impressed, he said. "They kind of think it's noble." Besides, he said, "drama and athletics are the only two professions that allow you to be paid for playing."
This is crunch time for the would-be thespians, particularly in New York, who usually learn their fate in April. A flood of applicants have been showing up, despite the formidable odds against being admitted and the almost inevitable prospect of low pay once they graduate: one 17-year-old hopeful, Laura Silva, recently traveled to the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University from Bogota, Colombia.
Juilliard, perhaps the most selective performing arts school in the nation, is sorting through 1,100 acting applications for its 20 positions, up 10 percent from last year, officials said. At the Tisch School, with the largest undergraduate drama department in the world, close to 2,200 applicants are competing for the 350 freshmen openings in 1998-99, up from 1,518 last year and 1,262 in 1996, and just 880 in 1993.
Mary Schmidt Campbell, dean of the Tisch School, said the boom seemed "a youthful defiance" of electronic media. "They're saying, 'My voice, my body, live and in person, in living flesh.' "
Some drama professionals tie the growing interest in acting to the youth entertainment culture of home video and cable and network television, as well films and theater. Some wonder, too, whether in a strong economy more parents are willing to see their children pursue the uncertain prospects of a career in the arts.
"It looks like a perfectly good profession," said Mr. Kahan, a stage director who has been on the Juilliard faculty for 25 years, the last 6 as director of the drama program. "They see a lot of actors in their living rooms. And TV looks so easy."
They come in actors' garb -- sweats, jeans and T-shirts -- and in various stages of maturity and professional development. One 17-year-old from Frankfort, Ky., who was auditioning at New York University had not seen much theater, but he had directed two plays. A young woman arrived with her stuffed bunny and propped it up as a talisman to ease her through her audition.
"Where I come from, a lot of people are pursuing this career who shouldn't be," said Ms. Ross of Dayton. "That's funny coming from me because maybe I shouldn't be either." But she quickly dismissed the heretical thought. "It's truly the only thing that makes me happy," she said.
Her mother, Kate, who accompanied her to Juilliard along with her music teacher, said they were doing everything to encourage her, including sending her to the Interlochen Arts Academy in Michigan in the summer. "We are true believers in 'follow your dream,' " she said. "If you don't, you'll never know. The arts and entertainment world is exploding. It can always be parlayed into something else."
At New York University's auditions in a simple black box rehearsal space, Arthur Bartow, artistic director of the drama department, opened with a pep talk: "We try to find out who you are. We try to look at you holistically. The best actors are good scholars. Acting is just a skill, a technique. It's not why people come to watch you. They come to watch you as a person." He told one nervous young woman who asked to take her shoes off and then left sweaty footprints on the floor: "Calm down. It's only the rest of your life. Breathe."
He interrupted a young man in the middle of his monologue. "Pull it closer to yourself," he said.
The boy pulled over a chair.
Mr. Bartow stifled a smile. "I don't mean the chair," he said. "I mean yourself. More exposing yourself. I don't care if you screw up the scene. You're not bringing it close to yourself. You're acting." He said the word as if it were an epithet.
Uptown, at Juilliard, a daunting triumvirate presided: Mr. Kahan and other drama faculty members, Elizabeth Smith and Daryl Quinton.
Richard, the M.I.T. graduate, was declaiming as Marc Antony when Mr. Kahan stopped him. "Is there a sport you play?" he asked.
The young man looked puzzled. "Wrestling," he finally said.
"That won't work," Mr. Kahan said. "I'd like you to play a game with somebody you know. You decide."
"I'm playing kickball?" Richard asked, not quite getting it.
"Yes, and you do your monologue," Mr. Kahan said, watching to see how he could improvise and blend the words and actions.
One who did rate a call back was a girl who stirringly rendered Tennessee Williams's pitiable Bertha. "Could you sing something for us?" Mr. Kahan asked.
"Sure," she said unhesitatingly, breaking into a song from "The Secret Garden."
After she left, Mr. Kahan said, "Best actor we've seen." But he and the others detected a speech imperfection that might need work.
The number of working actors and directors -- perhaps not the oxymoron the inevitable jokes suggest -- grew by 173 percent from 1970 to 1990, from 40,000 to 109,500, according to census figures cited in a 1996 National Endowment for the Arts report called "Artists in the Work Force." The definition of employed, however, is hedged with qualifications involving other jobs and part-time work. In the same period, employment in all the arts rose 127 percent and in the labor force as a whole, 55 percent.
(Actors' Equity Association, the union representing stage actors with some professional credits, strenuously disputes the acting figures, saying they lump in many marginal hobbyists.)
From 1991 to 1997, Federal labor figures show, the number of working actors and directors grew by 56 percent, to 136,000, while the labor force overall grew by 11 percent. The figures combine actors and directors, although actors account for the bulk of the category.
Alan Eisenberg, national director of Actors' Equity, called the figures misleading, citing the steady union rolls of about 33,000 members as a more accurate indicator. "Anyone can put down 'actor,' " he said.
Despite the numbers of young people flocking to acting as a career, the economic realities remain harsh, Mr. Eisenberg said. Equity reports its members earned median wages of only $5,705 last year, meaning half earned more and half less. Average annual wages were $13,967. And members worked an average of only 17.4 weeks last year.
Still, other leading drama schools apart from Juilliard and New York University, report a similar upward trend. At the North Carolina School for the Arts in Winston-Salem, the 500 applicants for this year's 30 openings were twice as many as applied six years ago.
"It's been going up steadily," said the dean, Gerald Friedman, who injected a realistic note: "At orientation I tell them a lot won't be working."
At the University of Delaware's graduate theater program, the 500 applications for a recent class of 38 represented a 20 percent jump. But more striking, said Sandy Robbins, the program director, is the clamor to enter a program geared to the classics. "I wouldn't have been surprised if it was for movies or television," he said.
Yet the surge is not uniform. Other schools, like Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, and the University of California at Los Angeles reported only modest rises in applications. And the Yale School of Drama, which accepts only 17 applicants a year, says it receives about 800 applications annually, a figure that has held "pretty steady" in recent years.
In the end, will they find work, other than in restaurants?
"There's a misconception the industry is just for famous people," said Betsy Immergut of State University College at Purchase, N.Y. "That they're not Harvey Keitel doesn't mean they're not employed in the field. There's theater companies and stage opportunities all over the world. Think in terms of skills developed. They can be teachers. They can be producers. The option is not between waiter or Academy Award winner. There's lots of jobs in between."
Gene Turisso, who has seen applications rise at both the American Academy of Dramatic Arts, where he is now the director, and the theater arts department at Northern Illinois University in DeKalb, which he led previously, said the profession had a growing cachet. "We're past the time parents feared sending Johnny to a stage career," he said. "He can become a literary agent. And law schools love theater graduates."

CORRECTION-DATE: March 24, 1998, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on Saturday about the popularity of acting careers for young people misspelled the surname of the director of the drama division at the Juilliard School. He is Michael Kahn, not Kahan.
The article also misspelled the surname of the head of the American Academy of Dramatic Arts and misstated his title. He is Gene Terruso, not Turisso, and he is president, not director.
