LENGTH: 1621 words

HEADLINE: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
Images of an Economy Devouring the Poor

BYLINE: By Vicki Goldberg 

DATELINE: HOUSTON

 BODY:
THE video welcoming visitors to Houston on the hotel channel confides that the man who built the Astrodome had a copy of it at home and one bedroom dedicated to P. T. Barnum, another with a bed resting on a calliope. The city's attractions are sometimes unique. Fotofest is one. It's the only international biennial gathering of photographers, curators, critics and exhibitions -- 70 shows this year -- in this country.
The festival has a few Texas quirks, like a mobile art show in a bus with a perilously tilted floor, and a show in a bar where the decor includes a large plastic cube heaped with worn-out shoes and a mannequin wearing nothing but a pink see-through bed jacket, items that quite outshine the art. 
 But Fotofest, which runs through March, also has some major distinctions. Its organizers, Fred Baldwin and Wendy Watriss, together with Houston galleries, museums and nonprofit spaces, have brought to America contemporary photography seldom or never seen here, including work from Brazil, Italy and Japan and fine shows of recent Finnish, Slovakian and Mexican work. There are better-known photographers, too, like Harry Gruyaert plus plenty of American photography, like a show called "Spirits and Construction." Unexpected treasures turn up amid the standard quota of dross.
This orgy of images, spread out over some unusual reaches of the city, requires a car, a map, adrenalin and patience, but even seeing merely a large part of it provides an uncommonly capacious overview. A show called "Stories About Us: Photographs from Juarez," at the Diverseworks Artspace gallery, presents especially strong subject matter: the horrors of the Mexican border city and the coruscating effects of global free trade on the poor.
William Tuman, the curator, has put together an exhibition powerful enough to be hard to take despite all the imagery of poverty and violence that has rained down on the world, dampening its sympathies. The 50 photographs in the show -- by 15 Mexican press photographers, all but one of them working in color -- address the city's miseries from different angles. Captions add illuminating data without becoming unwieldy; the effect is cumulative, gathering intensity as it goes.
The photographs and the deadly problems they depict were first set forth in a harrowing article by Charles Bowden in Harper's magazine in 1996 and since then in a book by the same author called "Juarez: The Laboratory of Our Future," published by Aperture. Mr. Bowden believes that these photographers have already captured the look of the future. "This future," he writes, "is based on the rich getting richer, the poor getting poorer and industrial growth producing poverty faster than it distributes wealth."
The photographers limn the terrors in Juarez: gangs kill at least 200 people a year, torturing many of them first. The drug traffic is rampant and violent. At least 150 girls disappear each year, most of them raped and then murdered. People live in cardboard shacks -- without electricity, heat or water -- that often go up in flames. Some live in dumps and compete with animals for food. Toxic emissions and untreated sewage pollute the air and water. Attempts to cross the border frequently end in death.
The photographers, all men save one, are young, broke, in constant danger and certain that they have a mission. One has been shot at and knows of a contract on his life; one wears a bullet-proof vest. One was photographing the bloated corpse of a raped and murdered girl when the body burst. It ruined his camera.
They are utterly explicit about violence: one records the blackened and shrunken face of a murdered girl mummified by the desert sun; another, a body tortured and burned beyond recognition. Very few of these photographs have been published in Mexican papers not only because they are violent, but surely also because they are politically damning.
Overt violence is only a small part of this exhibition. There are children playing near a smelter that belches fumes, others fishing for food in the polluted Rio Grande, a man trying to put out a fire in his house with a garden hose that emits a tiny stream, a mural of the enslavement of Mexicans painted on the Mexican side of the gates that close off the train tracks at the border. A chilling picture of the desert where many bodies have been found shows only sand, barbed wire and a post topped by a clown head with a big smile, bigger eyelashes and a charming little hat.
Mr. Bowden attributes the problems in Juarez to the economy's dependence on factories owned by foreigners, most of them American. (Convincing as Mr. Bowden is, it should be noted that Juarez has played host to poverty and violence for a very long time.) Parts shipped from America and elsewhere are assembled here and shipped back under an agreement that exempts them from high tariffs. The factories pay only slightly more than other Mexican factories and not enough to live on in an inflated economy. They have a six-day work week and no economic safety net other than severance pay, although the (mostly) women who work in them can seldom afford child care and get burned out, used up and disposed of fast.
Yet these factories have attracted millions of poor peasants ill prepared to do the work and unable to find housing or leave the county. Mr. Bowden writes that "Juarez is an exhibit of the fabled New World Order in which capital moves easily and labor is trapped by borders."
JUAREZ being our border, our neighbor and the site of our passionate disputes, it is hard to duck some sense of American responsibility for its ills. This makes the tale these pictures tell just a shade less simple to dismiss than such far-off dilemmas as Bosnia or Indonesia. The images are relatively artless, with the straightforward "tell it as it is" look of traditional press photography. Which makes them all the more gripping.
There was a time when news photographs and street snaps were thought to be unimpeachable truths -- I think that often they still are, except in special circumstances and classroom discussions -- and generally they looked like this. There is not much artistry here of the splendid post-modern variety that has complicated and beautified some contemporary reporting. The photographs are good enough, full of information, a professional step up from snapshots but not a whole lot better. They concentrate on subject at the expense of bravura composition and color. I suspect they might have been even stronger in black and white, the old-fashioned documentary mode that neither distracts nor lulls the eye with a fine note of blue or a harsh splash of red.
The Juarez photographers hope to change things. How much change photographs can inspire depends a lot on who sees them and perhaps where. An alliance of street photographers in Juarez has been organized with an archive of photographs, an office where 100 prints hang and plans for shows in Mexico City, Cuba and Europe. The organizer of the alliance has been quoted as saying that the Mexican Government keeps track of pictures published in foreign papers and will clean up a problem if a picture appears in The New York Times. Maybe. Eight of these photographs were printed last July in the Times's Week in Review section.
I found the exhibition wrenching -- although there's always the question of whether I am merely indulging my liberal guilt and will neglect to do anything about it. Still, the impact made it hard for me to view the next exhibitions tranquilly. For a moment, even good art photography began to look inconsequential in comparison to people's lives.
Art is always, perhaps unfairly, facing this kind of competition. Indeed, one of art's functions is restoring our easily threatened confidence in the ability of humankind to create order and beauty, a confidence the news media frequently undermine. Perhaps one should not go to a museum immediately after watching the local news.
After a bit, another part of Fotofest, the show "Five South African Artists," at the Vine Street Studios, pierced the clouds of my conscience. Here, two remarkable animated films by William Kentridge, whose drawings morph and redraw themselves in dreamlike tales that ricochet off various levels of the mind, deal indirectly with his homeland's hateful history. A strong piece by Sue Williamson mixes photographs and abbreviated quotes -- "covering up," "ordered to lie" -- to highlight the difficult mission and ambiguous results of the South African Truth and Reconciliation Commission hearings.
Both Mr. Kentridge and Ms. Williamson make art that confronts ugly realities. Which is not to say that this is the way to make good art; the great majority of political art fails as both art and politics. (This is somewhat less true of documentary photography.) But a major subject instantly pushes a work of art, literature included, to another level of ambition, from which it may vault higher or fall farther, and to another level of response. The subject alone can, if successfully translated into form, reach a range of emotions that pure beauty or stylistic sophistication have little access to. And in photography, especially documentary or news photography, subject counts heavily, because what is represented actually occurred -- barring fakery or manipulation.
People look at such photographs through their fears, their hopes and their consciences as well as their eyes, which is one reason reactions to images can differ so from person to person. The omnipresent image seldom evokes an omnipresent response, but one would have to be fearless, hopeless and blind not to respond at all when eyes and conscience both insist you do.

GRAPHIC: Photo: GRIM SHADOWS -- Mexican children play in a heavily contaminated area of Juarez, near a U.S. company that smelts copper. (Manuel Saenz/Casa de las Americas)

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Three Big Musicals, Three Fates

BYLINE: By VINCENT CANBY 

 BODY:
I believe in the power of St. Lazarus.
And he holds me in his sight.
I know that these jitterbug days I'm livin,'
Well, they won't last for all of us,
But they'll last for a long summer night.

 From the score of "The Capeman," music by Paul Simon, book and lyrics by Mr. Simon and Derek Walcott 
 The long summer night of "The Capeman" abruptly ends this Saturday when the $11 million musical closes at the Marquis Theater just two months after its official opening, which followed nearly nine weeks of paid previews.
Some Broadway professionals have been uncharacteristically caustic about the flop of the ambitious if unfocused, utterly flaccid show with which Mr. Simon made his debut as a Broadway contender. They don't talk about his haunting, widely praised score or, if they do, they say it isn't for the theater.
Instead, they prefer to equate the huge amount of money lost by the production with the size of the composer's ego: How could a man with no Broadway experience, someone who possesses only skepticism about the form itself, dare to come into town and, surrounded by other theater neophytes, attempt to teach the pros how to put on a show? Mickey and Judy could do it, but that was in the movies.
Yet the failure of "The Capeman" should not be a cause for derision but for lamentation, even beyond Mr. Simon's public of loyal admirers.
That would include everyone who, at the beginning of this season, read the schedule of forthcoming shows as an indication that, at long last, the Broadway musical might stand a chance of finding some important new identities. And none too soon. The people responsible for the current crop of long-running Broadway behemoths have not been heard from recently.
Andrew Lloyd Webber has abandoned -- for the time being, anyway -- the ornately melodramatic romances epitomized by his long-running blockbuster "The Phantom of the Opera." He has not presented a new show in New York since "Sunset Boulevard," though he hasn't been idle. He was hoping to come into town last season with "Whistle Down the Wind," but withdrew it for more work after the chilly reception for its tryout run in Washington.
The flow of epic operettas by Alain Boublil and Claude-Michel Schonberg, the French team that gave us "Les Miserables" and "Miss Saigon," appears to have also been temporarily staunched. Their latest endeavor, "Martin Guerre," which opened to dim reviews in London in July 1996, has closed for a second time to allow for still more tinkering. The show was clearly dead when I saw it on its second night, but Cameron Mackintosh, the producer, will not let it lie down.
Yet the number of musicals planned for Broadway this season, the variety of the auspices that were presenting them and the artists involved combined to create expectations of an unusually high order. In addition to "The Capeman," the prospects included "The Lion King," "Ragtime," "Side Show" and "Triumph of Love."
To the consternation of the traditional theater community, it's the Disney Company, the corporate giant whose name is synonymous with faceless clout, that has turned out to be the most eccentric and successful of the new producing entities. Forget "Beauty and the Beast," the company's first, very characteristic production still running at the Palace Theater.
This season's Disney appreciates both Broadway tradition and the care and feeding of great, idiosyncratic talent. Of the new musicals, only Julie Taymor's innovative production of "The Lion King," a singing and dancing show not quite like any other, has become a hit on a scale to influence musicals that come after. That it is being presented in the gorgeously renovated old New Amsterdam Theater, another Disney property, is simply a dividend.
Not to be outdone by Disney is Garth Drabinsky, the Canadian producer who hopes to assemble a new theatrical empire south of his border. He built what is virtually a brand-new theater, the Ford Center for the Performing Arts, and his first production in it is "Ragtime," the musical adaptation of E. L. Doctorow's satiric novel. Like the theater, which is second in size only to the Gershwin, "Ragtime" is big.
It is also well populated, handsome, literate and stately, being an epic operetta in the mode of a home-grown "Les Miz," though easier to follow. The show, which received very good notices from most critics and mixed ones in The New York Times, seems to have settled in for what is hoped to be a long run. It doesn't surprise, but then it doesn't offend.
Already gone: "Side Show," the adventurous, darkly romantic tale of the real-life Siamese twins Daisy and Violet Hilton, a musical whose freakish metaphor seemed to alienate audiences in spite of the witty, unhackneyed score by Henry Krieger and Bill Russell; and "Triumph of Love," a nervy but disastrous attempt to jazz up the elegant subtleties of Marivaux's 18th-century French comedy. The worst mistake made by the collaborators was to assume that Broadway audiences might share the tastes of third-year French Lit majors attending a jokey, one-night-only class show.
Which leaves us where?
Stephen Sondheim, the dean of Broadway composer-lyricists, has recently been writing what are in effect operas, no matter what he calls them. (His latest project, "Wise Guys," about the flamboyant Mizner brothers early in this century, is expected to open next year at the Kennedy Center in Washington.) Yet he can't neutralize his own influence. The rueful melodies and convoluted, blissfully surprising lyrics, the mark of all his work, continue to spawn more terrible imitations than those of anyone since, say, Stephen Foster.
Jonathan Larson's "Rent," the only show whose score and concerns speak without condescension to ticket buyers in their 20's and 30's, is a holdover from two seasons ago. Having come out of New York Theater Workshop in the East Village, "Rent" is also a reminder of the role that the nonprofits have played in keeping the Broadway musical as cutting-edge (and profitable) as it ever gets.
"Bring In da Noise, Bring In da Funk," the hit revue labeled "a tap/ rap discourse on the staying power of the beat," came out of the Joseph Papp Public Theater two years ago. Ms. Taymor, too, was nurtured by nonprofit theaters. But with Federal and state support being reduced, these theaters' future efforts are more problematic than ever.
IT is probably not a coincidence that both Larson and Ms. Taymor display something of the same buccaneering spirit of Gerome Ragni and James Rado, whose seminal rock musical, "Hair," with Galt MacDermot, started out at the Public Theater. It was also the Public that originated "A Chorus Line," Michael Bennett's landmark Broadway show.
The success of "The Lion King" notwithstanding, the Broadway musical is no further along now than it was last September, or 10 years ago when "The Phantom of the Opera" opened.
Frank Wildhorn is doing his best to fill the schmaltz niche with "Jekyll and Hyde" and "The Scarlet Pimpernel." Whether or not you respond to Mr. Wildhorn's rather simple melodies and the fustian narratives that are their contexts, you have to give him and his producers credit for the way they sold "Jekyll and Hyde." The show toured for months before coming to Broadway. By the time it opened in New York the music had been recorded and had reached the charts. "Jekyll and Hyde" was a known quantity, a hit, before any critic could reach for a quill pen.
"Ragtime" was seen in both Toronto and Los Angeles before arriving in New York. "The Lion King" also played out of town, in Minneapolis. In the years before productions became so big and cumbersome that they couldn't travel economically, pre-Broadway shakedowns were standard. They allowed time to gauge, fix, adjust, throw out, put in or, perhaps, to close. Opening cold in New York, like "The Capeman," is cruel and inhuman punishment for everyone concerned, especially in the city that invented kibitzing.
Don't think all is well because the Broadway box office seems to be thriving, the economy is good and inflation is under control. The value of the dollar has nothing to do with the escalating budgets for musical shows, which are beginning to resemble those for movies. It has to do with the old adage about having to spend money to make money, especially on Broadway.
Ms. Taymor's production of "The Lion King" looks as if it cost at least $15 million and, supposedly, it did. Should budgets continue to rise, the temptation must be to play it safe in the way that movie producers do, either by replicating last season's hits as brazenly as possible without plagiarizing them, or by producing sure-fire revivals. When in doubt, ransack the Rodgers and Hammerstein catalogue.
EVEN a producing company with pockets as deep as Disney's can't afford to throw money away on risky adventures, unless the investment can be written off as public relations. Both Disney and Mr. Drabinsky's Livent company, today's biggest new Broadway players, are publicly held. A flop or two of the magnitude of "The Capeman," and stockholders could get restless in a way to shake a corporation's foundations.
Broadway's continuing dilemma: How to present the new and the tried-and-true, the offbeat and the expected in ways that will attract the middle-aged, middle-class audience as well as younger patrons. It is possible to do that, though not necessarily in a single show.
"The Capeman" could have been such a show. The healthy preview business done by the production demonstrated that there was a large audience waiting to adore Mr. Simon's Broadway debut. But, fans or not, they couldn't easily adore a show designed so that neither the actors, who seemed clueless, nor the incoherent narrative were allowed to distract attention from the music. The curious result was that the excellent score was embalmed instead of being brought to life.
The show did not set precedents -- it was inept. It turned its back on those who most wanted to soar with it.
Broadway is adaptable. If it can accommodate Stephen Sondheim and the Who, along with Elton John and Tim Rice, Jerry Leiber and Mike Stoller, and Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d, it can certainly find a place for Paul Simon. Yet audiences should not be confronted, as Mr. Simon's are, by a kind of implacably stony-faced presence. They want to be addressed, persuaded, moved and implicated.
That is how musicals operate. In this connection it's instructive to pay attention to the Encores series at City Center. These concert revivals of shows of the past effectively remind us of the often lamentable state of the current Broadway musical.
Most Encores productions wouldn't last five minutes on Broadway. They are gloriously dated, but they force us to recognize what the American musical lost as it grew up and became more sober-sided. Among other things that seem to have faded: the irreverent, satirical, joyous spirit of an earlier age, especially as expressed in dance. Dancing seems to have all but disappeared from our theater. Well, not quite.
There is "Noise/Funk" and Garth Fagan's exuberant choreography for "The Lion King." Some of the most satisfying moments in "Ragtime" are provided by Graciela Daniele's dances, but the show could use more. The revival of the 1975 "Chicago" seems so fresh and so new largely because of Ann Reinking's dazzling re-creation of Bob Fosse's choreography. It gives the musical a dimension of spontaneous feeling and explosive life that can be generated in no other way.
It is therefore an astonishment that "The Capeman," whose director of record is Mark Morris, one of the most celebrated choreographers in the dance world today, has virtually no dancing at all. The suspicion is that Mr. Morris's collaborators ganged up on him and told him to sit in the corner. Yet "The Capeman" is a show that demands choreography.
You would think that Mr. Simon, Mr. Morris and Derek Walcott, a Nobel laureate for literature in 1992, all newcomers to Broadway, would have made some effort to understand how the musical connects with its audience. They appear not to have cared less. Great shows don't describe emotion but provoke it. They surprise. They may even disturb the peace a bit, as the nudity in "Hair" tried to do.
At the same time, producers must learn to recognize and utilize talented artists like Ms. Taymor without attempting to co-opt them.
If the Broadway musical is to survive, it can't afford to squander its resources: not only its money but also those collaborative artists who never let us forget that Americans, on stage anyway, are singing and dancing fools.

HEADLINE: Classical Music;
A Composer Who Actually Earns a Living Composing

BYLINE: By K. ROBERT SCHWARZ 

 BODY:
FORGET the Beethovenian model of the composer: wild-eyed, hair askew, struggling with recalcitrant material, shaking a fist at the gods. And the Romantic myth of the composer as bohemian, starving in a lonely garret, knowing that recognition will come only after death.
Ellen Taaffe Zwilich's reality is different. Like any good craftsman, Ms. Zwilich works at her desk every day. No agonized struggle stands between her and the music. Since her works are in great demand, she is that rarest of creatures, a composer who makes a living at her profession. 
 With American composers now marginalized to the point of invisibility, the sheer "normalcy" of her career is extraordinary. Well adjusted and disciplined in life as in music, the 58-year-old Ms. Zwilich has developed a relationship with performers and audiences that might have seemed impossible today.
When the violinist Pamela Frank and the Orchestra of St. Luke's, conducted by Hugh Wolff, offer the premiere of Ms. Zwilich's Violin Concerto on Thursday evening at Carnegie Hall, the extent of her achievement will be apparent. Introduced not by new-music specialists but by big-name performers, the concerto is yet another large-scale product of her clear-eyed work ethic. And the audience will not squirm at the thought of a premiere, for listeners have learned that Ms. Zwilich's music is not calculated to offend.
The appeal of her music to performers stems in part from the fact that she was a performer before she was a composer. She first played the trumpet, then, more seriously, the violin. By knowing what players find gratifying and writing parts that are idiomatic and flattering, she has earned their trust.
And her unbridled, almost childlike enthusiasm inspires musicians and listeners alike. "I shouldn't say this, but I really am having a wonderful time working on all this music," she said recently. "I feel like I've died and gone to heaven to be able to write instrumental music for the best orchestras and performers of our time."
Then, of course, there is the music itself. As Ms. Zwilich's style shifted from the dissonant modernism of 25 years ago to the attractive, tonal post-modernism of today, her list of commissions grew exponentially.
Ms. Zwilich, who was born in Miami, moved to New York to study violin with Ivan Galamian and immediately plunged into the freelance performance circuit. As a violinist in the American Symphony Orchestra when Leopold Stokowski conducted it, she mastered orchestral color from the inside out.
She eventually enrolled at the Juilliard School, studied composition with Elliott Carter and Roger Sessions, and in 1975 became the first woman to receive a doctorate in composition from the school. At first she embraced an atonal, systematic approach to composition. But when her husband, Joseph Zwilich, died in 1979, all the complexities of modernism suddenly seemed irrelevant, she said. Now she wanted license to express personal feeling.
She became a national celebrity overnight in 1983, when her Symphony No. 1 won the Pulitzer Prize for composition: again, the first awarded to a woman. Commissions poured in, reporters jostled for interviews, and Ms. Zwilich could suddenly devote herself fully to composition.
The gradual change in her musical style is more audible with every passing year. Ms. Zwilich claims to be barely aware of it. "I think I've gotten more expansive and unafraid," she said. "I think my music is more generous, more open emotionally. More than that I don't know."
But a colleague like John Harbison sees the change. "Now she works with very basic motifs that tend to be displayed clearly at the beginning of the piece, and the result is a clarity of design that is appreciated by performers," he said. "You feel the building materials expand and connect, and the process of development is very possible to follow."
Already in the First Symphony, high modernism had been jettisoned. The textures were stripped bare, the language was more emotive, and the germinal motifs were audibly transformed. Since then, the motifs have become simpler, even triadic, as the music has become increasingly tonal and consonant. Today it is neo-Classic in concision but neo-Romantic in intensity. It is dark-hued and muscular, its brooding, even menacing tone seeming the very antithesis of her own disposition.
Ms. Zwilich's detractors suggest that this journey from modernism to populism smacks of careerism. Those who champion her music disagree.
"She starts with something seminal, consisting of as few strokes as possible, and makes everything come out of that," said the pianist Joseph Kalichstein, who played in the premieres of her Piano Trio and Triple Concerto. "People criticize that and say it's too simple, but it's not really simple. It's only that she wants you to hear everything, not sit and analyze."
All these traits are evident in the Violin Concerto, which was written for Ms. Frank. "During our first coffee, Ellen said, 'So what's your wish list?,' " Ms. Frank recalled. "I told her I would love a giant chamber-music piece with everybody equally involved. I told her that virtuoso passage work doesn't interest me that much."
It happened that Ms. Zwilich shared Ms. Frank's preference for lyricism. "I didn't want to write a loud violin concerto, with the fiddle batting out a lot of forte passages," Ms. Zwilich said. "I didn't want to write something that called attention to the athleticism of the instrument." Indeed, Ms. Zwilich downplayed virtuosity so much that she discarded the notion of a long, formal cadenza.
In its lean orchestration, economical proportions and obsessive motivic development, the 26-minute work pays homage to a Classical tradition Ms. Zwilich is eager to continue. Over a decade and a half, she has written 3 symphonies (a 4th is on the way) and 12 concertos. Some of her smaller orchestral works have been performed more than 150 times. A prolific composer whose works appeal to the public and are played often: this is the kind of normalcy Haydn would have understood.
But real normalcy would require the re-integration of the composer into the community, and here, too, Ms. Zwilich qualifies. For the last three years, she has been the first occupant of Carnegie Hall's Composer's Chair, a position to which has brought considerable flair. She has produced or is producing three works on commission: "Peanuts Gallery," for a family concert, the Violin Concerto and a forthcoming string quartet. In addition, she was asked to design a new format for a new-music series. Her response was Making Music, now in its third season at Weill Recital Hall. Each program focuses on a single composer, whom Ms. Zwilich also engages in a cheerful onstage chat.
CHARACTERISTICALLY, Ms. Zwilich exudes an irrepressible optimism about the future of the American composer, and she wants the world to share it. However bland normalcy may be, Ms. Zwilich believes that it is the wave of the future. So she ignores the gloomy predictions about classical music in America and looks ahead with confidence.
"I look at a concert hall full of people, and some are there because they've been dragged by their partner, some because they think it's the thing they should do, and some because they want to give themselves to the music. And among all these people there's one person sitting there whose life is going to be changed by this concert. That's whom you write music for."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Newark's Slow Office Revival;
Investors Buying Big, Mostly Vacant Buildings

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
BETTING that Newark's slow commercial revival is about to turn a corner, investors are buying some of the big, old and mostly vacant downtown office buildings.
Investors have long been put off by a tangle of urban problems in Newark, where office vacancy rates in much of the downtown area have been well into double digits. But a small group of buyers, including some from Manhattan, now see a potential for profit. They also consider the city one of few places left to buy office space at bargain prices in the 11-county northern New Jersey market, where costs are rising as available space dwindles. The same is true in Manhattan. 
 In one of the larger recent transactions, the Cogswell Realty Group of Manhattan and partners purchased two buildings totaling about a million square feet, most of it empty. The plan is to turn 744 Broad Street into modern offices and 1180 Raymond Boulevard into student housing.
In another transaction, the Townsend Company of Towson, Md., bought a 380,000-square-foot building at 33 Washington Street that it will renovate and return to the market. The company is also selling Gateway II, a 783,000-square-foot Class A occupied building that it bought 15 months ago, to the Manhattan-based Witkoff Group and partners. Still other investors are said to be scouting the city as well.
Newark is beginning to attract more welcome attention, aided in part by new projects intended to stoke its revival. The most notable is the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, whose first phase -- including a 2,700-seat auditorium -- opened last October on 12 acres between Park Place and the Passaic River.
And Prudential Insurance Company of America, a city stalwart, has moved back some 3,800 employees from the suburbs to more than 300,000 more square feet of offices in the city as part of a plan announced two years ago to centralize its operations. The insurer has 7,000 workers occupying about 2 million square feet in the city.
Plans also are advancing for a minor-league baseball stadium and a light rail line linking the downtown to Newark International Airport.
A special improvement district, in which property owners tax themselves to help fight crime and grime, which is to be established downtown by this summer, has also sparked interest, as has the growing influence of public-private partnerships willing to promote development.
"A different investment atmosphere exists today," said Alfred L. Faiella, executive director of the Newark Economic Development Corporation, "and people appreciate that a critical mass is building in the downtown."
They also know that the city offers tax abatements and the downtown is in a state urban enterprise zone, where corporate tenants pay no sales taxes.
But lingering memories of the 1967 rioting that made Newark a symbol of inner-city frustration mean that New Jersey's largest city and its downtown office market still face an uphill climb.
With the ripple effect from Manhattan and "Jersey City all filled up, Newark is the next logical location," said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, adding that the potential is there "for a rebirth of the city's office sector into a viable economic node." But so are the risks, he said, noting that "by no means is it a slam-dunk."
Newark's downtown has suffered since the 50's when the middle class fled to the suburbs, followed by retailers. But by the 80's a wave of renewal gave way to the four-building, 2.5 million-square-foot Gateway office and hotel complex near Pennsylvania Station. The last downtown office building was completed in 1991 before the recession hit and demand for space fizzled.
Now Newark is benefiting from the improvement in the overall office market in the state and the region. Evidence of that is the 3 percent vacancy rate for the downtown's 6.8 million square feet of prime space -- much of it in the Gateway complex, where safety concerns are eased by aerial bridges that connect it to Penn Station.
WHILE in other office markets the lack of Class A space has caused activity to filter to secondary buildings, the same has not happened in downtown Newark. The vacancy rate for its 6.1 million square feet of secondary space is 39 percent, according to Sitar Company/ Oncor International, a real estate services firm based in Iselin, N.J.
There is a better chance now for such a spillover to occur "because the downtown has never reached this point before," said Jonathan S. Meisel, an associate director at the East Rutherford, N.J., office of Cushman & Wakefield, the national brokerage. He cited the lack of construction as an ingredient that did not exist a decade ago.
"Suburban sprawl has resulted in suburban crawl in terms of traffic congestion," said Dean Hughes, "so Newark's central location and access to highways and mass transit links is more significant today."
Still, selling downtown Newark will not be easy.
David S. Sherman, senior managing director at the Saddle Brook, N.J., office of Insignia/ESG, the national brokerage, said that it was "all about confidence," adding that beyond Gateway there was still the perception of crime. He and other brokers said that while demand continued to come from companies already in the city and from government agencies, growth from outside concerns was limited.
Investors, like those that bought 744 Broad Street and 1180 Raymond Boulevard, think that will change. "We saw an opportunity in a market that, slighted for many years, is on the rebound, except for a perception, which is five years behind the reality," said Arthur R. Stern, one of the investors.
Mr. Stern is a partner in Cogswell Realty Group based in Manhattan, which, with Lehman Brothers and other New York investors, bought the two buildings late last year from Newark Building Associates, whose general partner is Peter L. Malkin. Mr. Malkin, chairman of the Wein Malkin & Bettex law firm in Manhattan, has extensive holdings that include investments in the Empire State Building.
Other factors in the decision to buy, said Peter J. Marsh, another Cogswell partner, include the location of the buildings -- near the Gateway complex and the performing-arts center, which over the last five months drew 275,000 visitors. "On top of that," he said, "Manhattan is full and the demand for space continues."
The investment partnership bought the 641,000-square-foot wedding-cake style building at 744 Broad Street for $7.5 million and by this summer they will have invested $45 million to renovate it. Rents, now averaging $10 a square foot, will double, but they will still be 25 percent lower than Class A space in Newark and the suburbs, said Mr. Stern.
Given the scarcity of large blocks of space the partners will relocate existing tenants in the 35-story building to create up to 220,000 square feet of contiguous space. Leases are now under negotiation with six tenants for 44,000 square feet, said Mr. Stern, half of which is expected to be taken by a telecommunications firm from Atlanta. And to create more street life, he added, 48,000 square feet on the building's ground and mezzanine floors will be marketed for retail use.
AT the 440,000-square-foot structure at 1180 Raymond Boulevard, which the partners bought for just under $3 million, the plan is to convert it, at a cost of up to $40 million, to 1,400 dormitory rooms. Converting the Newark building into student housing, Mr. Stern said, will create additional street activity and fill a need from the city's five institutions of higher education. The partners are in the process of buying the ground lease under the building from the city.
Last November, the Townsend Company closed on its $12 million purchase of 33 Washington Street, the half-vacant 380,000-square-foot former headquarters of Blue Cross/Blue Shield of New Jersey. Townsend will invest about $4 million more to improve the building, said Geoffrey Schubert, senior vice president at the Teaneck office of CB Commercial, the national brokerage, which is working with Townsend.
"The bottom line is economics," Mr. Schubert said, noting that tenants looking to save money will be drawn to the building where rents will be lower than those in the prime buildings in the city.
The company is also under contract to sell Gateway II for a reported $84 million. The buyer is the Witkoff Group, along with partners, which expect to close the deal next month, said Kenneth E. Cohen, managing director at the Witkoff Group. "Newark is a definite growth area," he said.
Mr. Schubert said Townsend's purchase of 33 Washington Street was a bigger risk than its Gateway deal. But, he added, the company believes lightning can strike twice with its strategy of adding value and achieving an appropriate return in a city on the rebound.

LENGTH: 1300 words

HEADLINE: Government Called A Shoreham Victim

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
NINE years after the demise of Shoreham, a new analysis of America's largest dead-end industrial project has identified a victim beyond the obvious ones, the customers and shareholders of the Long Island Lighting Company and taxpayers around the United States, who will share a waste of more than $5 billion on the reactor.
The other victim, according to a newly retired policy planner at the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, Joan Aron, is government. Suffolk County, New York State, the N.R.C. and the rest of the Federal Government suffered a huge loss, she argues, not of money but of trust. They lost not only the trust of the public but the trust of each other, according to Ms. Aron. 
 In a new book, "Licensed to Kill? The Nuclear Regulatory Commission and the Shoreham Power Plant" (University of Pittsburgh Press, $18.95 paper, $45 cloth), Ms. Aron also argues that the true impact of the Shoreham debacle has not been felt yet, because one of its key products has not been tried yet, a "reformed" system for licensing future nuclear plants, designed by the commission to prevent future Shorehams. The new system calls for a single license to be granted before constructon begins, and not, as in Shoreham's case, a construction permit and then an operating license when construction is done. The new system will backfire and make nuclear power even less acceptable to the public, she argues, because it reduces the opportunity for public input.
Ms. Aron has taken on a difficult subject -- the writing of contemporary history -- because so many of the people involved in the story have their own passionate perspectives. But in a review of the Shoreham saga, Ms. Aron, who joined the staff of the N.R.C. in 1976 and worked there on and off until early this year, makes a case that governments acted in ways that no one should be proud of and that will have future effects.
"There's a large stake in making a decision that is perceived as 'correct' from all standpoints, including technical, economic, environmental, and policy considerations," she writes. "None of the contending parties -- Lilco, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, New York State or Suffolk County -- had confidence that the other participants were making an honest effort to achieve good public policy. Moreover, no party had confidence that the outcome would be 'right' or that the process would lead to the correct decision. Consequently, each party felt vindicated in departing from the customary rules governing the process and engaging and engaging in questionable practices to achieve its ends."
The Nuclear Regulatory Commisison refused to consider a 20-mile emergency planning zone in place of a 10-mile zone because the larger area might have doomed the plant, she said; Suffolk refused to seriously consider emergency planning because it might have been possible. Lilco plowed forward because it assumed, wrongly, that if it got a license to run the plant, the plant would run. The N.R.C. granted the plant a test license that resulted in radioative contamination and thus raised the eventual price of decmmissioning, because it could not cope with any other outcome, and nobody put the whole situation in context and cut a deal earlier that would have saved everyone time and money, she argues.
Government, of course, is also the cause of the debacle, with one level launching the utility and its ratepayers on a vast industrial project, while another created obstacles that would insure it was all a waste. In a telephone interview, Ms. Aron said that in the end, another problem was that no one in government would take responsiblity for solving the problem, of a reactor inspired by the "too cheap to meter" thinking of the 1950's, reaching completion in the post-Three Mile Island, post-Chernobyl 1980's, when the dominant question was what would happen if an emergency required an evacuation.
"Had anyone been willing to take responsiblity, you probably could have put an extra road on top of the L.I.E., or planned for some Dunkirk-like, imaginative way of getting away," said Ms. Aron, in a telephone interview. Building another roadway on top of the Long Island Expresway and then operating the reactor, she said, would have been cheaper than abandoning it. But the failure to take responsibility, she said, was "partially what's wrong with the decision-making process."
Ms. Aron knows about governmental cooperation and the lack thereof. An associate professor of political science at New York University from 1969 to 1976, she is also the author of "The Quest for Regional Cooperation: A Study of the New York Metropolitan Regional Council."
Shoreham is still very much a factor in Long Island's energy situation, giving the area the highest electric rates in the mainland United States and driving an effort that dates from the days of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to re-structure Lilco. But events beyond the control of anyone on Long Island have rendered it less important than it might have seemed in April 1989, when shareholders of the company voted to accept a deal to kill the plant.
Since that time, the technology for finding natural gas and the infrastructure for bringing it to market has improved markedly, and the price of oil has continued to decline. If Shoreham had run well, its uranium fuel might have replaced about 10 million barrels of oil a year, but over time, the importance of that oil has changed. In 1979, when opposition was strong but construction was well under way, that was worth about $400 million annually; today it is worth only about $150 million, and with the dollar worth less because of intervening inflation, the savings is much smaller than anyone had dared to predict.
Now Gov. George E. Pataki's plan for a partial state takeover of Lilco is advancing, and rebates to customers in Nassau and Suffolk are expected to be sent before Election Day. Rate cuts of 20 percent are also expected.
And with looser rules about who can make and sell electricity, the region continues to have plenty of power, even with the long-term shutdown of the three Millstone reactors across Long Island Sound in Waterford, Conn.
Meanwhile, with more than 100 nuclear plants operating around the country for the last nine years, not one of them has had an incident that resulted in orders to shelter or evacuate.
None of the people who were members of the commission while Shoreham was an issue are still there, although some staff members endure. The book is not kind to the N.R.C., but Ms. Aron, who retired in January and lives in Washington, said that she had not received any reaction from anyone at the agency. She was assisted with the book by Leo Slaggie, who is still the deputy solicitor at the agency.
Ms. Aron's conclusions about nuclear power may not matter, in the sense that it is not clear when any level of government will face a decision on opening a new reactor. She believes, though, that given certain turns in the energy market and concern about global warming and other forms of pollution, the question of how to regulate new reactors could indeed be important. But her conclusion about trust and government might apply to some other technical fields.
If a second nuclear era begins, she writes, with better-designed plants about which there are fewer technical questions, "there will remain a need for the N.R.C. to act -- and to be perceived by the public -- as a bold, vigorous regulatory body, with an aggressive approach to regulatory standards, safety analyses, quality assurance, and investigations of allegations of whistle-blowers (that is, those with safety concerns within and outside the agency), with ends of public health and safety paramount to all other considerations. In short, re-regulation instead of de-regulation."

HEADLINE: Goodwill Games Call World's Athletes to Nassau

BYLINE: By DAVID WINZELBERG 

 BODY:
WITH the completion of a $30 million swimming and diving center in Eisenhower Park this month, Long Island takes a big plunge into international aquatics competition.
When the Goodwill Games start here on July 19, 1,500 athletes from 60 countries will be competing in events at the Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum, the renovated Mitchel Athletic Complex and the new Goodwill Games Swimming and Diving Center, which Nassau County officials say is the second largest indoor swimming center in the world. 
 The pool has a movable floor to adjust to different depths, a 10-meter diving tower, permanent and portable seating for more than 3,000 people and will soon be open for use by county residents.
"This facility is going to be used for a major event, but it is going to be used for years after," the County Parks and Recreation Commissioner, John Kiernan, said. "It wasn't built just for the games."
Several Long Island swim clubs will be among the first to test the waters, in the Speedo Junior Championships, beginning on Tuesday. One thousand young swimmers from the Northeast will compete. Swimmers can qualify for a trip to the Senior Championships next week in Minneapolis, an event that will be held on Long Island next year.
"It's a wonderful opportunity for our kids and our staff to showcase Long Island and swim in a big championship in our own backyard," said Dave Ferris, head coach of the Long Island Aquatic Club.
In addition to the aquatic facilities, a $22 million renovation of Mitchel Park, financed mostly by the county, is under way for the track and field events of the Goodwill Games. On 67 acres adjacent to Hofstra and the coliseum, the park opened in the early 1980's. The upgrading will result in a nine-lane synthetic track, a regulation-size soccer field, a rifle and pistol range, a baseball field, two added lighted soccer fields and seating for 10,000 people. A two-story field house is being built, with locker rooms, conference rooms and press facilities.
After a recent inspection of the Mitchel complex, organizers of the Goodwill Games are planning additional changes, including two-story VIP boxes, an additional 6,000 seats and Jumbotron screens. Mitchel Park is to be the home for 44 track and field events, 22 men's and 22 women's, and women's soccer.
Some Goodwill events will be held in Manhattan, including basketball at Madison Square Garden, boxing and wrestling aboard the Intrepid Air, Sea and Space Museum, cycling in Wien Stadium at the northern tip of Manhattan, beach volleyball in Central Park and the triathlon.
But most of the competition will be on the Island, including all track and field events, figure skating and gymnastics at the Coliseum and 42 swimming and diving events at the aquatic center.
Created by Ted Turner in 1985, the games were founded to promote politically free athletic competition after the Olympics boycotts by the United States and the former Soviet Union in 1980 and 1984. After the inaugural event in Moscow in 1986, the games were held in Seattle in 1990 and St. Petersburg in 1994. With the lessening of international tensions, the games have switched focus, to benefiting children, particularly the Boys and Girls Clubs of America and Unicef.
The games are by invitation. Athletes, based on world rankings, are invited to participate. Past games have seen Jackie Joyner-Kersee, Carl Lewis and Edwin Moses in track and field; Michelle Kwan, Victor Petrenko and Kristi Yamaguchi in figure skating and Janet Evans and Matt Biondi in swimming.
Michael Plant, a former Olympian who is president of the games, said it would not be difficult to get the top athletes to appear. "They're not staying in dormitories, three to a room," he said. "They're put up in nice hotels. They're on worldwide TV and they come away with money."
Appearance fees will no longer be offered to lure top-name athletes to the games, although some money will be paid for promotions. Instead, competitors will vie for prize money based on performance. The $5 million purse is the largest ever for an international multisport event, according to games officials.
Backed by Time-Warner Inc., the games have a full-time staff of 150. Extensive media coverage is expected, including more than 100 hours of television to be shown worldwide. The cable superstation TBS is planning 45 hours of prime-time broadcasts, along with coverage on CBS-TV and HBO. There will be 600,000 tickets available for the events, priced at $10 to $60.
Organizers estimate that the games will bring in more than $50 million to the Long Island economy. "We alone will spend over $25 million in the New York-Long Island area," said one Goodwill Games official. However, the games have yet to turn a profit.
"If you look at the Super Bowl or the Final Four, they didn't make any money in the early days," Mr. Plant said from his office in Atlanta. "It's a long-term investment."
Mr. Plant has announced that the games will be "somewhere in the Asia-Oceania area" in 2002, but he says he is pleased with this year's site. "Over three million people live in the Long Island area," he noted. "It's a family oriented area, and sports is conducive to their quality of life.
He will also look for residents' cooperation. Mr. Plant said the games would need 10,000 volunteers to insure smooth operations.
The 80,000-square-foot natatorium was an integral part of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's bid for the games in 1991. "We knew the one major problem in the bid was the lack of a swimming and diving facility," said Mr. Kiernan, who is also a co-chairman of the Long Island Sports Commission. "Governor Cuomo went to Ted Turner and promised him if we get the bid, New York State would build a world-class aquatic center."
The Empire State Development Corporation, which is responsible for tourism and increasing jobs, was instrumental in building the sports complex. The state gave $24 million for the aquatic center.
"It's terrific that the Goodwill Games will be coming to Long Island," Gov. George E. Pataki said. "Not only will New Yorkers have a chance to watch competition between some of the best athletes in the world, but Long Island will reap the benefits of international attention and the tourism dollars it will bring."

HEADLINE: On Iona Campus, Students' Euphoria Turns Into Heartbreak

BYLINE: By DAN MARKOWITZ 

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE

 BODY:
THE "whoop" nine days ago that thundered out of Rice Hall, a residential dormitory on Iona College's campus here, sounded as if the movie "Animal House" was being remade. But inside, at midday, no toga party raged. Instead, more than 200 Iona students, faculty members and workers cheered, stomped and groaned to the big-screen image of their team playing Syracuse University in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament in Lexington, Ky.
Two days before The Ionian, the campus paper, ran the headline "We're In." One of only 64 teams in the country to make the tournament, Iona's team, the Gaels, had qualified a week earlier by winning the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference tournament in Albany. The Gaels had not been tournament bound since 1985, which explained why Rice Hall and the bars on North Avenue here were crowded with Iona fans glued to television sets. 
 In the Gael Club in Rice Hall, every Iona basket or close-up of an Iona player was greeted with roars and clapping. Even as their team fell behind midway in the first half by 10 points, no one admitted doubting their classmates' chances of stealing a victory over the bigger and higher-ranked Orangemen of Syracuse.
Chris Gomes, 19, a sophomore from Mahopac majoring in economics and political science, like many of his fellow students, was already looking past Syracuse to a prospective, Sweet-16 matchup with Duke University.
"How many chances does a small school like this have of making a name for itself?" he said. "It'd be great for the school to play Duke."
Dave Graham, a security guard, liked Iona's chances even as they trailed 30-20. "We've got a good bunch of kids," he said. "They don't panic. They all walk around the campus together. They're a family. Syracuse will falter."
A few dynamic minutes later, Iona forged into the lead, and the Rice Hall crowd rose to its feet, stomping and chanting and seemingly making more noise than the Iona fans being televised from Lexington, Ky.
The Iona surge added more gusto to the students' bold predictions for their team. Pierina Biundo, 19, a sophomore majoring in economics, said: "This is extremely exciting. I can't wait to see them make it all the way to the Final Four."
Pete Montanez, 21, a senior sociology major, waved a March 3 issue of The Daily News and pointed to his picture on the back page where he was shown as one of the many Gael fans swarming the Iona players after they won the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference tournament. "If I can get on the back page of The Daily News," he said, "we can win the championship."
Vinny DiNota, 20, a sophomore and an international decision technology major, said: "This team has a lot more heart than any team I know. I think it's fate that they make it to the Final Four."
Louis Barbier, 21, a senior also majoring in international decision technology, said, "We've got nothing to lose."
Nearby in the Mulcahy Center, the college athletics building, a group of staff members sat somewhat more calmly in the offices of the basketball coach, Tim Welsh, watching the game on television. It was Welsh, 36, who took over for his father, Jerry, three and a half years ago and turned Iona into a winner again. Primarily a commuter school of 3,500 undergraduate students, Iona was first put on the national basketball map by the legendary coach Jim Valvano in 1978 when he snatched the Gaels' current assistant coach, Jeff Ruland, away from the University of Kentucky.
Iona amassed a 53-13 record over the next two seasons and its first and only victory in an National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament game in three attempts. So as the Gaels edged in front of Syracuse by 3 points in the second half of their fourth tournament game in the school's 46th basketball season, Dr. J. Morrow, a psychology professor and the psychologist for the athletics department, said with a sigh, "I don't think I can survive 13 more minutes."
Kevin Van Meter, the school's public address announcer at Mulcahy for the last 29 years, paced the office, announcing the names of the Iona players who scored as if it were a home game and he was behind the microphone. With Iona leading 61-60 and 24 seconds remaining, Dr. Morrow said, "I think this is the most nervous I've been in some time."
Welsh had said a few days before the game that the N.C.A.A. tournament had grown into a national sporting frenzy because of the impact of television and "the excitement of the upsets." Now his team was on the verge of pulling off one of the tournament's biggest upsets. March Madness, one of the tournament's many nicknames, had gripped Iona and out on the main quadrangle only a handful of students could be seen milling about.
But at the finish, Marius Janeulis of Syracuse nailed a 3-point shot with a second remaining to squash Iona's Cinderella dreams. Tim Brando, announcing the game on CBS-TV, said of the contest's 15 lead changes, "It's been Heartbreak Hotel to euphoria."
Iona clearly dwelled in Heartbreak Hotel. The pain sketched on the faces of Iona players on television was mirrored by staff members in the office. Dr. Morrow said quietly, "I feel sick."
Outside, Tarance Rose, 25, a senior who played for the Iona team last year, called out to a friend across campus: "Did you see the game? That was a heartbreaker." His friend, walking with his head down like so many other students on the suddenly silent campus, did not even look up to answer.

HEADLINE: Meals for the Elderly: A Growing Need

BYLINE: By JULIE MILLER 

 BODY:
THE setting was the Pawcatuck Neighborhood Center, and the stuffed cabbage, mashed potatoes and carrots were served in plastic-covered containers. But for the 57 elderly from the Stonington area, gathered for lunch and bingo, the event was reminiscent of a family get-together.
Bill and Hilda Harrison, who are in their 70's, mingled with old friends and met new people, too. Bingo keeps their minds agile, the Harrisons said. "It's good therapy," Ms. Harrison said. "We're doing things while we're still able to get out." 
 The Harrisons also like the meal plan. "When we're home, we're apt to eat more than we need," said Ms. Harrison. "This way, we have a balanced meal, which is good at our age."
For Edith Garretson of Stonington, who recently celebrated her 98th birthday, the attraction at the Pawcatuck center isn't the food or bingo. "I come because of the people," said Ms. Garretson, who moves around with the aid of a walker or a cane. "I don't get out very much. This is the one time I can socialize."
The Pawcatuck Neighborhood Center, like other community groups nationwide, participates in the government-funded Elderly Nutrition Program for people 60 and older. The meals, offered at senior centers and delivered to people who are homebound, serve as not only a social device but also as a way to introduce the elderly in need to health services like blood pressure screening.
But financial support for the meal program has failed to keep pace with need. State spending has been flat for the past five years. A modest increase in Federal funds for the current year -- the first since 1994 -- was not enough to offset the growing number of older people and the increase in costs due to inflation. And budget proposals for the 1999 fiscal year do not increase funding for nutrition, said Christine Lewis, manager of the elderly services division of the state's Department of Social Services.
In Connecticut, 13 regional meal programs serve more than 12,500 meals daily at 200 locations. The number of participants has remained the same for several years. "There is a larger population that could make use of these meals. But directors of some programs hesitate to reach out and find more people, because they know they can't expand and stay within their budgets," Ms. Lewis said.
Federal funds, including some money from the Department of Agriculture, pay only about one-third of the cost of home-delivered meals, Ms. Lewis said. The larger share is covered with state, local and private contributions. Elderly participants are encouraged to make a donation at each meal.
The changing health care system is another factor affecting the meal programs. As elderly patients are discharged from hospitals and nursing homes more quickly, community agencies are expected to assume the job of caring for them. As a result, meal programs are relied on to provide food to a larger number of sicker and functionally impaired older people.
A decade ago, 60 percent of the elderly participants in the Thames Valley Elderly Nutrition Project, which serves 39 towns in the Norwich area, had their meals at senior centers. Forty percent received meals at home. But the picture is reversed now, said the director of the project, Mary Lou Underwood.
The trend is nationwide. Since 1980 the number of meals served annually has risen to 240 million from 168 million. Home-delivered meals now account for 49 percent of the total, according to the Federal Administration on Aging. By contrast, the Federal budget for the meal program, frozen at $470 million for four years, went up to just $486 million for the 1998 fiscal year.
"Programs across the nation are searching for answers. I'm not sure they understand how common their situation is," said Jean Lloyd, a nutritionist with the Administration on Aging. "I don't think we've come to grips as a society that we've grown older."
The Federal Older Americans Act, the source of support for the meal program, has not been reauthorized since 1995. Social service workers say the law should be updated so that it reflects changing demographics and health care trends. A Congressional committee has begun work on reauthorization legislation, and a bipartisan bill is expected this year, said a spokesperson for Representative Rosa L. DeLauro, a Democrat of New Haven.
"Congress needs to set policy for the next century," said Ms. Lewis of the state's Department of Social Services. "Reauthorization establishes policy for the program. If the act is reauthorized, you'll see stronger commitment, which usually means more money."
Meal programs rely heavily on fund-raising events and donations to defray expenses. Stephanie Belding, director of the meal program operated by the Community Renewal Team of Greater Hartford Inc., said she and other meal providers have also used automation to reduce labor costs and that they work hand in hand with volunteers -- many of whom are themselves elderly -- in order to save money.
"I think we're meeting the needs of the people we have in the program now," said Ms. Belding. "Are there others out there with needs to be met? Yes. Are there communities in which we don't provide the service? Yes."
The meal programs were intended to be grass-roots operations, dependent on staffing and money from local communities. Government funding was never expected to cover all expenses, noted Ms. Lloyd.
The Thames Valley Elderly Nutrition Project raises $500,000 annually from meal donations, contributions from municipalities and fund-raising events. Without that money, Ms. Underwood said, she would serve 500 fewer meals daily.
Still, Ms. Underwood had to cut her staff last year when support was reduced by approximately $70,000. She and the remaining staff worked in the kitchen and drove delivery trucks in addition to their regular duties, she said.
"We ended up burning the staff out," she said. On the other hand, "It's hard to tell people wanting home-delivered meals that there's a waiting list."
Home-delivered meals involve much more than food. They are a vital part of an elderly person's plan of care, said Mary Ellen Girard, a planner with the Eastern Connecticut Area Agency on Aging.
Delivery drivers are instructed to check on the person receiving the meal and notify the meal project immediately if no one answers the door. Drivers also watch for signs that the person is confused, hasn't been eating or is ill and alone.
Ms. Girard said that "the only daily visit for thousands of elderly people occurs through the person who delivers the meal. Many times it's the driver who finds the person on the floor or so ill they call an ambulance."
Greater challenges lie ahead. The number the elderly, especially those 85 and older, is expected to double by 2030. Many meal programs, locally and nationally, have waiting lists. There are 25 people on a waiting list in New London, Ms. Underwood said. A study published in 1996 found that 41 percent of home-delivered meal programs nationwide had waiting lists.
Ms. Belding perceives the problem as part of a larger issue.
"How are we going to care for these people, who want to stay in their own homes? To do that, we need to bring in the home health aide to clean and prepare meals. I see that need growing within the whole area of long-term care."
Ms. Belding said she and other meal providers are looking forward to a time when managed care will cover meal costs.
"We all have to realize the Federal Government can't pay for everything," she said. But, citing the benefits of home care, she added "it's a lot less expensive than nursing homes."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Susan Lord is among guests at the Pawcatuck Neighborhood Center. (Carla Cataldi for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Winter? Or How It Used to Be Known

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
THOSE who might have thought that the winter a year ago was the winter that wasn't can now readjust their thinking. The season that just drew to a more or less blase close was the real thing, the bona fide winter that wasn't, according to meteorological records.
It barely snowed. It froze occasionally. Golfers basked in a spring-like glow almost straight through from November to March, the period that used to be known as winter. Municipal road-clearing budgets went practically unused for the second season in a row. 
 A year ago in the Westchester section, the 1996-97 winter was described as wimpy. In retrospect and compared with the winter that failed to occur a year later, that was an exaggeration.
This year, February passed without a snowflake falling in Central Park for the first time since Federal officials began keeping weather records in 1869, and so far, the ground during March has been similarly nearly nonwhite. "The 1997-98 winter had the least amount of snow and was the warmest winter on record in a very long time," reported Michael Wooldridge, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service on Long Island.
As a point of comparison, New York recorded 75 inches of snow in 1996, including 21.2 in February.
In all, only 0.5 inch of snow fell on Central Park -- although rainfall was heavier than usual -- with temperatures averaging 7 degrees warmer than normal. The 1997-98 nonwinter was typical of an El Nino year when usually cold waters off the coast of Peru turn warm and spawn milder and wetter weather elsewhere, Mr. Wooldridge said.
There may be more atypical weather in store this year. El Nino's little sister, La Nina, could generate cooler than normal water temperatures off Peru during the summer, presaging a vicious hurricane season.
"We'll have to wait and see," Mr. Wooldridge said. "There are still a lot of what-if's in the equation."
Meanwhile, department of public works chiefs and finance commissioners throughout the county were cheering as they surveyed both their budgets and the condition of municipal roads after two mild winters.
In New Rochelle, Highway Superintendent Thomas G. McKnight said that in 39 years of serving the city: "I've never seen weather like this. We bought 3,000 tons of salt, and I doubt if we used 100."
Observing that the sandboxes along 75 miles of city roads were still full, he added: "Some winters are bad, some good. After a while, you learn to go with the flow."
Finance Commissioner Howard Rattner of New Rochelle was pleased as well, reporting that the surplus from the city's snow-removal budget was headed for the general fund. "Two years ago, we ran over our snow-removal allotment," he said.
In Greenburgh, Albert C. Regula, Commissioner of Public Works, said he too was happy. So far in the town's snow-removal budget for 1998, only $45,000 out of an available $325,000 has been spent. And the roads are going into spring with few potholes, allowing Greenburgh to move ahead with other projects. "We haven't had a lot of the freeze-thaw cycles that do so much damage," Mr. Regula said.
While many enumerated the pluses of the two-year respite from snow and ice, other businesses, like American A&C Towing in New Rochelle, sat idle far more than normal, Jeffrey Findel, the owner, said.
Some mild grumbling was also heard at Brewer's Hardware and Marine Center in Mamaroneck, where Anthony Lividini, the general manager, reported that snow blowers and salt were far from hot commodities.
At House Center True Value Hardware in White Plains, the owner, Alfred Urban, said the good weather set off a negative chain reaction.
"During harsh winters, things break down and people head for the hardware store," he said. "They have to reinsulate windows, make repairs. It affects us all the way down the line."
Local ski shops, however, reported booming sales. There may have been no snow in Westchester, but New England had more than enough. Christopher Foster, a store manager at Princeton Ski Shops in Elmsford, said of the winter: "Terrific season! Awesome. Better than we expected."
Overall, businesses prospered as a result of the warmer-than-normal temperatures, with Telecheck, a leading payment systems company in Houston, reporting that sales in New York rose 5 percent in February because shoppers were undeterred by weather as they were elsewhere as the storms of El Nino played havoc with the economy.
From a naturalist's perspective, Christopher Carrol Letts, a staff educator for the nonprofit Hudson River Foundation, expressed downright disappointment about the season that wasn't in the New York City region.
"I missed winter," Mr. Letts said, mournfully. "I like shoveling snow and cutting wood."
Another frustration: the birds had adequate plant life to feed on because there was no snow cover this year, making them only occasional visitors to Mr. Letts's feeding stations. "They didn't show up for dinner as I had hoped," he said.
And because the sap has been running since October, Mr. Letts did not insert maple syrup taps this spring, deciding to save the trees from further stress.
With temperatures remaining mild except for a few days in late December and early January, ice fishing, too, has been mostly out of the question.
The warm temperatures late in February and early March prompted bulbs to emerge prematurely, leaving most of them, except for the snowdrops, vulnerable to the cold snap that followed. "Along comes this crush of cold, and the dwarf iris and crocus are -- forget it," Mr. Letts said. "They're spaghetti."
The shad appearance up the Hudson River -- which starts about the time the forsythia blooms -- is due early next month and will continue through mid-May. But fishermen are watching closely to see if the fish, like the flowers, make an early run this spring.
Many of the spring birds, including the robin and the red-winged blackbird, arrived weeks ago, and some were unprepared for the cold, said Anne Swaim, a staff naturalist with the Saw Mill River Audubon Society, one of five Audubon chapters in Westchester. Most, though, are thriving and beginning their spring song making.
The skunk cabbage has been out since February; the gentle pussy willows are in bloom; the peepers are conducting their annual spring chorus, and woodpeckers are drumming happily on tree trunks.
At Muscoot Farm in Somers, four baby lambs made their debut recently, and a dozen more are expected shortly.
Goat kids are due, along with kittens, ducklings and Easter chicks, the County Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation said.
The shift to spring, along with the lengthening days, has generally contributed to humanity's improving mood, reported Dr. Maureen D. Empfield, director of psychiatry at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco. Those who suffer from episodes of seasonal affective disorder, depression that coincides with fewer hours of daylight, are finally experiencing some relief. And those who feel just plain down when the weather is dreary, are brightening, she said.
"Many people are affected by the weather," Dr. Empfield said. "When there's a lot of snow, they tend to be more anxious. When spring comes, they feel like getting outside and starting projects. Rarely does anyone come into my office and complain about the sunshine."
Looking ahead to spring, the county's golf courses -- Saxon Woods in Scarsdale, Maple Moor in White Plains, Mohansic in Yorktown Heights and Dunwoodie and Sprain Lake in Yonkers -- will officially reopen on Saturday. The county's automated tee-time reservation system at 242-4653 began accepting reservations yesterday.
The Parks Department will sponsor a countywide volunteer cleanup of its parks, pathways and nature preserves on April 5 from 9 A.M. to 3 P.M. to remove graffiti, clear trails, prepare flower beds and clear away debris. All participants will receive discount coupons redeemable at county parks. For more information or to sign up for a project, call 285-4481.
