HEADLINE: For Metropolitan Phoenix, 6 Golf Courses a Year

BYLINE: By VERNE G. KOPYTOFF 

DATELINE: PHOENIX

 BODY:
IF all of the fairways and greens in this hot, cactus-studded metropolis -- 165 golf courses, in all -- were placed in a straight line, the swath of grass and sand traps would stretch hundreds of miles across the Sonoran Desert.
Daunting? Perhaps. Overkill? Not at all, at least in the minds of many golf-course developers. 
 Since 1992, crews have bulldozed an average of six new golf courses a year through the sprawl of retirement communities and housing tracts here in central Arizona, according to the Arizona Golf Association. Studies by the National Golf Foundation in Jupiter, Fla., show that metropolitan Phoenix is among the country's leaders in the number of golf courses that have opened since 1992 as well as in the number planned or under construction.
"Golf wasn't always cool," said Lawrence Hirsh, president of Golf Property Analysts, a golf course appraisal and marketing company in Harrisburg, Pa. "But it is now. The growth has been going on for a while and I don't see it slowing down at least for the next few years."
The construction of golf courses in Phoenix, typically at a cost of $5 million to $15 million each, coincides with a renewed interest in golf development in many parts of the country, especially around Washington, Detroit and Boston and in the Sun Belt. In all, 2,432 courses opened or expanded between 1992 and 1997, according to the National Golf Foundation.
Experts have several explanations for this phenomenon. Tom Patrick, president of the Golf Industry Association of Arizona, says that demographics is one of the driving forces behind the construction.
"Baby boomers will be reaching the perfect age category when they have a lot of time on their hands," said Mr. Patrick, who is also vice president in charge of golf for SunCor Resort and Golf Management, which operates several courses in the Phoenix area. "They will be looking for entertainment and recreation like cruise ships and golf. People tend to play more golf as they grow older."
Development of golf courses, Mr. Patrick said, has been spurred by the improving economy, expanding tourism, the availability of Wall Street money to finance construction and improved access to bank loans. People are less skittish about investing in golf courses these days, he said, because of the sport's high profile and the emergence of large corporations that own several courses, rather than "mom and pop" entrepreneurs who operate just one or two.
Phoenix is particularly attractive for golf development, experts say, because it is among the fastest growing metropolitan areas in the country. The population, currently 2.7 million, grew 22.7 percent between 1990 and 1996.
The sport has a major economic impact on the state's economy. A study by the National Golf Foundation shows that golf generated $905 million in greens fees and related sales in 1996, placing it among the top 10 industries in the state, according to the Arizona Department of Commerce.
Golf is hardly a new arrival to Phoenix. For years, snowbirds by the thousands have migrated here to spend part of their winters with their drivers and putters.
PARTLY because of this legacy and partly to be competitive, developers of upper-middle-class and luxury subdivisions often dress up their properties with at least one golf course to entice buyers and increase the price that they can charge for a plot of land. Mr. Patrick said a lot in a golf community can cost a minimum of 10 percent more than one in a regular residential complex. If the lot is on the fairway, he added, it can cost as much as 200 percent more.
Such is the case at Superstition Mountain, a planned community that opened recently near Apache Junction, a suburb 50 miles east of downtown Phoenix. Earlier this month, workers at the development were putting the finishing touches on one of two 18-hole golf courses that sprout where there was once only palo verde, cholla and thorns.
The two rolling courses, set against a backdrop of scrubland and granite escarpments, were designed by Jack Nicklaus. Thomas J. Popa, vice president of the Superstition Mountain Company, said building the courses would probably have not been worth it if memberships, which cost $35,000 and are limited to 780 families, were the only source of income.
The Superstition Mountain Company, which is owned by Lyle Anderson Company, a major golf community developer, plans to sell 250 lots, from a half acre to an acre, at an average cost of $250,000. Negotiations are under way to sell an additional 750 lots to a builder, who will package the lots with a choice of several homes at an inclusive price of $250,000 and $650,000.
But the reliance on golf in developments like Superstition Mountain presents a potential problem, given that the number of enthusiasts is limited. Will nongolfers be reluctant to pay a premium for living near a golf course that they will never use?
Not at all, Mr. Popa said. "In developments like this one, at least 25 percent of the buyers don't play golf," he said. "But they want to live on the course.
"They like the parklike atmosphere and the guard-gate security," Mr. Popa added. "They just want to be in a planned community where home design is controlled so that they have the resale price security."
People from out of state who choose to live at Superstition Mountain may notice that the golf courses are somewhat different from what they are accustomed to. Regulations in Arizona limit every 18-hole course to the equivalent of 90 acres of grass to conserve water.
The result is sometimes a "target course," which requires players to hopscotch balls over saguaro cactus and dry washes to greens that are the size of a helicopter landing pad. At Superstition Mountain, designers complied with the law by creating roughs with less unmowed grass than usual and more patches of granite pebbles.
Some people question whether all of the multitude of golf courses in metropolitan Phoenix can survive. Gene Krekorian, a golf real estate specialist at Economics Research Associates in Los Angeles, said that some courses in Phoenix -- those that are not tied to a residential development or resort and must survive solely on golf-generated profits -- may eventually feel the strain of overbuilding.
"The long-term prospects are reasonably good," he said. "In the short- to mid-term, you can very easily have a situation where there is a softness in the market."
For the time being, people involved with the golf industry in the area report that tee times are so hard to get that players must often reserve a few weeks in advance. Greens fees on private courses, which can vary between $35 and $175 during the winter high season, are escalating.
"There is plenty of demand as long as the economy remains relatively strong," said Ed Gowan, executive director of the Arizona Golf Association.

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
A Troubling Legacy of Conversions

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
HARDLY anyone would argue with the suggestion that now is a good time to be a co-op shareholder selling an apartment. Hardly anyone, that is, but someone whose apartment is in a building in which a majority of the units are still owned by the original sponsor.
"This is New York's dirty little secret," said James G. Samson, a Manhattan lawyer who represents co-ops and condominiums. "I would say that there are several hundred co-ops in New York right now where sponsors own more than 50 percent of the units." 
 The reason the issue is so important, Mr. Samson and other co-op lawyers say, is because apartments in such co-ops are virtually impossible to sell because lenders are exceedingly hesitant to provide financing in buildings in which fewer than half the units are owned by residents.
The problem, of course, is not new. Co-op lawyers, boards and shareholders in some buildings have struggled for years to convince, cajole or compel sponsors to sell units they still own. In other buildings, boards and shareholders have taken a less aggressive approach by deciding to wait patiently for the day when the co-op market itself would be robust enough to provide sponsors with the necessary incentive to sell apartments.
In recent months, however, co-op watchers have become increasingly concerned that sponsors in some buildings -- perhaps many buildings -- may never have that incentive. For while the sales market is as robust as it has been for many years, the rental market is equally strong -- and many sponsors seem content to hold onto their unsold apartments, collect the monthly rent checks and let the co-op board take care of the business of being a landlord.
"If a sponsor doesn't sell in this market, he has no intention of selling," Mr. Samson said. "And the scariest part is that if we don't hurry up and start forcing them to sell, we're going to destroy the credibility of the co-op market for good."
Mr. Samson is not the only co-op expert who is concerned.
Carol Ott, publisher of Habitat, a New York-based magazine that covers co-op and condominium issues, said she had been told by several co-op lawyers that some sponsors do not seem to be trying to sell their unsold units to new tenant-shareholders.
"This is particularly true for buildings in the outer boroughs," Ms. Ott said.
Errol Brett, a Manhattan co-op lawyer, said that there was an obvious reason why sponsors had stopped selling apartments after the initial conversion has taken place -- lack of an economic incentive to do so.
"The breakdown in the system is that when buildings were being converted, everybody believed that as sponsors obtained vacancies they would just continue selling until they were eventually out of the picture," he said. "But the sponsors realize now that if they sell an apartment that becomes vacant and they put the money in the bank, the interest they earn is nothing compared to what they can make in rent on a deregulated apartment."
Mr. Brett explained that when a building is converted, tenants generally can either buy their unit or remain as a rental tenant. If a nonpurchasing rent-regulated tenant moves out after the conversion, the apartment is then deregulated. That means that the sponsor -- or an investor who has stepped into the sponsor's shoes as a "holder of unsold shares" -- can now rent the apartment at market rent.
"You can be sure they get a better rate of return by renting," Mr. Brett said, adding that the rent being received typically far exceeds the maintenance charges the sponsor must pay to the co-op.
Steven M. Goldman, a Manhattan lawyer who represents both sponsors and co-op boards, acknowledged that sponsors do not appear to be in any rush to sell unsold apartments. The question, however, is whether there is any obligation on their part to do so.
"When I'm representing a co-op board, I'd like to say that a sponsor is obligated to effectuate the plan that he originally intended, which is the total conversion of the building to tenant-ownership," Mr. Goldman said. At the same time, however, Mr. Goldman said, it is generally presumed in the law that individuals cannot be forced to sell property they own simply because it would be in someone else's best interest for them to do so.
Jonathan Beyer, chief of the New York State Attorney General's Real Estate Financing Bureau, agreed.
"Right now, there is no law that requires a sponsor to sell his unsold units," Mr. Beyer said. Once a sponsor sells the minimum number of units required to declare the co-op conversion effective -- usually 15 percent of the units -- the sponsor may then sell additional units whenever he chooses to do so.
Moreover, Mr. Beyer said, since sponsors are required to file reports with the Attorney General's office after the conversion only when they are selling apartments, there is no easy way to determine how many sponsors now hold unsold apartments if they are not actively marketing them.
Generally speaking, he said, the only way the Attorney General's office can force a sponsor to sell units would be to prove that he or she never really intended to sell all the apartments in the building in the first place and thereby perpetrated a fraud against the shareholders. But since the proof required is one of original intent -- as opposed to a situation in which a sponsor who originally intended to complete a conversion subsequently changed his mind -- it is extraordinarily difficult to win such a case.
"There is no question that this can have a very practical and very real impact on consumers," Mr. Beyer said. "But we can only enforce the laws we have."
He added that shareholders who believe they are being harmed by continued sponsor involvement can call the Attorney General's office at (212) 416-8122 for a survey that will be used to develop future suggestions for legislation.
And though only the Attorney General can bring a fraud action against a sponsor under the Martin Act -- the law that authorized and now regulates the co-op form of ownership -- shareholders and boards are not entirely helpless.
"If you're a shareholder, and the sponsor is not selling his unsold apartments," argues Mr. Samson, "the sponsor is damaging the co-op and can be sued for common law fraud," something he has done on several occasions. "The problem is that it's often impractical to sue because you can end up with some expensive litigation."
Addressing that problem just became easier as a result of a court ruling obtained by Peter Livingston, another Manhattan co-op lawyer. Last month he convinced a New York appeals court to rule that a co-op board had the authority to impose an assessment against all shareholders -- including a sponsor -- to support litigation against the sponsor.
"That means shareholders and boards may not be as powerless as they may think," Mr. Livingston said.

HEADLINE: Streetscapes/William Van Alen;
An Architect Called the 'Ziegfeld of His Profession'

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
THE Art Deco Chrysler Building at 42d Street and Lexington Avenue is a touchstone for New York City architecture. Yet its architect, William Van Alen, remains little known.
Only a few of Van Alen's works approached his 1929 masterpiece, but most show the hand of "the Ziegfeld of his profession," as he was described by a colleague. Although the dedicated may still make a pilgrimage to a few sites, many survive only in picture archives. 
 William Van Alen was born in 1882 in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. His father, Jacob, who founded the New York Stove Works, died around 1890. Van Alen's mother then married a hardware merchant. William Van Alen went to public school, and at 16 got a job as an office boy with Clarence True, at that time a major architect-developer of row houses on the Upper West Side.
Van Alen studied at night at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, and about 1902 was hired by the architectural firm of Clinton & Russell, working as a draftsman on the Hotel Astor in Times Square.
He later graduated from the Ecole des Beaux-Arts in Paris. In 1930, the critic Kenneth Murchison wrote in The American Architect magazine that Van Alen was "the only American student who returned from Paris without a box full of architectural books." Murchison wrote that Van Alen's attitude as a young architect was, "No old stuff for me! No bestial copyings of arches and colyums and cornishes! Me, I'm new! Avanti!"
Van Alen started his own practice in 1911 with an office in the Metropolitan Life Tower at 24th Street and Madison Avenue, which from 1909 to 1913 was the tallest building in the world. No buildings designed by him independently in those years have been identified. In 1914 he formed a partnership with H. Craig Severance. In 1992, Severance's daughter, Faith Hackl Stewart, said that "Mr. Van Alen was a Beaux-Arts man, but my father got most of the business for the firm."
Many writers have credited Van Alen with the design of most of the firm's buildings, including their Standard Arcade, a two-story arcade of shops designed in 1914 at 50 Broadway. The building was not much more than two giant Doric columns with a wide sheet of glass between, unusual for its openness.
Another early design was the Albemarle, a 1915 office building at the northwest corner of Broadway and 24th Street, which was notable for the lack of a cornice. In this period Van Alen was still living at home in a Brooklyn row house at 411 Putnam Avenue with his mother, stepfather, sister and aunt.
On Jan. 16, 1916, Van Alen married Elizabeth Bagley at the Tompkins Avenue Congregational Church; Severance was his witness. The 1920 census recorded the Van Alens living in a five-story apartment house at 738 St. Mark's Avenue in Brooklyn.
In 1920 Van Alen began establishing his credentials as a modernist, with commissions for several big midtown buildings, including the Gidding Building, at 724 Fifth Avenue between 56th and 57th Streets, and the Bainbridge Building, at 37 West 57th.
The latter structure is the clearest Van Alen statement: a sheer wall of limestone with windows set flush at the line of the facade and giant show windows on the lower floors, discarding the pretense of heavy masonry walls "supporting" the upper ones.
These buildings were sophisticated but were appreciated mostly by connoisseurs. But in 1924, when Van Alen designed the new Childs restaurant at 604 Fifth Avenue, at 49th Street, everyone noticed. Van Alen rethought the midblock site (which had a church garden along the south end) and gave his building a curved corner wrapping back to the side wall so that the building overlooked the church lot, effectively doubling the frontage.
The Childs building, which still stands, had curved windows at this corner. It was apparently the first use of cantilevered construction, with no corner column, in New York. The critic John W. Harrington said the building seemed "at first blush to be entirely of rock crystal" and called the technique the "Quartz school of architecture."
Van Alen enlarged on this idea with his Lucky Strike storefront, at the northwest corner of 45th Street and Broadway, and the Delman shoe store at 558 Madison Avenue, at 56th Street, both completed in 1927. The Lucky Strike storefront was stainless steel, with an oval window curved around the corner, a spectacular feat of glazing that remains unduplicated.
At the Delman Building Van Alen put two oval windows on the second floor, where cobblers in blue smocks built shoes, attracting an audience. Murchison wrote that he made a "moving picture out of a couple of lasts." At the top he put a curious classic-modern touch, a triangular gable broken into an abstract rendition of the traditional form of a broken pediment.
In 1928 Van Alen was hired by Walter Chrysler to design a tall building at 42d and Lexington. Construction was nearly complete in late 1929 when the magazine The Architect awarded him a "Doctor of Altitude." The next year Murchison described Van Alen as "the Ziegfeld of his profession" and visited him in his office on the 65th floor of the Chrysler Building, which was guarded by "two firm and unyielding secretaries, both of them ex-shotputters from the Vassar College team."
That was the same year Van Alen had to sue Chrysler for his fee; he put a mechanic's lien on the building.
VAN ALEN also owned the northeast corner of 56th Street and Lexington Avenue, and a month before the October 1929 stock market crash he announced plans for a 26-story apartment hotel, which would have revealed how he would design to satisfy only himself. But the Depression killed that project, and the worsening economic climate must have cast a chilly gloom over the annual ball of the Beaux-Arts Institute of Design at the Hotel Astor.
Nonetheless, Van Alen appeared in a dazzling costume modeled on the Chrysler Building, made of silver metal cloth trimmed with black patent leather, flame-colored silk and flexible wood. The shoulder ornaments were the eagle heads at the 61st-floor setback.
There was not much to do for an architect of gaudy skyscrapers in the 1930's, but Van Alen tried other fields. In 1934 he published a design for a modernistic copper-clad house to be mass produced, and in 1936 he erected a similar steel house as a demonstration on a vacant lot at 39th Street and Park Avenue. The developer Charles Paterno built an apparent twin at the southeast corner of 107th Street and Riverside Drive in the same year. In 1938 Van Alen lost his Lexington Avenue site in foreclosure.
Although The Architectural Record reported that manufacturing plants for the house had been set up in New York, Cleveland, Pittsburgh and Chicago to serve over 100 dealers, so far only the model itself is known to have survived. It was relocated to the Sea Gate section of Brooklyn about 1941, where it stands at 5100 Ocean View Avenue.
Van Alen died in 1954, leaving only his widow -- no children or even nieces or nephews are known to survive. He left most of his estate in trust for his wife, and upon her death it was distributed to the Beaux-Arts group. It sponsors a yearly Van Alen prize, and in 1995 took the name Van Alen Institute, to honor its benefactor. But of Van Alen's office records -- scrapbooks, drawings, correspondence, student work -- nothing is known to survive.
Van Alen's buildings have proved more durable. The Lucky Strike storefront in Times Square lasted only a few years, as did the Standard Arcade on lower Broadway. But the Childs restaurant building on Fifth Avenue, although altered, still survives. The Gidding and Bainbridge buildings are fairly intact, as is the Albemarle Building and, of course, the Chrysler Building.
The peculiar Delman Building, although demolished in the 1970's for what is now the Sony Building at 56th and Madison, has earned itself a minor footnote in history. Its successor, built as the AT&T Building, was considered remarkable for what was often called its "Chippendale top," the form of a broken pediment often seen on 18th-century furniture. A generation ago such classical details were startling.
In 1989 the architect Philip Johnson was queried about whether the origins of his newer building owed anything to the structure on the site. He wrote back that he had been unaware of Van Alen's building but that, in any event, "there is nothing very original about a broken pediment."

HEADLINE: What Public? Whose Use?

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS 

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY

 BODY:
IF it were just a question of public relations, it would be no contest. On one side of Columbia Place is a casino belonging to Donald Trump. On the other are Vera Coking, a widow in a three-story building that she ran for decades as a boarding house; Clare and Vincent Sabatini, proprietors of a little Italian restaurant, and Peter Banin, a gold merchant who tends his shop into the wee hours, just himself and a small gray cat named Junior.
The Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, a state agency, is condemning these properties, as the Federal and State Constitutions say it may do for a "public use." The plan is to turn them over to the Trump organization for parking and landscaping to enhance what one executive at the Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino called the visiting gambler's "sense of arrival." 
 That's not really a public use, the property owners say. But theirs is not an easy argument in the law of eminent domain, by which a government agency can take property. More and more often, courts are finding that a public use is whatever the legislature says it is -- not just building roads and schools but enticing bigger, better employers and taxpayers, whoever they may be. The old owner gets fair market value, the new owner moves in, and the government acts as real estate broker.
The case on Columbia Place is a test of how expansive this view can get. It is also a test of how far Atlantic City will go in breaking eggs to make omelets or, in this case, bigger casinos. That has been the story for 20 years of gambling in this city, an odd and spectacular social experiment that necessarily involves a lot of money and real estate changing hands.
 "New Jersey is so congested and urbanized, and because in Atlantic City casinos are almost a public use, Atlantic City is like a Petri dish for this stuff," said John H. Buonocore Jr., a Morristown lawyer who has handled several eminent domain cases in Atlantic City.
If it weren't for eminent domain, there would be no new Atlantic City. It owes its reconstructed self in part to the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, known as CRDA (CREE-dah), which in 13 years of existence has condemned 300 to 400 properties. Others have fallen to the city and its housing authority and similar agencies.
At the moment, the city map is dotted with condemnation fights involving casinos. Down the street from Trump Plaza, several properties around the Tropicana casino-hotel were condemned recently for its expansion. Up the street, at the site of the huge casino development planned by MGM Grand, one owner is contesting the designation of a tract including his property as an "area in need of redevelopment." And across town, several homeowners are suing in Federal court to stop a $330 million tunnel that would plow through a middle-class black neighborhood to deliver traffic to the planned Mirage casino development.
 
Trump Plaza Case: A Stark Example
But the question of whether a government can condemn land on behalf of someone else has seldom been presented to the courts in a case as stark as that now before Judge Richard Williams of Superior Court, who heard arguments last month on whether the constitutional concept of "public use" is large enough to encompass Donald Trump. A ruling is expected any day now.
"Even with a broad interpretation of government power, this case falls beyond it," said Dana Berliner, a lawyer for the Institute for Justice, a conservative legal organization in Washington that is challenging the condemnations. "I'm hoping this causes the New Jersey courts to draw the line. It's really hard to argue with a straight face that taking a woman's home of nearly 40 years to give it to Donald Trump for a limousine waiting area is a public use."
The Trump organization and the development authority do make this argument with a straight face. They point to the 1993 state law that authorized public funds and condemnation powers for the purpose of constructing hotel rooms and "appurtenant facilities" (later amended to include casinos) in Atlantic City. Under that law, they argue, these ends constituted a public use that the authority was securing when it entered an agreement with Trump Plaza Associates in 1993 to acquire the properties across the street.
"Our board acted appropriately four years ago," said James B. Kennedy, executive director of the development authority, in that the three parcels were necessary to the Trump expansion project as it was presented to the agency.
Now, however, the authority wants out. It is fighting Trump in the case before Judge Williams, claiming that the company's lawyers agreed last summer to drop plans to condemn the Sabatinis' restaurant and the gold shop belonging to Peter Banin and his brother Josef.
By then, the authority's lawyers argue, the hotel expansion was basically finished, having fanned out around the little corner occupied by the Banins and the Sabatinis. As for Mrs. Coking's property, sitting squarely in the middle of the expansion project, the agency says there is little it can do except proceed with condemnation.
In the meantime, the authority has taken a bath, public relations-wise. It did not look good when the British Broadcasting Corporation covered the fight, or when Garry Trudeau devoted six "Doonesbury" cartoons to the spectacle of Mr. Trump lining up against a little family restaurant.
Mr. Kennedy acknowledges the beating his agency has taken. He also notes that the authority's main job is collecting taxes from the casinos to rebuild the city, not helping the casinos acquire more property.
"When you're taking property from an established business or homeowner on behalf of a casino," he said, "even if you can make the legal, intelligent argument in terms of economic development and job creation, it's much, much harder for people to accept."
None of this hindsight was available in July 1994, when the development authority filed condemnation suits against the Sabatinis, Mr. Banin and Mrs. Coking. The authority had made its first and last offer: $700,000 for Sabatini's Restaurant, $169,500 for Mr. Banin's shop, which is next door, and $251,250 for Mrs. Coking's house, which stands alone down the street, across from the casino entrance.
The Sabatinis, who opened their restaurant in 1965, had done well. Mrs. Sabatini, in a quiet hour before dinner one recent evening, recalled the neighborhood when it was full of roses and hydrangea and guest houses that sent summer tourists to line up outside the restaurant.
When Trump Plaza was going up in the early 1980's, the Sabatinis fed so many company employees and workmen that they billed Trump by the week. Once the casino restaurants opened, business tailed off, but there's still a regular crowd at Sabatini's bar, including a lot of Trump employees. They had a few talks with Donald Trump's brother Robert ("Robert was a gem," Mrs. Sabatini said) about leasing the property to the Trump organization, but nothing came of it. Nor did anything come of vague talks with Donald Trump ("he's charming, but he's a businessman") in later years.
That's where things stood when the development authority announced its plan, made its offer and filed its condemnation suit.
"At first it's denial -- this can't happen," said Mrs. Sabatini, who acknowledges only that she and her husband are past retirement age. "You don't know where to turn except to lawyers, which is very expensive."
"When all this started, it was a personal dilemma," she continued. "At this point, it's a crusade for all small businesses in Atlantic City in conflict with government representing casinos. This shouldn't happen in Atlantic City. It shouldn't happen in this country."
That's what Peter Banin says, too. Mr. Banin, 42, a Russian immigrant and a goldsmith, runs the Golden Island, a jewelry business and pawnshop. The shop is tiny, but the price the Banins paid for the building five years ago -- $500,000 -- reflects what he says is the Golden Island's strong point: "location, location, location."
"I never thought that in the U.S. because one party wants something it will be backed up by the government," Mr. Banin said. "Here, you buy it, you pay for it, you work to pay for it again, and then CRDA says, 'I want this.' The worst part is this has nothing to do with public purpose. Trump Plaza Associates is not a public purpose."
He said Trump did make an offer last summer, for $225,000. "Everything has its price, and everything can be bought or sold," Mr. Banin said, "but not right now."
The Banins and the Sabatinis can at least hope that the development authority prevails in its efforts to drop condemnation proceedings against them, in which case they could stay put or negotiate directly with the Trump organization, which recently paid $1.2 million for a small parcel down the block.
For Vera Coking, there is no such possibility, unless the courts bar the condemnations altogether. Her white house stands alone in the shadow of Trump Plaza's east tower, with only a tiny skirt of sidewalk setting it off from an expanse of blacktopped parking lot.
 
A Clash Over Money, And Perhaps Over Egos
While the authority no longer wants to pursue her property, either, Mr. Kennedy said, it can find no legal grounds to drop the case and is obliged to carry out its condemnation of the house for $251,500, though that figure can be contested before a jury.
Mayor James Whelan, who favors leaving the Banins and the Sabatinis alone, is exasperated by Mrs. Coking. "It's a house next to a casino," Mr. Whelan said. "It doesn't work. We're rebuilding the city, and if Vera Coking wants to live in Atlantic City, and if she wants to live on a beach block in Atlantic City, we can accommodate her.
"Frankly, I think it's not so much an issue of Mrs. Coking wanting to stay there and live," he said. "It's a case of Mrs. Coking wanting a higher price for her property. That's what's going on."
Glenn A. Zeitz, Mrs. Coking's attorney, acknowledges that his client would accept a deal if it were sweet enough. "She has reached a point in her life where if they'd give her a fair price she'd sell," he said. "But she's not going to get run out of town on a rail from a place she has lived in for 35 years."
He cited the case of another elderly widow on the block who in exchange for her house accepted $150,000 from the authority, which then turned the property over to Trump; as part of the deal, Mr. Zeitz said, she was given a room in Trump Plaza and meals -- "all the meatball sandwiches they can make for her" -- for the rest of her life.
Mr. Zeitz says the Coking property is essential to Trump's plan because Trump never intended to keep using this block of multimillion-dollar real estate for surface parking but would put up more casino floor once it took title and razed the Coking house.
"Anybody who believes Donald Trump wants to take my client's property and use it to park 57 cars for 30 years also must believe in Santa Claus," Mr. Zeitz told the court last month.
Mr. Zeitz, who said he had talked to Mr. Trump several times about the case, speculated in an interview that "at this point it has become a matter of ego."
"Here's a man who has said the joy in life is in the getting, not the having," Mr. Zeitz said. "Well, this demonstrates it. If he was going to use good business sense, he would have settled this five years ago."
Mr. Trump and other company executives declined to respond. "We're just not going to comment while it's in litigation," said a spokesman, Thomas O'Neil.
Mr. Trump also figures in another eminent domain fight in Atlantic City, though in this one he is taking the other side. In this battle, he is supporting, to the tune of $165,209, some homeowners who would be displaced by the road and tunnel that is planned to link the Atlantic City Expressway with the property staked out for a casino development by Mr. Trump's rival Steven Wynn, chairman of Mirage Resorts.
Public use is not an issue here, as the project, which is to be financed mostly by the state, is a classic government use of land. Nonetheless, several homeowners and community groups have sued in Federal court to forestall condemnation by the state Department of Transportation on the ground that the decision to route the tunnel through an African-American neighborhood violates civil rights laws.
The plan would claim nine houses on Horace Bryant Drive, which runs along a canal on the city's west side, as well as scores of vacant and industrial properties. The lead plaintiff, Lillian E. Bryant, is a resident of one of the houses, a former freeholder and the daughter of Horace Bryant, who was the first black New Jersey Cabinet official.
Ms. Bryant, who campaigned in the 1970's to get casino gambling for Atlantic City, is not so bitter about Mr. Wynn, though she said she was infuriated to see him announce on television that "I'll be a great neighbor." Rather, she said, "I have to blame our elected officials who say people over on Horace Bryant Drive are getting in the way of progress."
"We were so intent on making sure organized crime wasn't going to come in," she said. "But we forgot to ask if we shouldn't have safeguards for our elected officials who might not be able to understand the sophisticated games people are going to play with them."
The case points up not just the power of casino money but the huge racial divide in Atlantic City. "The folks on the west side clearly feel betrayed," said Councilman Lorenzo Langford, who in the May 12 election is challenging Mayor Whelan's re-election. "The African-American community generally feels betrayed."
And like Ms. Bryant, Mr. Langford says the fault lies with the officials, state and local, who offer other people's real estate as economic incentives.
"Our economy is so healthy that everybody wants to be here," he said. "We need parking lots and hotels. Well, two things cannot occupy the same space, and we've got a limited amount of space. How many casinos should we have? Nobody's even asked that yet. I believe, personally, that we've got enough."
In court, that argument is mostly irrelevant. "In New Jersey, municipal action is almost always upheld," said Mary S. Henifin, a land-use lawyer who is representing residents of a downtown South Orange neighborhood that has been designated an "area in need of redevelopment."
Mr. Buonocore, the Morristown lawyer, is handling an Atlantic City case similar to Ms. Henefin's: his client, Joseph Zoll, owns eight lots in an "area in need of redevelopment" -- in this instance, redevelopment by MGM Grand on a 38.5-acre site subject to condemnation by the city. The city argues that Mr. Zoll is a speculator who has held out for a price substantially higher than other owners in the area received.
"It's just scary to me," Mr. Buonocore said, "when they can yell, 'Jobs! Progress! Development!' and say anybody who gets in the way is a bad person."
It has even been a little scary to the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, which changed its policy a year ago to work around property where possible rather than condemning it. Mr. Kennedy said the agency had changed since the Trump deal was struck, and that "there are folks on the board who look on condemnation as an illiberal practice."
Norman L. Zlotnick, the Banins' attorney, is encouraged by a recent state Supreme Court decision that urges "heightened scrutiny" of cases like these. But he said, "When you're trying to fight a condemnation on public-use grounds, New Jersey is a very hard state."
Meanwhile, if the court compels it, the authority will finish its work on Columbia Place. "In a perverse way," Mr. Kennedy said, "probably the most decent thing at this point is to try to move the condemnations as quickly as possible and let a jury decide what it's worth."

HEADLINE: Dear Shareholder: The Dog Ate Our Earnings

BYLINE: By JAMES SCHEMBARI 

 BODY:
THREE years ago it was O. J. Simpson's fault. In 1996, the Summer Olympic Games were blamed. Just last fall the fingers were pointed at Diana, Princess of Wales, of all people. When companies lose money, seemingly nothing is safe from taking the blame, except, maybe, the companies themselves.
This year's scapegoat is particularly defenseless: El Nino. Granted, the weird weather is the reason the anchovies of Peru left for cooler waters, the lobster catch is off in Cuba and gold mining has slowed in Guyana. But declining sunglass sales? A shrinking golf club market? No matter. Over the last month or so, one company after another has reported poorer numbers and blamed El Nino for the results. 

The Blame Game
Saks Holding, the parent of Saks Fifth Avenue, said in a monthly sales report that February sales were off because rain caused by El Nino kept shoppers at home. Similarly, the retailers Gottschalks, Federated Department Stores and Big Dog Holdings all cited El Nino for hurting sales. LaCrosse Footwear said it sold fewer shoes, Toro complained of lower snow blower sales and Callaway Golf didn't sell as many clubs. Labor Ready said it assigned fewer temps to outdoor jobs. Glacier Water Services didn't sell as much purified water. And with the sun behind the clouds so often in California, sunglass sales at Sunglass Hut weren't up to snuff.
Indeed, so many companies are blaming El Nino that some analysts wonder if this isn't just the latest "dog ate my homework" excuse.
"There's a habit to play up events of very low consequence," said Martin S. Fridson, a managing director of Merrill Lynch. "The nice thing about El Nino is that it's an act of God and nobody is going to blame management for a weather pattern."
Or as Robert Streed, a money manager at the Northern Trust Company, put it: "There's a joke that goes around my office: Whenever a retailer reports bad sales it is because of the weather; whenever they report good sales, it's because of astute management."
Hurricanes have always been linked to poor earnings. The Persian Gulf war was the villain in 1991. And as if O. J. Simpson didn't have enough troubles, he was blamed for keeping people inside watching his trial instead of going out to shop. Even the funeral of Princess Diana was blamed for keeping people at home.
"People were so transfixed by these events that they didn't go shopping?" Mr. Fridson said. "Can they prove that, can they measure that? I think the whole idea is to blow smoke in the investor's eyes."
Sometimes the excuse-making takes place on an even larger scale. Although news of the Titanic sinking affected the stock market in 1912, no company had the gumption to blame the disaster for poor earnings. But some executives in South Korea are reportedly complaining that the wildly popular movie "Titanic" is siphoning money from the nation's struggling economy.
 
Silver Linings
Mr. Fridson sees something at work in the company reports that he calls "earnings smoothing." Because Wall Street tends to reward a steady stream of positive earnings, he said, companies often use their leeway under accounting rules to manipulate their numbers to smooth out a negative quarter. But eventually they have to account for their losses, and an act of God is often an easy way out.
Of course, some companies have found silver linings in all the clouds.
The Coca-Cola Company, for example, says it has sold more soft drinks in Peru because those same abnormal warm temperatures that have driven away the anchovies have made Peruvians thirstier. The Michigan Ski Industries Association, while noting the lack of snow, reminded skiers that the warmer weather means "You can dress lighter and tan faster." At Liquidation World, a Canadian company that buys merchandise in insurance sales and bankruptcies and sells it to the public, Dale Gillespie, the chief executive, sounded almost gleeful about the weather.
"El Nino is wreaking havoc, from ice storms to flooding, which is providing a great variety of inventory for all of our 63 outlets," he said, noting that the company recently received hardware and clothing from a Montreal department store whose roof had collapsed in a storm. It also bid on a store full of women's shoes near Houston that was destroyed by a tornado.
"Every day is like Christmas around here," added Wayne Mantika, the company's vice president.
Peter L. Bernstein, an economic historian and investment adviser, is skeptical about the whole El Nino effect. "If El Nino was something endemic in the system," he said, "you wouldn't have seen the creation of more than 300,000 new jobs in January."

HEADLINE: DEMOGRAPHICS;
Reviewing Census Data, Essex Counts Blessings as Well as People

BYLINE: By ANDREA KANNAPELL 

 BODY:
Few jaws dropped over last week's Census Bureau report showing that Essex County is not sharing in the general population increases of its suburban neighbors, and, indeed, has lost more people than any other New Jersey county. The cause was simply the march of history, demographerssay.
Still, the experts say, there are a few eyebrow-raisers in Essex County, which had a net loss of about 27,000 people from 1990 to 1997. (With more than three-quarters of a million people, it is still the state's second-biggest county, second only to Bergen). 
 For one thing, Newark seems to be faring rather well. Based on another batch of census data, released last November, 17 of Essex County's townships, cities and villages lost a higher percentage of population than Newark did. And that information was collected long before the New Jersey Performing Arts Center opened, an event hailed as a turning point in Newark's long-awaited renaissance.
There are other indications that Essex County's fortunes may not be fully represented by the population figures. James W. Treffinger, the County Executive, said that tax ratables -- everything the county can tax, from property to business transactions -- have increased by $120 million in the last two years, reversing a vicious decline. "The ratable base in 1992 was $38.1 billion," he said, "and between 1993 and 1995, we had lost an incredible $1.5 billion in ratables." Now, he said, "the ratable hemorrhage has stopped, and we're up by $120 million."
In 1995, he said, the county's bond rating was "one grade above junk bonds." He said the county's short-term bonds now earn Moody's highest rating, MIG-1. Additional improvements are expected if proposals to create a special improvement district in Newark are approved. The designation, already used in 30 areas in the state, including Jersey City, allows businesses there to charge lower taxes, and channels those taxes directly back into local improvements.
And jobs and population are a "chicken-and-egg story," said Thomas Wright, who directs the New Jersey office of the Regional Plan Association, which makes policy recommendations for sustainable growth in the metropolitan region of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
"People move out of urban areas because the quality of life is better and the cost of living is cheaper in the suburbs," he said. "Jobs go out there for the same reason. People go out because jobs are there, and jobs go out because people are there. The two trends reinforce each other."
What's worrisome about the trend, he said, is that while the population of themetropolitan region from Trenton to New Haven has grown by 12 percent in the last 30 years, its land use has grown by 60 percent.
The Regional Plan Association has long held that suburban crowding will destroy the very qualities that made the areas attractive in the first place. That could make urban areas like Essex County more attractive if they can increase their paying jobs and stock of affordable, attractive housing.
The housing is coming, according to Mr. Treffinger, who cited the 4,000 condominiums in Society Hill, a development that is bringing middle-class housing to downtown Newark. And Pam Goldstein, a spokeswoman for Newark's Mayor, Sharpe James, said that the Housing Authority had been tearing down the city's monolithic public housing units while building 1,700 to 2,000 units of low-density affordable housing. Still, there are no vast tracts of former farmland available for development as there are in the fast-growth counties, like Somerset, Hunterdon, Ocean, Sussex and Monmouth. In Essex County, new housing means demolition, rehabilitation, and lots of bureaucracy.
Mr. Treffinger noted that the county's tax levy as of December 1998 will be identical to the levy of January 1994. People on fixed incomes, like the elderly, will not find themselves priced out of their homes, he said, decreasing one source of population loss. And stable property taxes, he said, will make Essex County affordable to young couples, potential additions.
Demographic experts say that Essex County has found itself at the tail end of a wave of change that it used to lead. The county's boom time was in the 50's, according to James W. Hughes, dean of Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers.
"There was a tidal wave of metropolitan expansion in the postwar era in Bergen, Essex and Union Counties, counties that had both land for suburban development and urban centers," he said. The tract house movement was really focused in those three counties, he said, resulting in a chunk of housing stock now seen as antiquated.
"What's driving population growth and the housing market today is a maturing baby boom," he said. "The people born between 1946 and 1964 are now a generation with maturing derrieres. And in the process of their family-raising, they are trading up in the housing market. All the fast-growth areas are areas where the trade-up housing is being built." Otherwise, he said, such housing is hard to find.
The inner-city housing is no more appropriate, he said. The economic base of those early urban centers -- Newark, Elizabeth, and a dense core in Bergen -- was heavy manufacturing and industrial, and the housing for workers in those fields were houses for four to six families built in the late 19th century. "Those are at the end of their life cycle," Dr. Hughes said. "They have none of the amenities. People, to the degree they can leave them, will."
There are some "inlying suburbs" that remain very attractive, he said, but they are also very pricey. "Places like Maplewood, Short Hills, Livingston, and Montclair are ferociously expensive," he said, "so the broader middle class goes to the edge."
And while white residents are moving out of the county, so are black residents. The immigration of black southerners was a significant population source in the postwar era, but that has reversed, Dr Hughes said. "There is now a pronounced flow of African-Americans back to the South, particularly the middle class," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Dodging raindrops near the Prudential building in downtown Newark. (Photographs by Dith Pran for The New York Times)
 
Table: "BY THE NUMBERS/A Closer Look at Essex County"
New Jersey's population grew 4 percent, to a little over 8 million, from 1990 to 1997, according to date released last week by the United States Census Bureau. At the same time, however, Essex County lost 3.5 percent, more than any other New Jersey county. SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 15; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: Developmentally Disabled Want Institutions Closed

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Andrea Kannapell's cover article "Into the Outside World" (March 15) deals with the closure of two different kinds of institutions, one for people with psychiatric disabilities, and the other for people with developmental disabilities. They were set up to do entirely different things for people with entirely different disabilities. 
 I am writing in response to what she said about closing developmental centers, those places where 3,500 people with developmental disabilities still live in this state. Ms. Kannapell gives a very balanced view of the controversy over closing developmental centers. One gets the impression that opinions on the subject are equally divided and that equally cogent arguments can be made on either side.
Nothing could be further from the truth. The overwhelming majority of people who have lived in those places would never go back to them, want their friends freed from them and want them all closed. Most professionals and most parents of other people with developmental disabilities agree with them. Even though 4,500 families are on a waiting list for community placement, no parents are trying to put their child in one of those institutions today.
The closure is opposed by two small groups of people: those who make their living off of developmental centers -- employees and their unions, the politicians and the businesses in the communities where they are situated -- and a few hundred families of people still in there.
The economic interests of the first group should not be allowed to keep 3,500 people hostage. The opposition of the family members is more troubling, until one discovers that 25 scientific studies have shown that 83 percent of families find their loved one is better off living in the community after he or she is placed there, even though they may have opposed the closure before it happened.
As Ms. Kannapell points out, New Jersey leads the nation in the number of people in those places per capita. That only begins to tell the story of how far behind this state is in the humane treatment of its citizens with developmental disabilities. Five states have closed all their developmental centers; 17 have 200 people or fewer in them.
Those places are a thing of the past. Keeping people in them any longer is wantonly cruel and stains our state's good name. Governor Whitman should be commended and supported for moving to close them. Many of us who have disabilities voted for her last November for that reason alone. It is that important to us, that other people like us are set free to live their own lives at last.
 
ETHAN B. ELLIS
Piscataway
 
The writer is executive director of the New Jersey Development Disabilities Council.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 3042 words

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Royal Blue Collars

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
FOR a quarter-century, the message from the job market has been loud and clear. Avoid traditional blue-collar work. Go to college. Scramble for a foothold in the service industry elite, where unions and seniority mean little and adaptability is the most prized talent. If you are really ambitious and prepared to risk your life savings, start your own business.
But don't try telling that to Lynn Hummel, a former bank clerk who tripled her earnings by becoming a longshoreman in Los Angeles. Or to Eugene Vasser, who says he makes "substantially more than $100,000 a year" working for a welding equipment maker in Cleveland that pays according to individual productivity. Or to Herman Aguirre, a Colombian immigrant who worked his way up from janitor to master jewelry maker in a New York City loft factory and now commands a six-figure income. 
 This handful of redwoods, of course, should not be mistaken for the forest. The median annual earnings of male high school graduates in 1995 were just $29,000, down by one-fifth since 1976 after taking inflation into account and barely 60 percent of those of their counterparts with college credentials. The earnings data for women show the trend, too: the average pay for those with high school diplomas was $19,856 in 1995, down 5 percent in 20 years and just 59 percent of the earnings of college graduates.
Nonetheless, in the right jobs and under the right circumstances, "there's still a pot of gold for blue-collar workers at the end of an increasingly slender rainbow," said Daniel Hamermesh, an economist at the University of Texas.
For some, success turns on working longer and harder. For others, high pay comes with highly valued skills not taught in college. And for still others it is a matter of breaking into the club -- of joining one of the small, powerful unions that vault semiskilled workers into the upper-middle class. Even if only a handful can follow these paths, the lack of earnings opportunities for people who work with their hands makes every case worthy of a close look.
Consider Ms. Hummel, who was a 29-year-old divorced mother of a chronically ill child and had no health insurance back in 1984, when she first heard about job openings at the Port of Los Angeles.
"All I knew -- and needed to know -- was that it paid well and came with medical benefits," she recalled.
Along with thousands of others, she applied for a place on the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union roster of "casuals" -- people who are eligible for employment on the wharves at union scale when seasonal demand exceeds the supply of union members. Five years and hundreds of phone calls later, she was allowed to take a test to prove she had the dexterity and strength for the work.
In an era when few women worked at the sprawling port, the initiation was rough. "The men called us tramps," she remembered. Worse, there was little formal training, and few colleagues were willing to show her the ropes in a risky job involving heavy equipment. But she persisted, eventually quitting her full-time job at Coast Federal Savings so she could accumulate enough hours to qualify for full union membership.
Ms. Hummel, now 43, made $81,000 last year operating the oversized forklifts that stack the big steel containers and instructing casuals to maneuver trailer trucks through the maze of dockside obstacles. Teaching -- especially teaching the women trying to break into the union -- is obviously a labor of love as well as money. "You have to remember where you came from," she said.
Most longshoremen make considerably more than Ms. Hummel: last year, full-time workers at West Coast ports averaged $97,000. Unionized clerks working comparable hours averaged $114,000, while foremen averaged $148,000.
Ms. Hummel has opted for regular hours, avoiding better-paid weekend and night work. And she can afford to. Apart from shoes ("I have a thing for Joan and David"), sport utility vehicles (she drives a Chevy Tahoe) and winter vacations in Mexico, her tastes are modest. Besides, she is now married to a longshoreman, and her daughter, who has grown out of her childhood asthma, has managed to join the union, too.
Loading and unloading ships is dirty and fatiguing work. "Just try attaching a 72-pound lashing bar to a container when it's raining and windy," Ms. Hummel said.
But mining and bricklaying are difficult jobs, too, though median annual earnings in those two fields barely top $35,000. Longshoremen earn much more for one obvious reason: their union controls the supply of labor at every West Coast port.
There is a less obvious reason, too -- what Lawrence Katz, an economist at Harvard, calls "the importance of being unimportant." While the $700 million paid to West Coast longshoremen in 1996 was hardly small change, their wages represent only a tiny fraction of the total cost of moving hundreds of billions of dollars worth of international cargo from factory to consumer. Accordingly, shippers are prepared to pay the premium needed to have the work done.
But just as competition has eroded the seemingly impregnable positions of other elite unions -- notably those of the construction trades -- pier workers may someday become vulnerable, too. There are no legal impediments, for example, to someone building a modern, high-volume port in Mexico, out of the reach of the union.
"It would kill us," said Joe Miniace, president of the Pacific Maritime Association, a trade group for cargo carriers on the West Coast.
Mr. Miniace isn't saying what the businesses he represents will ask from the longshoremen to forestall this threat. But he makes no secret of the potential for further automation on the docks.
"Computerization," he predicted, "could raise productivity as much as containerization has over the past 40 years."
 
The Profits of Productivity
If Ms. Hummel's good fortune seems a throwback to 30 years ago, when many unions had the leverage to dictate wages, Eugene Vasser's is in part a function of an even older labor tradition: piecework.
Mr. Vasser left Birmingham, Ala., after graduating from high school in 1968. Then he served in Vietnam as a noncommissioned officer, where he coordinated Army flight operations. And then he hit gold -- a job with the Lincoln Electric Company.
Lincoln is America's largest specialized manufacturer of welding equipment, with sales of $1.16 billion in 1997. But the reason that the company's name is familiar to almost every business school student is its longstanding commitment to linking pay to both individual productivity and the profitability of the corporation.
Millions of American workers, from sales representatives to truckers, are paid according to their output. Many others collect annual bonuses tied to their employers' profits or revenues. But Lincoln is nearly unique among large American companies, paying all shop-floor workers according to a formula based on how much they produce, how much they contribute to the team effort and how much the company earns.
In Mr. Vasser's case, that adds up to a whole lot. Last year, despite taking more than a month's unpaid leave in the Army Reserve, he had income of more than $100,000 from Lincoln.
In part, that was a matter of focus. He tends three different work stations in what could pass for a 1950's metal shop, tackling one set of tasks when there is slack in another. He takes just 20 minutes for lunch in his nonunion employer's grimly functional cafeteria. And he is constantly monitoring inventories of supplies. "You have to be pro-active," explained Mr. Vasser, who is 47.
In part, too, his income reflects the long hours he puts in -- typically 10 hours a day during the week, plus 8 hours on Saturday.
"I have a very understanding wife," he said.
Delayed gratification is apparently the watchword in many phases of Mr. Vasser's life. He lives simply in Twinsburg, Ohio, far from the tumult of Cleveland, and commutes in a five-year-old Toyota pickup. While three children (including two, by a first marriage, now in college) can run though a lot of cash, he and his wife, a social worker, still manage to save 40 percent of their income.
"When I retire, we'll go back to Alabama," he explained, where the Vassers have already bought some land.
Mr. Vasser, who has been at Lincoln Electric for 25 years, ranks in the top 10 percent in pay at the company. But all 3,400 Lincoln Electric shop-floor workers do well, with wages averaging $58,000 in 1995 (the last year for which the company would provide data), not counting the value of their rich package of medical, vacation and retirement benefits. And the company, which is publicly traded, hardly operates as a charity. Last year's net income of $85 million represented a healthy 20 percent return on shareholder equity in a very competitive industry.
Is there a lesson here for companies fighting tooth and nail to keep down wages -- or for the average production line worker making $13 an hour? Lincoln Electric thinks so. It publishes how-to books on incentive pay and invites anyone with a serious interest in the subject to study how the company manages to pay twice as much as competitors do while remaining a low-cost producer of welding machinery.
But very few manufacturers have taken the pay-for-performance route, and the reasons are not hard to fathom.
For one thing, it is difficult to sustain large differences in pay for the same job category. Measuring individual productivity in industrial settings can be a challenge, too, points out Edward Leamer, an economist at the Graduate School of Management at the University of California at Los Angeles.
Lincoln maintains an ever-changing catalogue that rates thousands of operations according to the time and skill they require. Inevitably, there is ambiguity. New equipment, which often reduces the pay associated with an operation, can anger workers. And the interdependence of operations, in which all workers must pull their own weight to maximize output, can lead to friction.
"People know each other's warts and bumps, and they don't always talk about them politely" at the regular shop-floor meetings, acknowledged Dick Sabo, a spokesman for Lincoln.
Lincoln's success is also difficult to replicate because it requires highly disciplined and motivated labor. The pace is fierce and overtime is often mandatory. Moreover, with very few foremen around, workers must often make decisions on their own.
"Only one applicant in 75 is hired," Mr. Sabo said, "and nearly half of them leave within 90 days."
 
The Apprenticeship Track
Herman Aguirre's work setting could hardly be more different than Lincoln Electric's Dickensian shop floor. The cheerful loft where Mr. Aguirre labors on Greenwich Street in Manhattan's TriBeCa neighborhood looks like an exceptionally tidy artist's atelier. But his rag-to-riches blue-collar experience is probably even harder to mass-produce.
Mr. Aguirre, the son of a cafe owner, finished high school in Bogota, Colombia, then worked there as a shoe and dress salesman. But ambition drove him to emigrate in 1980 to the United States, where relatives of relatives introduced him to Jose Hess, the owner of a company bearing his name that makes high-end gold and diamond jewelry.
Hired as a cleaner-upper and all-around gofer, Mr. Aguirre soon found his way to an informal apprenticeship, learning jewelry-making late in the afternoon after he had finished his janitorial duties.
"He was sneaking in early to get the cleaning done," Mr. Hess recalled.
Mr. Aguirre had no previous training as an artisan, but he clearly had the aptitude, working his way from tasks like polishing finished jewelry to far more demanding ones. At 40, he is now Jose Hess Inc.'s model maker, carving prototypes of new designs from blocks of wax and creating elaborate instructions for casting and assembling the pieces. "He's at the top of the craft," said Mr. Hess, whose jewelry is sold at Fortunoff and Saks, among other stores.
The job pays $30 an hour, plus benefits. Mr. Aguirre, however, has set up a workshop in his home in Elmont, N.Y., where he labors nights and Saturdays at his regular wage; that brings his average weekly earnings from Jose Hess to close to $2,000.
"With two children in Catholic school, parents in Colombia and a wife who stays home, I have a lot of bills to pay," Mr. Aguirre said.
This route to high-paying work -- an apprenticeship in a demanding craft -- is still open. But just barely. Efforts to integrate high school curriculums with local job demands have yet to have much impact. Unions that run apprenticeship programs, mainly in construction trades, are losing ground. And -- probably most important -- corporations are not motivated to invest heavily in worker training if the skills are portable.
"Employers won't train people who have a high probability of not being there next year," explained Alan Krueger, an economist at Princeton University.
Another key factor is that computers are changing -- and usually reducing -- the skills needed to perform traditional blue-collar crafts. Mr. Aguirre is now working to improve his English so he can use the software that is already available for designing simple jewelry. And it is a safe bet that the next generation of jewelry makers will need to know more about computers and less about carving butterflies out of wax.
 
Lessons From the Sea
The skills gap left by unions and employers could, in theory, be filled by government. Bill Clinton came to office preaching just this, and it remains on his agenda. But if hopes of a big push in training have not been fulfilled, there is evidence elsewhere in the economy of the payoff to government investment in "human capital." Indeed, that is how Neil Scheuerlein managed his shot at the brass ring.
Mr. Scheuerlein finished high school in Concord, Calif., in 1976. With better-than-average grades, he could have gone to a good college at the state's expense. But rebelling against the values of the day, Mr. Scheuerlein enlisted in the Navy immediately after graduation. He trained for two years to be a nuclear technician and then spent four years as an electrician's mate on the U.S.S. Porgy, a fast-attack submarine. But, disappointed by the prospects for advancement -- "they weren't going to let me command a sub," he jokes -- and yearning for a stable family life, he left the Navy in 1982 with the rank of electrician first class.
The nuclear Navy has long been a fast track to jobs in the commercial power industry; nuclear utilities covet the training, military discipline and rigorous psychological screening required for submarine service. Like many others before him, Mr. Scheuerlein followed the path of least resistance, taking a job at Southern California Edison's San Onofre nuclear complex north of San Diego.
At San Onofre, where twin 1,100-megawatt units can produce a fifth of the electricity consumed in Southern California, Mr. Scheuerlein quickly rose through the ranks. Beginning as an apprentice equipment operator, he passed the Federal licensing test in 1990 to become a control-room operator -- the highest nonmanagement job in a nuclear plant.
The work carries substantial responsibilities. Like airline pilots, control-room operators mix long stretches of boring routine with occasional moments of tense decision-making. Shutting down a malfunctioning reactor prematurely can cost the utility millions of dollars; permitting one to operate when there is a risk of releasing radiation is obviously even worse.
And, like airline pilots, nuclear control room operators are rewarded with modest hours and large paychecks. Mr. Scheuerlein works as many as 50 hours some weeks, but gets 14 consecutive days off in every five-week cycle. He is reluctant to reveal his exact pay. But under the Utility Workers of America union contract, control-room operators make $34.70 an hour plus very substantial premiums for working overtime, nights and weekends. "Just say I make between $80,000 and $110,000 a year," Mr. Scheuerlein suggested.
"Do I have enough money? Of course not," he said. His income supports two sons in grade school plus a stay-at-home wife, Renee, a college graduate just finishing the requirements for a California teaching credential. And there are mortgage payments on a house in the relatively expensive town of Oceanside.
Still, it's a lot more than most high school graduates can ever hope to earn, unless they begin successful businesses of their own. And it is tempting to credit his union -- or "the importance of being unimportant" -- with the achievement.
Tempting, but probably wrong. For starters, Mr. Scheuerlein served a long, poorly paid apprenticeship in the Navy, a qualification that Southern California Edison has found to be at least as useful for nuclear control room operations as a college degree. What's more, the Federal Government insists that a minimum number of licensed technicians be on the job at all times at nuclear power plants. For power companies, it pays to offer hefty wages to licensed operators in order to minimize turnover.
But that hardly makes nuclear technicians a model for improving the earnings of noncollege graduates in the real-world job market. Few blue-collar workers, after all, can benefit from so much training at Washington's expense -- or so much regulation at their employer's expense.
Indeed, as intriguing (and inspiring) as the success of these four workers may be, there is little in their stories to suggest a plausible route to upward mobility for the large majority of uncredentialed workers. Union bargaining power has long been on the wane. Lincoln Electric has few imitators. Employers are understandably reluctant to invest in long apprenticeships.
So the conventional wisdom rings true: Knowledge workers are kings, and opportunities for those lacking a college education are extremely limited.
"In an economy as large and varied as America's, you'll find some blue-collar workers who win the lottery," said Mr. Krueger of Princeton. "But the sad fact is, most people who lack white-collar skills aren't finding jobs that support a middle-class life."

HEADLINE: ANN ARBOR, MICH.;
It's Not Your Mother's VW

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

 BODY:
THE bull's-eye of Volkswagen's target market for the New Beetle is a place like Ann Arbor, home of the University of Michigan and tens of thousands of young, well-educated trend setters. So how do students, soon to be gainfully employed and ready to release their pent-up consumer demand, describe the car?
Sweet. Adorable. Cute, cute, cute. 
 Outside the Theta Xi fraternity house, members re-created Volkswagen-stuffing contests of past decades, and 10 managed to cram into a silver Beetle without trying too hard. "My mom fell in love with one of these long ago, and I think I could do the same," said one Theta Xi, Evans Longacre, a senior majoring in math and economics. "My mom had one, and she cried when my father forced her to sell it at a garage sale."
Across the street, a half-dozen young women dashed, squealing, out of the Kappa Alpha Theta sorority house for a closer look.
"I love it -- it's the cutest thing," said Ali Felton-Church, 18, a sophomore biology major. "I like that it's compact on the outside but roomy on the inside."
Lindsey Yellich, 19, a sophomore in organizational studies, said she felt special ties to Volkswagens. First, her hometown is Santa Cruz, Calif., a laid-back town where Beetles have roamed for decades. And, second, "my mom went into labor for me at my dad's office, and he had to use his secretary's Beetle to take her to the hospital," she said, adding, "She got nauseous riding in the back seat, because there was no room."
Although the New Beetle got mostly standing ovations, there were a few Bronx cheers. Steve Raasch, 33, a graduate student in electrical engineering, conceded that the car was "striking looking, no question." But, he said, "the whole concept of 'It's a Bug, it's a Bug' is silly. It's not a Bug; it's a Golf." He described the car as "a brilliant marketing ploy on the part of VW."
And Ruben Delasierra, 36, a graduate student in natural resources, said: "It's oxymoronic to match a Bug with a water-cooled engine. The chassis is not a unique chassis. It looks like it has too much makeup. VW should give people something that is closer to the real thing."
But a group of high school students, visiting Ann Arbor from Lake Orion, Mich., called the New Beetle "awesome," "sweet" and, of course, "cute." And at Wines Elementary School, only one student in Cheryl Petsch's first-grade class dared to call the Beetle ugly. Most ran around the car to verify what their teacher had told them: Somebody moved the engine from the back to the front. MICHELLE KREBS

SECTION: Section 3; Page 11; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 905 words

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Welcome to Your Closet: Employers Cut Costs With Smaller Offices

BYLINE: By ELAINE UNDERWOOD 

 BODY:
WHEN Karen Berman starts her new job this week as director of marketing and sales at Tempest Software in New York, she will be sitting in a tidy cubicle no bigger than the average bathroom. Not that she minds.
"I don't need a big, fancy office -- in fact, I think it would be inappropriate," said Ms. Berman, who is more concerned that her sales calls will disturb Tempest's hard-working programmers. 
 Since the 1960's, corporate America has cut real estate costs by putting support staff in cubicles. More recently, though, cubes have also become the norm for senior managers like Ms. Berman. It has come to the point where requesting a spacious private office as a perk can be politically incorrect.
In the mid-1980's, a poll conducted by Michael Brill, a workplace researcher and architect, found that 65 percent of recently promoted workers wanted more office space as a reward for their labor.
"They wouldn't have the guts to say that anymore," said Mr. Brill, president of the Buffalo Organization for Social and Technological Innovation, which designs new office environments for Xerox, Sun Microsystems, I.B.M. and other blue-chip companies. "The world has changed drastically. You are not a team player if you ask for more space."
Personal space is shrinking as companies try to cut real estate costs, usually the second-largest corporate expense after personnel costs. In 1994, upper management's private stake averaged 289 square feet a person, according to the International Facility Management Association. By 1997, at the 297 corporations in the survey, upper management made do with 280 square feet.
And every foot counts. A loss of even nine square feet means that a coffee table and extra chairs may have to go.
Thanks to the booming economy, commercial real estate in Manhattan, like a number of other prime business markets, is as tight as prime residential properties. Jonathan Switzer, senior managing director at the Winoker Realty Company, who specializes in office space south of 30th Street, has seen real-estate costs mushroom. "Two years ago, I was doing deals at $16.50 a square foot; the last deal I did was at $23 a square foot," he said.
One tenant needed to add eight more people to an already crammed space. After having Mr. Switzer survey the market, then trying another broker, the client returned. "They said they'd renew their lease and find a space planner to figure out a way to make everyone fit," Mr. Switzer said.
As computer technology storms the workplace, companies are finding that employees need less space to store paperwork. And some corporate real estate planners are questioning whether employees who travel frequently even need their own offices.
Consulting businesses are among the most aggressive space shrinkers. Between 1992 and 1997, Ernst & Young cut workers' space from 300 square feet a person to 160 square feet. "We've reduced our real estate portfolio by almost 30 percent as we've continued to grow," said Larry Ebert, the director of real estate services at the firm. By holding space to a minimum, real estate has slid from the firm's second-biggest expense to third, behind technology.
TO get there, Ernst & Young took the next step, embracing "hoteling" -- a policy under which auditors and management consultants, who spend most of their time at clients' offices, call ahead to book cubicles at the home office as needed.
A few days before a trip home, for example, a consultant will call the firm's "concierge" to reserve a room. A credenza with the consultant's papers is wheeled in and his or her personal phone number is hooked up to the extension in the temporary office. The worker-to-office ratio at some Ernst & Young locations runs as high as 10 to 1.
"In some offices, hoteling is strained," Mr. Ebert said. "You call and we might not have a room. But over all, the system works very well."
Office furniture makers like Herman Miller of Zeeland, Mich., spend much time figuring out how to make tight spaces livable. One company system provides personal cabinetry for active work files, but workers are supposed to file works in progress in communal file cabinets in public areas. Finished work goes to off-site archives.
Other furniture systems in the Herman Miller line-up include "body pocket" desks that curve to make the space seem less confining, according to Keith Winn, a research program manager at the company. "Panel heights are coming down, too," he said. "We find the less enclosed you are, the less you will feel like you are in a box."
Facility managers can have problems, too. One told Shari Epstein, the associate director of research at the International Facility Management Association, that his job was like "trying to figure out how to fit 18 eggs into a carton that holds 12."
It is a growing refrain. Walter Hunt, a managing principal at Gensler, an architectural and interior planning company, said that when one client, a Boston financial institution, moved to new headquarters later this year, managers and administrators would receive offices measuring 42 square feet, compared with 64 square feet today.
Wanting universal standards for employee work stations, the company had Gensler study its South American operations, where managers and administrators had just 28 square feet of space apiece. "We found that to be too dense," Mr. Hunt said. "There's a limit to how tight you can go."
