HEADLINE: SPENDING IT: FOCUS ON HOME EQUITY LOANS -- 125 PERCENT LOANS;
Bigger Amounts May Bring Bigger Risks

BYLINE: By DEBRA NUSSBAUM 

 BODY:
PERHAPS the most aggressively promoted deal in home equity now is the "125 percent" loan, a financial product that seems to defy the usual laws of collateral.
Jim Palmer pitches these loans for the Money Store, and tabloids are filled with ads for them by other lenders. Even so, "I would never let someone in my family get one," said Margaret Scott, president of Mortgage Advisory Services, a mortgage broker in Manhattan. 
 Lenders have usually insisted that a mortgage and home equity loan add up to no more than 90 percent of a home's value. But about two years ago, some lenders raised that ceiling, issuing loans that, when combined with mortgages, came to as much as 125 percent of a home's market value.
Say a homeowner has a house worth $200,000 and a mortgage balance of $150,000. With a 125 percent loan, the homeowner can borrow another $100,000, resulting in total debt of $250,000.
By conservative estimates, about $10 billion in 125 percent loans were made last year, said Christine Clifford, vice president of David Olson Research, a Columbia, Md., company that tracks home equity data.
Earlier this month, the First Union Corporation entered the market by agreeing to buy Money Store, a Union, N.J., lender specializing in home-equity and mortgage loans to people with troubled credit histories that now offers 125 percent loans. Spokesmen for the Money Store declined to comment for this article.
Most of these loans are made by lenders other than banks, Ms. Clifford said; First Plus Financial Group in Dallas has about 40 percent of the market. Lenders say the loans are often used to pay off credit cards -- debt that averages $30,000, she said.
For lenders, the drawback of a 125 percent loan is clear: part of the debt is essentially uncollateralized.
Lenders hedge that risk by charging a steep price. Interest rates are generally in the range of 14 percent, far greater than for the average home equity loan, now around 9 percent. And to get the loans, borrowers may also have to pay three to six points in advance; each point is 1 percent of the amount borrowed.
Also, the interest paid on home equity loans, including the existing mortgage, is tax-deductible only up to the value of the home. Anything more than 100 percent of value is not deductible.
Lenders offering 125 percent loans defend them as serving a variety of consumer needs and being a route to cheaper debt.
Daniel T. Phillips, chairman and chief executive of First Plus, said that the average loan his company issued was $32,500 and that the average value, combined with the original mortgage, was 111 percent of the home's value. The majority of borrowers are 30 to 54 years old, have average income of $57,500 a year and want to pay off high-interest debt on credit cards.
Only about 5 percent of those who inquire about the loans end up getting them, he said. "The bar has been lowered in some companies," he said, "but we have continued to raise the bar."
Still, even some lenders in the "subprime" market are wary of the loans. Champion Mortgage, the Parsippany, N.J., lender that was bought last year by Keycorp, does not offer them. Daniel Rich, its chief financial officer, said, "We cannot see how giving someone a 125 percent loan makes them better off and how their ability to pay is that certain."DEBRA NUSSBAUM

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT: FOCUS ON HOME EQUITY LOANS -- PREDATORY LENDING;
How Serial Refinancings Can Rob Equity

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FOR Ormond and Rosie Jackson, an elderly couple in Brooklyn living on Social Security, the problem started in 1990, when a salesman knocked on the door saying he could have the windows on their home repaired for payments of $43 a month over 15 years. Six years later, the Jacksons had amassed $88,000 in new debt, seen the equity in their home melt away, paid tens of thousands of dollars in fees and been served with foreclosure papers by their lender.
Helen Ferguson, a widow in Washington, needed money in 1991 to repair her home, on which she was making a monthly mortgage payment of $260. In the next five years, she says, she was talked into borrowing ever-larger amounts through a series of refinancings, each of which included hefty payments for points and credit insurance, leaving her with $70,000 in new debt and monthly payments of $810 -- far above her monthly income of $504 from Social Security. 
 Their stories -- laid out in testimony last week before the Senate Special Committee on Aging -- are increasingly common among people who have taken home equity loans. Regulators, consumer groups and Congressional investigators say the poor and the elderly have proved especially vulnerable to predatory lending practices by companies intent on generating big fees by constantly refinancing high-interest loans.
The problems have grown in tandem with the "subprime" lending industry -- companies that make loans to people with little income or with checkered credit histories. The industry has grown sharply in recent years, from a tiny niche in consumer lending to 15.5 percent of total home equity lending in the first half of 1997, according to the Federal Trade Commission.
A trade group for the industry said it condemned any abusive practices, but said they were limited to a tiny minority. One of the few companies whose practices were criticized by name during the hearing -- the Associates First Capital Corporation, which is in the process of being spun off to shareholders by the Ford Motor Company -- said in a statement afterward that it adhered to the "highest standards."
Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, who held last week's hearing, said most lenders acted ethically and legally.
But, he said, the industry is being tainted by a few lenders that mislead consumers and stretch or break the law. Jodie Bernstein, the director of the F.T.C.'s Bureau of Consumer Protection, said complaints about subprime lenders had increased.
Regulators and consumers groups said three types of lending practices drew the most complaints from consumers.
The first is known as equity "stripping." It occurs when the lender grants a loan to a consumer based not on the borrower's ability to repay but rather on the equity that the borrower has in a home. The elderly are particularly vulnerable to the practice because they often have substantial equity in their homes but live on fixed incomes.
"Loans made to individuals who do not have the income to repay such loans usually are designed to fail," Ms. Bernstein said.
The practice of "packing" credit insurance and other products and services onto loan agreements often exacerbates the problem. Regulators said lenders often wrapped the insurance into the loan package and failed to detail the costs.
According to a former employee of several big subprime lenders who testified anonymously, once a borrower has signed up, the lender's primary goal is to keep the customer refinancing the loan at regular intervals, providing opportunities to charge more points and fees. The practice, known as "flipping," was routine at the institutions where he worked, the former employee said.
Mr. Grassley said that while there might be legislation to deal with the problems, and that increased enforcement of regulations was helpful, the best solution was consumer awareness. "It is my belief that we cannot legislate ethics, morality and compassion," he said, "but I can do my best to insure that individuals that are served by the subprime market are fully aware of the situation before they sign on the dotted line."

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 3; Style Desk 

LENGTH: 1719 words

HEADLINE: 'But Darling, It's You'

BYLINE: By ALEX KUCZYNSKI 

 BODY:
THE Oscars are here, and Hollywood is in full frivolous bloom. Wolfgang Puck is engaged in all-night souffle-making sessions at Spago. Experts who specialize in plucking famous eyebrows are booked around the clock in their suites at the Four Seasons hotel. And the boulevards of Beverly Hills are humming at high pitch with talk of Hollywood's most important power game: who's wearing what.
Whether or not you care if Kate Winslett is wearing Valentino or Alexander McQueen, or even if she's going to win the Oscar for Best Actress, one thing is reasonably certain: she'll look terrific, like all the rest (except for the conspicuous frump or two). Give the credit to a battalion of behind-the-scenes handlers called stylists, whose job is to perpetuate the carefully constructed illusion of Hollywood ease and glamour. (You thought David Bowie had style? Hey, there was one year in the early 90's when a stylist bought every piece of clothing he wore.) 
 And now, the long, refined arm of the stylist has started to reach beyond Hollywood. As high-powered, fashionable Americans become more pampered as they float on a buoyant economy, the personal stylist has arrived as one more professional adviser to add to the ever-growing entourage that already includes colorist, nutritionist, aromatherapist and personal trainer.
That powerful executive in head-to-toe Ungaro? She didn't choose that suit. The perfectly turned out long-lost cousin at the wedding? You're looking at some high-ticket help.
Stylists -- part wardrobe specialists, part image therapists and much more than personal shoppers -- are the people who hunt through department stores, boutiques, ateliers and showrooms in the quest for that special vintage evening bag, that perfect dress, that underwear that won't leave bulgy lines. They're the ones who book the makeup artist, kidnap the overextended eyebrow-shaper and arrange for the hairdresser, the trainer and the personal chef.
David Neuman, 37, the president of Touchstone Television in Los Angeles, decided he needed a stylist when he changed jobs. A former executive at Whittle Communications, Mr. Neuman moved to Touchstone, a division of the Walt Disney Company, two years ago. Accustomed to wearing sleek Armani suits, he was flummoxed when he crash-landed in Disney's J. Crew-and-jeans work environment.
"Every company has its own corporate culture," Mr. Neuman said. "Disney turned out to be casual. But there's casual, hanging-out-with-your-friends-on-the-weekend casual, and then there's corporate casual."
He called Deborah Waknin, a Hollywood stylist whose work he had admired when she re-styled the news anchors on "Channel 1," a Whittle national program for high school students. Ms. Waknin has worked over the wardrobes of actresses like Halle Berry and Kim Delaney, both of whom she is dressing for tomorrow night's Oscar ceremonies, and also dresses a regular group of Hollywood civilians. (Stylists can be hard to find: it helps to know someone in the industries around which they cluster -- film, television, music and fashion.)
Mr. Neuman's primary problem, it seemed, was Casual Friday.
"He said, 'My Fridays are supercasual and I can wear jeans or khakis,' " Ms. Waknin recalled. "So I went and ransacked his closets and edited out what he really didn't need, what was outdated, and kept a lot of what was great." Besides adding some plaid shirts and suede blazers, Ms. Waknin said she also bought Mr. Neuman "shoes, socks and comfy underwear."
Twice a year, Ms. Waknin overhauls Mr. Neuman's closets, arriving at his house with racks of clothing. She takes Polaroids as Mr. Neuman tries things on: if he passes something up and then decides he wants it, they can identify the outfit quickly and snatch it up. She also may suggest a haircut now and then.
"Some executives might have a spouse who does this for them," Mr. Neuman said, "but if you're single and you don't necessarily have someone who is going to take care of that part of your life -- well, it allowed me to turn this over to someone who is an expert."
In the rarefied world of the stylist, daily fees range from $1,500 to $5,000 a day (Ms. Waknin won't reveal her rate). And that doesn't include the price of the clothes, which Mr. Neuman pays for himself -- retail.
Neither Mr. Neuman nor Ms. Waknin said they considered it ironic that a man who can run a company should be so baffled by Casual Fridays.
"David is a workaholic," Ms. Waknin said. "He's 24-7. My clients don't have enough time. They'll call me and say, 'I'm going to an event -- it's black-tie and a little conservative,' or, 'It's at the White House' or 'It's an event at Francis Ford Coppola's winery for the weekend.' And I will understand what they are looking for. It's a costume-designing event. You get a script and you have to execute the outfit according to what the script says."
Of course, image consultants and personal shoppers have been around for years. Membership in the Association of Image Consultants -- a professional group whose members charge an average of $150 an hour for advice on wardrobe and makeup -- is up to 600, from 100 in 1990. But image consultants don't bring the full wardrobe to your house, don't have the top stylists' prized insider status at fashion houses, nor do they act as contractors for makeup artists and hair colorists. And personal shoppers are typically limited to merchandise from the stores they work for, don't handle the accompanying universe of beauty practitioners and don't get steep daily fees or even commissions.
Betty Halbreich, who has headed the personal shopping division at Bergdorf Goodman for 23 years, calls personal styling "day care in clothing."
Angelenos seem to demand more care than New Yorkers. Susan Ashbrook runs Film Fashion, a Los Angeles company that acts as a liaison between fashion designers and celebrities and places designers' clothes and accessories in films. She has started a division that caters to women who need personal stylists: it will open for business immediately after the Oscars rush. She has set her fees at around $1,500 a day.
"There are so many choices out there, and people have so little time," said Ms. Ashbrook, a former publicity director for the designer Richard Tyler. "It seemed about the right to time to expand beyond celebrities."
Ms. Ashbrook pointed to the popularity of In Style, the monthly magazine devoted to celebrity clothing. At In Style's inception, in June 1994, the circulation figure guaranteed to advertisers was 500,000; this January, that figure exceeded 800,000. Other magazines, like People, Us and Allure, have also tapped into the desire to mimic -- or maybe just dream about -- the elegance of celebrities. They regularly devote ample space to the clothes famous people wear. Of course, not everyone can be Sharon Stone, which is where Ms. Ashbrook comes in, her Palm Pilot at the ready.
"I'll be targeting women in politics, finance, women who are C.E.O.'s of major firms and who have the money and the means to pay for couture fashion," said Ms. Ashbrook, who recently styled Cathy Booth, the West Coast editor of Time magazine, for Time's 75th anniversary party at Radio City Music Hall.
"We went through her closet and planned an outfit -- something that made her feel empowered, sexy and pretty," Ms. Ashbrook said. Ms. Booth eventually chose a dress of her own -- "something that showed her great legs," Ms. Ashbrook said -- over the long skirt she had originally planned to wear.
But doesn't all this personal dressing bring to mind the image of a thumb-sucking child standing in front of a bulging closet and howling, "Mommy, I don't have anything to wear"?
Even Mr. Neuman of Touchstone admits that he sometimes feels that his closet is "a grown-up version of Garanimals," the clothing brand for children that lets them match outfits themselves (if the T-shirt has a lion on it, it goes with the lion pants).
Phillip Bloch, the Los Angeles-based stylist who calls himself "a fashion yenta" and "stylist to the stars," certainly has indulged his clients, who have included Jim Carrey, Sandra Bullock and Lauren Holly. Warner Books published his paean to the stylist culture, "Elements of Style: From the Portfolio of Hollywood's Premier Stylist," this year. And Mr. Bloch says he is particularly proud of the civilian styling he has done -- for example, the family and bridesmaids at Angela Bassett and Courtney B. Vance's wedding. He helped choose the gowns, supervised the tailoring and coordinated the hair stylists and makeup artists.
And then the most important moment arrived.
"There was Angela's entire family, all dressed up and crammed in the bathroom, everyone offering to help get her dress on," he said. "She just snapped her fingers, looked up and said: 'Phillip! Phillip!' "
"She had me -- me -- zip up her dress," sighed Mr. Bloch, whose range extends to record producers and television executives, past and present.
"A friend of mine called me yesterday and said: 'Jamie Tarses is going to call you -- she really needs you -- I gave her your number," Mr. Bloch exulted.
Nancy Berry, the vice chairwoman of the Virgin Music Group Worldwide, asked Mr. Bloch for his help on an outfit for last year's MTV Music Awards.
"You can't wear the same dress two or three times when you're in the public eye," said Ms. Berry, 39, "or else people think you don't have any clothes. And I was in a crisis." Mr. Bloch trolled through vintage clothing stores in Los Angeles until he discovered a short antique black kimono, over which he and Ms. Berry strapped a tight black corset.
"And I sure didn't have to worry about anyone else having the same outfit," Ms. Berry said with a laugh.
"These people are busy, they're important, and they're stars in their own business," Mr. Bloch said, adding that Ms. Berry had also asked him to help her find clothes for day wear. "But as I went from store to store trying to find the clothing she liked, I realized she had already bought everything, in her size, in every store. She had cleaned every place out."
And Mr. Bloch's solution?
"I went back to her and said: 'Honey, you don't need a personal stylist. You need a personal fashion designer.' "
Ah. But that's next year.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
Scudder's European Emissary

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
FOR Carol L. Franklin, Park Avenue has it all over Ouagadougou. As a young woman, Ms. Franklin toyed with the notion of a career in the Foreign Service. During high school, she spent a year as an exchange student in Nicaragua. At Smith College, she majored in French literature, spending her junior year in Paris studying at the Sorbonne and l'Institut d'Etudes Politiques.
But it became clear over the years that the world of diplomacy was not the path she wanted to travel. 
 "As I learned more about it, I decided it wasn't for me," she said, "because you don't control your own destiny and make your own decisions. And so I thought I would try to marry my interests in international with the business world."
Investors in the two funds that Ms. Franklin manages can be happy that she did. For the three years ended March 13, the Scudder Greater Europe fund has returned 32.3 percent a year, on average, compared with 24.2 percent for its peer group of other European stock funds, according to Morningstar Inc., the financial publisher in Chicago.
The closed-end fund she manages, Scudder New Europe, has nosed past even that impressive tally: it returned 33.3 percent based on the fund's market price compared with 29.2 percent for its peer group of closed-end European stock funds.
Much of the funds' rally has come from the recent spurt in European markets, raising the question of how long the run can continue. "It has been a fairly breathtaking ride over the last year and a half," she said. "And we think we will have a pause. But if you look at where interest rates are, at the fact that these economies are recovering and at structural and cyclical factors, there is every reason to believe Europe could have an extended period of expansion the way we have in the United States."
In 1981, Ms. Franklin joined what was then Scudder Stevens & Clark and soon began to manage money. She has been investing in Europe the last decade, much of that time as lead manager of the high-profile Scudder International fund.
About four years ago, Ms. Franklin felt it was time for an open-end European fund.
"We could see all the structural changes that were going on in the region," she said. "Europe, which had experienced a period of premature euphoria after the Berlin Wall came down, just looked ripe for takeoff."
Spurred by global competition and the wave of restructuring that has washed over American businesses, Europe's companies are inching toward their own form of shareholder democracy.
And now that many of Europe's big economies are picking up, stock indexes are setting records in a number of countries .
Ms. Franklin cites several other reasons for her bullishness.
"In most countries, the economies are mature, but the stock markets are not," she said. "Expansion in European markets will take place because you will see a lot of small, family-owned and privately owned companies come to market. It is a region where we will see lots of new names."
Two of them are in Greater Europe's portfolio.
Telepizza S.A., a Spanish pizza franchise, went public in 1996. Now the dominant player in the country, with a 70 percent share of the fast-food pizza market and a growth rate upward of 40 percent, the stock has tripled since the fund bought it a little over a year ago. Ms. Franklin thinks that at 19,920 Spanish pesetas ($128.27), the stock still looks reasonable. .
Dassault Systemes S.A., a computer-aided design and manufacturing company in France, is another example.
Its initial public offering, a little over two years ago, was at 118 French francs and it now trades at 241.5 French francs ($39.41), or 32 times its expected 1999 earnings. But Ms. Franklin still thinks it is fairly valued. "They went public to give their employees options and also because they felt it was important for customer visibility, that their customers would feel more secure dealing with a public company that has some degree of transparency. I think that is a view other European companies will adopt,"
PRESSURE for change will come after the European Monetary Union creates a single currency next year. "Many believe E.M.U. will not go through, but I'm not one of them," Ms. Franklin said. "If you look at all the pressures the E.M.U. exerts, you can imagine that what it can encourage is something like a virtuous cycle that will create an equity culture which not only lowers the cost of capital but encourages the investment Europe needs."
The dynamism that Ms. Franklin sees today in Europe is reflected in her fund's strategy. "I look for one of two things in companies: growth or change," she said. "A company can be expanding into new markets or technologies. Or it could be adapting a new focus by shedding peripheral assets or bringing in new management."
Scudder Europe's portfolio is laden with finance and technology issues. "We like finance because it is a sector with growth prospects in asset management and is a change industry in terms of consolidation," she said. The fund holds a big stake in Commerzbank, which was up 57 percent in dollar terms last year, as well as several other bank stocks, in France, Italy and Portugal.
The fund's technology holdings include Cap Gemini Sogeti of France -- a software consulting company that Ms. Franklin believes has developed the best product to help companies adjust their computers to deal with the year 2000 problem. The stock is up 48 percent this year in dollar terms. It now trades at 749 French francs ($122.22), and it still seems fairly valued, Ms. Franklin said.
The fund's biggest holding is Misys P.L.C., a fast-growing British hardware and software company that provides services to the insurance, food and construction industries. Ms. Franklin said she bought in last August, at about 1600 pence a share. It closed on Friday at 2,742.50 pence ($45.71).
As far as geographic breakdown, the fund is currently heavily weighted in France, Italy, Spain and Portugal. While the fund has no money in Eastern Europe, Ms. Franklin expects to invest there. "We see more opportunity right now in Western Europe," she said. "Eastern Europe will be the next leg for this fund, as some of those countries develop."
What risks face investors in European stocks? Failure to implement monetary union would hit the markets hard, Ms. Franklin said. Some political factions in countries like France, which has high unemployment and expensive social welfare programs, are resistant to change and attempts at reform could lead to unrest. And the Asian crisis could hurt Europe, especially if it leads to a significant slowdown in the United States.
"Dealing with the social safety net is the bump in the road that has to be met, and E.M.U. will help to force that issue to be addressed," she said.
But Ms. Franklin has one sure-fire method for easing any fears about European markets. "When you compare how Japan is doing with its structural problems with how Europe is doing, it is very encouraging to be in Europe," she said.

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
No Krantz, Koontz or Coffee Bars

BYLINE: By EDWARD LEWINE 

 BODY:
GABI FRIEDMAN stood transfixed before a towering wall of books. Clutching a work of feminist history and the essays of Walter Benjamin, she explained why she had come from New Haven, where she is studying law, to Labyrinth Books on Morningside Heights. "I heard about this place up at Yale," said Ms. Friedman, 28. "People were saying there is finally a good bookstore in New York."
That depends on your definition of a good bookstore. In this era of the bookshop as lounge, newsstand, coffee bar and pickup joint, in a city that might be mistaken for Barnes & Noble land, Labyrinth has gone in a different direction. It opened one year ago as a no-frills bookstore for scholars. 
 "We wanted to be an academic bookstore," said Christopher Doeblin, a 38-year-old college dropout who owns Labyrinth with Cliff Simms, 40 (B.A. in philosophy from Columbia). "We knew that this formula would work." Mr. Doeblin is emphatic that his first year in business has proved there is a market for scholarly books. "Can we sell a 'Cambridge History of Greece and Rome' at $120 each?" he asked, pointing to the 15-volume work. "Yes. There are people out there who will buy them."
But even as Labyrinth's owners celebrate what they call the "very satisfying" feeling of having made it through a year when many in the book world predicted failure, they face new challenges in their own backyard and on the Internet.
The 7,000-square-foot store occupies two floors of a squat bunkerlike building on a quiet block of 112th Street, between Amsterdam Avenue and Broadway, next to a post office. The floors are unpainted cement; there is almost nowhere to sit. The space is packed with rows of shelves filled with weighty tomes on subjects like history, philosophy, women's studies and math. The John Grisham fan should look elsewhere.
"Most contemporary book stores today convey a sense of space," Mr. Simms said. "We wanted an older, almost archaic idea of a space completely filled with books."
Labyrinth was born from the ashes of Barnard Bookforum, a store on Broadway near 116th Street that closed in 1995. Mr. Simms and Mr. Doeblin had been managers there, but they left in 1993 in a dispute with the owner over money. They also had a plan to open their own store and sell the kinds of books that Bookforum did not stock in significant numbers. "We stood on the sales floor of that store for six years and saw what people wanted," Mr. Doeblin said. "But we kept having to say no to people."
Already thousands of dollars in the hole from the Bookforum debacle, the two men borrowed all they could on their credit cards, $20,000, and opened a wholesale book warehouse in Yonkers, Great Jones Books. They buy remaindered books at auction and sell them to retailers. Last year, Great Jones did $2 million in sales, they said.
A bookstore, though, remained their goal. "We wanted to create this store," Mr. Doeblin said. "It's like that Bob Dylan song, 'When I Paint My Masterpiece.' "
Enter Jonathan R. Cole, a sociologist and the provost of Columbia University. He too thought the Columbia neighborhood needed a bookstore for scholars. After what Mr. Doeblin described as tough negotiations, the university agreed to construct a new building on 112th Street, where the rent is about $20 a foot, one-fifth of what it is on Broadway. The partners got a Federal small-business loan, and Labyrinth opened in March 1997.
Richard Howorth, who owns a store named Square Books in Oxford, Miss., and is the vice president of the American Booksellers Association, said that scholarly bookstores worked differently than those catering to the mass market. For instance, Labyrinth stocks a much wider range of books (about 90,000 titles), with fewer copies of each title than the average store. It carries an inventory of 130,000 volumes in all.
"The more depth you have," Mr. Howorth said of scholarly bookshops, "The more likely you are to get more orders."
Labyrinth does not carry profit makers like cookbooks, self-help manuals, children's books or novels by Dean R. Koontz. It is a tight business to run because the markup on scholarly books can be as little as 25 percent, compared to as much as 48 percent on mass-market titles. It is also time-consuming to deal with academic publishers and keep up with academic trends. "You have to be smart," Mr. Howorth said. "It's not every book buyer who can plumb the depths of cognitive psychology."
Labyrinth's owners said they sold about $2 million worth of books in the first nine months and broke even. But they freely admit they caught a big break because construction has forced the Columbia University Bookstore to operate out of a smaller, makeshift space on campus until 1999. That has given Labyrinth a crack at the lucrative course-book business, which amounted to 30 percent of sales in 1997.
Besides the Columbia store, run by Barnes & Noble, Labyrinth is under pressure from Posman Books, in the old Bookforum space, which stocks a variety of scholarly and popular books. The manager, John Hessler, said Posman would be refurbished this spring and probably take over a stationery store, growing to 6,000 square feet from 3,700. "We feel that we are better than Labyrinth in history, philosophy and poetry," Mr. Hessler said. "As far as the cutting edge, we are it in those areas."
As if all this isn't enough competition, Internet booksellers like Amazon.com special order scholarly books and ship them to customers worldwide. Labyrinth needs "to develop a national market and fight off the New York competition," said Robert Oppedisano, the director of sales for Oxford University Press in New York. "But they have as good a chance as anybody."
The owners say they aren't worried. They are taking bids from designers for a Web site to sell books on the Internet, and they say they wish their neighborhood competitors well. "I don't think there is such a hostile environment," Mr. Simms said. "I think there is a place for a good bookstore with a good focus."
That is music to the ears of scholars and aspiring scholars. "This is what it should be," Ms. Friedman of Yale said as she looked around Labyrinth. "There should be lots of great stuff everywhere."

GRAPHIC: Photo: At Labyrinth, the floors are unpainted cement; there is almost nowhere to sit. The space is packed with rows of shelves filled with weighty tomes on weighty subjects. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)

They are for the most part obscure, but the following five works of philosophy, history and economics were the best sellers at Labyrinth Books in its first year.
1) "Wall Street," by Douglas Henwood (Verso, 1997) A left-leaning deconstruction of Wall Street. (124 copies)
2) "Justice, Nature and the Geography of Difference," by David Harvey (Blackwell, 1996) A Marxist analysis of nature and feminism. (108 copies)
3) "Deconstruction and Pragmatism," by Chantal Mouffe (Routledge, 1996) A debate between the Pragmatist philosopher Richard Rorty and the Deconstructionist Jacques Derridda. (98 copies)
4) "Unheroic Conduct," by Daniel Boyarin (University of California Press, 1997) An analysis of sexuality and Jewishness. (94 copies)
5) "Sense of Reality," by Isaiah Berlin (Farrar, Strauss & Giroux, 1997) Essays by the noted philosopher. (92 copies)

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT: FOCUS ON HOME EQUITY LOANS;
Lenders Laud the Value of Home Sweet Equity

BYLINE: By DEBRA NUSSBAUM 

 BODY:
DURING the recent stampede for mortgage refinancings, home equity loans -- consumers' solution for everything from high-interest credit card debt to college tuition -- were temporarily left behind. Now banks that want to keep the market going strong are promoting the loans aggressively.
"Are lenders ramping up offers? Yes, they are," said Keith T. Gumbinger, vice president of HSH Associates, a financial surveyor and publisher in Butler, N.J. "People are refinancing and paying off their second lien. As refinancing picks up, lenders are focusing on making new lines of credit to refill their portfolios." 
 But even as banks dangle such promotional teasers as below-prime interest rates, rebates and extended repayment schedules, some financial planners urge caution.
"They are selling money and they want people to buy it," said David Little, a planner with Eclectic Associates in Fullerton, Calif. "Don't take all this free money. It's not really free."
Home equity credit comes in two basic forms: a loan for a fixed amount to be repaid within a certain period, or a line of credit, which essentially lets homeowners convert equity into a checking account of sorts and draw on that account as needed.
A line of credit's variable interest rate usually floats with the prime rate, now 8.5 percent. The monthly bill is for interest only and there is no deadline for paying off the loan's principal -- except the borrower's tolerance for paying interest.
For consumers with equity in their homes, the attraction is loans with little or no closing costs, interest that is tax deductible and interest rates lower than those carried by credit cards or consumer loans.
Home equity lending is now a solid part of banks' portfolios, and lenders regard the borrowers as some of their best customers. People tend to keep up loans when the alternative is foreclosure on their homes.
Banks with accounts insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation had $98.1 billion in home equity loans outstanding at the end of 1997, up from $85.3 billion in the corresponding period a year earlier. Yet growth was slowing, up less than $2 billion from the third quarter of last year.
That is at least partly a result of the latest wave in mortgage refinancings, whose customers make up much of the same market for home equity products. Additionally, if homeowners hoping to refinance already carry a home equity loan, they must pay it off to get the new mortgage.
All that puts extra pressure on banks' home equity portfolios. So deals are coming out in force. The national average for a fixed-rate home equity loan with a 10-year term is 9.37 percent, according to HSH. The average interest rate for a home equity line of credit is running about 9.69 percent. In its survey of 10 major markets, Bank Rate Monitor, a financial data company, says a credit line averages 8.56 percent.
But with a little hunting, a customer can easily find better rates and special offers. The Bank of New York started a special this month on its "Prime for Life Equity Link" credit line: prime minus 1 percentage point for the first six months, or 7.5 percent at current rates, then converting to the prime. The offer expires on March 31.
At the Norwest Corporation of Minneapolis, home equity business has "seen a lift," said Janet LaFrence, senior product manager, because the bank changed its rules last fall to let customers take a home equity loan for 25 years, rather than 15, and monthly payments were lowered on lines of credit. (By stretching out the life of a loan, however, both provisions set up borrowers to pay more interest over the long haul.)
At the First National Bank of Chicago, borrowers can get a rebate of as much as $500 on the first month's interest payment on either a home equity loan or a line of credit. For a line of credit ranging from $25,000 to $49,999, the rate is the prime plus half of a percentage point -- now, 9 percent.
Even in a borrower's market, though, some financial planners and credit counselors question whether the loans are a good way for homeowners to handle debt.
Philip C. Johnson, a certified financial planner in Clifton Park, N.Y., does not favor using home equity loans to pay off credit cards. "You don't use your home to buy something that will expire before the debt does," he said. If the loans must be used, he said, use them for "a worthy long-term goal, not for going on a cruise."
He recommended calling banks and credit unions and making sure there are few fees and little or no closing costs. Consumers, he added, need to be clear what the rate is after the teaser rate expires; in this market, he said, a borrower should be able to get prime.
Ann B. Diamond, a financial planner in Manhattan, said that equity loans could be helpful in paying off credit-card debt or education loans. But borrowers have to realize the possible consequences.
"You have to understand your house is on the line," she emphasized. "You have your home at risk. If you can't make the payments, that's a pretty big penalty to pay."
Nancy Nauser, president of Consumer Credit Counseling Service Mid-America in Kansas City, Mo., a not-for-profit agency, said that home equity loans "can be very positive or negative."
The key, she said, is the borrower. "You need to make sure you are disciplined enough to not get in any more debt until that loan is paid off. If you use those credit cards again, you're just going to double the debt. People don't realize that."
Read the contract carefully, Mrs. Nauser said. "Ask how long are you going to be paying and how much interest are you paying," she said. "Compare all of the terms. Is there a big penalty if the payment is five days late?"
To Paul Froehler and Victoria Pena-Froehler in Chicago, a home equity line of credit made more sense than paying credit card debt. The Froehlers took a $15,000 line of credit from First National Bank of Chicago in January to replace their computer and television and to pay down a high-interest credit card.
"I'm going to permanently retire credit card debt," said Mr. Froehler, a first vice president for the Sanwa Business Credit Corporation, a commercial finance company. "To me, this is also for reserve. It's there if my roof falls in. I like the tax deductibility of it."
The Froehlers have used about $8,000 on the line so far. Mr. Froehler plans to pay off some of that with an annual bonus this spring, but will keep the credit line available to use toward a new car and for when their son goes to college next year.
The interest on Mr. Froehler's loan is 11.5 percent, higher than the usual offer because the loan-to-value ratio was 96 percent, meaning that the loan, when combined with the existing mortgage, came to 96 percent of his home's value. But the rate is still considerably lower than the 18 percent the couple was paying on their credit cards.
Mr. Little, of Eclectic Associates, said his firm does not suggest home equity loans for debt consolidation except as a last resort. Some home equity loans, he said, are "just allowing someone to live beyond their means. It doesn't address the problem, it just covers it up."

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT/MUTUAL FUNDS;
The Art of Swimming Against the Tide

BYLINE: By MARCIA VICKERS 

 BODY:
"BUY when blood is in the streets." No one takes that investing adage more to heart than a contrarian like Anthony M. Gallea.
Mr. Gallea, 48, is a senior portfolio manager at the Smith Barney office in Rochester, where he oversees $600 million in client assets. He is also the co-author, with William Patalon 3d, a business reporter for The Baltimore Sun, of "Contrarian Investing" (Prentice Hall/New York Institute of Finance, $25). 
 Here, Mr. Gallea discusses the central premise of contrarianism -- that when everyone holds a stock or sector or country in low esteem, it may be precisely the time to invest. He also explains how to pick winners, how to limit risk in this chancy field and which investment areas he is keeping a contrarian eye on: Japan, the metals market and energy stocks, among others.
Q. What is the contrarian philosophy?
A. It attempts to ascertain an extreme or consensus opinion and then see if there is an argument for investing in the other direction. It's the theory that if everybody believes something and has acted on it, then the money available to push that investment in the same direction is diminished.
Q. What's the difference between contrarian and value investing?
A. I think that a contrarian starts with the sentiment or the psychology of the situation and then proceeds to the financials, and a value investor starts and ends with the financials. Both try to buy assets at a discount, but I think all investors try to do that, even growth investors.
Q. You have said that contrarians have nerves of steel. What other personality traits do they have?
A. I'm not so sure it's nerves of steel. It's more a willingness to think independently. For most people, it's not easy to invest in a way that is in disagreement with their friends, their seeing and reading and so on.
Q. Can you give an example of the extreme opinions contrarians seek?
A. The crash in '87 is one example. The consensus opinion was that the market was in deep trouble. That turned out not to be the case.
But right now the U.S. market isn't saying a thing to me as a contrarian. I don't think there's extreme bullish or bearish sentiment; opinion seems equally divided. People feel that I'm bearish, as a contrarian, because there's a lot of bullishness around. But I don't sense any extreme.
I sense more of an extreme in the Far East, in the metals market and in Japan. Those markets may be saying something to contrarians.
One sector that is worth watching is energy. People are becoming more bearish about energy and there's more in the papers about it that reminds me of what I used to see in the 70's. It's not there yet, but if you got some additional drop in energy prices, energy stocks would become a lot cheaper and then a contrarian might see it as a time to buy.
Q. How do you know if there is extreme opinion against a stock?
A. One difficulty we've had as contrarians is to quantify extreme opinion. Then we ran across a study by John Howe of the University of Kansas about stocks that are down 50 percent or more. He did an exhaustive study -- thousands of stocks over many years -- and found that stocks that had dropped 50 percent or more from their 52-week highs tended to outperform the market and those that were up 50 percent or more tended to underperform.
That led us to the work of other academics and market people saying that this works. So, we don't consider a stock unless it's dropped at least 50 percent from its 52-week high. That's our proxy for contrarian sentiment.
Q. Are you looking at any particular stocks right now? What about Nike?
A. There is no stock I'm looking to buy this morning. As for Nike, I've been following it. It doesn't meet the first criterion of down 50 percent, so I wouldn't buy it. But the world is awash in sneakers. People are generally not pleased with that whole sector. They think that sneaker prices are too high. If I could buy Nike 50 percent below its highs, then, sure.
Q. Because you still think that it's a good company.
A. Any time you can buy a big-name blue chip or a franchise stock at 50 percent off, the odds are well in your favor. These companies have lots of resources, lots of money, lots of people. They can work out problems that small, one-product companies can't. If you look back, all of these big, big companies that have gotten into trouble -- Citicorp, I.B.M. -- make it out, by and large.
Yet, people tend to take a piece of news, extrapolate a new worry from it, treat that as fact and extrapolate yet another worry. We take events and psychologically push them forever into the future in a straight line. We underestimate the muddle factor: that we all tend to muddle through problems eventually.
You have a parallel situation in Japan today. You have widespread difficulties in financial companies that are well publicized. The Government seems to be "pushing on a string" -- do you remember that phrase from many years ago, when the Fed was dropping interest rates but couldn't get the economy moving? The market there is down more than half from its highs of several years ago. Yet it's a great industrial power; it's not going to slide into the ocean and disappear. We have $10 million invested there now.
Q. Your secondary criterion is buying by insiders or savvy outsiders.
A. We found a study showing that a net increase in such buying tends to forecast a higher price. So we set inside buying as additional confirmation because once you've got a stock down 50 percent, that doesn't mean it's going to go anywhere.
Q. Can you give me some examples of insider buying?
A. Here's one: Sunglass Hut. I should note that we do make a market in Sunglass Hut and we have a speculative rating on the stock.
At any rate, you see them in all the malls. The stock declined from $20 to the $6-to-$7 range between July 1996 and July 1997. So it met the first screen: down at least 50 percent.
Then we picked up in the S.E.C. filings that Sunglass Hut insiders had bought about 100,000 shares in several transactions last summer.
The story was pretty simple: there hadn't been any new lines of fashion sunglasses in the prior year and there was a bit of overexpansion. But those are the kind of things you work out of. Anybody who's ever been in retail knows that you get overinventoried at times.
So we bought the stock at $6.75 last summer and it is now at $10.50. So it hasn't had a big move yet. But that is the kind of stock that we look for.
Q. How can you predict whether an ailing company will recover?
A. After you find a stock trading at a 50 percent discount to its 52-week high, you do the fundamental analysis by reading an analyst's report, whatever. Then we pick four of the fundamental ratios a value investor might look at. If we get a stock down 50 percent or more and then two of these four line up, you don't have to have insider buying.
Of course, in looking at these four ratios, everything is not necessarily going to be pretty because a stock doesn't drop 50 percent and look beautiful. What you want to get is a sense of whether the company has got time to work it out.
We start with a price-to-earnings ratio of less than 12. That means earnings are not highly priced. Next we look for a healthy price-to-free cash flow -- less than 10. Free cash flow is the money that's left over, after paying for basic expenses and enlarging the existing business, for creating new products, buying complementary businesses and the like.
Then comes the price-to-sales ratio. If it is less than 1, each share is backed by a good amount of sales -- say, the share is $7 and sales per share are $10. So you've got some good numbers coming in the top line, although whether they get to the bottom or not you don't know. And then if the book value is less than 1, that tells you there are good underlyingassets: bricks, mortar and the like.
Q. How long does it typically take for a contrarian portfolio to generate satisfactory returns?
A. Ben Graham, the father of value investing, believed that it took approximately two years for a company to work out its problems. But in some cases, a stock just seems to go right out of the chute.
Q. How do you limit risk?
A. We put no more than 3 to 5 percent of a portfolio in any single stock because these companies are in some trouble. And we have a 25 percent stop-loss order -- an order to sell if the stock falls below a certain price -- because you can be wrong and there are times just to get out.
If you find a stock with a big price decline you often are led to other stocks in the industry. So we limit ourselves to 15 percent, 20 percent, in any industry, so we don't substitute industry risk for a stock's risk.
As for selling, Ben Graham believed that a 50 percent profit was a good target. That dovetails with John Howe's work, that a stock up 50 percent tends to underperform.
If you believe a sale after a 50 percent profit is premature, you can stay in and set a stop-loss order at a 30 percent profit. So if the stock goes from 10 to 15 you're going to set a stop at 13.
Another risk rule we have is that after three years if you don't have a 50 percent profit, you just leave.
Those are the basic risk rules. You try to set some discipline for yourself because we're all weak. We go to cocktail parties and tell our friends about a stock we bought. Then the stock starts to drop and you find yourself defending it and then your ego is at stake. We need something to save us from ourselves.
Q. How can average investors get into the contrarian game?
A. If somebody has a 401(k), for instance, he may say, "Of all my funds, what hasn't done well?" If the Far East hasn't done well, he might say, "Maybe I should put 5 or 10 percent of my 401(k) there."
That is, just begin to take a more skeptical view and get some side investments that are going in a different direction. I'm not comfortable having all my assets moving in the same direction all the time. Maybe this is doing well for me this year, this isn't doing well for me. But next year maybe they'll flip-flop.
Q. Why do people overreact to news and create the kind of extreme opinion that you look for?
A. I think that's the real story about contrarian investing. People constantly look outside themselves for the answer, in the market. What is required is more introspection. I don't mean this to sound like crystals and Sigmund Freud, but we don't spend enough time analyzing ourselves. We are the filter through which all this information flows.

GRAPHIC: Photo: As a contrarian, Anthony M. Gallea studies the psychology of a possible investment, then the financials. "For most people," he said, "it's not easy to invest in a way that is in disagreement with their friends." (Forest McMullin for The New York Times)
 
Chart: "How to Play Troubled Stocks"
Anthony M. Gallea follows these principles for investing in an out-of-favor security. The presume the investor has studied the company's basics -- its financials, management, competition and so on.
 
BUY
If the stock is trading at 50 percent or less of its 52-week high and
Either insiders or savvy outsiders are buying large numbers of shares.
Or the stock satisfies two of these four valuation ratios:
* Price-to-earnings less than 12
* Price-to-free cash flow less than 10
* Price-to-sales less than 1
* Price-to-book less than 1
 
SELL
If the stock has risen 50 percent since purchase*
Or the stock has been held three years
Or the stock falls 25 percent below its purchase price.
 
BUT
To limit risk:
Never put more than 3 to 5 percent of a portfolio in one stock.
Never put more than 15 to 20 percent of a portfolio in one industry.
 
*Exceptions allowed, with certain safeguards.

HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH;
Do Preferred Shares Close the Door?

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
An investor has brought a lawsuit challenging a recent move by Gabelli Equity Trust to offer preferred shares. The suit, on behalf of all shareholders entitled to vote at the annual meeting last year, was filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan and seeks to rescind a 1997 vote that allowed the shares to be issued.
Over the last 12 months, several closed-end stock funds like the $1.3 billion Gabelli Equity have been trying to offer preferred shares, typically depicting the move as an attempt to bolster returns. But some critics, like the shareholder suing Gabelli, say the issuance of preferred shares is aimed at thwarting attempts by holders of the funds' common stock to force a conversion to open-end status. 
 "Issuing preferred shares is a bad idea because it will deprive common shareholders of the ability to control major decisions of the fund, including any proposal to open-end the fund," said Theodore Hess-Mahan, the lawyer representing the shareholder, C. William Carter.
The lawsuit "is a scurrilous attack," said Mario Gabelli, president and chief investment officer of the fund. "Given the level of interest rates and everything that's going on, the offering of preferred shares is in the best interest of shareholders."
By investing the proceeds of preferred shares, closed-end funds can bolster their portfolio returns so long as they earn more than the dividend payment. But this leverage, which magnifies returns in up markets, has the opposite effect in down ones.
Critics focus on another feature of preferred shares: They typically allow their owners to veto attempts by holders of common shares to convert a closed-end fund to open-end status. Such attempts have become more frequent as shareholders lament that their shares trade at a discount to a fund's net asset value.
Shareholder skepticism is often well founded, said Thomas J. Herzfeld, a Miami investment adviser. "Shareholders have become very sensitive to fund managers' proposals because the industry record on manager proposals leaves a lot to be desired," he said.
Unlike open-end mutual funds, whose unlimited numbers of shares are bought and sold at net asset value, closed-end funds have a set number of shares that are bought and sold on stock markets. The shares may trade at a premium to the value of the securities held by the fund, but more often they trade at a discount.
Gabelli is no stranger to these types of lawsuits. Another Gabelli closed-end fund, Gabelli Global Multimedia, is grappling with a similar lawsuit, filed last year.
Recently, another closed-end fund, General American Investors, won shareholder approval to issue preferred stock. The move came after three shareholder attempts to turn it into an open-end fund.
 
A Repurchase Plan At Piper Capital
Piper Capital Management said last week that it planned to recommend that the boards of directors of 4 of its 16 closed-end funds ask the Securities and Exchange Commission to allow the funds to buy back up to 10 percent of their shares annually, for five years, at net asset value. The funds are American Strategic Income Portfolios I, II, and III and American Select Portfolio.
The buybacks would be contingent on the funds' discounts to net asset value exceeding 5 percent over a specified 12-week period each year.
Alternatively, the company said it might ask the boards of the four funds to authorize a buyback of up to 10 percent of the funds' shares at net asset value in 1999 and 2001.
The company said it would make the recommendation on the second buyback only if the S.E.C. did not approve the first repurchase plan. Under the second plan, shareholders would have to approve a new contract that continues Piper's advisory role at the funds. The contract results from the planned acquisition of Piper's parent, the Piper Jaffray Companies, by U.S. Bancorp, announced last year.
Piper also said it might ask each fund to adopt an open-market repurchase program, if shareholders approve the new advisory contract. Under the program, shares would be bought from investors at market prices. Purchases would be made only when the previous day's closing market price was at a discount to net asset value.
The management announcement follows one in February that five of Piper's other funds would seek to become open-end funds, allowing shareholders to sell their shares for full value. Piper said the four funds in the new proposal were not considered for conversion to open-end status because their investments were too illiquid. Presumably, the current buyback plan is offered in compensation, Mr. Herzfeld said.
"I think that they're throwing the shareholders a bone," he said. He described as "a little iffy" the prospects that the share repurchase plan would narrow the funds' discounts to net asset value, which on Thursday ranged from 7.0 percent to 9.4 percent.
 
The Road to Delaware For Vanguard Funds
The Vanguard Group is asking fund shareholders for permission to reorganize eight of its funds from Maryland corporations into Delaware business trusts at a meeting scheduled for May 1.
The changes would be the first in a wave of reorganizations planned for the 85 Vanguard funds. Proxies already have been mailed to shareholders of the eight funds: Asset Allocation, Equity Income, Growth and Income, Preferred Stock, Wellesley Income, Wellington and both Windsor funds. Proxies will be sent to shareholders in the other Vanguard funds by the end of May.
Because of lower tax rates in Delaware, the change should save $17 million in taxes on all its funds annually, said John Woerth, a company spokesman.
Vanguard, which has built a reputation on frugality, broke new ground by allowing shareholders to submit proxies on line, saving printing and mailing costs: so far, 10 percent have voted via computer, and another 20 percent by phone, Mr. Woerth said.
 
A New Fund for Dreman
Scudder Kemper Investments said it would offer a new fund, Kemper-Dreman Financial Services, to be managed by David Dreman, the value investor. The fund will be sold through brokers and carry a maximum initial sales charge of 5.75 percent. It will invest largely in the common stock of securities firms, investment management companies and insurance companies. Among other funds, Mr. Dreman manages Kemper-Dreman High Return Equity.
