HEADLINE: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

BYLINE: By JESSE McKINLEY and ANDREW JACOBS 

 BODY:
THERE are two commonly held beliefs about today's New York. No. 1: Things are good. No. 2: Everyone agrees about No. 1.
The prevailing wisdom holds that the city is basking in a glorious period of renewal, evidenced and enhanced by a robust economy, a revitalized cultural scene and surging self-confidence. 
 After all, the argument goes, Wall Street is up, crime is down and the sidewalks are cleaner than they've been in years. High-tech, media and financial businesses are growing, and theaters, bars and restaurants are packed. The Knicks are scrappy and even the Mets are showing promise.
The optimism seems to be catching. A recent New York Times poll found that Americans see New York as a place more likely to be revisited than reviled. More than 60 percent described Gotham's image as good, compared with 43 percent two years ago.
But in a city well stocked with skeptics, cynics and grumblers, some see this upbeat news as largely a creation of high-powered civic boosters -- financial, real estate, media and government elites -- who have a major stake in how the city is perceived. And, the critics say, the city's refurbished image has little to do with the lives of most New Yorkers.
"The question of whether the city has really improved depends on whom you ask," said Stuart Ewen, chairman of the film and media studies department at Hunter College and an expert on public relations. "For many middle-class people, it's a pleasing time, and of course it's good to have a city where people can walk the streets safely. But for many other people, it's become a very hard place."
Indeed, for every cheery headline and giddy proclamation about the new New York, you can find equally dour assessments of the city's fundamental well-being. Welfare rolls may be down, but the number of food pantries is up. AIDS deaths have declined, but the incidence of heart disease is still, per capita, among the highest in the country. Wages may be up, but so are rents.
Even some optimistic economists say the good times, such as they are, may not last. "The booming market is pulling the city's economy along by the nose," said Mark Zandi, chief economist of the Regional Financial Association, an economic consulting and research firm. "If that were to falter, it would be a significant problem."
Mr. Zandi observed that the city's economy is more diverse than it was a decade ago, and less dependent on Wall Street. But he also pointed out that Manhattan was enjoying the majority of the new opportunities, the bulk of which benefit highly skilled workers. "Manhattan is in the vortex of the boom," he said. "It's blossoming well ahead of the boroughs."
And even for those feeling the flush of success, there can be downsides.
"Everyone's so busy getting rich, they've forgotten how to have relationships, how to be good parents and how to live," said Dr. Herbert J. Freudenberger, a psychoanalyst on the Upper East Side who coined the term "burnout" in the 1970's. "I'm seeing more discontentedness than ever before. The pressure to make money, to succeed and to keep up an expensive life style has become so intense, so all-consuming, that work has become the be-all, end-all."
As stressed out as New Yorkers may be, the rest of America seems to think they're nicer than ever. The Times poll found that 41 percent of Americans now viewed New Yorkers as "friendly," compared to 27 percent two years ago. But despite the impression that New York has become a kinder, gentler town, reports of anti-gay and domestic violence are on the rise.
"We'd be the first to admit that New York is not perfect," said Colleen Roche, a spokeswoman for the Mayor. "It's a work in progress. Still, there's no denying that homicides are down 71 percent, that 360,000 fewer people are on welfare and that 209,000 new jobs have come into the city over the past four years."
"And besides," Ms. Roche added, "this is New York City. People will always find something to complain about."
Even some of the most hardened naysayers concede that in at least some respects, life in the city has improved over the last several years. But conversations with some three dozen New Yorkers -- from artists to executives, radicals to conservatives -- revealed a number of concerns, including the persistent notion that the recovery has largely favored the rich while neglecting some longstanding problems of the poor.
Others have more philosophical gripes. "I'm thrilled that the hedges in front of my house have stopped getting stolen, but I'm not crazy about the Disneyfication of our city and the moral police trying to eradicate anything that encourages impure thought," said the author Gay Talese. "Trash and that which offends are what makes New York the great city it is."
In a town with such wild diversity, of course, consensus would be difficult, if not impossible. Here's a sampling of nits, crits and opinions from some who see the Big Apple as half-ripe:
 
LUC SANTE
Author of "Low Life: Lures and Snares of Old New York" (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, 1991)
 Whenever people get really excited about boom times, I begin to get worried and these days really have an edge of hysteria to them. It's one thing to be recovering from the Depression in 1936 and sing "Happy days are here again," but today the mood of congratulation is so strenuous. I'm especially suspicious because this unprecedented prosperity that seems to have affected everybody doesn't seem have affected anyone I know personally. Nobody is actually going hungry or losing their homes, but that possibility is never beyond the pale.
 
PENNY ARCADE
Performance artist currently performing in "Sex, Subversion and New York Values"
 The idea of New York as a cultural capital comes from the street up. Culture in New York starts on the street and not Madison Avenue. What made New York unique is that it was a big city made up of small distinct neighborhoods. Giuliani is making his bid for the big time by delivering the broken spirit of New York homogenized and sanitized to the rest of country. And even from a marketing viewpoint, that's killing the goose that laid the golden eggs that were in demand all over the world.
 
PETE HAMILL
Author and journalist
There is a palpable difference in the city right now, a lifting of the sense of menace and an exuberance walking in street and riding the subways. I don't know whether or not you can measure prosperity with statistics. I don't know what the unemployment rate was in Florence in 1460, but I know it was a hell of a city.
Now, on the other hand, there's all kind of problems that are associated with this boom. The middle-class people who used to flee to New Jersey as soon as kids got to be 6 or 7 are staying in lot of districts, and that puts a tremendous crunch on housing, which allows these rotten filthy slime landlords to take advantage and charge $4,000, $5,000 for a warehouse space. The reason that's bad for the future is we don't know who is not coming to New York -- that's the statistic that doesn't exist.
We don't know if we're losing kids who want to be painters, or actors or writers but can't afford to live here. Kids used to feel able to come and double up in apartments, but certainly nobody's going to come from the boondocks anymore and live in SoHo and be an artist. You can't afford to park there, let alone live there.
 
ANDREW S. HEIBERGER
President of Citi Habitats, Manhattan's largest residential brokerage firm
 I've never seen the market so tight. They say the vacancy rate is around 1 percent, but that's an illusion. The vacancy rate simply represents the amount of time it takes a landlord to clean out and paint an apartment. These days, some apartments last an hour on the market before they're snapped up. Professionals making $75,000 a year are being forced to live with roommates or to ask their parents for help paying the rent. In any other city, these same people would be living in spacious two-bedroom apartments.
The tight market is also making people rent-poor, forcing them to alter their life styles, making them live in non-doorman buildings, limiting how often they go out and forcing them into the outer boroughs. I had one couple from California come looking for separate apartments. They were engaged but were not ready to live together. Of course they couldn't afford to live apart.
Business may be good for us, but I feel bad for my customers. There's a lot more frustration and a lot more crying in the office. It makes our job more difficult because they are often angry and bitter.
 
LEWIS BLACK
Comedian whose one-man show "Black Humor" is running at the Cherry Lane Theater
Here we are paying a gazillion dollars in rent, and most of us don't even have a thermostat in our apartments. New York is the only place on earth where you can't control the heat in your home. We're stuck with all these heavy metal radiators that we can't turn off. All my windows are open, and it still feels like I've got malaria. If I lived on my ledge, maybe then I'd feel comfortable.
They talk about crime being down in New York. Well, I live on West 43d Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenue, which was once the unofficial worst block in the city. Now that Disney swept 42d Street clean, my block is the official worst block. Drugs, prostitutes, you name it. We've got people running around whispering, conducting all kinds of business, but they don't have briefcases.
And one more thing. The city thinks it's giving us a bargain by selling 11 subway trips for the price of 10. What kind of marketing is that? Buy two, get one free. Or buy four, get one free. But buy 10 and get one free? That's pathetic.
 
 
 
Step Right Up And Into the Cattle Car

 
GENE RUSSIANOFF
Staff attorney, Straphangers Campaign
 The good news is that people are coming back to mass transit in droves. The bad news, however, is also that people are coming back in droves. There's been a 30 percent increase in bus ridership since the free transfer. It's crowding the buses and slowing service.
Have you taken the M-23 lately? It's my mother's bus. Every time I mention free transfers to her, she goes into a towering rage. "Now it's like some cattle car," she says. There's not enough service, it's true, because people like me, who would walk a few blocks, now get on the M-23 because it's free. And there's a ton of us. People are virtually hanging on the sides. My mother is a senior citizen, and even she says it's a slow boat.
I mean, it's a good thing they're flooded with customers, it's a good thing people are leaving their taxis and family car and rental black cars, but there's definitely not enough buses to deal with rising number of riders and now longtime riders say they're facing unpleasant traveling conditions. There's no such thing as free lunch or a free transfer.
 
JOHN KAEHNY
Executive director, Transportation Alternatives, a bicycle advocacy group
 The thing that makes New York so attractive to people is the fact that it's the only walking city in the country. But instead of cultivating that, Mayor Giuliani seems to be promoting a car culture, putting pedestrians behind barricades, ticketing jaywalkers and encouraging people to drive to megastores. There are now seven million car trips into the city every day, and congestion is costing millions of dollars in delays and lost business, not to mention the cost to our air quality and quality of life. Thirty years ago, Mayor Lindsay recognized the problem of too many cars in the city and blocked off Madison and Fifth Avenues one day each weekend.
 
LARRY SEAMAN
Commercial fisherman, Jamaica Bay, Queens
 I got no major complaints about the water. But you ever get in a car and drive? That never changes. They say the roads have gotten better, but come on, before you couldn't drive anywhere, so what's the diff? I'm a waterman, but I got to go in the morning to get gas for the boats, and from what I seen they could be handling this a little better. Like when someone breaks down, how about clear them off the highway so the rubberneckers don't slow down? Other cities take cars off the road. What's the problem? It's just mismanagement. I see a lot of those D.O.T. guys sitting on their rears not doing anything. I fish all my life. What are they doing?
 
H. CLAUDE SHOSTAL
President of the Regional Plan Association
Things are clearly better, but all this euphoria is masking major problems that no one is addressing, mainly infrastructure. It's not sexy, but if we don't act during the good times, we're going to pay dearly during the next downturn, and we won't be able to compete with cities like Hong Kong, Paris and London, which are all investing in their infrastructure. Look around and the last thing we built was the Verrazano Bridge and that was 30 years ago. In the 80's, all we did was try to catch up from the years of neglect.
We should be building the Second Avenue subway to relieve the overcrowded Lex line. We should be building a new west side subway to help develop the far west side. The Long Island Rail Road should be brought into Grand Central. And it's absurd to rebuild the elevated Gowanus Expressway. A tunnel makes more sense.
Government has to get over this idea that we can't build anything substantial. If you think about what makes this city great, it's things like Central Park, the subway, the bridges; these things didn't just happen.
 
BRENDAN SEXTON
President of the Municipal Art Society
We're a city that fought its way back from the ravages of graffiti, vandalism and litter, but we don't seem to show any imagination for what to do next.
Unlike other cities, New York's public spaces, newsstands, kiosks and street furniture don't look like much. And the things that are beautiful we tend to tear down in the name of progress. New York thrives on commerce, and unfortunately this sometimes leads to shortsightedness.
It doesn't cost more to design and plan well. It is now, during the good times, that we should be thinking about the long view. A little bit of imagination goes a long way. Just as it's important for a city not to be scary and dangerous, it's also important for a city to be attractive. Now that people feel safe, we have to make them feel pleased.
 
 
 
A Bigger Bank Account, A Better Spouse

 
WILLIAM S. BESLOW
Manhattan divorce lawyer
Ironically, prosperity isn't necessarily a good thing for marriages. In fact, I've found that a sound economy actually promotes more divorce. As people work harder to achieve and maintain success and their ever-escalating life styles, there is less time to devote to spouses and kids. That often leads to more friction and more unhappiness at home. Strangely enough, it seems that the more successful you are, the more stress and pressure you feel.
People's selfish impulses also get fed by a booming economy. The harder people work and the more they achieve, the greater their sense of entitlement. They want to spend more time going out, dining out, and rewarding themselves. Then there's the sense that they're entitled to an across-the-board upgrade: a better job, a bigger income and a better spouse.
 
HEATHER MAC DONALD
A fellow at the Manhattan Institute and a contributing editor for its publication, City Journal
 Family breakdown is a large and, unfortunately, nearly completely unaddressed problem. Giuliani mentioned it in his State of the City, but I'm not aware of any follow-up. As long as illegitimacy remains as high as it is, any other social initiative, whether it be school dropout rate, or poverty, is doomed to failure.
I think many of our policies implicitly support single parenting, not just welfare, but our housing policies give priorities to homeless families. Guess how many homeless families are two-parent operations? Almost none. Single-parent family equals poverty, and the city gives priority to single-parent families. I advocate rewriting the policies to give priority to married parents. The same goes for day care.
And I think most appalling of all is day care centers in high schools. There's already 41 day care centers that completely normalize teen-age pregnancy and send the message that we expect you to get pregnant and then have a nice day care center for children. And the city is planning to put in a day care center every time they renovate a school.
 
TRACY QUAN
A spokeswoman for Prostitutes of New York, a sex workers advocacy group
Whenever the economy and tourism improve, the sex industry benefits as well. But at the same time, this new wave of repression, arrests and anti-sex hysteria is really hurting prostitutes. It's all very hypocritical since the sex industry provides real benefits to New York's economy. We spend plenty of money at restaurants, beauty salons and other city services; prostitutes feel strongly about working instead of living off welfare. The reality is that tens of thousands of New Yorkers directly and indirectly depend on the sex industry for their livelihood.
Just as important is what we provide to tourists, businessmen and conventioneers. People expect a certain level of excitement and entertainment when they come to New York. So while diplomats, CEO's and politicians will probably continue to have access to their high-end trysts, the eradication of the most accessible commercial sex will hurt the average tourist and middle-class john. The crackdown on commercial sex is an attack on the middle class while claiming to pander to middle-class morality.
 
 
 
Still Reading A Tale of Two Cities

 
JOHANN MOORE
Founder of the New York City Medical Marijuana Buyers' Club and a candidate for the gubernatorial nomination for the Green Party
I think there is a lot of apathy in the activist community, and I certainly believe that that apathy is partly a result of the hype campaign that everything's getting better and if we only keep on working within the system things will keep on getting better.
 
THOMAS K. SMALL
A Brooklyn lawyer who has used a wheelchair since childhood
They talk about a booming economy, but all I know is that I've sent out 20 resumes in the last month and I've only gotten one nibble. I think employers in New York are still afraid to take a chance on disabled workers.
In fact, life in the city hasn't gotten much easier for people like me. Taxis are still not accessible, and the subway is basically off-limits to wheelchairs; buses are fine if you have all the time in the world. Even traveling on the sidewalk can be perilous because so many intersections still don't have curb cuts. Sometimes I mount the sidewalk, go to the next corner and find there's no way to get down. Then I have to go all the way back and either cross over or go into the street, which scares me because one of my friends was hit by a car and killed that way.
 
DENNIS M. WALCOTT
President of the New York Urban League
If you look beyond the positive pronouncements, you'll see that African- Americans are not benefiting from the boom as much as whites. Thousands of people have to work two or more jobs just to put food on the table. They have no health insurance, no child care, and they are forced to send their children to terrible schools, limiting opportunities for their children to do better.
Another worry is the black middle class, which is seriously vulnerable to an economic downturn. Compared to white homeowners in similar neighborhoods, especially in southeast Queens, black households are usually kept afloat by the combined income of two or three family members, many of whom work as civil servants or hospital workers. If layoffs occur, these kinds of jobs are the first to go, which will threaten the viability of these communities.
 
PHILIP KASINITZ
Associate professor of sociology at City University of New York's Graduate Center and author of "Caribbean New York: Black Immigrants and the Politics of Race" (Cornell University Press, 1992)
Despite all the celebration, New York is still a tale of two cities, a place of stark disparity between rich and poor, black and white. But more troubling is that these disparities, it seems, have become largely accepted. There are still plenty of neighborhoods like Howard Beach and Bay Ridge where blacks cannot live. Of course demographics are constantly changing; white flight is still going on, even though there isn't much attention focused on it. The fault lines of race are shifting all the time, and in places like Canarsie and Flatlands in Brooklyn and portions of southeast Queens, whites have been moving out one block at a time.
 
DENNIS DeLEON
President of the Latino Commission on AIDS
 In terms of the Latino community, the permanent underclass is still there. Life has not changed. Unemployment is enormously high, among young people especially, and the opportunity for jobs and education seem to be shrinking.
But there's this weird phenomenon under way: Because the media say things are better, many people really feel things have gotten better, even though by the quantitative indices there's no difference. There's this kind of buzz; people actually believe the quality of their lives has improved even it hasn't improved one iota. It's a great public relations effort.
I guess it's kind of like everyone wants to be a winner. People get tired of being negative. I think previous administrations had a tendency to dwell on bad stuff in the community and the problems and everything you don't have. And so finally when someone says things are better and you can be part of it -- even though nothing has changed -- people want to hear that. People want to hear things are good.
 
 
 
Safe and Happy, And Aching for a Fix

 
STUART EWEN
Chairman of Hunter College film and communications department; author of "Pr!: A Social History of Spin" (Basic Books, 1996)
 As the news media become increasingly consolidated in New York and increasingly dominated by voices of vested wealth, they have become among those who have been the prime beneficiaries of the current barbeque. You have to understand that the people guiding the editorial policy in this city are making six or seven figures and are hobnobbing with the powerful; and spin and effectiveness of spin is all in proximity.
Handing people a press release does not get things in the newspaper. What's been created is basically an ongoing exchange of saliva between the media establishment and the people who can provide good news. That's what's happening vis-a-vis the new New York City. There may be some who feel uneasy with Giuliani's authoritarian style, but they're the very people who, to a large extent, are benefiting from the story of New York as a safe and happy place.
 
JASON FARRELL
Executive director of Positive Health Project, a Manhattan-based agency that works with intravenous drug users
Thanks to Hollywood and the fashion industry, heroin use among white professionals is on the rise in New York. Besides the fact that people have more money to spend on drugs, they're attracted to heroin because they think it's chic and risque. Of course it's as dangerous as it ever was.
While the rate of HIV transmission continues to drop for some groups, new infection among intravenous drug users is still growing by about 3,000 a year. The numbers are pretty scary. About 30 percent of the city's injecting drug users are now infected with the virus. The city's crackdown on deviant behavior may be pushing the drug problem further out of sight, but it's not reducing the dangers associated with addiction. In fact, it's making it harder for us to reach people because they're fearful of surfacing.
 
CHRISTINE QUINN
Executive director of the New York City Gay and Lesbian Anti-Violence Project
We keep hearing about how crime is down in New York, but if you are a gay man or lesbian it's still pretty dangerous out there. There were 658 anti-gay incidents last year, up from 575 the year before. That's a 14 percent increase during a period that most crime plummeted.
More than 80 percent of the anti-gay incidents we documented were violent. And unlike in the past, when the typical weapon was a rock picked up from the ground, these days it's more likely to be a bat or a pipe brought from home. That means that people are traveling around the city with the primary objective of hunting down a gay person. We're also seeing much more serious injuries, more attacks taking place in the outer boroughs and more incidents involving police officers.
If everything is so wonderful in the city and people are so much happier, why are so many New Yorkers acting uncivil to gay men and lesbians? Maybe the police should focus less on jaywalking and more on those who beat up gay people while they're jaywalking.
 
ALAIR TOWNSEND
Publisher of Crain's New York Business
What's happening in New York is quite positive, but people have to realize that we still haven't figured out how to overcome the business cycle. I've always thought of New York as a city of manic-depressives, people who need direction to be happy. Frankly, we need to get a grip.
People seem to think there's no end to how high is high and how tall is tall. Of course, I remember a time not long ago when we talked about how the last person leaving New York should turn the light off. These days the talk is about how much everyone loves New York and how great everything is. I just hope a small part of their brain remembers this when times aren't as good.

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
A Ski Area Without the Extremes

BYLINE: By GIOIA DILIBERTO 

DATELINE: ALTA, Utah

 BODY:
WITH the white peaks of the Wasatch Mountains rising behind him, Onno Wieringa, manager of the Alta Ski Lifts Company, stood in the middle of the road leading to this venerable resort and politely, but firmly, stopped every car trying to get in.
"We are sorry you will be unable to ski Alta today," read the note Mr. Wieringa gave to each driver he turned away. "If we were to permit more skiers on the mountain it would compromise the quality of the experience skiers have learned to expect from us." 
 In a business that has been downhill for a decade, Alta stands out as one of the nation's few ski areas with more customers than it needs. While most ski operators are pouring large sums into capital improvements -- big hotels, ice rinks, nightclubs, snowtubing chutes -- to lure more people, Alta continues to turn a profit, even as it limits skiers to about 3,500 a day.
"We've always been on a steady upward basis," said Jodie Shrontz, a granddaughter of one of the resort's founders. "Some years aren't as big a leap as others, but we've always made more every year."
With a reputation for some of the best snow in the world and lift tickets that are relatively cheap -- $28 a day compared with $56 at Vail, Colo. -- Alta seems poised to grow. But that doesn't appear likely.
For one thing, there simply isn't the space. The resort lies at the narrowing top of Little Cottonwood Canyon, 25 miles southeast of Salt Lake City. Only about 125 acres of vacant land are available near the ski area, and much of that sits in avalanche paths. Five small hotels are within skiing distance of the slopes, but further development is limited because of access to water -- controlled by Salt Lake City -- and the zoning rules of Alta, a town of 397 people.
What's more, the Alta ski area is protected by old money and its stockholders' commitment to preserving the area. They are supported by loyal, hard-core skiers, a blend of locals and out-of-staters who return to the area season after season. "We want to keep Alta as it is," said Paul Laughlin, whose family owns a controlling stake in the resort.
Indeed, Alta hasn't changed much since it was founded nearly 60 years ago. Most of Alta's runs are natural, and there are no nightclubs, T-shirt shops or fancy restaurants. Only eight exposed chair lifts serve the slopes. (Aspen, Colo., has 30.) All carry only two or three skiers a chair, and most open onto knife-edged ridges that cannot accommodate many people.
The elements that Alta enthusiasts regard as strengths, other skiers might call deficits. There are no gondolas, and the longer trips can make for frosty rides on chillier days. The food at the restaurants on the mountain is basic burger-and-chili fare, not the gourmet experience, say, at nearby Deer Valley.
Even so, "Alta is one of the few places that's beautiful and romantic as skiing was in the old days," said Bill Levitt, Mayor of the town of Alta for 28 years and owner of the 55-room Alta Lodge.
As large conglomerates take over more ski areas, the small, independent resort that grew from one person's passion for the sport is an endangered species. In recent years, four big companies -- Vail Resorts, American Skiing, Intrawest and Booth Creek -- have been snatching up ski areas nationwide. They now own 31 percent of the nation's 507 ski resorts.
The conglomerates are bucking up the industry, which, based on 50 million skier days each year, generates more than $1.5 billion in lift tickets alone. "In general, the industry did well this year," says Mark Manson, an analyst with Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette. Revenues are up, he added, and the conglomerates "are enjoying very strong growth." Capital expenditures across a sample of 177 ski resorts nationwide increased from $167.5 million in 1995-96 to $237 million in 1996-97 -- a jump of 41 percent, according to the National Ski Areas Association.
Confidence in these ventures is fueled by the growing popularity of snowboarding, which is expected to account for 20 percent of lift ticket sales this season. Indeed, boarding, once disdained as the industry's ruin, is now embraced as its possible savior.
Yet Alta is one of only six resorts in the National Ski Area Association where snowboarding isn't allowed. "For us it was a business decision," Mr. Wieringa said. "We already have enough people at our door."
Alta, though, is an industry anomaly, not "an economic model that works," said Barry Rothberg, an analyst for Furman Selz. Typically, resorts "that rely on lift ticket sales alone have very horrible business models," he said. "Basically, Alta is an uphill transportation company. They're getting paid because they're taking you to the top of the mountain. Alta provides a very Bohemian old-fashioned experience and is able to pull it off because the terrain is spectacular and the weather is about as reliable as it gets."
The ideal, Mr. Rothberg said, would be a resort whose profits reflected a third of a skier's total vacation costs, including transportation, lodging, food, entertainment and lift tickets. Vail Resorts comes close, earning between 25 percent and 30 percent from each ski vacation on the mountain.
Alta looms nearly 11,000 feet up Little Cottonwood Canyon, just south of Salt Lake City. Storms dump an average of 550 inches of light powder on Alta's slopes annually, more snow than elsewhere in the region, including Snowbird, only 1.5 miles away.
In the mid-19th century, Alta was a silver mining town. But in the early 1900's it was destroyed by fire and avalanches. For years, the lone resident was the eccentric George Watson, who lived in a tiny cabin, declared himself mayor and bought some old mining claims that turned out to be worthless. In 1939 he deeded 1,800 acres to the United States Forest Service in lieu of back taxes.
Soon thereafter, Joe Quinney, a Salt Lake City lawyer, and James Laughlin, the New York publisher of Delmore Schwartz and Ezra Pound, obtained a lease from the Forest Service and started putting in chair lifts. They recruited two Norweigen ski-jump legends, the brothers Sverre and Alf Engen, to run a ski school.
THE Forest Service still owns most of the resort's 2,200 acres. The five lodges belong to individual families. The Alta Ski Lift Company owns the lift operation, a few administration buildings, three restaurants and the Alf Engen Ski School. The Laughlin family owns 51 percent of Alta Ski Lift; the Quinneys, 25 percent, and Dick Bass, the owner of Snowbird, 11 percent. The rest is divided among a handful of others. (Quinney died in the 1980's, and Laughlin died last summer.)
The owners won't release figures on revenues, but gross income from the more than 453,000 lift tickets sold in the 1996-97 season alone would be about $12.6
million annually. Alta Ski Lifts pays 2.5 percent of net income to the Forest Service for use of the land.
As with any business at the mercy of the elements, revenues depend on the weather. But in 60 years, there have been only two disastrous winters. In 1976-77, a severe drought hit the mountain, leaving it tufted with grass at Christmas; in the early 1970's, it rained all January and "everyone in the lodges checked out," recalled John Cahill, owner of the Alta Peruvian, one of the resort's hotels.
The founders envisioned Alta as a playground for themselves, their friends and the locals. Ms. Shrontz, who lives in Alta, said Quinney, her grandfather, wasn't interested in the ski area as a way to become rich.
Indeed, Alta's pricing policy is different from that at other resorts, said Michael Berry, president of the National Ski Areas Association: "There's no kids' pricing and no discounts -- except to skiers over 80. Also, they don't spend very much money, if any, on marketing. It's all word of mouth."
Because the company has no mortgages, it is financially healthier than most other ski resorts. "A lot of places go out on a limb to build 500-room hotels. Then they can't fill them, and they're in trouble," said John Guldner, the town manager.
In contrast, nearby Snowbird, a world-class resort, was in financial trouble until recently. It opened in 1970 and serves slightly fewer skiers a year than Alta does. Lift tickets that include a high-speed tram to the top of the mountain cost $47, and the ambiance is much different -- "lots of concrete and fast lifts," Mr. Rothberg, the analyst, said. Moreover, Snowbird advertises heavily and positions itself as a four-season resort.
But Alta's commitment to staying small and independent remains firm. When Mr. Wieringa first proposed at a town meeting several years ago that Alta limit the number of cars and buses that could park on the mountain, some local shop owners were opposed. But Mr. Wierenga convinced them, Mr. Levitt said, "that in the long run, it was the smart thing to do."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 16; Column 4; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1193 words

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Looking Back At Jackson Hole

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
SINCE the start of the 1970's, an obscure group of economists and health specialists had been flogging notions of universal medical care to the deaf ears of legislators and Presidents.
The group's organizers, Paul M. Ellwood, formerly a pediatric neurologist in Minneapolis, and Alain C. Enthoven, a health economist at Stanford University, had a theory about expanding the cost-efficient practices of managed care into a vast system that would cover all Americans. 

'Grotesque' Version
Then six years ago, during the Presidential primary campaigns in New Hampshire, they received a call from Bill Clinton's health advisers, who wanted a briefing about the plan. Suddenly, the Jackson Hole Group, as they called themselves, was a household name.
"The rest is bad political history," Dr. Ellwood said.
Four years after the demise of the Clinton Administration's "grotesque" formulation of the Jackson Hole plan, as Mr. Enthoven puts it, managed care now dominates the marketplace, having evolved on its own because of economic pressures.
Eighty-five percent of all workers are now covered by some sort of managed-care plan, up from 50 percent four years ago. But the results are mixed, many consumers are unhappy and health care has returned to the top of the nation's political agenda. No one in Congress or the White House has an appetite any longer for grand schemes and revolutions. And no one is picking the brains of Jackson Hole this time around.
As they look back at the swift and far-reaching changes they helped inspire, the Jackson Hole planners say they were right about some things and wrong about others.
"The real weakness in the system now is nobody trusts anybody," Dr. Ellwood said. "Health plans are on the defensive, doctors are on the defensive and patients are skeptical."
The unadulterated Jackson Hole plan was simple, at least in theory. Called managed competition, it envisioned a Government-guided system of private health plans and insurance companies that would compete to enroll large regional pools of workers and other groups. Vigorous competition to win contracts with employers would drive down the cost of care. The savings would then be used to extend health care to the uninsured. Plans that enrolled disproportionately high numbers of young, healthy workers would subsidize plans with older and sicker workers.
In hindsight, Dr. Ellwood and Mr. Enthoven acknowledge that it was unrealistic to expect Congress to revamp the whole health care system with a single bill.
Peter Boland, a health care consultant in Berkeley, Calif., said the plan was "a plausible model that probably could have worked with modification." One flaw, he said, was the assumption that employers could readily be organized into regional groups to purchase care. Another was "a distinct lack of choice on behalf of consumers," he said.
 
No Consumer Voice
Mary Jane England, a psychiatrist and a Jackson Hole member, said the plan was drawn up without the involvement of consumers. "From 1993 to now, the biggest shift that we've seen is the shift to consumers," said Dr. England, who is the president of the Washington Business Group on Health, an organization of large employers.
It was the luxury of wide-open choice, and the accompanying rise in costs, that inspired the Administration's pursuit of a plan in the first place. Enrollees in the prevailing fee-for-service plans could get whatever care they wished from doctors who could prescribe and charge whatever they wished. Insurers would write them checks and then raise the premiums they charged employers.
As managed care has spread, so have complaints from consumers and physicians about the loss of choice and prerogatives. A consumer rebellion has already prompted at least 43 states to enact laws expanding consumer rights.
But managed care, left to the marketplace, has had some successes. It met the overriding goal of the planners -- stopping the soaring inflation in health costs at the start of the 1990's. The nation's spending for health care in 1996 reached $1 trillion, 4.4 percent and $50 billion more than in 1995 -- the smallest percentage increase in 37 years.
Still, the planners did not anticipate how the marketplace would reward the system's participants. Employers are unscathed. They have been holding the line on the premiums they pay to insurers and managed care organizations, forcing the managed care industry as a whole to lose money last year. And employers have been requiring workers to pay ever larger shares of the premiums.
As a result, the Employee Benefit Research Institute reports, 41.4 million Americans under 65, or 17.7 percent of the population, has no insurance at all, compared with 38.3 million, or 17 percent, in 1992.
As the White House and Congress tinker with the system the marketplace wrought, that gap could begin to shrink. Last year, Congress voted to try to extend coverage to five million of the nation's 10 million children, and this year the President has proposed extending Medicare coverage to the uninsured among people who are 55 to 65.
Such initiatives have become possible, Dr. Ellwood says, because of the Federal budget savings arising from managed care's leveling of health care costs. "Our idea," he said, "was that enough money could be saved from managed competition to pay for the coverage of those who didn't have it."
 
Healthier, Not Happier
For those who are insured, it is too soon to tell whether managed care has improved health in any significant way. Statistics from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention show that people are no sicker than they were in the fee-for-service days.
But managed care, by encouraging preventive medicine, with all but free mammograms, physical examinations, prenatal care and childhood immunization, has probably produced some health improvements.
"Maybe people aren't happier," said Uwe E. Reinhardt, a health economist at the Woodrow Wilson School at Princeton. "But they're healthier."
This month, Mr. Clinton told the American Medical Association that he is taking a "step by step" approach to health care reform.
In the new debate, the lightning rods are the President's promise of better quality of care -- implying more choice and regulation -- and industry's warnings of rising costs, driven by regulation, that could leave still more people uninsured.
And the debate will center on new questions, like how much government should intervene to stop abuses of the market-driven health care system; how far to go toward coverage for the working poor who have no insurance; how much choice to allow H.M.O. enrollees; how much to let doctors reclaim control of health care decisions, and how much consumers, their employers and the economy will accept in higher premiums to pay for greater choice.
"The best thing the Clinton plan did," said Jack Faris, president of the National Federation of Independent Business and a participant in the Jackson Hole deliberations, "was to tell us in the private sector we'd better get our act together and improve quality and lower cost and give us a wider selection of care."

GRAPHIC: Photo: With the costs of managed care rising, Norman C. Payson, the new chief executive of Oxford Health Plans, made a case for huge rate increases last week. Oxford lost $20 million last year on individual policies, whose holders tend to be sicker than people in more profitable group plans. (John Sotomayor/The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

HEADLINE: The Nation: What New York Renaissance?;
Left Wing, Right Wing, Sneering at This Town

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:

CONFIDENTIAL MEMORANDUM
To: The United Media Elite
From: The I Love New York Subcommittee
Subject: Naysayers
 WE don't know how it happened, but there is now strong evidence that many out-of-town writers and thinkers aren't getting the message about New York City's glorious comeback. In recent months, dissenting voices have been heard, daring to suggest that the city may actually have much more work to do. 
 Granted, most of these voices are coming from the provinces, from chip-on-the-shoulder places like Washington, London and Los Angeles, towns that long ago lost their bids to become capital of the world. But what is striking about these dissents is that they are coming from across the ideological spectrum, from conservative publications like The Weekly Standard and National Review to centrist Democrats to socialist university professors.
They are filtering their arguments through their own ideologies, of course. Those on the left believe the city has become increasingly oblivious to the social costs of prosperity, while conservatives believe the city hasn't gone nearly far enough in cutting taxes and stimulating the economy. Others are regionalists, passionately promoting areas like the Pacific Rim at our expense. But each is using our renaissance to once again set New York apart as a unique cultural symbol -- and just at the moment when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is finally poised to lead us into the American mainstream.
It is that entry that they most resist, even as they applaud the sudden decline in crime and sleaze that for so long served as our city's trademarks. They all seem to make the same point: We in the media elite, who have worked so hard to control what the nation thinks, have no idea what is really going on west of the Hudson, and thus we cannot fathom how far New York still has to go to catch up with prevailing economic and social trends. Thanks to our efforts, the world is flocking to our suddenly safe streets but knows nothing of our sky-high unemployment rate or business taxes. We in the media elite would rather rhapsodize about the tourist and immigration boom than explain the 1.07 million New Yorkers who, according to last week's census figures, joined the exodus from the city during the 1990's.
 
'Hype'
Take Joel Kotkin, for example, a centrist who used to work for the Democratic Leadership Council and now writes about urban policy as a senior fellow of the Pepperdine Institute for Public Policy in California. In an op-ed piece in The Los Angeles Times last month headlined "The Hype That Made New York," he argued (with a distinctly anti-Eastern accent for a former New Yorker) that "New York's much ballyhooed 'resurgence' " is more public relations than economics. At the behest of the city's real estate industry, he charged, we have exaggerated our turnaround while ignoring more significant shifts in places like Houston, Boston and, God forbid, Los Angeles.
Because our industry is clustered in a few blocks of midtown Manhattan, he said, we have been lulled into complacency by Mr. Giuliani's soothing reductions in crime without even realizing that economic growth in the other four boroughs has been stagnant for years. (At least the city is doing better than the surrounding three-state region.)
 
Manhattan-Centered
"Not surprisingly, the Manhattan media elite tends to share perceptions growing out of common experiences," Mr. Kotkin wrote. He even quoted a Smith College professor, Stanley Rothman, who said: "These guys are basically all from the same place. They all read The New York Times and they talk to each other more than anyone else."
Asked in an interview to explain a recent New York Times poll that found that the image of New York around the country had vastly improved, Mr. Kotkin laughed and said all of us have created that perception with our flattering newsweekly profiles of Mr. Giuliani, our merry Seinfeld episodes, our Fortune cover stories promoting New York as the most improved city for business.
"The fact is that Houston and Dallas have had much stronger recoveries than New York, but you never read about that because you don't know about it in New York," he said. He doesn't seem to understand that our frame of reference is our own historical experience, not that of lesser cities.
Mr. Kotkin is no conservative, but his skepticism has been echoed in right-of-center publications like The Weekly Standard, The Economist, National Review and The Financial Times of London. Many conservatives seem uneasy with the idea that New York could begin to turn itself around while retaining its rent control system, high tax structure and enormous municipal budget. And the libertarians among them recoil at the Mayor's notion that government should encourage civility. Even The City Journal, a quarterly published by Mr. Giuliani's favorite think tank, the Manhattan Institute, reminds the Mayor in its current issue that New York's city and state tax burden is twice as high per capita as those of the average Midwestern or Eastern city, and nowhere near as low as those of the South and West.
William Tucker, who wrote an article in The Weekly Standard in January titled "New York City, Economic Backwater," said in an interview that New Yorkers are so excited to have escaped their doldrums that they don't realize how much greater the booms are in places like Research Triangle Park in North Carolina. For all the hype that he accuses us of giving New York's multimedia industry in downtown's Silicon Alley, the community remains tiny and may be growing stagnant. Several promising New York-based Web sites have recently closed down, including two last week.
"New York is doing tremendously well this year, but there are all these underlying structural difficulties with the city's economy that are invisible now because the market is so high," he said. "It's still crushing small businesses with its tax structure, which makes me think of what unbelievably vast potential the city would have if it really got in gear."
The Giuliani administration, of course, argues that it has just begun the task of rolling away years of anti-business policies, and insists that the turnaround has just begun. But The Financial Times says the recovery has not been evenly distributed.
"The Wall Street boom, and the megabucks it has generated in New York, has already driven up property prices to the point where, by and large, only the reasonably well-off middle classes (and those benefiting from controlled rents) can afford to live in Manhattan," Richard Tomkins wrote in the newspaper last weekend. "Conspicuous consumption is rampant, and the highest form of artistic endeavor is regarded as the ability to get a table at Balthazar."
 
Creative Complacency
Though this trend may mean more ad pages and higher revenues for all of us, many writers have suggested that it is spreading a stifling blanket of complacency over the city's "creative sector," which often thrives in hard times. Dwight Garner, an editor at the on-line magazine Salon, wrote last year that he is taking the subway more than ever now, seeing it as "one of the last places where the city feels genuinely alert, racially mixed, edgy, engaged." Robert Fitch, author of "The Assassination of New York," says the city's failures to create economic diversity are having serious cultural consequences.
"There's a somnolent quality to the characteristic areas of New York City activity," said Mr. Fitch, a professor at New York University who will be making this point in a speech to the Socialist Scholars Conference this weekend. "Where's the vitality in the art world? In music and dance? Cultural life has been narrowed down to entertainment."
Fortunately, no one need ever know of these fringe seditionists with their talk of Houston and underground railways, if we can simply remain united and ignore them. By the way, does anyone know if the subway runs beneath Midtown?

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1421 words

HEADLINE: The Nation: Pride and Prejudice;
The South's History Rises, Again and Again

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: JACKSON, Miss.

 BODY:
LIKE an anthology of short stories threaded by a common theme, a confluence of events in Mississippi last week provided a poignant test of William Faulkner's wry observation that "the past is never dead; it's not even past."
Clearly that was more true in the mythic South of Faulkner's fiction than in the modern South that promotes itself so relentlessly as New. But as developments in Mississippi last week demonstrated, the region's noble ambitions are still weighed down by the transgressions of the past. Hard as it tries -- and it tries more earnestly with each passing day -- the South never quite pulls free of the most repellent aspects of its history. 
 The week began with a contentious forum held by the President's Advisory Board on Race at the University of Mississippi, an institution still coming to terms with the deadly riots of 1962 that greeted the enrollment of its first black student, James H. Meredith. Next came the unsealing of 124,000 pages of documents from the state's defunct Sovereignty Commission, a domestic spy agency disbanded in 1977 after waging an illegal, 21-year war on the civil rights movement. And the week ended with an ugly confrontation in the state Capitol between legislators and Gov. Kirk Fordice over a voting rights bill that has generated yet another debate over states' rights and race.
 
Anguish and Anger
At the intersection of all three events there is reason to believe that many in this most Southern of states have concluded that they must address their past forthrightly to move forward. But in doing so they must inevitably confront anguish and anger -- evoked by haunting images of Medgar Evers and other civil rights martyrs. And they face a paradox: the fact that revisiting the past both stimulates catharsis and stokes resentment. Whether it ultimately speeds healing or retards it is hard to know.
"Medgar Evers and James Meredith both said that if we ever turn the corner on race, Mississippi will be the best place in the world to live," said David Sansing, a University of Mississippi historian, who turned to the metaphor of a traffic circle to explain the South's progress. "We have turned the corner, but it's not a 90-degree turn," he said. "It's like one of those things that I drove in England last summer, a roundabout. Maybe we'll get off of it one day. But at least we're in motion, and that's more than you can say for much of the country."
That race relations in the South do not always advance in a straight line could be seen Tuesday morning at the Mississippi Department of Archives and History, where the Sovereignty Commission files were unsealed.
Ellie J. Dahmer, the widow of Vernon Dahmer, a leader for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People in Hattiesburg whose 1966 firebombing death is being reinvestigated, was there with her two children, hoping to discover something in her late husband's file that would implicate a local Ku Klux Klan leader, Sam Bowers. "At last, Mississippi is willing to rebuild some of its past," said Mrs. Dahmer, clutching the agency's surveillance records on her husband.
But also on hand was Richard Barrett, a white lawyer from Jackson who defended the members of the Sovereignty Commission as patriots. He handed out fliers arguing that Mississippi's streets were safer and its schools were better when the commission was at work.
The commission, supported by tax dollars and housed in the Capitol, was, in the words of a longtime Mississippi journalist, Bill Minor, the "K.G.B. of the cotton patches." As the civil rights movement was sustained by the Federal courts, Mississippi and several other Southern states institutionalized their resistance by creating such agencies to track the activities, associations, political affiliations and sexual proclivities of their citizens.
When the Mississippi Legislature shut the agency, it sealed the records -- those that had not been destroyed -- for 50 years. The American Civil Liberties Union and several other plaintiffs challenged the closing of the files, and succeeded in opening them 29 years early.
The records show that the commission used both physical and economic intimidation to fight its foes. A 1958 memorandum from a commission investigator, for example, noted approvingly that steps had been taken to silence a black preacher, W. B. Ridgeway of Hattiesburg, who had testified before a Congressional committee about the curtailment of black voting rights.
"Economic pressure had been applied to members of his congregation in such a way that they got on Ridgeway pretty hard and effectively," wrote the investigator, Zack J. VanLandingham, "and since that time there has been nothing heard out of Ridgeway."
Few details were too inconsequential for the commission's records. The purchase of a new Singer sewing machine was noted in the file on Rita Schwerner, a civil rights worker whose husband, Michael, was later murdered. License plate numbers were collected and traced. Marital spats were detailed.
 
States' Rights Redux
Against that legacy, it was hard to miss the irony unfolding in the Capitol, where lawmakers argued last week with Governor Fordice, a Republican, over his insistence that voters show identification at the polls.
Last month, Mr. Fordice vetoed a bill that would have made Mississippi the final state to adhere to the National Voter Registration Act of 1993, which requires states to make registration forms available in drivers' license bureaus, social service agencies and other state offices. Mr. Fordice has said the "motor voter" law should be renamed the "welfare voter" law, and has charged that it is an unconstitutional imposition on his state's rights.
Under pressure from the Justice Department, however, he has said he would sign a bill that included a mandatory voter identification provision to deter fraud. The Legislature has rejected that proposal, specifically because of objections from black Mississippians who harbor fresh memories of the obstacles erected by the state to keep them from voting in the past.
State Senator John Horhn, a black Democrat from Jackson, said black Mississippians were very suspicious of the voter identification requirement, given that the state once had an agency charged with the surveillance of its citizens and the abridgment of their rights. "It's something that we are very wary of and that we don't trust," he said.
Mr. Fordice charged last week that many of the legislators opposing his proposal "are here because of voter fraud." Mr. Horhn responded by saying that the Governor "has repeatedly shown himself to be a callous, unthinking dolt."
On Monday and Tuesday in Oxford, members of the President's Advisory Board on Race gathered at the University of Mississippi for a forum dedicated to gauging the community's progress on race. Again, the old South and the new one clashed.
A black student and a white student from Oxford High School declared their friendship with a heartfelt hug, but also pointed out that black and white students segregated themselves at lunch. Black speakers complained about the lack of a black doctor in town, adding that a nonwhite physician would have trouble attracting white patients. When a white man in the audience stood to proclaim that it was his "freedom" to wave the Confederate flag at Ole Miss football games, a white student responded by saying that most students would appreciate it if he did not.
Former Gov. William F. Winter, a member of the advisory panel, and John Hope Franklin, the historian who serves as its chairman, both commented on the progress reflected in the simple fact that such a discussion was being held at Ole Miss, a place with such a history of racial strife. The university's chancellor, Robert C. Khayat, who has tried to tone down Confederate symbolism at the school, said events in the South "move forward and backward, seldom in a straight line."
Such acknowledgements of the region's complexities are becoming more common across the South, as are apologies for past behavior. Last fall, at a 40th anniversary commemoration of the desegregation of Little Rock Central High School, Arkansas' Republican Governor, Mike Huckabee, said the violent white resistance to school's integration "may be forgivable, but it is not excusable."
"In the Proverbs," added Mr. Huckabee, formerly a Baptist preacher, "it says that he who conceals his sins does not prosper. But whoever professes and renounces them will find mercy."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 3; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1152 words

HEADLINE: The World;
Clinton's Spotlight Now Turns to Africa

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: ABUJA, Nigeria

 BODY:
FOR millennia, Africa has largely remained a mystery to the outside world, marked perhaps more by its isolation than by any other feature.
This stubborn reality can be traced to the earliest times and is reflected in the hopelessly misrepresented images of ancient cartographers, whose graphic distortions were as errant as the half-myths and false science that passed for knowledge about a place long known among Westerners as the Dark Continent. 
 From the Roman era, trade winds from the west made maritime commerce with remote India much easier for the Mediterranean world than it ever was with the much-closer eastern coast of Africa.
And on the west of the continent, Africa's greatest civilizations rose and fell with hardly an echo; the formidable natural barrier imposed by the vast and hostile expanse of the Sahara Desert enforced the silence.
When outsiders have engaged Africa at all, Africans complain, they have almost always done so in the interest of extraction. And the products they have taken, from salt to slaves, gold to oil, have consistently served prosperity elsewhere rather than any development here.
The perspective of millennia may seem needlessly long for those who will watch President Clinton visit Africa this week, the first trip by an American leader to the continent in 20 years (except for a lightning trip by George Bush to visit American soldiers in Somalia).
But for guests and hosts alike, it will ultimately be against this backdrop that Mr. Clinton's voyage will be measured.
The logic comes direct from Mr. Clinton's quarter. For this President, a man as versed in the art of the message as any modern leader, the first order of business will be one of images: changing the way Americans think of Africans, and perhaps vice versa.
 
America, Meet a Continent
Mr. Clinton has already spoken of "introducing the people of the United States to a new Africa -- an Africa whose political and economic accomplishments grow more impressive each month." He comes promising to help pull Africa out of its long isolation, and to assist in what he calls the continent's budding renaissance. There will be talk of new trade initiatives, certainly, and of democracy, of the environment and of working together for peace.
Both the backdrops selected and the countries to be visited (Ghana, Uganda, Rwanda, South Africa, Botswana and Senegal -- all of which, except for Rwanda, exemplify strides toward democracy or economic growth or both) reveal the underlying message -- a belated welcoming of Africa into a shared and fast-shrinking planet from perhaps the only man alive who can credibly make such a greeting.
Like every other important message these days, Mr. Clinton's message to Africa will be borne on the wings of the media. The television images beamed back to the United States promise to be of an Africa that few Americans suspect exists: of modern cities and articulate statesmen and fully fleshed-out people rather than the cartoon-like images of Africans as tribalized villagers that have prevailed.
"We are hoping to accomplish two things," said Susan Rice, assistant Secretary of State for Africa. "The first is to try and show Americans a picture of Africa that is different from the one-sided view they often get of conflict and warfare and famine." The President, she said, "also wants to convey that the United States is serious about building a new relationship with Africa for the 21st Century, one built on mutual interest and mutual respect."
Experts in American policy toward Africa who have seen past flourishes of interest fade like desert blossoms say they are cautiously optimistic that this time something different may be at work.
The mutual interest that American officials now speak of concerns the continent's huge, if mostly unrealized, economic potential, and growth rates that have been creeping up for a decade. Mr. Clinton comes armed with new legislation that, if ratified by the Senate, would lift barriers on much African trade with America and encourage American private investment as well.
 
To Be Heard
It would also create annual cabinet-level meetings between African and American officials. "Africa is the only continent that doesn't have something like this already," said Salih Booker, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations. "It gives Africans a real opportunity to step up to the plate and articulate some ideas and defend their positions on important issues rather than waiting for outside powers to simply decide matters on their behalf."
As happy and proud as many Africans will be to be playing host to the leader of the United States, there will also be real skepticism borne of long history. Where American Presidents are concerned, the gold standard in Africa was set by John F. Kennedy and Jimmy Carter, two leaders still seen by many Africans as having been uniquely interested in the fortunes of their continent -- even more significant, as Presidents who not only took from Africa but gave as well. After the echoes of Mr. Clinton's rhetoric have faded, it is against this measure that many will judge him.
At the height of the Cold War, Mr. Kennedy created the Peace Corps, sending the first volunteers to Ghana, Mr. Clinton's first stop. Mr. Carter is still revered here for his emphasis on democracy and human rights -- two themes that over the years have mostly been absent from Washington's policies toward the continent.
Mr. Clinton and his entourage will arrive with a mantra focusing on trade, not aid, and the point will be made insistently, if delicately, that America's budget priorities cannot include the large-scale assistance that many African countries say they badly need.
But Africans have been growing more confident in their own emergence from decades of dictatorship and dependence, and so they think of more than just economic aid when they ponder what might constitute a meaningful gesture from outsiders who want to give back something to a continent that they have long taken from.
In one capital after another, educated youths look to an Asia where Western-dominated financial institutions are rushing to ease an economic crisis, and these young people are posing incisive questions about why their poor countries have not received similarly sympathetic hearings on issues like crushing foreign debt.
And there is the matter of democracy. When Africans have worked so hard in this decade to change the rules of politics in their countries, fighting authoritarianism and trying to make the citizen count, why has the West so often been silent?
"Clinton's best gift to Africans will be to take us seriously as people," said Totobi Kwesi, a Ghanaian university student. "Let Africans and the world know and never forget that we suffer like other people, perhaps more, and that our needs are the same. That is worth more than money."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 943 words

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN

 BODY:

MARKETS
Higher Still and Higher
Ignoring earnings warnings from several companies -- most recently, Sunbeam and Rockwell International -- investors kept bidding up stock prices, sending the Dow Jones industrial average to five consecutive records. The Dow ended the week at 8,906.43, up 303.91. Behind the market's gains are low interest rates, low inflation and bullish analysts. Abby Joseph Cohen, the co-chairwoman of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs & Company, raised her 1998 Dow target to 9,300. . . . The boards of the National Association of Securities Dealers, and the American Stock Exchange backed merger plans. Frank G. Zarb, chairman of the N.A.S.D., said a market of markets would result. The N.A.S.D. promised to invest at least $110 million in technology and other improvements if it takes control of the Amex. 

TRADE
A Yawning Deficit
The United States trade deficit surged in January to its deepest level in a decade -- $12 billion, up from $10.9 billion in December -- the Commerce Department reported. It said the financial crises in Asia had depressed demand for American goods in that part of the world, and the Administration again called on Japan to address the imbalance by stimulating its economy. Japan reported that its trade surplus for February climbed 88.7 percent from a year earlier, to $9.8 billion. The surplus with the United States, Japan's biggest trade partner, rose 32.9 percent, to $4.14 billion.
 
BASEBALL
Media Moguls on Deck
Even before the baseball season opens, Rupert Murdoch seems to have hit a home run. His Fox Group took over the Los Angeles Dodgers from the O'Malley family for a record $350 million. Club owners turned aside objections of Mr. Murdoch's rival, Ted Turner, baseball's first media mogul-owner, and overwhelmingly approved the sale, which ends an era of family control. Tom Schieffer, president of the Texas Rangers, said Fox's TV involvement with baseball was a key factor in the approval. Fox is in the third season of a $575 million, five-year national TV contract with the major leagues; it has a $43 million-a-year national cable deal and local TV agreements with 22 of the 30 clubs. . . .The New York Yankees' principal owner, George Steinbrenner, said that he had discussed selling a portion of his franchise to Cablevision Systems, which owns the Knicks and the Rangers, but no deal had been struck.
 
MERGERS
Insurance Battle Ends
Maurice R. Greenberg, chief executive of American International Group, appeared to bow to a rival, Henry R. Silverman, chief executive of Cendant, which offered $67 a share, or a total of $3.1 billion, for American Bankers Insurance Group of Miami. The offer was $9 more than Mr. Greenberg's latest bid. . . . Aetna agreed to buy New York Life Insurance's health care subsidiary, NYLCare Health Plans, for $1.35 billion. . . .Alltel, an independent local telephone company, agreed to acquire 360 Communications, a big cellular carrier, for more than $4 billion. . . .Ispat International, a London-based steelmaker known for global acquisitions, agreed to buy Inland Steel of Chicago for $888.2 million and to assume $538.6 million of debt. . . .Carl C. Icahn withdrew his $43 million offer to bail out Pan Am.
 
BRITAIN
Labor's New Tight Fist
Presenting the first full Labor budget in 20 years, Gordon Brown, right, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, pledged incentives to get people off welfare, saying, "Your responsibility is to seek work, and my guarantee is that if you work, work will pay more than benefits." He and Prime Minister Tony Blair, at left above, explained in a public meeting that the budget also included more money for education and health, cuts in corporate taxes and rewards for long-term investments and personal savings. Called the "Iron Chancellor" for his tight-fisted approach to spending, Mr. Brown has raised the standing of the Labor Party in financial circles to a level previously unknown.
 
BANKING
A West Coast Behemoth
The nation's two largest savings and loan companies agreed to a $9.9 billion deal that would create a giant capable of competing with the big new players of consumer banking. Washington Mutual of Seattle agreed to buy H. F. Ahmanson of Los Angeles in a stock swap that would make it triple the size of its nearest competitor in the savings and loan business. It would become the seventh-largest company in the banking industry, behind BankAmerica on the West Coast but ahead of Wells Fargo. . . . Chase Manhattan, the nation's largest bank, said it would lay off 2,250 employees, or about 3 percent of its work force, as it consolidated administrative and business functions.
 
IN BRIEF
Canning Digital Spam
Unsolicited electronic junk mail -- commonly called spam -- is increasingly bedeviling cyberspace. Now Sendmail, the electronic post office used on about 75 percent of the computers that route E-mail messages to recipients on the Internet, is being fitted with software tools to battle spammers. . . . An unexpected ruling by a Federal judge in Colorado sharply increases the risks associated with financing and leasing airplanes. It threatens to make it much harder for new and financially troubled airlines to get airplanes. . . . Boeing said that by 2000 it would eliminate 8,200 jobs, mostly in Long Beach, Calif. The reductions are in addition to 12,000 job cuts announced in December. . . . Fidelity Investments plans to close three of its largest and best-performing mutual funds -- the Growth and Income, Contrafund and Low-Priced Stock funds -- to new retail investors after April 3, but it will offer several new funds.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 4; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

HEADLINE: DIARY: THE ECONOMY;
'Eerily,' Fed Sees Prosperity

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN 

GRAPHIC: Photo: The economy in all regions of the United States remains strong, the Federal Reserve said in its "beige book" survey of regional economic conditions, yet inflation seems "eerily calm." Indeed, the Consumer Price Index for February rose only 0.1 percent, held down by falling oil prices. That left the inflation rate for the last year at just 1.4 percent. HEADLINE: Too Many Arms to Twist

BYLINE: By Jack F. Matlock Jr.; Jack F. Matlock Jr., a professor at the Institute for Advanced Study, was Ambassador to the Soviet Union from 1987 to 1991.

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J.

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration's frenetic diplomatic activity in recent weeks in and around Serbia's Kosovo region provides a fresh example of floundering in today's international environment. Senior Administration officials have made public threats that, if carried out, could embroil the United States in an ethnic war with slight if any relevance to American security.
In response to outrageous Serbian police attacks on ethnic Albanians in Kosovo, Secretary of State Madeleine Albright announced on March 7 that the United States held Slobodan Milosevic, the Serbian leader, "personally responsible" for developments in Kosovo and reiterated that the United States "will not tolerate violence." Earlier, Robert Gelbard, the United States envoy, was even more pointed when he threatened "the most dire consequences imaginable" to the Yugoslav Government. 
 By making implied threats to use military force -- an idea that has no support among our NATO allies -- and by blaming Mr. Milosevic for all the violence, the Administration is setting itself up for a Hobson's choice: if our threats do not deter him, we will either have to take action that can only worsen the situation or be seen as engaging in a bluff. Worse, our posturing can encourage those Albanians who use force and violence to assert their irredentist claims not only in rump Yugoslavia but also in Macedonia.
Certainly it is in the American interest to deter another Balkan war, as it is to discourage brutal Serbian treatment of ethnic Albanian citizens. But the problem cannot be solved by bluster or military action, much less unilateral American strikes. A solution will require Mr. Milosevic to agree to restore the autonomy to Kosovo that he took away in 1989 and to protect the rights of ethnic Albanians and Serbs alike.
By blaming Mr. Milosevic alone for the recent crackdown, and not giving adequate public attention to the violent actions by armed Albanian separatists that provoked it, we hardly encourage compromise. By not insisting publicly that the Kosovo Albanian leaders drop their demand for full independence and negotiate in good faith for autonomy within Yugoslavia, we seem to be insisting on something no Government in Belgrade can accept, with or without Mr. Milosevic.
Our NATO allies and, importantly, Russia have taken a more balanced approach, exerting pressure on each side to conduct negotiations on self-rule. But if armed Kosovo Albanians continue to attack Serbs in the region, it is difficult to see how talks could lead to a settlement or how the Yugoslav Government could resist public pressure to retaliate.
If the American threat were an isolated tactical error, it could be excused as an uncharacteristic blunder easily fixed. Unfortunately, it fits a pattern of strategic misjudgment that has marked the Administration's foreign policy of late. The Administration has maneuvered itself very close to a lose-lose choice in dealing with Saddam Hussein, and has weakened American leverage and ties with allies by attempting a "dual containment" of Iraq and Iran.
The Administration has also reduced our ability to keep weapons of mass destruction away from terrorists and rogue regimes. By pursuing a mindless expansion of NATO, the United States has given Russia more cause to hold on to its nuclear arsenal and resist an American role in preventing leaks of nuclear technology.
The collapse of the Soviet Union transformed the international environment. The United States no longer has a global rival that can threaten it by exploiting local conflicts. We, therefore, can safely insist that other countries accept the prime responsibility for keeping peace in their neighborhoods. The United States must be able to counter threats to regional balances of power when they occur. But over the long run, we can maintain our strength and influence only if we can do so with the support and participation of our friends.
Europeans should be required to bear the prime responsibility for insuring peace in the Balkans. Islamic states, which along with Israel have the most to lose from Iraq's weapons of mass destruction, must be responsible for supporting effective means to contain Saddam Hussein. Israelis and Palestinians must understand that they bear the responsibility for settling their problems and that others will not intervene to save them from themselves. Tough love works.
Our assistance will often be essential. But we need to resist the temptation to jump into every unstable situation. As the Persian Gulf war showed, our military power is most effective when used in coalition with others. It also showed that even a spectacularly successful military victory cannot assure future peace. It takes an orderly regional neighborhood to do that, not an overeager sheriff rushing in from another continent.
The United States is now strong enough, both economically and militarily, to commit blunders without sensing the immediate effects. The public seems oblivious to the dangers that lie ahead if the United States continues, without strategic design, to inject itself into one crisis after another, treating much of the world as its protectorate.
Uncle Sam still needs a big stick in this dangerous world. But the American people and our friends abroad will eventually whittle it to a toothpick unless he remembers Theodore Roosevelt's advice to speak softly and use it sparingly.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
