HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Chicago's Jordan-Jackson-Pippen Triangle

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE 

 BODY:
He is becoming more vocal all the time, detailing his team's plight to anyone who will listen. Either Michael Jordan feels eternally wronged by the management of the Chicago Bulls, or he is up to something more productive, something that might lay the groundwork for his guaranteed return next season.
Something like keeping Scottie Pippen as his teammate. 
 Jordan has often said that his future in Chicago is tethered to whether Phil Jackson remains as coach. But as he keeps criticizing the desire of the owner, Jerry Reinsdorf, and the general manager, Jerry Krause, to break up the aging dynasty after this season, it is clear that he is doing more than just complaining.
Speaking on the condition of anonymity, at least three of Jordan's teammates said that he was sounding off because he wanted management to take a serious look at retaining Pippen, and that he would in fact play without Jackson as his coach.
The thinking is that the Bulls would not have a shot at winning another title without Pippen, who becomes a free agent at the end of the season. Given that Jackson is committed to taking a year off or signing a long-term deal with another team, Jordan's ill feelings toward Krause and Reinsdorf are directly related to how they have treated Pippen.
"There should never be this type of turmoil on a championship team when an organization is about to win their sixth championship," Jordan said last week. "I felt we were treated better when we hadn't won than when we won five. This organization bent over backward for us, had a better appreciation for us when we were on the verge of winning. Now we're on the verge of winning six and it's a different approach. It's a waste."
He was recently asked by a reporter from The Dallas Morning News whether he would return next season. "As for that," he replied, "you damage so much of the relationship, what's the purpose?"
It sounds as if Jordan is finished with the game again. But what if he is merely trying to siphon one more season of salary from Reinsdorf for Pippen and himself?
 
Time to Strike a Labor Deal
 With the worst-kept secret in the league about to be made public tomorrow at the Board of Governors meeting in Dallas -- the owners will vote to exercise their right to re-open the collective bargaining agreement on April 1 -- one pertinent issue remains: can the two sides work out a deal before November and prevent the league from losing any games to its first work stoppage?
"Lockout isn't part of our vocabulary right now," said Russ Granik, the league's deputy commissioner. "We've got three months to focus on putting some kind of deal together. You never know, but we have a very cordial and professional relationship with union leadership, and we'll do our best to try and maintain that."
Said Billy Hunter, the players association's executive director: "If you factor in a potential lockout, we've still got between now and October and November to work out a deal. I intend to objectively consider what's on the table."
The current agreement will not officially expire until July 1.
If a lockout is imposed, teams cannot sign free agents and the summer shopping spree is considerably shortened, at the least.
To make the deal work, the league is said to be interested in employing any strategy necessary -- a hard salary cap like the National Football League, perhaps, or limiting the amount a team can pay a single player -- that will put a ceiling on overall players salaries, so that they cannot increase at a greater percentage than league revenues.
Granik claims that 13 of the 29 teams failed to show profit last season and that 57 percent of basketball-related income is currently going to the players.
The threshold for opening the agreement was any number over 51.8 percent. With television revenues taking up a big chunk, the difference between 57 and 51.8 percent is roughly $85 million.
While the union disputes some of those figures and will point out that a 70 percent jump in television revenues next season should not equate to anyone crying poor, more than 20 of 29 teams are interested in fixing the current system.
The give-and-take process over the next few months should be intriguing, given that the league has not battled a unified players association for some time. And who knows what will become of the rookie salary scale, which has been blamed for the current haves and have-nots economic climate.
But expect both sides to compromise before the summer ends. It is not easy when a bunch of grown men who make their living off a game have to find a way to divide up millions of dollars. But Commissioner David Stern, Granik and Hunter are smart people, smarter than most baseball people who foolishly tested the patience of their consumers in 1994.
 
Duncan a Slam Dunk for Prize
 As his double-doubles keep piling up and he runs away with the rookie of the year award, Tim Duncan soon will have another honor bestowed upon him. Duncan, the No. 1 pick of the San Antonio Spurs last June, is almost a shoo-in to be named to the team for the world championships this summer, two officials with USA Basketball confirmed.
The team, which is viewed as a precursor to the team the United States will send to Sydney, Australia, for the 2000 Olympics, will compete in Athens from July 29 to Aug. 9.
If Duncan is named to the team -- two spots still remain -- he will join Grant Hill, Terrell Brandon, Gary Payton, Vin Baker, Christian Laettner, Glen Rice, Allan Houston, Chris Webber, Tom Gugliotta and Kevin Garnett.
Shaquille O'Neal was originally named to the team, but declined. He was replaced by Gugliotta, meaning the need for a center was not met. Besides Duncan, there is still one more roster spot that could filled by any of a plethora of capable swingmen.
Antoine Walker might be the most logical choice, but there are marketing needs to weigh.
Does the N.B.A. give Kobe Bryant time to develop, or do they just need to sell more jerseys?
 
Washington on Carlesimo
 One of P. J. Carlesimo's former players not affiliated with the N.B.A. has finally spoken out about the demanding style of the Warriors coach.
 
Well, sort of.
 Denzel Washington, while a sophomore at Fordham in the 1970's, played for the junior varsity under Carlesimo. He remembers long practices, lots of screaming and, too, a lot of unforgettable basketball lessons.
"He would run us all day and make us work and work," the actor said. "We always thought it was crazy.
"But you know what? We were always prepared for the fourth quarter, and we hardly ever lost. Some of the things I learned from him, I still apply myself. I coached my son's team, and that was one of the philosophies I got across to them, to always be ready for the end of the game."
Washington, who plays the father of Ray Allen's character in Spike Lee's new film, "He Got Game," which comes out on May 1, was not on scholarship at the time.
"I was kind of a taxi-squad guy," he said. "I just walked on because I played with a lot of those guys in intramurals. I didn't get to play that much, but it was a great experience playing for him. Now in retrospect, I had no idea where he was headed."

HEADLINE: 3 Men Accused of Killing Brooklyn Father

BYLINE: By KIT R. ROANE 

 BODY:
An unemployed Brooklyn man found dead in his ransacked apartment on Wednesday afternoon had been tied up, beaten, asphyxiated and then urinated on by a former roommate and two accomplices who wanted to steal his stereo, the police said yesterday.
Tips from neighbors and anonymous callers led to the arrests Friday of the three suspects -- the former roommate, Omy Irizarry, 24; Daniel Bonefonte, 19, and John DeMatteo, 30 -- said Sgt. Brian Lavin, supervisor of the 60th Precinct's detectives bureau. 
 The men went to the apartment of the victim, Joseph Guidone, 39, in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn shortly before 3 P.M. on Wednesday, Sergeant Lavin said, then hid in the second-floor hallway, waiting for Mr. Guidone's 16-year-old son to return home.
When the son was spotted, the three men donned black masks, grabbing the youth from behind and forcing him to open the door to his father's apartment, the sergeant said. Once inside, he said, they tied the teen-ager with rope to the foot of his father's bed.
The attackers then waited in the apartment, Sergeant Lavin said, knowing that Mr. Guidone would be home soon to care for his son, who neighbors said is mentally handicapped. When Mr. Guidone arrived a few minutes later, the three men overpowered him, dragging him into the bathroom before tying his hands and legs and sealing his mouth and eyes with tape, the sergeant said.
The pillage began in earnest, with furniture upturned and possessions thrown to the ground, the police said. But in the end, the three men escaped with only a few old television sets and a stereo system. They were displeased, and before they left, the men went back to visit Mr. Guidone on the tile of his bathroom, Sergeant Lavin said.
"They started taunting him, hitting and kicking him around," Sergeant Lavin said. "Then they covered his head with what appears to be a plastic bag and suffocated him. We don't know why, but they were laughing. Two of them urinated on the body."
Police officers found his body around 4 P.M., after Mr. Guidone's son managed to break free of his bindings and ran to a neighbor's house to call 911. The son, who is under a doctor's care and taking medication, was placed with relatives, Sergeant Lavin said.
Leads came quickly, he said, adding that residents recalled seeing Mr. Irizarry and two strangers loafing around the building around the time of the killing. The police also received several anonymous calls with information about where to find the former roommate, and around noon on Friday, Mr. Irizarry and Mr. Bonefonte were spotted talking on the telephone at a nearby pool hall, Prime Time Billiards. They gave up to officers without a struggle, the police said.
Mr. DeMatteo was arrested 11 hours later as he stood on the corner of 46th Street and Sixth Avenue in Brooklyn, a few blocks from his mother's home, the police said. When detectives went to the house, according to the police, they found Mr. Guidone's stereo sitting on the floor in a bedroom there.
All three suspects have been charged with murder, burglary and robbery, the police said. If convicted of the most serious offense, they would each face 25 years to life in prison. Each suspect has prior convictions, Sergeant Lavin added. He said Mr. Irizarry is on parole for a burglary conviction and Mr. Bonefonte is on parole for robbery.
Mr. Guidone had few possessions other than a couch and his stereo, residents at the Marlboro Housing Development said yesterday as they recalled a quiet man who spent his days caring for his son and always smiled at neighbors in the hallway.
"When the ambulances came, I just thought that somebody was sick because there are a lot of elderly people here," said Mary Ruiz, 75. "But it was Joseph, and God, I was shocked when I heard people talking about it."
"They took the best things he had and now what about his son?" she added. "I feel sorry, real sorry, for that boy."

HEADLINE: AIDING CONSUMERS IS NOW THE THRUST OF ANTITRUST PUSH

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY with LAURA M. HOLSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 20

 BODY:
When the Government challenged the proposed mergers of the nation's four largest drug wholesalers earlier this month, the pronouncements from the Federal Trade Commission did not follow the script that trustbusters used for much of the last century, decrying the power of big, monopolistic businesses.
No, the Government's chief complaint was that the mergers might raise the prices consumers pay for drugs by even as much as 1 percent. 
 The United States is in the midst of a merger boom, the greatest in a generation. Nearly as many mergers were announced in the last three months of 1997 as in all of 1991. As many of these deals join together giants in the same markets, the Clinton Administration has been re-engaging the machinery of antitrust enforcement after it fell into disrepair in the 1980's.
The Justice Department, for example, is threatening to go to court on Monday to block the merger of two military contractors, Lockheed Martin and Northrop Grumman.
But the motivation -- or at least the explanation -- for the Government's actions has changed. Ever since the Sherman Antitrust Act was enacted in 1890, the Government has mostly acted to protect the ideal of competition within industries and prevent price gouging.
In practice, though, that doctrine usually revolved around a simple "bigness led to power and unfair behavior," said Eleanor Fox, a professor of law at New York University and an antitrust expert. In the last few years, the Government has offered a more politically attuned explanation for bringing its antitrust club out of the closet. Now officials concentrate on protecting consumers and select cases largely on their ability to trumpet that argument.
"These cartels are taking billions of dollars out of the pockets of American consumers," Joel I. Klein, head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, said in an interview. "So the antitrust focus is intensifying."
The new approach arose after the Reagan years, in which bigness in business was rarely considered to be particularly bad. By giving antitrust a focus on consumer impact, the Government has not only offered a more appealing reason to revive antitrust enforcement when old-fashioned populism no longer stirs many voters, it has also given itself a tool for distinguishing between those mergers -- even some of the biggest -- that can be viewed as benign and those that pose a real threat. And even when Washington takes on a high-profile case that resembles the old trustbusting, like the attempt to restrain Microsoft, the Government now puts the benefit to consumers at the forefront.
William J. Baer, director of the Bureau of Compliance at the Federal Trade Commission, which shares responsibility with the Justice Department for overseeing mergers, explained the difference. "It used to be that the presumption of control of the market was enough," he said. "But now we are trying to tell the story of how the consumer will be worse off."
That was the case when the F.T.C. ruled against the drug mergers. At that time, Mr. Baer said, "If the merged companies were to have raised their drug prices so that consumers would have felt even a 1 percent increase, that would have been a problem."
A year ago, when the commission ruled against the merger of Staples Inc. and Office Depot Inc., the nation's two largest office supply discounters, the chief complaint was that eliminating competition between the two chains, even if there were plenty of other companies selling office supplies, would inevitably lead to higher prices for consumers.
As part of its new focus, the Government has also begun taking on cases that it used to ignore. In the 1980's, the Government showed no interest in nonmerger situations, such as the case against the Microsoft Corporation, where companies were accused of using their market domination to stifle innovation.
Standing on the courthouse steps in January, after a Federal judge accepted Microsoft's offer to sell Windows 95 with the company's Internet browser hidden or partly removed, Mr. Klein said, "This will increase consumer choice and send precisely the right message to the market."
Businesses recognize this change. Charles Koob, an antitrust lawyer at Simpson Thacher & Bartlett in New York, says he advises clients who want to know whether a merger is likely to win approval to ask themselves what customers will say. "The one thing the Government is concerned about is when customers are unhappy," he said. "They have a strong base of customers who have complained and complained loudly."
Robert Pitofsky, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, said the change was a reaction to conservative critics in the 1980's, who complained that antitrust activism often propped up weak, inefficient businesses.
"They were right," Mr. Pitofsky said. "Now we care about competitors not because they are more worthy people but because without them, consumers will be hurt. And I think the system is better now."
Some experts believe the new approach is merely rhetorical at times. "Everyone knows how to put the arguments in terms of consumer protection now," Professor Fox said. "But sometimes it can be an empty buzzword."
Nonetheless, the nature of today's mergers often raises the threat of harm to consumers in different ways than mergers of the recent past.
In the latter half of the 1980's, there was another large merger wave -- 2,883 mergers announced in 1989, for example, compared with 3,702 last year. But many of the combinations back then brought together unrelated industries, raising fewer antitrust concerns. Today, many corporations are merging with competitors, giving the combined companies the power to dominate their industries and, in theory, control the prices and availability of products.
That is one reason, among others, why the Justice Department has stepped up its investigations, to a total of 276 last year, compared with just 83 in 1989 and 74 in 1988, at the peak of the last wave of mergers. Another is that the current Administration rejects the common argument of that era that the free market could largely police itself.
Yet even as the Government trains its antitrust guns on some highly visible deals, such as the drug wholesalers' mergers and the proposed merger between Lockheed Martin and Northrop Grumman, its enforcement chiefs insist that they are not mounting a new offensive against mega-mergers. The investigation into the military contractors' merger, they say, revolves around the same question: Would it foster too limited a choice and higher prices for buyers -- or in this case, a single buyer, the Pentagon?
Indeed, the current approach still allows the vast majority of mergers to pass muster. The commission's figures show that the Government investigates about 15 percent of mergers and challenges less than 5 percent of them.
Corporations, meanwhile, generally do not seem to be shying away from mergers because of regulators.
"We haven't seen clients who say, 'We don't want to merge because Justice will block it,' " said an investment banker who asked not to be identified because he is handling several merger deals being reviewed by regulators.
The Clinton Administration is also moving to revive interest in nonmerger cases against companies where market power alone, antitrust officials contend, may pose a threat to consumers. The Justice Department's decades-long investigation of I.B.M. fell apart in the early 1980's at the same time that its case against AT&T was settled with the breakup of the telephone monopoly.
Now, in addition to the Microsoft case, the Justice Department is investigating accusations that Anheuser-Busch, the nation's largest brewer, is using its dominance to persuade distributors not to carry several competing micro-brewery brands.
The department is also looking into charges by smaller competitors of what they call predatory practices by some of the major airlines, which can leave travelers to and from cities dominated by a single carrier with overpriced air service.
And a senior Federal official said the Government was studying Intel's practices to see whether it, as the nation's dominant manufacturer of microchips, is unfairly squeezing competitors out of the market. No decision has been made on whether to open a formal investigation.
"There's definitely a large increase in these civil, nonmerger cases," said Robert Litan, director of Economic Studies at the Brookings Institution and a former antitrust official in the Clinton Administration. The overall increase in enforcement comes at a time, Mr. Litan said, when the need for it might have been expected to decline. Open markets and the integration into a world economy were always thought to increase competition and reduce the need for antitrust action, he said.
Earlier this month, the Aluminum Company of America, the world's largest aluminum maker, announced that it would pay $2.8 billion in stock and cash for Alumax, the third-largest aluminum maker in the United States. At the time, Alcoa's chairman and chief executive, Paul O'Neill, said he was confident that the Justice Department would find little in the merger to haggle over. The aluminum market is global and the combined United States companies would be more competitive against foreign competitors. To Mr. O'Neill, the "idea that some of this has anything to do with concentration in the U.S. is ludicrous."
Mr. Klein, while not commenting specifically on the aluminum case, thundered in reaction to that general thesis, "I thoroughly reject the analysis that globalization reduces the need for enforcement."
In general, Mr. Klein added: "We are pro-competition. And that is pro-consumer."

Clinton Is to Observe Vast Changes in Africa
When President Clinton begins a 12-day trip to sub-Saharan Africa today, he will be visiting a region very different from the one last traveled by an American President, 20 years ago. Apartheid is gone in South Africa, economic reform has swept the continent, and more countries are electing their governments. 1
 
The President's trip is a tribute to the growing influence on foreign policy of 34 million African-Americans. 6

NATIONAL 16-34
 
Skirmishes In Jones Suit Raise Harassment Issues
Over the last two months, the sexual accusations involving President Clinton have unleashed a torrent of debate about sexual harassment, and where to draw the legal line between uncouth behavior and that which is grounds for a lawsuit. Sexual harassment, a rapidly evolving legal field, was never defined by statute, but developed as an offshoot of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. 1
 
After four years of exchanging news-conference salvos and blizzards of briefs, Paula Jones's case against President Clinton is set to got to trial on May 27, with the verdict in the President's own camp far from settled on whether his lawyer, Robert S. Bennett's fisticuffs approach is what is best for victory. 28
 
Gambling Industry's Gains
Confronted by a rising concern about the growth of casinos and by the threat that a national commission on gambling could recommend new regulations and taxes, casino operators and other gambling interests have more than quadrupled their contributions to Federal candidates and political parties since 1991. 1

HEADLINE: Former Boyfriend Arrested in Killing Of a Law Student Near Columbia

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER 

 BODY:
The police said last night they had arrested a 23-year-old former boyfriend in connection with the death of a Columbia University law student who was found with her throat slashed in her university apartment on Friday.
Investigators disclosed no motive in the killing of Hyeseung Lynda Hong, 26, a third-year student and native of South Korea who had accepted an offer of a full-time job at a prestigious Manhattan law firm, to begin after her graduation. 
 But Assistant Chief Kevin Farrell, commander of the Manhattan detectives, said they believed the suspect, Edmund Ko, of Cliffside Park, N.J., had killed Ms. Hong about 11 P.M. Wednesday, two days before her body was found. Chief Farrell said Mr. Ko, who is to be charged with murder, had been arrested last November as a co-conspirator in the slashing of another of his former girlfriends.
Mr. Ko, who is also from Korea and is unemployed, had not confessed to killing Ms. Hong as of last night, Chief Farrell said, but witnesses had told the police that they had seen him at her apartment on Wednesday night.
The body of Ms. Hong was discovered by a male friend -- identified by some of Ms. Hong's friends as a current boyfriend -- on Friday night in her apartment on West 113th Street. The crime horrified students and faculty there, who mourned the violent end of a life on the threshold of a bright future.
"All of us kind of think in the future -- 5, 10 years from now," said Karl Barrios, 25, a classmate. "To have someone die like that seems very sudden, very painful. Everybody here is still in a state of shock."
Mr. Barrios said he remembered Ms. Hong bringing a date named Edmund to a gathering of law school students about two years ago. He described him as an "affluent guy," who dressed well. He was "a pretty unremarkable person, nothing out of the ordinary, not weird or anything," Mr. Barrios said.
Chief Farrell said that Mr. Ko and Ms. Hong had apparently ended their relationship about six months ago. In Mr. Ko's earlier arrest, the Chief said, he had been accused, along with two women, of slashing the face of a former girlfriend in New Jersey. One of the other women actually did the slashing, Chief Farrell said.
The police had said there was no evidence of forced entry into Ms. Hong's ground-floor apartment, owned by the university, in Morningside Heights. They also said there was apparently no theft involved. Detective Mark Patterson, a police spokesman, said there did not appear to be any evidence of sexual assault, although investigators were awaiting results of an autopsy.
Law enforcement officials said yesterday that Ms. Hong's family was in Korea and had not yet been notified of her death. The family now lives in Virginia.
Her friends yesterday remembered Ms. Hong as exceptionally talented, even in a class of high-achieving students. After a summer internship at the law firm Cravath Swain & Moore last year, she had been working there part-time this semester and was expected to join the firm as a full-time associate in the fall, said Harry Silver, the firm's executive director.
"She was very friendly, always smiling, always optimistic," said Alla Lee, 34, a third-year classmate of Ms. Hong's. She was "kind of laid back in a way, not a worry type at all. Also a very attractive woman."
Details of Ms. Hong's life were sketchy yesterday, but friends said she moved with her family back and forth from Korea and graduated in 1990 from Millburn High School in Short Hills, N.J. Neighbors said her father is an importer. The family, which also includes her mother and a younger sister, apparently spent some time in California.
In high school, neighbors said, Ms. Hong worked for the student newspaper, sang in the girls' chorus and took several advanced-placement courses. She already talked then about becoming a lawyer, they said, but she also considered medicine.
A high school classmate described her as "a nice person, intelligent, always full of life."
"To me this is shocking because it's someone who lived across the street from me, that I saw day in and day out for three years," said the former classmate, who insisted on anonymity. "It really hits home."
Ms. Hong, a psychology major, graduated from Cornell University. Friends said she planned to become a corporate lawyer.
At Columbia, she was active in Asian-American issues, and a leader of the Asian-American and Pacific Law Students Association, which met and held seminars to explore the role Asians and Asian Americans in law and society. Last year she helped put together a seminar on the extent to which Asians were reflected in United States case law, and she attended meetings about the role of minority women in society.
"I think she was one of those people who felt like we were going to be ground breakers," said her friend and classmate Anny Huang, 24. "Women have worked and struggled for many generations to do whatever their talents and character and intelligence would let them, and she intended to do it."
Ms. Huang said that even though Ms. Hong was clearly driven, she did not seem to show it.
"That is one of the things that people really admired about her," she said. "She didn't seem to take everything so seriously. She was able to do really well but there was no arrogance about her. She had confidence. And of course she knew she was very, very pretty."
Tom Yun, 55, the owner of the Mill Korean Restaurant down the street from Ms. Hong's apartment, said she was a regular customer, who mostly came alone to eat. He said he has seen her less in recent months, apparently as she has been making her move from student to young lawyer.
About two weeks ago, Mr. Yun said, "She was carrying a briefcase, all dressed up. I said, 'Where are you going?' She said, 'I'm going downtown. I have work to do.'
"Usually she wasn't dressed up," he said. "That's why I remember that."
The police said that Ms. Hong, who lived alone in an apartment in a neat four-story building at 548 West 113th Street, was last seen on Wednesday. The police said that her male friend said he had become worried and went to her apartment because he could not get in touch with her. He called the police, saying he found her unconscious in an apartment covered with blood. Chief Farrell said the apartment was so bloody that it appeared that there had been a struggle or that Ms. Hong had wandered around the apartment after being slashed.
The police say that Ms. Hong was dead when the officers arrived. No weapon has been recovered.
The slaying set off a wave of fear on the campus and along the quiet block, between Broadway and Amsterdam, which is home mostly to Columbia students and professors. The last slaying on Columbia's campus was in 1988, when a security guard was shot and killed.
"This is the first real serious gruesome incident I have been anywhere close to," said Margaret Connelly, 21, a senior studying political science. "It's a reality check."
Albert Sheu, 25, a friend of Ms. Hong's said: "It's incredibly tragic. This doesn't happen to law students here. It doesn't happen."
Columbia University said it was in the process of setting up special counseling services for both students and Ms. Hong's relatives.

HEADLINE: Big Macs to Go

BYLINE: By Nicholas D. Kristof; Nicholas D. Kristof is the Tokyo bureau chief of The Times.

 BODY:

Golden Arches East
 McDonald's in East Asia.
 Edited by James L. Watson.
 256 pp. Stanford, Calif.:
 Stanford University Press. Cloth, $45. Paper, $16.95. 
 I once asked my 5-year-old son, who has grown up largely in Tokyo, about his favorite Japanese foods. Gregory thought for a moment and decided on rice balls and McDonald's.
It makes perfect sense to think of Big Macs as Japanese food, since McDonald's is a much more important part of his life in Japan than it is when we are on vacation in America. In particular, given the cramped homes in which most Japanese live, when his Japanese friends have birthdays the most common place to hold parties is McDonald's.
"Golden Arches East" is a fascinating study that explores issues of globalization by focusing on the role of McDonald's in five Asian economies, and it comes to conclusions that Gregory would approve of: that in many countries McDonald's has been absorbed by local communities and become assimilated, so that it is no longer thought of as a foreign restaurant and in some ways no longer functions as one.
At a time when academics regularly write impenetrably about abstruse irrelevancies, this book is engaging and arises from straightforward questions: how do countries react to McDonald's, and what does the interaction say about those nations? This book, edited by James L. Watson, a distinguished China scholar and professor of anthropology at Harvard University, was a terrific idea, and the authors pull it off very well. Separate scholars look at McDonald's in Hong Kong, China, Taiwan, South Korea and Japan.
The inquiry is not trivial. McDonald's has had an enormous impact in Asia, affecting manners and mores and the way people live. Ten percent of the beef sold in Japan is in McDonald's hamburgers, and the daily lives of most Japanese people have been shaped more by McDonald's than the State Department.
The most fascinating aspect of this study is its exploration of how McDonald's changed Asia. While America may envision itself as a global beacon for democracy and free markets, this book suggests that the most powerful American influences in East Asia are more mundane.
Take toilets. Bathrooms in Hong Kong restaurants used to range from the merely dirty to the wrenchingly disgusting. And then McDonald's rode into town, in 1975, with bathrooms that offered a novelty -- cleanliness. Perhaps the impact is exaggerated, but this book credits McDonald's for helping to raise standards of cleanliness in public rest rooms in Hong Kong.
Likewise, the concept of waiting in line was an alien one in Hong Kong in the old days, and the battle to get on a bus or to get to a cash register was usually like a rugby scrum. Then McDonald's, aghast at the chaos, rigorously imposed lines at its restaurants. The result, many Hong Kong natives think, was that McDonald's helped spread the concept of waiting in line throughout the territory.
Japan's mores have been changing for decades, as an extremely formal country has become steadily more casual, and McDonald's may be a catalyst in that process. Japan has an ancient taboo against tachigui, or standing while eating, but this is breaking down, and this book suggests that part of the reason is the spread of McDonald's -- whose first outlet in Japan did not have any seats at all.
In China, restaurants traditionally have been maelstroms of loud conversations and bones strewn on the floor. But according to this book, customers at McDonald's outlets in China spoke in lower tones than in other restaurants and were careful not to spit or throw rubbish on the ground: "People in McDonald's were, on the whole, more self-restrained and polite toward one another. One possible explanation for this difference is that the symbolic meaning . . . of the new food, along with customers' willingness to accept the exotic culture associated with fast food, has affected people's table manners in particular and social behavior in general."
All this may amount to American cultural imperialism. But it is hard to imagine even the most passionate nationalist in Asia denouncing American exports like courtesy or clean toilets.

HEADLINE: Hoosier Hysteria

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re " 'Hoosiers' No More, but Heroes All the Same" (Sports pages, March 19): As someone who grew up during the heyday of the single-class basketball tournament, I think you did an excellent job of capturing the history and essence of Hoosier hysteria. 
 The decision to go to the four-class system was driven by economic benefits for the small schools. Polls showed that the general population favored staying with the single-class tournament; it was the schools' athletic directors who did the voting.
Consolidations created an even greater size gap between the original small schools that were left and the rest. (For example, in my county, which was once a sectional site of about 20 teams, there are now only four schools.) Yet I think that in the long run, most will like the four-class system just as much.
 
BOB RISSER
Hoffman Estates, Ill., March 19, 1998

HEADLINE: What the Elephant Forgot

BYLINE: By David Frum; David Frum is a contributing editor to The Weekly Standard.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A friend of mine recently ran for office on the ticket of a right-of-center political party. He'd call me late at night, after finishing a hard day of campaigning, and burst into a self-mocking parody of the speeches he had been embarrassing himself by making from dawn to dusk. "Let me say how sickened I am by the evils of child abuse! I yield to no one in my condemnation of the illegal trade in puppies! We must move ahead, while leaving nobody behind!"
My friend is a British Conservative, but he could just as well have been running for Congress as a Republican. The vapid, empty politics he was ridiculing has become almost the official credo of Congressional Republicans. The party's politics today careers wildly from feel-good mini-policies a la Dick Morris (the cigarette tax increase) to vast but empty gestures (the repeal of the Internal Revenue Code). 
 Four years ago, the Republicans won a major Congressional victory by promising large and important reforms in the operation of the Federal Government. Four years later, they are hoping to hold onto their majority by refraining from doing anything at all.
Psychologists have observed that if you apply electric shocks to a dog at random intervals, it falls into a condition called learned helplessness. It decides it's going to be punished whatever it does and ends up lying on the floor and whimpering.
Something like that seems to have happened to the Republicans. They appear disoriented. They trample on their professed principles, discarding (for example) their alleged commitment to federalism by knuckling under to the President's poll-driven scheme to force all states to adopt the same drunken-driving rules. They meekly accept the gutting of the work requirements in the 1996 welfare reform law and abjectly assent to huge Presidential spending proposals.
Worse, they are dreaming up equally bloated spending programs of their own, like the colossal highway bill, which would leave scarcely a blade of grass in the lower 48 states unpaved. (Where are the environmentalists when we need them?)
By heroic effort, the Republicans narrowly avoided losing the House in 1996. Having won, they no longer seem to have any idea what to do with their victory.
This is sad, because very soon they are likely to have an opportunity to do a lot. The Clinton Presidency is badly damaged -- much more badly damaged than polls alone reveal.
This is a President who did not address the nation from the Oval Office during the Iraq crisis, who doesn't dare take questions from the press and who lives in dread of the evidence gathered by the independent counsel's office. Just as a weakened Richard Nixon offered his Democratic opponents national health insurance in 1974 if only they would relent on Watergate, this President too may soon be asking his opponents, "What can I do for you?"
Sometime between now and then, the Republicans need to work out an answer.
The right answer, or answers, must be bold without appearing reckless. In 1995, the Republicans wounded themselves with a program that sounded radical (to the alarm of some voters) without producing much in the way of political change. The task for 1998 is the opposite: to assemble a program that advances Republican principles while reassuring voters of the party's moderation and good sense. There are dozens of possible elements of such a program. But here is one that might form the basis for all the others.
In his 1996 campaign, President Clinton claimed that the Government was the smallest it had been in 30 years. But the Federal tax burden as a share of gross domestic product will in the coming fiscal year exceed 20 percent for the first time since 1945. The figure was less than 18 percent when Mr. Clinton took office. The Tax Foundation, a Washington research organization, points out that tax burdens on middle-class families have returned to within whispering distance of their 1981 peaks.
Mr. Clinton defeated Bob Dole by convincing Americans that any tax cut would require unacceptably large spending cuts in Medicare and Medicaid and in education and environmental programs. But now, with the budget balanced, Republicans might be able to put their case in a new way.
In the 1999 fiscal year, the Federal Government expects to spend $6,443 for each of the 269 million people living in the United States. In 1996, President Clinton convinced Americans that the Federal Government should spend no less. Why, then, can't Republicans try to convince Americans that the Federal Government should spend no more? What if the Republicans made no net increase in per-person Federal spending their central negotiating demand? You could even fit it on a bumper sticker "$6,443 -- and not a penny more."
With the budget balanced and the economy growing, a per-person spending limit would quickly reverse the relentless growth in Government. Should the economy continue to chug along at the 4 1/2 percent predicted by the President's budget, a per-person spending limit would shrink the Government's overall tax claim to some 16 1/2 percent over the next five fiscal years. That would make about $330 billion available to return to the people in the form of grand tax cuts, and all without nicking a single dollar from any existing Federal program.
 Spin-meisters like Frank Luntz argue that Republicans should avoid harsh words like "cut" and "control" when referring to Government programs and instead say "preserve" or "protect." Somewhere along the way, however, what began as advice about communications metamorphosed into injunctions on policy. Not only did Republicans avoid talking about spending control; they ceased practicing it. Unfortunately, despite the spin-meisters -- despite Mr. Clinton's famous concession that "the era of big government is over" -- the battle over the size and scope of the Government remains the central divide of modern politics.
Republican leaders in Congress show little patience with external critics who do not have to face voters, who are not under attack by the President as "extremists" and who urge the Republicans to gird for another round of seemingly hopeless combat. But today's accommodationist strategy also exacts its price, and the feebleness and drift that we see in today's Republican Party are only the first installment.
There is a middle way between suicide and surrender, and the balanced budget gives Republicans a chance to explore it. They should put the spin-meisters back in their place: figuring out new and attractive ways to explain conservative principles, rather than figuring out new and attractive substitutes for those principles.
The Republican task now is to stand for something bigger and better than highway spending. Republicans must prove to the voters that as fervently as they oppose the illegal trade in puppies (and of course they yield to no one in their opposition to that!), they actually have some idea of what they intend to do with the trust the people have reposed in them.

HEADLINE: Wall St. Journal Joins Life-Style Bandwagon With New Section

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

 BODY:
Since 1889, The Wall Street Journal has helped its readers make money. On Friday, it brought out a new section to tell them how to spend it.
Like a Hawaiian shirt on a stockbroker, Weekend Journal is the monochromatic business daily's full-color embrace of the kind of life style journalism and its rich advertising base that other American dailies, including The New York Times, began adding two decades ago. 
 Weekend Journal has a wine column, an antiques column and an expensive-house-of-the-week feature that joins the book, movie reviews, sports and travel articles that already appear in the five-day-a-week paper.
There is even The Journal's first crossword puzzle, whose clues will hardly strain a languid weekend in the country. Example: four-letter word in phrase ending "sapiens."
The new section adds about six pages of news space to the paper, said Richard J. Tofel, a spokesman for Dow Jones & Company, which owns The Journal. The section will be devoted largely to the kind of high-end consumer, retail, entertainment and life style advertising the paper has been losing out on with its all-business, no-play format. Significantly, three of the new advertising pages, including the premium back page, can be bought in color.
The Journal hopes that Weekend Journal will travel home on Fridays and that both men and women will pick it up and spend time with it over the weekend. The daily version is now read mostly by men, and mostly at work.
"The business strategy is about broadening the advertising base, but the reader side is not about broadening but deepening, because the most precious thing to us is how much time people spend with the paper" Mr. Tofel said. "Journal readers already spend more than 40 minutes a day with the paper, and anything you can do to add to that number is absolutely key."
Coincidentally, USA Today also changed its weekend format on Friday. The paper's Life section has been split in two for Fridays, producing Life Weekend and Life Destinations & Diversions to expand the amount of room for editorial content and advertising by 14 pages, said Steve Anderson, a spokesman for the paper.
USA Today, which has a Friday circulation of two million, charges $75,600 for a full page in black and white and $114,500 for color. The Wall Street Journal, with a weekday circulation of 1.8 million but with a more affluent readership, charges $99,998 for a page in black and white for consumer, entertainment, leisure and travel advertising -- the kind sought by the new weekend section -- and $124,859 for color. The Journal charges higher rates for financial advertising.
The new Journal section is edited by Joanne Lipman. In her message to readers on Friday, she introduced the section as an "appeal to your passions, not just your obligations."
Ms. Lipman also wrote: "The Journal has always been essential reading when it comes to daily business. Now we hope we can become just as essential in helping you manage your personal business."
The first Weekend Journal devoted most of its front-page space to the Oscars and to examining what the prize would mean in salary to the main contenders. A movie review, which appears behind the editorial page in the first, or A section, on other days, occupies the left-hand column on the front page. The final front-page feature describes sport utility vehicles as politically incorrect but still desirable and lists the safest of the big trucks. The article hints at the section's target audience by illustrating the piece with a photo of the Mercedes ML320.
Other columns cover decorating, wine, antiques ("Economic turmoil abroad means bargains in Asian art at home"), travel and wine. Nat Hentoff reviews jazz, and the section is anchored on the next-to-last page by Taste, a page of columns on American culture edited by Robert L. Bartley, The Journal's editor.
Friday's main feature in Taste was a roundtable discussion whose participants, including Judith Martin, a.k.a. "Miss Manners"; Don McLean, composer-singer of "American Pie," and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, debated whether American culture is healthier or sicker than it was 30 years ago. Their answer: sicker.

HEADLINE: Taking In the Sites;
Finding Business Ethics on and About the Internet

BYLINE: By SREENATH SREENIVASAN 

 BODY:
The World Wide Web is not exactly a haven for good business ethics. It can be a lawless place filled with unscrupulous operators pushing get-rich-quick schemes and other scams.
Naturally, those who study business ethics worry about the Web. "Every possible abuse of integrity and decency takes place on the Web," said Laura Pincus Hartman, director of the Institute for Business and Professional Ethics at DePaul University in Chicago. 
 Randy Pennington, an ethics consultant based in Dallas, said there was "a sense that moral and ethical values are not important" on the Web. But that does not surprise him. "There is no standardization in technology on the Web, so why do we expect standardization in behavior?" he said.
Mr. Pennington said that to avoid an attempt at "regulation of ethical behavior in the future, the on-line community must regulate itself."
"This country has a history of regulating those industries that do not control themselves," he added. Despite the global nature of the Web, he sees the possibility of Government intervention.
The Netcheck Commerce Bureau is one attempt at self-regulation. The agency, which has 700 corporate members in about 80 countries, maintains a list of companies involved in electronic commerce. Visitors to Netcheck's site can register consumer complaints about anything from unsolicited E-mail to copyright disputes. There is even a place to compliment a company. The site's philosophy is that "public pressure is the only real deterrent in this new frontier."
The Web is also a great place to learn about and research the issues of business ethics, both within the Internet and beyond. An excellent starting place is the site of the institute at DePaul that Ms. Hartman heads. The site provides an introduction to business ethics but goes well beyond that. It is home to the Online Journal of Ethics and has comprehensive links to other sites that deal with the topic.
The business of domain names and how they are registered involves some of the worst breaches of ethics on the Internet. Corporations and nonprofit groups are being forced to spend a lot of time, money and energy to fight piracy of high-profile .com and .org addresses. Even in the world of business ethics, names can be less than clear. For example, Business-ethics.org is the home of the International Business Ethics Institute, and Businessethics.org belongs to the Council for Ethics in Economics. The institute, which has a truly global background, has a site that contains a sparse brochure. The council -- which is trying to "strengthen the ethical fabric of business and economic life" -- has a more substantial site with articles from the quarterly publication Ethics in Economics, and texts of speeches on ethics organized by the institute, based in Columbus, Ohio.
The Ethics Resource Center is a leading nonprofit ethics consultancy. The site offers information about the center's work with large corporations in developing ethics programs.
The Center for Business Ethics, at Bentley College in Waltham, Mass., is home to the Ethics Officer Association. This group represents the executives that help police many of the nation's large corporations.
Few industries have been mired in as many questions about ethics, both real and perceived, as the military industry. One attempt to address its problems is the Defense Industry Initiative on Business Ethics and Conduct, a group of large military contractors, which has an in-depth site about the organization and aspects of Government contracting. Much of the information is applicable to other industries.
Unlike many other sites, the Better Business Bureau site, which is run by the Council of Better Business Bureaus, is aimed at consumers in addition to the corporate world. It provides tips on various consumer frauds. It also has a guide to "establishing an ethical business" and a detailed code of advertising that explains common abuses and misleading claims.
Establishing an ethics code is an important step for any company or industry, and a growing number of sites carry such codes. The DePaul site has compiled a list of direct links to a variety of codes, including Johnson & Johnson, Northern Telecom and the National Association of the Remodeling Industry. Also included is the code of ethics of the International Ethical Business Registry, a Canadian organization that promotes ethics codes. Among the aims of the registry: donating at least 10 percent of its gross income "toward the betterment of mankind." Its site has pointers about setting up a first-time code and answers a common question: "Is a code of ethics like a mission statement?"
(Answer: "No. A mission statement states what you do. A code of ethics states how you do it.")
At first glance, a site that promises "business ethics from an Islamic perspective," as the Islamic Training Foundation does, seems to be far removed from most of what is available on the Web. But in a closer look at some of the material, readers learn that Allah describes successful people as those who are "inviting to all that is good, enjoining what is right and forbidding what is wrong." What non-Islamic business ethicist would not endorse such a view?

HEADLINE: Box Office: Top Gauge For Films

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD

 BODY:
The movie industry concerns itself with many things, from artistic expression and storytelling to deal-making. But the business is nearly unanimous on one basic measure of success that supersedes all else: ticket sales.
Artistic merit is important. Creativity counts. Novelty is appreciated. Oscars are coveted. But all of those things matter more if they help produce ticket sales. The best evidence of Hollywood's embrace of this standard is that when a movie studio boasts to the movie community, it takes out an ad in Daily Variety and plasters across one or two pages the name of the film, a photo of the actors and, in huge type, the box- office gross, usually followed by an exclamation point. 
 And this gold standard has caught on outside of Hollywood. Many newspapers, including The New York Times, run a table of the weekend box-office grosses early each week. Teen-agers today are as conversant with the weekend box-office figures for "Titanic" as children of another era were with Bob Gibson's strikeout totals or Maury Wills's stolen bases.
Given the reliance on these figures, it is perhaps surprising how old-fashioned the systems are for collecting them, particularly when compared with those used for other forms of entertainment.
In the television business, Nielsen's Media Research uses sophisticated devices attached to thousands of television sets nationwide to automatically provide data on viewing habits. Soundscan has developed a point-of-sale computer system that feeds detailed data on sales of recorded music to central computers, and the systems for registering the sale of magazines in supermarkets is almost completely automated.
But the method of collecting the box-office figures is more prosaic. Basically, it is a relay system of faxes and telephone calls, and then some improvising.
The basic figures are generally collected by the E.D.I. unit of A. C. Nielsen, a market research company. Daniel Marks, a senior vice president of the company, said that the heart of the system was a room with about 35 people on telephones. Those people race to begin their work at the end of every weekend.
Starting on Sunday, they communicate with hundreds of theaters with a total of about 25,000 screens. This covers 80 percent to 85 percent of the market, including most of the busiest screens, Mr. Marks said.
"It's not a simple task, but the numbers are pretty good," he said, adding that the method of collecting the numbers has not changed appreciably in decades.
Initially, A. C. Nielsen provides what are called flash figures, or quick tallies that do not include the entire weekend. The studios frequently subscribe to the company for these figures and then adjust them with their own surveys of theaters that had not been counted. Most of the studios then estimate the entire weekend's box-office grosses, and these are the figures many publications print on Monday morning.
Studio executives said that they must subsequently produce audited box-office figures and that experience had made these early estimates quite accurate. But there are exceptions. Late last year, Miramax had to acknowledge that it overstated the opening weekend gross for "Scream 2," announcing that $39.2 million in tickets had been sold. Miramax later announced that the figure was actually $33 million.
"There are mistakes, but it rarely happens, and there is a self-adjusting mechanism," Mr. Marks said. "This is maybe a little old-fashioned, but it really works."


GRAPHIC: The list often used in Hollywood to determine which movies have made the most money adds the amount a movie made in each year of release to a running total. By this method, "Titanic" has already taken in more at the box office than any other movie. But this method does not account for the effect of inflation. For example, the average price of a movie ticket in the United States in 1948 was 36 cents. Today, it is $4.59, nearly 13 times as much.
Chart: "Big at the Box Office"
 Among movies for which complete historical data are available, here are the films with the largest domestic box-office grosses, adjusted for inflation. The list excludes some high-grossing older films, like "Gone With the Wind" and "The Ten Commandments" because historical data were not available. Variety estimates, using a different method, that "Gone With the Wind" has earned more at the box office than any other movie, taking in more than $1 billion since it was first released in 1939.

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
Forget About the Next Star; Look for What's Different

BYLINE: By NEIL STRAUSS 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., March 22

 BODY:
The line to see the seminal New York rock band Sonic Youth spilled outside the club La Zona Rosa here on Thursday, winding along Fourth Street in a motley, traffic-blocking mess of teen-agers and music industry drones. Though the club was already full, the crowd was reluctant to leave. The occasion was the South by Southwest convention, which in 12 years has changed from a showcase for local acts to the reigning meet-and-greet of the rock business.
A subject of front-page, above-the-fold articles in local papers, South by Southwest attracted some 6,000 people for four days of deal making, drinking, panel watching, cell phone brandishing and concert hopping. (Nearly 12,000 music fans registered just for the concerts, not for the discussions and panels.) The event pumped some $8 million into the city's economy. Each night there were 220 or so shows, and Sonic Youth's was probably the most anticipated and crowded one of the week. 
 Though music conventions like this are celebrations of the new, opportunities to expose young bands to jaded, busy and self-important music industry players, Sonic Youth is -- despite its name -- an older institution. It is an emissary from a time in the early 80's when being a noisy guitar-rock band meant sacrificing commercial ambitions for a small but loyal niche audience. That was before alternative-rock was coined as a genre, before Nirvana and Pearl Jam broke the music through to a mass audience, before record labels began tempting these noisy bands with contracts worth millions of dollars. In the time from the start of the music's popular crest to its decline, from about 1990 to 1996, rock conventions like South by Southwest thrived. They were places to feel one step ahead of the game, to pick out the rock bands that seemed destined for success.
But now, with the pop pendulum swinging back into the middle of the road, the music audience tiring of carbon copies of carbon copies of Nirvana and Pearl Jam, and bands like the Spice Girls and Hanson (who actually tried to get a deal at the convention four years ago) making popular music G-rated again, the atmosphere at this South by Southwest was very different. It was no longer about seeing the up-and-coming rock star, the baby band that record labels are relentlessly competing to sign, but about looking for something different. It is a time of confusion in the rock world: few people even know what genre, let alone what band, will be catapulted from clubs to arenas.
The highlights at the festival were acts dabbling in electronic dance music; groups augmenting standard rock instrumentation with flutes, violins, brass instruments, vintage keyboards, even bagpipes; history-rummaging lounge and country acts; innovators from Asia, Europe and Australia, and rockers sporting matching outfits, choreographed stage moves and theatrical flourishes in direct opposition to the downtrodden realism and anti-showmanship esthetic of alternative bands. Rock music is once again sinking into a diverse mire out of which in a few more years (when the pendulum swings away from the middle of the road and out toward a more extreme or innovative sound) any one of these styles could be plucked and deposited on top of the pop charts.
Sonic Youth's performance brought home the cyclical nature of the music business. Though the concert was packed, and the band is among rock's most influential explorers, it was once again out of step with the times. The bulk of its performance consisted of detuned, deconstructed, wide-open songs from its forthcoming album, resulting in a show challenging enough for several talent scouts to admit that if Sonic Youth were an unknown band performing this same set at a smaller club, it would never be signed to a major record label. (It's currently on the Seagram-owned DGC Records.)
"I'd rather see the bands that are all dressed up, playing weird instruments, running around screaming and singing in Japanese, because it's different and exciting," said one fan at the conference.
The Japanese actually had a major presence at South by Southwest, delivering some of the week's best performances. Cornelius, an eclectic Japanese star in his first American concert, played with his band in matching red-and-white crew-neck shirts and sunglasses, vacillating unpredictably between beautiful Beach Boys-inspired pop, dense clusters of noise and loose sonic tinkering as film collages flashed and fluttered in perfect synchronization with the music.
Delivering a more modern sound from Okinawa, a Japanese island known for its distinct traditional music, Cocco was the festival's sleeper hit, coming on like a Japanese Fiona Apple. Waifish, passionate, gifted and seeming disturbed, she belted out dark yet beautiful ballads and angst-riddled, violin-enhanced rockers while lost in a poetic hell of her own.
Other noises from Japan included the avant-garde wailing of O*N*T*J; the dense guitar assault of Zoobombs; the loose, fragmented, faux-naif rock of Seagull Screaming Kiss Her Kiss Her, and the freeform, double-drumming cacophony of Demi Semi Quaver, led by a singer dressed like a glam version of Marie-Antoinette who announced, "I wonder why we play here because we are so Japanese."
Elsewhere, American Indian groups like the family rock trio Blackfire sang angry songs of protest and alienation as did rappers like Latryx. Groups from Sweden like Cloudberry Jam played a bar-band equivalent of lounge-rock; New Zealanders like Te Vaka presented ethnic amalgamations of music and dance; Mexican rap noodlers like Plastalina Mosh presented themselves as their country's answer to the Beastie Boys, and Welsh bands like the Stereophonics played straight-ahead, hook-heavy power-pop.
No matter what country they were from and how different their music was, rock bands seemed to be screaming: "Look at me! We're something different!" They spit fire and set their instruments ablaze (Motor City Devils, Nashville Pussy), wore bizarre or coordinated outfits (Motor City Devils, the Eyeliners, Cornelius, Demi Semi Quaver), played nontraditional rock instruments (Drums and Tuba, for example, were exactly what the name promised) or simply strove for classic pop perfection (the High Llamas, Richard Davies, the Push Stars, and Apples in Stereo), all of these acts a throwback to a time before and a contrarian response to alternative rock.
Unlike the Winter Music Conference, a dance-music convention that gathered some of the genre's top underground disk jockeys and electronic musicians for all-night parties in Miami earlier this month, at South by Southwest there was no sense of vitality and urgency; there wasn't an audience that felt it was in the know and onto something that the rest of the country would soon wake up to. Dance music at South by Southwest was simply presented as one element in the panoply of sounds.
Even within its niche, dance acts were extremely diverse: Amsterdam's Junkie XL pushed the big beats of the Chemical Brothers and the Prodigy further into the realm of fraternity party music; Germany's To Rococo Rot looked back to its country's legacy of progressive rock for minimal, propulsive electronic-enhanced jams; the Propellerheads showed how well two English white men could appropriate old-school rap scratching, beat-boxing and breakbeats, and Martyn Bennett merged drum-and-bass dance music with bagpipe and woodwind solos.
More than dance music, the sound at the conference most recently scooped out of its pocket and onto the pop charts was ska, one of the few longtime underground genres that -- despite two great ska showcases at the festival -- the cognoscenti in the business refuse to take seriously, explore or even discuss in a sentence that doesn't end with "all the same" or "be happy when that's over."
There is another way to navigate through the concerts here besides looking for new bands, and that is to see the Texas legends: the folk, country and roots singers who have become local institutions, representatives of a legacy as looming and active as an oil rig. In the street during the day, at the homes of musicians like Joe Ely and Jerry Jeff Walker in the evening, and at clubs all through the night, performers (including Jimmie Dale Gilmore, Alejandro Escovedo, Don Walser, Ray Price, BR5-49 and Junior Brown) displayed their virtuosity as singers, songwriters or guitarists.
Every year most of these musicians perform at the festival, and their shows are nearly always packed. It is a reminder to the business that there is music out there beyond trends, charts and radio play, that chronicles in timeless terms an individual's search for meaning and stability in a country built on violence and eclecticism. More than a multimillion-dollar deal with Sony or Warner Brothers, the status and longevity of these musicians is a goal for the hundreds of fledgling bands that performed at the festival to aspire to.

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 346 words

HEADLINE: Military Mischief in Indonesia

 BODY:
American military training for Indonesia's notoriously brutal anti-riot troops is a dangerous idea that was expressly prohibited by Congress on human rights grounds years ago. But such training has been going on, quietly, since 1992. The Pentagon cynically sidestepped Congressional objections by moving the Indonesian training from the military education program, where it was prohibited, to a different bureaucratic pocket.
The case for an end to the riot troop training is now especially strong because it seems likely that the troops will be used to crush legitimate democratic protests. President Suharto's erratic response to the severe economic crisis and his stage-managed re-election have sent demonstrators into the streets and his Government's legitimacy to a new low. 
Regrettably, the Defense Department persists in believing that all military training programs are of great benefit to the United States. Pentagon officials argue that such training forges valuable friendships with future foreign military leaders and teaches trainees greater respect for civilian authority and for human rights.
Such benefits may realistically be expected in countries where top military and political leaders are committed to professionalizing the armed forces. But the record of American training efforts in repressive military cultures like Indonesia's is bleak. Unambiguous success stories are rare, while some military graduates of American training programs, like Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega in Panama, have gone on to lead ugly, anti-American dictatorships. In Indonesia, the riot-suppression trainees can be expected to absorb American instruction in subjects like advanced sniper techniques and special air operations and ignore any accompanying civics lessons.
Washington faces difficult enough challenges as the Indonesian crisis unfolds. It should not be complicating its agenda by tying the reputation of the United States to anti-riot troops whose history is marked by gratuitous violence and whose future behavior Washington is powerless to control.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Ugandans Hope Trip Will Aid Democracy and Trade

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: KAMPALA, Uganda, March 22

 BODY:
Charles Katongole, a taxi driver by trade, swung the pickax into the earth at the main traffic circle outside this hot and humid capital with a purpose today. Sweat drenched his face and body.
The sidewalk he had volunteered to repair was still just a strip of chewed-up earth, and it had to be completed before President Clinton's arrival on Tuesday. 
 "If this work isn't finished, we will keep going through the night," he said, mopping his brow. "I'm very excited to see the President. I think he will bring us peace. What I want from him is to say something about this one-party system. This system of one party -- I don't like it."
Ugandans, whose country a decade ago was a brutal dictatorship in economic collapse, are now preparing for President Clinton's visit with pride and great expectations. Some, like Mr. Katongole, are hoping that Mr. Clinton will push their President, Yoweri K. Museveni, to abandon the ban on party politics that has been the hallmark of his Government.
Others say they expect the Presidential visit to attract American investors. It is a chance, they say, for Ugandans to show the world that their country has been transformed from an economic basket case into a great place for doing business.
Still others are hoping that Mr. Clinton will come bearing gifts: grants for schools, infrastructure and the like.
What is certain is that when Mr. Clinton's airplane touches down at Entebbe Airport at 1:30 Tuesday morning, he will be entering a country that is a far cry from the dirt-poor and oppressed nation ruled by Milton Obote and Idi Amin in the 1970's and 1980's.
Mr. Museveni, a guerrilla leader who seized power in 1986, has won accolades not only for restoring security and the rule of law to most of the country, but also for liberalizing the economy, restricting the money supply, cutting the public payroll and raising taxes.
He has sold off Government-owned industries, scrapped currency controls and established free markets for coffee and the other commodities that power this economy, shoring up agricultural production and exports.
On paper, the result has been stunning, diplomats and economists say. Uganda has seen an average annual economic growth of 6.7 percent for the 12 years of Mr. Museveni's tenure.
But on the ground, Uganda, a fertile, rain-fed land the size of Oregon, remains one of the poorest countries on earth, with an average per capita income of around $260 a year. A guerrilla conflict in the north and west of the country has sapped the Government's resources, forcing Mr. Museveni to spend a fifth of the $1 billion annual budget just to keep the army supplied.
In the end, the country's growth has been phenomenal partly because the economy had sunk to such a low point in the mid-1980's. In addition, Mr. Museveni has been helped by aid from the United States and other major industrial countries who want to support his pro-market policies. The World Bank and the International Monetary Fund have provided loans and debt relief, and foreign aid now pays for about 46 percent of the national budget.
In 1996, Mr. Museveni won the first election to be held in 16 years by a landslide. His opponents were crippled by the ban on party activities. He has steadfastly delayed a return to party politics, arguing that economic development must come first and that parties have done nothing in Uganda's history but foment chaos and sectarian violence. A referendum on party politics is planned for 2000.
But aside from some grumbling from businesses about taxes and from opposition leaders about the one-party system, Mr. Museveni remains immensely popular. Most Ugandans who remember the days of Mr. Amin and Mr. Obote, when thousands of people were routinely imprisoned or killed for political reasons, see him as a savior.
For the White House, Mr. Museveni's Uganda is the perfect place for Mr. Clinton to promote his vision of America's new relationship with Africa, a partnership based on commerce rather than economic aid.
"This journey will be my opportunity and yours to help to introduce the people of the United States to a new Africa, an Africa whose political and economic accomplishments grow more impressive each month," President Clinton said this month.
In an interview today, Mr. Museveni said Mr. Clinton's policy of promoting commerce rather than economic aid was the best way to develop the continent. He added that he expected the visit to generate "trade, investment and tourism" for Uganda.
"I think Mr. Clinton has taken a wise decision by recognizing the potential of Africa, which others have not appeared to have recognized," he said. "I think this is good for America, not only for Africa."
But what Mr. Clinton sees is unlikely to be representative of Uganda's poorer regions. Ugandans have been sprucing up their capital and the three sites Mr. Clinton will visit, all of which are within 40 miles of Kampala.
In the capital, the police have removed hundreds of beggars, street children, prostitutes and the disabled from downtown Kampala, telling them to go elsewhere for a few days and putting some in temporary lodging outside the city.
Volunteers and civic groups have been working feverishly to sweep the streets, remove rubbish piles, repair sidewalks and fill potholes. Several roads where Mr. Clinton will travel have been repaved, and the shoulders have been repaired.
On Tuesday, Mr. Clinton will meet with Mr. Museveni and then fly to a grade school in Kisowera, about 12 miles east of the capital, where he is expected to give a speech and announce a new American aid program for education, Ugandan officials said. He will then go to Wanyange, a village near Jinja, the lake port about 36 miles further east, to see a program that provides loans to small entrepreneurs.
Wednesday will be dominated by a meeting with heads of state from East and Central Africa at a hotel in Entebbe, the Lake Victoria port 20 miles south of Kampala. The President is expected to fly to neighboring Rwanda in the morning for a quick visit.
The mood in Kampala is ebullient and excited. In dozens of interviews, residents said they saw Mr. Clinton's visit as a final confirmation that their country had been resurrected from the depths of dictatorship and has rejoined the world's respectable nations.
"Uganda used to synonymous with Idi Amin," Edith Ssempala, the Ugandan Ambassador to the United States, said on a talk radio program, echoing the views of many Kampala residents. "We are overcoming that, quite clearly."
Leila Lule, 36, a housewife, was also lending a hand with the cleanup operation. "It seems Uganda has become one of the countries that will develop," she said. "We have never had a President from America come to visit us here. It implies that maybe in the future there is something good for us -- development and modernization."
Down in the city's commercial area, owners of small businesses took a more pragmatic view of the President's visit. Several said the economic policies so admired by foreign diplomats and the World Bank had meant nothing to them but higher taxes, lower profits and less money in circulation.
They said they hoped that Mr. Clinton's entourage of American officials and business leaders would include investors who might put money into Uganda.
"It will help our Government bring investment here," said Godfrey Bukenya, 28, a partner in a tiny shop selling kettles, pots and pans. "We are finally recognized. We have a stable Government. We are moving forward."
