HEADLINE: Mr. Yeltsin's Latest Surprise

 BODY:
Russia's President, Boris Yeltsin, is turning the abrupt dismissal of top government officials into his trademark governing style. Yesterday Mr. Yeltsin, only recently returned to work from a severe respiratory infection, surprised Russia and the world by dismissing his Prime Minister, Viktor Chernomyrdin, along with his entire Cabinet. Mr. Yeltsin's achievements over the years have been impressive. But his increasingly mercurial leadership, marked by erratic pronouncements, frequent health crises and sudden removal of top aides, now threatens to undermine Russia's political stability and the confidence of foreign governments and investors.
As acting Prime Minister Mr. Yeltsin chose Sergei Kiriyenko, a 35-year-old technocrat associated with Boris Nemtsov, one of the most reform-minded members of the Chernomyrdin Government. No sharp lurches in economic or foreign policy are likely, and many ministers and officials are expected to return in old or new roles. But Mr. Chernomyrdin's departure instantly scrambles the outlook for the 2000 presidential election and revives uncertainties about a smooth succession should Mr. Yeltsin's health further deteriorate. 
 Mr. Yeltsin blamed the Chernomyrdin Government for failing to translate its economic reforms into a better life for ordinary Russians. That is a fair indictment in a country where life expectancy is shrinking, public services are collapsing and paydays are frequently payless. But by some economic measures, the Chernomyrdin Government has not performed badly. It has halted the long slide in output and has controlled inflation. It is still struggling to get taxes paid, although it recently moved to collect from some of the bigger corporate holdouts. It has strengthened ties with the United States through twice-a-year meetings of the Gore-Chernomyrdin commission.
These policies are likely to continue under Mr. Kiriyenko and his still-to-be-chosen permanent successor. But so too is the pervasive corruption that stained the Chernomyrdin record. Seven giant banking and business groups have close ties to the country's most powerful political leaders, and Mr. Yeltsin's own re-election campaign was largely financed by these businessmen and bankers. They have been rewarded with chances to scoop up shares in former state enterprises at well below market rates.
Unfortunately there are no quick fixes for most of the sufferings that have soured many Russians on reform. But reform would surely be helped by more confidence-inspiring political leadership, from Mr. Yeltsin on down.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Increase in Oil Prices Sends Most Market Gauges Lower

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
A jump in oil prices reverberated through financial markets yesterday, leaving stocks generally lower, precious metals higher and the bond market unchanged.
The different responses reflected investors' varied interpretations of the impact of the oil price increase. In the stock market, it seemed that it was mostly an excuse to sell after the major stock gauges had set a string of new highs last week. 
 The sharp jumps in the prices of gold and silver showed that some investors were worried about inflation. But the bond market's calm signaled that other investors were less worried as they concluded that the price of oil is still very low compared with just five months ago.
"It was a topsy-turvy day," said Timothy M. Ghriskey, senior portfolio manager at Dreyfus.
In the stock market, oil stocks did rally, and along with a rebound in technology stocks that helped lift the Nasdaq index 3.35 points, to 1,792.51. Among technology stocks, Microsoft was up 2, to 83 7/8, and Cisco Systems jumped 1 1/8, to 64 3/4. Oil stocks were led higher by Royal Dutch Petroleum, up 1 1/4, to 58 1/4, and by Exxon, up 7/8, to 68.
But declines in drug and financial stocks and oil-related selloffs in transportation stocks helped pull the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks down 3.61 points, to 1,095.55. The stocks of all the major airlines, which have been benefiting from lower oil prices, ended lower.
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped further, falling 90.18 points, or 1 percent, to 8,816.25. It was pushed lower by the Boeing Company, which said late Friday that it was facing delays in the delivery of some of its new 737's. Boeing was off 1 13/16, to 51 5/8. Coca-Cola fell 1 5/8, to 75 7/8, after an analyst at Lehman Brothers lowered his earnings estimates.
But stock market analysts did not think that the stock market decline was important. "Nothing really significant happened, but it was an excuse to sell," said George Cohen, a principal at Cohen, Klingenstein & Marks, an investment manager.
Mr. Ghriskey added that the flow of cash into stocks from investors is so strong that he does not see the stock market correcting, or dropping 10 percent, any time soon.
In the bond market, the news was that nothing happened. After declining a little in the morning, bond prices recovered. The price of the 30-year bond was unchanged at 103 13/32. The yield remained 5.88 percent.
Robert Pugliese, senior vice president at J. W. Charles Securities Inc. in Boca Raton, Fla., said the market's initial reaction to the jump in oil prices was a knee-jerk fear of inflation.
"Oil producing countries have always had some difficulty in maintaining some price support system, and on a worldwide basis it would be virtually impossible," he said, referring to a weekend agreement among leading producers to cut their oil production.
But he also warned against completely discounting yesterday's oil price increase. "Low oil prices have given everyone a sense of security."
This metaphorical shrug in the bond market was a stark contrast to the reaction in the commodities market. The price of gold for April delivery jumped $7.30, or 2.5 percent, to $299.50 an ounce, while the price of silver for May delivery rose 24.5 cents, to $6.38 an ounce.

HEADLINE: SHAKE-UP IN RUSSIA: THE CONTENDERS;
4 Who Would Succeed Chernomyrdin

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

 BODY:
Here are brief sketches of the people most often mentioned as Boris N. Yeltsin's next Prime Minister.
 
Grigory A. Yavlinsky
A radical economic reformer and populist, Grigory A. Yavlinsky, 45, has jealously guarded his position as Mr. Yeltsin's most ardent democratic critic. Mr. Yavlinsky, leader of the liberal Yabloko faction in Parliament, complains that Mr. Yeltsin has failed to push economic reforms far enough. 
 Although he has parted ways with the President on economic and foreign policies in principle, the ambitious Mr. Yavlinsky, who ran for president in 1996, has made it clear that he would join the Cabinet if offered the post of Prime Minister.
Intelligent and charming, Mr. Yavlinsky is admired by politicians and scholars in Washington and in Cambridge, Mass., where he is a frequent speaker at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard. His image is more shaded in Russia, where his sometimes naked ambition and chronic inability to get along even with like-minded politicians have alienated some supporters.
 
Sergei Kiriyenko
Sergei Kiriyenko, 35, is a close ally of the leading reformer remaining in Mr. Yeltsin's Cabinet, Boris Y. Nemtsov.
He found out about his new position as Acting Prime Minister when he woke up yesterday.
His relative obscurity as Fuel and Energy Minister and his lack of a track record with Parliament might help him get confirmed without a fight.
Although he is a liberal from the reform crucible of Nizhny Novgorod, he has worked well with representatives of the oil and gas industries. They are by far the most important sources of income in the nation, and nobody who crosses them would have a chance of becoming Prime Minister.
 
Boris Y. Nemtsov
The First Deputy Prime Minister, Boris Y. Nemtsov, 38, is a charismatic man who has often been spoken of as Mr. Yeltsin's heir apparent. As Governor of Nizhny Novgorod, he gained a reputation as one of Russia's boldest young leaders. Despite his outspoken stance against Mr. Yeltsin's conduct of the war in Chechnya, the President sought him out to help lead the reform group in his second Administration.
When he decided to come to Moscow he was quoted widely in the press as saying that he was on a kamikaze mission but that some kamikazes survive. It's unclear whether he will be among them. His reputation suffered because Mr. Yeltsin blamed him for some of the Government's failings, but he has agreed to stay on. His high profile as a reformer would make it hard for him to be confirmed by the Communist-led Parliament.
 
Yuri M. Luzhkov, 61
Yuri M. Luzhkov, 61, a highly unlikely choice, is nonetheless somebody Mr. Yeltsin might want to draw into the Kremlin rather than letting him remain aloof. Mr. Luzhkov is the brutish, gruff Mayor of Moscow, who manages more than any politician in Russia to get things done.
He has presided over the biggest building boom in Russian history, and he became so popular that Mr. Yeltsin had to rely on him to help win his own re-election in 1996. Like all powerful people attached to the President, Mr. Luzhkov finds that his star rises and falls with some regularity.

GRAPHIC: Chart/Photos: "Who's Out"
Viktor S. Chernomyrdin
Dismissed as Prime Minister, Mr. Chernomyrdin, 59, had served for five years in a Cabinet where one-year careers are considered lengthy. Stolid, solid, loyal and unassuming, Mr. Chernomyrdin managed to lead the Government through years of painful reform that are nowhere near through, but he helped insure that the future will look nothing like the past.
 
Anatoly B. Chubais
Lionized in the West as the man who vowed above all to bring Russia to the free market, Mr. Chubais, who was First Deputy Prime Minister, may be the most despised man in Russia. His early efforts at privatization were widely viewed as vast federal gifts to inside operators at the expense of millions of workers who got nothing but promises they cannot redeem.
 
Anatoly S. Kulikov
As Interior Minister, General Kulikov presided over the most aggressive attacks on Grozny during the war against Chechnya, but he was largely responsible for Russia's defeat and humiliation. The former national security adviser Aleksandr I. Lebed once demanded that President Boris N. Yeltsin choose between the two men. Now he won't have to.

HEADLINE: Hotel Company in Talks to Buy Four Seasons

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Strategic Hotel Capital Inc. is close to a deal to buy the Four Seasons Hotel, New York's tallest hotel and a symbol of the city's economic fortunes, for more than $350 million, according to real estate executives.
Strategic Hotel Capital has been in discussions for several weeks with the Hong Kong owners of the imposing limestone hotel on 57th Street near Park Avenue. Designed by the architect I. M. Pei, the 52-story, 370-room Four Seasons has some of the highest room rates in the city. The 3,000-square-foot Presidential Suite on the top floor is $7,000 a night. 
 If the deal is struck, the current owners, the Lai Sun Group, will have nearly doubled their money in a mere 18 months. Lai Sun and a consortium of Hong Kong investors led by Polylinks, a Hong Kong real estate company, bought the hotel in August 1996 for $190 million.
Strategic Hotel Capital would gain an expensive but well-known property to add to its rapidly expanding collection of hotels. Analysts say that the company is preparing a public stock offering for the near future.
"There's a lot of demand for hotels in New York today from any operators or investment groups that aren't already here," said Paul Stern, a hotel broker with the Sonnenblick-Goldman Corporation. "The Four Seasons is unique in that it's a world-class trophy. It would be a nice centerpiece for their contemplated public offering."
Laurence Geller, president of Strategic Hotel Capital, declined to comment.
The value of the Four Seasons has fluctuated significantly, as has much New York real estate. The chairman of the EIE International Corporation of Japan, Harunori Takahashi, hired Mr. Pei in the 1980's to design the tallest and most luxurious hotel in New York.
By the time it was completed, during the recession in 1993, it had also become the most expensive to build. The cost had swelled to $477 million, or $1.3 million a room, and the hotel market in New York was in bad shape, and room and occupancy rates were heading downward.
Mr. Takahashi lost the property and most of his empire to the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan.
In 1996, Ambrose Cheung, a director of Lai Sun, led a group that bought the hotel at a 60 percent discount. At a party celebrating the acquisition, Mr. Cheung led a jubilant rendition of "New York, New York," while a karaoke machine projected the lyrics on a screen. He said at the time that the deal reflected his faith in the value of New York.
In the meantime, room rates at New York hotels have increased, as has the number of tourists and business executives coming to the city. Rates at the Four Seasons average more than $550 a night, among the highest in the city, hotel analysts say. Since it opened, the hotel has been run by the Four Seasons, a hotel management company.
Strategic Hotel Capital, the investment group to which Mr. Cheung is considering selling it, was formed last year by Goldman Sachs & Company, Security Capital Group and Mr. Geller.
"It's not a done deal," an executive familiar with the negotiations said. "But I would assume Strategic badly wants a trophy hotel."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Players Foresee Release As Other Refugees Wait

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER 

DATELINE: NASSAU, the Bahamas, March 23

 BODY:
Four Cuban baseball players being held in a detention center here negotiated with sports agents today and were told they could expect to be released after just a few days in custody. Meanwhile, more than 100 other Cuban refugees locked up with them, who have been held for months in the bare-bones compound, began a hunger strike to protest their plight.
While all the refugees shared the same muddy encampment, there was a marked division between the gaunt-eyed detainees who have few prospects and the athletes who could think about having it all. 
For the Bahamian Government, caught in the middle of high-stakes diplomatic and business negotiations, there was little choice. If the ballplayers succeeded in getting another Caribbean country to sponsor them, the Bahamas would release them and put them on an airplane for that nation, presumably a stopover before the United States and, possibly, baseball glory and riches.
Joe Cubas, a Miami sports agent who has helped other Cuban baseball players who defected obtain major league contracts, is petitioning Costa Rica and Nicaragua to admit the group, an associate said today. The players, a coach and four other defectors left Cuba by boat last Friday. Before leaving, they hid for more than a week waiting for good weather, and rumors swirled that they had been lost at sea or washed ashore in the Dominican Republic.
The players are first baseman Jorge Luis Toca, 23; second baseman Jorge Diaz, 23; catcher Angel Lopez, 25, and shortstop Michael Jova, 17. A new team of agents, from Total Sports International, turned up at the detention center today, beckoning individual ballplayers from the barracks-like shelters that house 151 Cubans and 50 or so Haitians and other illegal immigrants.
As each athlete walked to the perimeter fence to speak to the agents, the less fortunate refugees sat stone-faced outside the barracks, their backs pressed against the wall.
"They get a good Bahamian diet," said Arthur Rolle, superintendent of the center, commenting on the detainees' complaint that their health was being compromised by meals often lacking in protein. "Peas and rice and some chicken. Maybe even some pork chops. Sometimes."
William Nottage, a Bahamian immigration superintendent, said: "I don't blame them for being upset. Some have been held here since November. They are asking if their cases are any less credible than these athletes."
Unless another country offers political asylum, Cuban refugees here must await an interview by representatives of the United Nations High Commission on Refugees, said Luther E. Smith, permanent secretary of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Most are judged economic refugees and sent back to Cuba, a track record that has kept Bahamian relations with Havana cordial, he said.
If the High Commission recommends political asylum, it is usually granted, Smith said, but the process can require months. Top Cuban athletes usually do not have to endure normal channels. Sponsorship by a third country facilitates quick release to that nation and makes possible relocation to the United States.
Defecting players who reach the United States after first entering another country do not have to enter the free-agent draft and can negotiate with clubs as free agents.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Angel Lopez, left, and Jorge Luis Toca are two of the four Cuban baseball players who are currently in a Nassau detention center. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Throngs Greet Call by Clinton For New Africa

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: ACCRA, Ghana, March 23

 BODY:
Be fore the largest crowd he has ever addressed a whooping and clapping throng estimated by the Government here at more than half a million -- President Clinton opened his 12-day tour of Africa today by pledging more American interest and aid while calling for a deeper African commitment to democracy and free markets.
But Mr. Clinton was careful to pair his message with scorn for American "stereotypes that have warped our view and weakened our understanding of Africa." Describing his trip, by far the longest undertaken here by an American President, as "long overdue," Mr. Clinton said, "It is time for Americans to put a new Africa on our map." 
 Mr. Clinton's midmorning speech on a sweltering day was joyfully received -- too much so, at one point, for his taste. When he shook hands after his speech, the crowd surged against the steel barricades, threatening to crush at least one woman and perhaps even overwhelm the President.
Mr. Clinton, his face contorted in anger, raged at the crowd to get back, as ferociously pounding drums seemed to lend it momentum. But as the President gestured with his arms, scores of hands continued to clutch at them. It was a rare public display of what some of Mr. Clinton's close advisers and friends have described as private bursts of temper.
Braced by Secret Service officers, Mr. Clinton moved farther along the barricade and the pressure of the crowd subsided somewhat.
There was no precise count, but the crowd filled the concrete parade ground of Independence Square, which has a capacity of more than 200,000. As Mr. Clinton appeared with the Ghanaian President, Jerry Rawlings, the air over the upturned faces became a blur of tiny American and red, green and gold Ghanaian flags.
At one point in his speech Mr. Clinton dabbled in Akan, the language of Ghana's largest ethnic group, the Ashanti, and briefly draped a brilliant cape of golden kente cloth over his black suit.
"Democracy requires human rights for everyone, everywhere," he said. "For men and women, for children and the elderly, for people of different cultures and tribes and backgrounds. A good society honors its entire family."
On a day so humid one almost had to chew to breathe, people started gathering more than four hours before Mr. Clinton appeared. Scores were overcome in the heat, with only an occasional breeze off the Gulf of Guinea; hundreds pleaded for water with Ghanaian officials and American reporters.
The President, traveling with 800 aides, members of Congress, security agents, reporters and others, arrived after an overnight flight from Washington, and left eight hours later for a late-night flight to Uganda.
This afternoon Mr. Clinton visited a project run by an American nonprofit concern, TechnoServe, with Peace Corps volunteers to improve farming, increase access to credit and teach women to read. Ghana was the first nation to accept Peace Corps volunteers, in August 1961.
In remarks at the project, Mr. Clinton dwelled on the significance of his visit for black Americans, one of his most loyal political constituencies. The President was accompanied by the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, his special envoy to Africa; by several black members of his Cabinet and Congress; and by black businessmen like Bob Johnson, the owner of Black Entertainment Television.
"I don't think you can possibly imagine what this day means to the members of the Congressional Black Caucus, to the African American members of my Cabinet, and those who hold senior positions in the White House and in the departments of Government," Mr. Clinton said. "It wasn't so very long ago in the whole sweep of human history that their ancestors were yanked from the shores of western Africa as slaves. Now they come back home to Africa and to Ghana as the leaders of America."
Mr. Clinton also praised Mr. Rawlings "for his leadership for democracy, for economic reform."
In meetings with Mr. Rawlings, Mr. Clinton promised some new American aid beyond the $52 million in development assistance the United States provided last year. A severe drought has crippled Ghana's hydroelectric plants, cutting the country's power supply in half. Mr. Clinton told Mr. Rawlings today that the Department of Transportation would provide a guaranteed $67 million loan to pay for two natural-gas power plants mounted on barges.
In a gesture that fit the day, Mr. Clinton also promised $500,000 to help the Ghanaian police improve their crowd control.
The centerpiece of the day was Mr. Clinton's 15-minute address this morning, which was intended to frame his tour of Africa.
"My dream for this trip," he said, "is that together we might do the things so that 100 years from now, your grandchildren and mine will look back and say this was the beginning of a new African renaissance."
Consistent with the optimistic theme of his visit, the President emphasized the progress of Ghana, whose economy grew about 5.5 percent last year. But his audience's sentiments about the country's state was better illustrated by the loud applause when Mr. Clinton said, "The United States is ready to help you."
People in the crowd rattled off lists of the country's needs. "Ghana needs everything," said Esther Guiama, 47. Michael Gyebi Sarpong, 53, added, "We need money for infrastructure, education, health and farms.".
In a 24-minute speech before Mr. Clinton's, Mr. Rawlings called for foreign investment here. He said that Africans had learned that "only by allowing the individual to flourish can our communities also flourish." Mr. Rawlings wore a traditional war dress known as a batakari, a puffy brown patterned shirt with spotted animal skin attached to the left shoulder.
Mr. Rawlings introduced the President as "a very innovative politician with a very dedicated wife."
This trip has come at a propitious time for Mr. Clinton, who is under pressure at home from the independent counsel investigating his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky, the former White House intern. But it was clear that the President would not escape his troubles in Africa.
Ghanaian reporters grilled their American colleagues about details of the crisis, and Mr. Rawlings appeared to refer to it in his address. He told a lengthy story about how well the Clintons had treated a Ghanaian nurse they employed in Arkansas, and then declared, "When you are talking about the character of a person, this is how some of us define the character of people."

Clinton Arrives in Uganda
 ENTEBBE, Uganda, Tuesday, March 24 (By The New York Times) -- President Clinton's jetliner, Air Force One, touched down smoothly at Entebbe International Airport in Uganda at 1:21 this morning.
Twenty minutes later, the President and his wife emerged, waved, smiled and descended the steps. Looking tired, Mr. Clinton shook hands with the Ugandan President, Yoweri K. Museveni, exchanging a few words and smiles. Then he and Mr. Museveni walked leisurely to a Marine Corps helicopter, which carried the President and Mrs. Clinton to the capital, Kampala, about 20 miles northeast.

HEADLINE: Method or Madness? Lewinsky's Lawyer Baffles Washington Establishment

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Back in the days before he became as familiar a television fixture as "Seinfeld" reruns, William H. Ginsburg once observed, "A trial is not a game, but it is theater."
In a Washington drama that has often seemed closer to "Waiting for Godot" than "Advise and Consent," few of the actors have been harder to read or subjected to more baffled, sometimes dismissive, reviews than Mr. Ginsburg, the Beverly Hills medical malpractice lawyer whose defense of Monica S. Lewinsky has put him at the center of the furor swirling around Bill Clinton's Presidency. 
 Mr. Ginsburg has morphed from a little-known California lawyer to an unavoidable TV talking head to the avuncular half of Washington's ultimate power couple of the moment -- squiring his client around town from dinner at the Cosmos Club to Larry King's book party to Washington Wizards basketball games.
Legal experts have wildly differing assessments of Mr. Ginsburg's loquacious, seemingly contradictory performance, but if they do not agree on the answer, they do agree on the question: crazy or crazy like a fox?
Whether Mr. Ginsburg is blundering his way through unfamiliar terrain or roiling the legal and political waters to his client's benefit has become one of the more intriguing subplots of the Lewinsky matter. And while the political and legal fallout from the accusations of Kathleen E. Willey could make Ms. Lewinsky's position even more precarious, legal experts have sharply differing views on Mr. Ginsburg's role so far.
"You can talk to 20 lawyers and get 20 different notions of what's going on," said William B. Moffitt, a Washington defense lawyer, "but what really matters is what happens to his client, and that remains up in the air right now. If he manages to get his client out of here without testifying and without being prosecuted, he'll have had a successful run."
Mr. Ginsburg has been widely criticized, particularly by Washington lawyers who say he could have got complete immunity for his client easily and early. But if, as some legal experts have suggested, Mr. Ginsburg's strategy has been to protect the former intern legally, diminish her value to a grand jury and to any prosecution and perhaps prevent her from going down in history as the woman who helped bring down a President, his tactics and strategy may be harder to read.
What is clear is that Mr. Ginsburg and his client have had a constantly shifting trajectory. When Mr. Ginsburg arrived in Washington, his air of authority and oratorical flourishes were viewed as instantly invigorating to Ms. Lewinsky's defense. Now he is regularly accused of irresponsibly milking his 15 minutes of fame and changing course like a traveler lost in a blizzard.
Ms. Lewinsky seems to have gone from the center of the drama to someone like Beckett's Godot, hovering tantalizingly out of sight.
And while Mr. Ginsburg said that he welcomed the degree to which both of them had been pushed out of the spotlight by the attention now being focused on Ms. Willey's accusations that President Clinton forced himself on her sexually, others say Ms. Lewinsky could resurface in a more vulnerable position later.
Critics say Mr. Ginsburg has spent too much time on television and not enough time boning up on criminal law. They say he has sown confusion rather than told a consistent story. They say he inexplicably seemed to negotiate from weakness rather than strength when the special prosecutor desperately needed Ms. Lewinsky's testimony, and then lost his chance to protect her and receive immunity.
Mr. Ginsburg went from portentously saying his client was ready to "unload everything she has -- everything" to flatly denying that Ms. Lewinsky had had any sexual relationship with the President. He coyly said early in the proceedings that Ms. Lewinsky "at this time" was standing by her original affidavit. Later he said the affidavit was "factual."
He has publicly questioned the credibility of his own client, saying, "All 24-year-olds and all 18-year-olds and 19-year-olds tend to embellish."
"Chauncey Gardiner," sniffed Joseph E. diGenova, a Washington lawyer and former United States Attorney, referring to the dim-bulb gardener whose inanities were misinterpreted as profundities in the novel and film "Being There." "It's an amazing performance. To what end, I know not."
Others say Mr. Ginsburg has left Ms. Lewinsky a ripe target for possible prosecution on perjury or obstruction of justice charges, particularly in connection with talking points she apparently delivered to Linda R. Tripp about Ms. Willey.
"At the end of a criminal trial there would barely be enough of her left to pour into a shot glass," said Jonathan Turley, a Washington lawyer and professor at the George Washington School of Law.
But Mr. Ginsburg says most of the criticism reflects the clubby tribalism of Washington lawyers. "I have discovered that anyone who is not practicing law inside the Beltway is a country lawyer," he said.
And he denied that his account had shifted over time. He said that the hiring of a Washington lawyer, Nathaniel Speights, had compensated for any criminal law or Washington shortcomings in Ms. Lewinsky's defense and that any zigzags in his account had resulted from trying to keep up with the leaks coming from the independent counsel's office. With a bit of exasperation, he said that people who criticized his early proffer in the case or the degree to which he negotiated for immunity had no understanding of the specific facts of the case.
While standing by remarks that he hopes the country avoids the economic and social turmoil that would come from the fall of a President, Mr. Ginsburg derided speculation that his strategy was affected by concerns about Mr. Clinton's future.
"That's screwball, that's nuts," he said. "I'm defending a little girl, young lady. I don't care about bringing the President down or holding him up."
Lawyers who know Mr. Ginsburg from Los Angeles say he is anything but a legal naif. They portray him as a knowledgeable, politically astute lawyer, with a startling record of winning difficult cases and a sharp, strategic approach to the law.
Bruce Givner, a former partner of Mr. Ginsburg, describes him as a "superb courtroom lawyer," with an actor's command of the courtroom and the ability to instantly develop strategies in hostile situations. He recalls the way Mr. Ginsburg spent years in the 1970's and 1980's defending a swimming pool maker, Anthony Pools, parachuting into small towns in Arizona, Louisiana or Texas to defend the company against lawsuits filed by parents whose children had been rendered quadriplegics in swimming pool accidents.
"He was defending this big California public company, arguing to jurors who were neighbors of the kids crippled for life, and he always won," Mr. Givner said. "He's the kind of guy who walks into the courtroom and everyone says: 'He's a nice guy. He's trustworthy. He's honest. He's sincere,' and he won time and again against staggering odds."
His success as an advocate leads those who know him in Los Angeles to see his news media appearances more as a sign of his confidence in his ability to argue his case to the largest possible constituency than as evidence of egocentric grandstanding.
Robert Levinson, who practiced with Mr. Ginsburg for six years, said Mr. Ginsburg had "the uncanny ability, sort of a sixth sense, to know what to do in all kinds of situations."
He said Mr. Ginsburg's approach could either be "a pure defense strategy" or something less conventional in which he was trying both to demonize Mr. Starr and to render his client increasingly less useful to the prosecutor.
"If it's the latter, look what's been accomplished," Mr. Levinson said. "Now you even have Trent Lott criticizing Starr, and Monica's account has become such mush there's nothing concrete to be gained by pursuing her. There's nothing to grab hold of."
Skeptics say that just because Mr. Ginsburg is a fine malpractice lawyer does not mean he is the ideal lawyer to handle this case and that if Mr. Starr has been demonized, the White House and Mr. Starr's own behavior have more to do with it than Mr. Ginsburg. And they say that Mr. Ginsburg might have stumbled more than dashed to a position that could help his client.
But others say that, for all the smoke and ever-shifting political winds, Mr. Starr still has no criminal case against either Ms. Lewinsky or the President.
"Whether he planned it or lucked into it, Ginsburg has a client who didn't testify before the grand jury and is moving out of the zone of danger daily," said Larry Pozner, a Denver defense lawyer and president-elect of the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers. "Ken Starr has a nothing-burger. A good prosecutor could not get to first base with what he has, and Ken Starr can't find the ball park."
Of course, none of those passing judgment know the details of Mr. Ginsburg's dealings with Mr. Starr and what sort of designs Mr. Starr has on Ms. Lewinsky.
And ego being in no short supply among lawyers, Mr. Ginsburg is hardly the only lawyer being routinely hooted at by his peers.
As a result, the conventional legal wisdom has been that Mr. Ginsburg is playing out of his league; President Clinton's lawyer, Robert S. Bennett, is responsible for a legal blunder worthy of the hall of fame by allowing the Paula Corbin Jones lawsuit to head toward trial, and Mr. Starr has been so majestically inept as to put the whole independent prosecutor mechanism in jeopardy.
"This is a ballet of incompetence," said Alan M. Dershowitz, the Harvard University law professor. "You could use it to teach a whole year's course on how not to practice law."
Still, as the ebb and flow of the furor surrounding Ms. Willey once again proved, it is impossible to predict where Mr. Clinton's legal odyssey is headed and who the winners and losers will be.
"Members of the bar ought to be a little more cautious about kicking each other's teeth in until we see what the results are," Mr. Moffitt said.

HEADLINE: Into Africa

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: ACCRA, Ghana, March 23

 BODY:
Africa is the Rodney Dangerfield of continents; the world seems to pay it scant heed and shows it less respect.
The United States has been no exception. In a 1994 study of United States policies toward Africa, Peter J. Schraeder of Loyola University in Chicago wrote that they have always been marked "by indifference at worst and neglect at best." 
 That is what President Clinton is setting out to change in his trip here, which will last for 12 days -- three times longer than all of his predecessors combined have spent in this vast continent, which the missionary David Livingstone once described as the "running sore of the world."
In recent decades Africa has mostly meant trouble, from the Biafran insurgency to civil war in Angola, from famine in Ethiopia and Somalia to genocide in Rwanda, from Ian Smith to Idi Amin.
Only the transition from apartheid to democracy in South Africa under Nelson Mandela's leadership has broken the pattern dramatically enough to catch the eye of significant numbers of Americans.
Surveying Africa in 1994, the Nigerian novelist Wole Soyinka, a Nobel laureate, commented, "Rwanda is our nightmare; South Africa is our dream."
Mr. Clinton landed in Accra this morning on a journey he described as "long overdue." He thinks the winds of change are blowing, says a "new African renaissance" is at hand, and just by coming he has accomplished something. He has demonstrated, say diplomats and students of Washington's African policy, that the United States no longer considers Africa peripheral.
"The Africans had pretty well concluded that we didn't give a damn about them," said C. Payne Lucas, who heads Africare, an organization of American volunteers in 30 African countries. "We've ignored this continent, except for the Peace Corps, the big oil companies and a crisis here and there, so this trip is a very helpful signal."
Yet there is widespread, profound skepticism about the President's broader goal of establishing important, lasting economic links with Africa. Mr. Clinton is raising expectations, perhaps beyond his capacity to fulfill them.
Richard M. Moose, who served as Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs in the Carter Administration, said last week: "It is going to take huge human and financial resources to transform the place, and we haven't the slightest idea where they are going to come from. Certainly not from us. It's hard to believe that we will ever again offer aid on a cold war scale."
The United States hopes that trade, not aid, will do the job.
But most African countries have small populations, shaky legal frameworks, if any, and negligible middle classes. Education and health care are often inadequate. Transportation links among African nations remain primitive.
That is a formula certain to worry potential foreign investors, who are skittish in any event after last year's reversals in Southeast Asia. Investors want predictability and order, which are hard to guarantee even in the new Africa.
The chosen White House instrument is the Africa Growth and Opportunity Act, which the House of Representatives approved this month. Senate action is pending.
The legislation forms the background of this trip. It seeks to promote the privatization of government enterprises across Africa, with sales of state assets open to all comers, including foreigners. In return, African countries could export to the United States without the hindrance of tariffs or quotas.
Critics argue that the act would allow foreign corporations to buy African resources at fire-sale prices and exploit low-wage African labor.
"This bill nakedly and unqualifiedly promotes the interests of American business," said one vocal foe, Randall Robinson of the lobbying group TransAfrica. "It should be called the African recolonization act, because the United States and Europe have the money and would grab the assets."
Mr. Clinton has chosen an itinerary that will take him to countries the Administration sees as success stories -- countries described in carefully modulated terms by Susan E. Rice, the influential Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, as "pretty good performers, economically and politically, all things considered."
One aim, she said in an interview in Washington, is to show Americans "the side of Africa that's not bodies floating down rivers."
The President himself was less guarded in remarks broadcast throughout the continent before his arrival, talking of "an Africa whose political and economic accomplishments grow more impressive each month."
That is a very carefully edited Africa. It excludes Somalia, where 18 American soldiers died five years ago trying to end chaos and famine: it still has no Government. It excludes Angola, where the United States is promoting peace negotiations that have not brought peace.
It excludes the Congo, although Mr. Clinton will meet with its leader, Laurent Kabila, during a stop in Uganda. Mr. Kabila seems to be drifting into the cruel and corrupt pattern of the man he deposed only last year, Mobuto Sese Seko, and the decision to include him on the schedule came only after a heated argument within the Administration.
Most important, it excludes Nigeria, which with South Africa is the most important country in sub-Saharan Africa in terms of population and resources.
Pope John Paul II landed there on Saturday and called on Nigerians to guarantee human rights. The Vatican asked the Government of Gen. Sani Abacha to free 60 political detainees.
United States officials have been sending signals to General Abacha that it disapproves of his apparent plan to take off his uniform and run as a "civilian" candidate in elections planned for August, but it is not clear what Washington could do to stop or punish him if he does so.
Administration officials speak enthusiastically about what Mr. Clinton called "the new face of Africa" and about a new breed of democratically inclined leaders. But Mr. Moose, warning that the picture is spotty, describes such comments as "a pretty thin batter they're spreading."
Ghana is a case in point. It is rich not only in manganese and cocoa but in talented people, proud that one of its sons, Kofi Annan, is Secretary General of the United Nations.
Economically, though, Ghana is still not back to where it was a quarter-century ago. To a correspondent returning to Accra after an absence of almost three decades, progress seems sparse.
There is an exuberant animation to street life, as always, and bars are full. But power outages are more commonplace than ever, and most of the population of three million still lives in dusty shantytowns ringing the more modern buildings at the city's center. And democracy has been elusive -- Jerry J. Rawlings, the President, seized power by military force not once but twice, although he has committed himself to leaving office in two years in accordance with Ghana's Constitution.
The nation's economy is growing at 5.5 per cent a year, an encouraging figure, and the Ashanti Goldfields Company, as it proudly noted in newspaper advertisements today, became the first sub-Saharan enterprise listed on the New York Stock Exchange in 1996. The big aluminum smelter, owned by the Kaiser Aluminum Corporation and the Reynolds Metals Company, continues to produce ingots for export to the United States, though at sharply reduced rate because of power shortages.
Ghana's per capita income is still less than $500 a year. Like most Africans, most Ghanaians are little touched by industrial growth. Few of the dreams that Ghana dreamed in 1957 -- when it became the first black African country to free itself from colonial rule and a leader in the non-aligned bloc -- have been realized. Many opportunities have been missed, beginning in the heyday of Kwame Nkrumah, the charismatic, American-educated politician who led the nation with so much verve and so little wisdom.

HEADLINE: U.S. Is No Model For Europe's Jobless

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The two front-page "Help Unwanted" articles (March 19 and 21) on the European job drought note that joblessness in the United States is at a record low because of a surge in the service industry, wage flexibility and fewer regulations. However, two other important aspects of the American growth model were left out. 
 First, the United States sends three times as many people to prison, as a percentage of its population, as any European country. This reduces the number of unemployed, since prisoners are not counted as jobless in labor statistics and there is increased job growth in the prison industry. Second, America's defense industry is a job-creating machine few other countries can match.
 
MARK CASSELL
Milwaukee, March 21, 1998

HEADLINE: U.S. Is No Model For Europe's Jobless;
Struggling to Survive

 BODY:

To the Editor:
A March 19 front-page article describes the anger of France's unemployed toward a welfare system that does not provide a "decent standard of living." 
 In the United States, welfare provides less than survival benefits. A typical family of three on assistance in New York City receives an average monthly grant of $577, half the Federal poverty level. After rent, this leaves families with at most $6 per person a day to pay for food, clothing, utilities, transportation and school supplies.
New York has not raised the public assistance grant since 1990, although the cost of living has increased by 25 percent since then. A cost-of-living adjustment in the welfare grant would go a long way to help recipients participate in education, training and employment.
 
CRISTINA DIMEO
Coordinator
Welfare Reform Network
New York, March 20, 1998

HEADLINE: SHAKE-UP IN RUSSIA: THE OVERVIEW;
YELTSIN DISMISSES HIS ENTIRE CABINET IN SHOW OF POWER

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 23

 BODY:
Demonstrating once again his enormous power and his mercurial nature, President Boris N. Yeltsin astonished the nation today by dismissing his entire Cabinet, including his loyal and dedicated aide, Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin.
Even for people who have grown used to Mr. Yeltsin's almost Shakespearean penchant for casting off those closest to him at regular intervals, today's actions seemed difficult to comprehend. 
 Theories swirled through the capital like a cyclone. Some said it was part of a larger battle between factions of rich businessmen seeking to control the Government. Others are convinced that Mr. Yeltsin acted from confusion.
But there is a simpler explanation. In the last two months, with the 67-year-old President often ill, disengaged and out of the public eye, discussion of his possible successor has again become a common topic on television and in the press.
The next elections are not until 2000, and nothing infuriates Mr. Yeltsin more than the suggestion that he has lost any of his political authority.
By abruptly removing Mr. Chernomyrdin, Mr. Yeltsin has lost the only stable figure in his Cabinet, and the United States has lost its most direct pipeline to the Russian leadership. In Washington, American officials expressed worries over future relations with Moscow. Page A8.
"This decision grows from a simple fact, said Aleksei Zudin, an analyst at the Center for Political Technologies here. "While the President was ill, Viktor Chernomyrdin became much stronger. Boris Yeltsin interprets such things with great jealousy and annoyance."
Mr. Yeltsin has a long and well-documented history of dismissing anyone -- including aides who once resided comfortably within his inner circle -- whom he considers capable of challenging his leadership.
Last year he dragged himself from a hospital bed to dismiss Aleksandr I. Lebed, the national security adviser who he had once hinted was his heir apparent but who then grew a little too visibly eager for the job. And this is the third time in three years that Mr. Yeltsin has dismissed Anatoly B. Chubais, the highly controversial economic reform leader, from a senior post.
Although much was made today of Mr. Yeltsin's having dismissed his entire Cabinet, which is technically true, there are only three major victims so far: Mr. Chernomyrdin; Mr. Chubais, whose departure as First Deputy Prime Minister was expected, and Anatoly S. Kulikov, the hard-line Interior Minister.
Mr. Kulikov was a proponent of the disastrous war in Chechnya and in charge of the tax police, whose failure to increase revenues has also damaged the Kremlin's credibility.
Most of the other Cabinet members will almost certainly keep their jobs. "The dismissal of the Cabinet does not mean a change of course in our policy," Mr. Yeltsin said in a surprisingly folksy and conciliatory speech to the nation. "It is an effort to make economic reforms more energetic and effective, to give them a political push, a new impulse. The renovation of power is a natural process. You can't have a Government without changes."
Mr. Yeltsin initially said he would take over temporarily as his own Prime Minister, but then he named the young Energy Minister, Sergei Kiriyenko, as First Deputy Prime Minister until he names a permanent Prime Minister.
Mr. Kiriyenko is an obscure official who has solid reform credentials, and the President's spokesman said tonight that Mr. Kiriyenko would have to be considered the leading candidate.
That would make some sense if what Mr. Yeltsin wants is a weak Cabinet. Because he is not well known, Mr. Kiriyenko would have a far easier time gaining confirmation in the Communist-dominated lower house of Parliament.
He would also be entirely dependent on Mr. Yeltsin, having no significant political power of his own.
"The offer came as a complete surprise," Mr. Kiriyenko, 35, said at a news conference today in which he pledged to adhere to the course of reforms. "I learned about it this morning."
Mr. Chubais, who has battled bitterly over the future course of economic openness and reform in Russia with a small group of businessmen, most notable among them Boris A. Berezovsky, stated often in the last few months that his time in the Kremlin would soon end.
As for Mr. Chernomyrdin, almost from the day that he became Mr. Yeltsin's Prime Minister, there have been rumors that he would be relieved of his post.
Stolid, unimaginative and almost deadly dull, Mr. Chernomyrdin somehow developed into the most respectable and predictable member of the Cabinet. He remained in part because his loyalty was absolute.
That and his unique ability to work with the Communists in the Parliament, foreign colleagues like Vice President Al Gore and representatives of the powerful oil and gas industry he once led kept his job secure. But recently Mr. Yeltsin's daughter, Tatyana Dychenko, his closest and perhaps only real confidante, has been said to consider Mr. Chernomyrdin a threat.
Today, Mr. Yeltsin said he had told Mr. Chernomyrdin that it would be best for him to take a political course and prepare for the 2000 elections. But nobody would see that as an endorsement. Mr. Chernomyrdin, an uncomfortable speaker, was unable to say today that he would seek the presidency when Mr. Yeltsin's second, and last, legal term expires.
Few political analysts give him much chance without the power of the prime ministership or the direct support of Mr. Yeltsin. During parliamentary elections in 1996, the profoundly uncharismatic Mr. Chernomyrdin -- at the behest of the President -- helped create a new party, Our Home Is Russia. It was trounced at the polls. Today he seemed oddly resigned to his fate.
"I want to tell you openly that I worked six years in the Government," said Mr. Chernomyrdin, appearing somber but self-assured at a news conference, "including five years as Prime Minister, and I was ready every day for this turn of events. This was not a tragedy for me."
The Russian markets at first plunged on the news of Mr. Yeltsin's action, but they recovered during the day after it was clear that a radical new course was not likely.
Still, Mr. Yeltsin's latest surprise may damage the economy that he said in his speech he wanted to rescue. The Central Bank had to immediately intervene in the currency markets this afternoon to keep the ruble stable. Needless expenses like that will make it much harder to find the money to pay the back wages owed to millions of workers, which is one of the reasons Mr. Yeltsin gave for dismissing the Cabinet.
He will also have to make some effort to convince the West that his decision today was not as capricious as it appears. And he will have an opportunity this week when he meets here with the Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany and President Jacques Chirac of France.
"Boris Yeltsin loves to surprise everyone and to make moves that no one expects from him," said Nikolai Petrov of the Carnegie Moscow Center.
Mr. Yeltsin often blames his Government for the problems of the Russian people. It is a role that the Russian chief has taken on himself since the days of the czars -- and it usually works.

LENGTH: 1474 words

HEADLINE: Wine Talk;
Price Chaos on Restaurant Lists

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial 

 BODY:
IT is time for a significant celebration, an elegant dinner with wine. Not just any wine, either, but Chateau Petrus. You might do it at Lespinasse, in the St. Regis Hotel. They have the rare 1982 Petrus. At $5,000 a bottle.
Or you might bypass Lespinasse and amble a few doors west on 55th Street to Michael's, a popular spot where the very same wine goes for a mere $1,000. With the $4,000 your little stroll saved you, you might throw in a weekend in Bordeaux, even visit Chateau Petrus. That would be celebrating! 
 A bit farfetched? The trip, perhaps, but not the disparity in the price of Petrus. I, and plenty of other people who eat out regularly, have often been appalled not only by the staggering increase in restaurant wine prices but also by the seemingly arbitrary and capricious way prices differ from one restaurant to another in New York.
Nowhere does the chaotic state of the city's wine lists become more apparent than in a new study prepared by the Zagat Survey, the publisher of the restaurant and hotel guides. The three-month project, which was just completed, examined the wine lists of 64 restaurants drawn from the 1998 Zagat Survey of New York City Restaurants.
There are startling differences from top to bottom of the lists. For example, the moderately priced New Zealand Cloudy Bay sauvignon blanc ranges from $29 at Jean Georges to $75 at Manhattan Ocean Club. But the most extreme disparities apply to highly touted wines, almost all of them from Bordeaux and Burgundy, that are in short supply.
Take the 1982 Petrus: At Le Cirque 2000, the wine sells for $4,000, up from $3,750 a few weeks ago. La Cote Basque and La Grenouille sell it for $2,400; Harry's at Hanover Square and the Four Seasons both have it for $1,750.
Chateau Petrus produces less than 4,000 cases of wine a year, so sales are by allocation. Ten years after the vintage, when it is mature, the wine is almost impossible to acquire, except for the few bottles that turn up at auctions. An established restaurant that bought the 1982 Bordeaux in 1983 got the lowest prices and can, if it wishes, sell the bottles at far lower prices than a restaurant that opened last year and had to set about acquiring a cellar at the top of the price market. And the most fashionable restaurants, like Lespinasse and Le Cirque 2000, cater to a clientele that demands famous labels, regardless of price.
The more prestigious a wine is, and the harder it is to acquire, the more some people will pay to get it, like season tickets to the Knicks or Giants games. Such wines are more often drunk by deal makers, film stars and rock musicians than by wine connoisseurs.
Beyond the Petrus example, others large disparities tumble out of the survey. At Le Cirque, a bottle of Chateau Latour 1982 sells for $2,400, or more than four times the $575 it costs downtown at Harry's at Hanover Square.
The 1993 Le Montrachet, Marquis de Laguiche, from Joseph Drouhin, $530 at La Grenouille, is $210 at Mark's.
Grange 1991, the famous Australian wine formerly known as Grange Hermitage, is $700 at Le Cirque and $245 at Chiam.
The 1993 vintage of Opus One, the California wine produced by Robert Mondavi and Chateau Mouton-Rothschild, sells for $225 at Windows on the World and $89 at Cite.
Krug Brut Champagne 1985, $320 at Oceana, is $160 at Barbetta and $150 at the Oyster Bar. Beaulieu Vineyards Private Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon, also from the 1985 vintage, is $196 at Maloney & Porcelli and $85 at Harry's at Hanover Square.
The longest list in the Zagat study was at Windows on the World, with 669 wines; the shortest was at Cafe des Artistes, with 44 wines. The lists were divided into three categories: bargains, expensive and moderate.
Without question, Harry's at Hanover Square, a well-known haven for Wall Street wine lovers, had the best prices in the city. According to the Zagat computations, Harry's had 62 of the lowest prices and none of the highest.
Some of Harry's wines that were priced lower than at any of the other restaurants polled were Calon-Segur 1982, at $110 ($300 at Le Bernardin; Cos-d'Estournel 1982, at $185 ($550 at La Grenouille); Cheval Blanc 1982, $795 ($2,600 at Le Cirque); 1983 Haut-Brion, $145 ($440 at La Grenouille), and the 1984 Jordan Cabernet Sauvignon, $55 ($175 at Park Avenue Cafe). There are 586 wines on Harry's list and, by the way, there is a Harry: Harry Poulakakos, the owner and a passionate wine enthusiast himself.
"I buy in quantity and I keep my margins low," Mr. Poulakakos said. "My customers are spenders, but they are intelligent spenders."
Among other restaurants with significant numbers of the lowest-priced wines were Chiam, which tied Harry's with 62 (but Chiam had one wine with the highest price); Sparks Steak House, with 35 of the best prices; Ben Benson's, 24; Union Square Cafe, 20; Michael's, 18; Windows on the World, 18; Cite, 17, and Aureole, 14.
The restaurants with the highest prices were invariably among those noted for the city's highest food prices. Topping the list with the largest number of the highest or, in Zagat's words, the worst, prices was La Grenouille, with 55, followed by Daniel, 43; Le Cirque, 34, and Lespinasse, 28.
Others on the highest-price list were Le Bernardin with 24; Gotham Bar and Grill, 22; Maloney & Porcelli, 22; Les Celebrites, 21; the Four Seasons, 20, and Jean Georges, 16.
Among restaurants with moderate prices, the Carlyle had 13 of the best prices and 37 of the worst; Smith & Wollensky, 24 of the best, 21 of the worst; La Cote Basque, 11 best, 14 worst, and Barolo, 9 best, 16 worst. At the most expensive places, wine bargains were as scarce as empty tables.
"Daniel and La Grenouille," Zagat's researchers reported, "feature very few items in the under $40 range, perhaps a Loire white here or an American red there but no Burgundies or Bordeaux." At Le Cirque, only Italian whites were cited as good buys. Lespinasse was cited for offering "quite a number of wines at $50 and under," hailing from the Loire Valley, Calif.; South Africa, and Chile, among other sources.
To a degree, prosperity is the culprit behind outrageous wine prices. Customers are willing to pay almost anything for the best wines, and the only place many of them can be found is at auctions, which means paying more than retail.
"A lot of it is just keeping current," said Ralph Hersom, wine manager at Le Cirque 2000. "When we reopened in April 1997, most of our stocks of good wines had been depleted, and we were forced to go back to the auctions to replenish.
"If you follow auctions at all you know some of the older Bordeaux go for $10,000 and $15,000 a case -- $18,000 for the 1982 Petrus. If we want the wines, we have to pay those prices."
Danny Thames, the wine manager for the New York Restaurant Group, agrees. His restaurants include Smith & Wollensky, Cite, Manhattan Ocean Club, Park Avenue Cafe, Maloney & Porcelli and the Post House.
"I can't keep Opus One in stock at the Post House," he said. "At one point I was down to four bottles. I was barely able to find some at an auction. And of course, I had to raise the price." Each restaurant in the group buys separately because of individual liquor licenses, Mr. Thames said, which accounts for different prices for the same wine.
The 1987 Opus One, for example, is $288 at Smith & Wollensky, $275 at the Post House, $272 at Park Avenue Cafe, $253 at Maloney & Porcelli, $283 at Manhattan Ocean Club and $203 at Cite.
The Zagat wine list survey was intended as an internal document, but the publishing company expects to make it available in several weeks on its Web site (www.zagat.com) and by telephone at (212) 977-6000; a price, if any, has not yet been determined.
The study did not go into the economics of wine buying, but one fact stands out: There is no strong customer resistance to these prices. A case in point: On March 10, a group of six men dined at Le Cirque. Their bill: $22,840. Mr. Hersom said they drank a bottle of Roederer Cristal Champagne, 1990; a bottle of Chateau Le Pin, 1988, and a Chateau Petrus 1982. Then came three bottles of Chateau Cheval Blanc 1961, a bottle of Chateau Margaux 1945 and a bottle of Taylor Port, also 1945. Their food bill was less than $3,000; the rest was wine.
Most New York restaurants are not involved in this status game. There are hundreds of restaurant wines priced at $20 or less, which means that given the effects of inflation over the years, many of these wines are less expensive than they were 20 years ago and are bargains even if there is some disparity in prices.
New Yorkers can be canny wine buyers, and if they stay alert, prompted by this latest survey and their own experience, they will find the places with the most attractive wine lists. They know there is life after Petrus.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
Trade Associations Form Electricity Supply Deals

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
As property managers and owners in New York and Westchester Counties prepare for the April 1 changes in state regulations that will allow them to choose their supplier of electricity, a group of real estate trade associations has announced an agreement with two of the new power suppliers.
The Electrical Power Procurement Alliance said it had negotiated a deal with New Energy Ventures-East and with Con Ed Solutions, the unregulated subsidiary of Consolidated Edison, that would provide immediate savings on electrical costs when the first, modest phase of deregulation starts on June 1. 
 The organizations, which include the Building Owners and Managers Association, which represents mostly commercial properties, and Associated Builders and Owners, which includes residential properties, represent purchasers of about one-third of Consolidated Edison's total power generation capacity. Although individual owners and managers would not be required to purchase from companies selected by the alliance, the collective buying power of the group gave it more negotiating influence than any individual, officials of the group said.
"We came together to handle deregulation on the broadest base possible, representing the smallest users to the largest," said Peter DiCapua, president of the Owners Committee on Electric Rates and a spokesman for the overall group. He said the savings would be in addition to the one-time $50 and $75 incentives being provided by Con Ed under its agreement with the Public Service Commission to induce smaller customers to switch to other suppliers, including Con Ed Solutions.
He said the arrangements worked out with Con Ed Solutions and New Energy Ventures-East represented the most favorable terms that were offered by the 12 energy service companies, or ESCO's, that would sell electricity in Con Ed's service territory.
"We believe the deal we have made with these two ESCO's is the best in town, and if someone comes up with anything better, we can get out of this one in 30 days," Mr. DiCapua said. He said there was a guaranteed minimum savings of 5 to 6 percent, depending on individual circumstances, and incentives to shrink bills further.
The deregulation that will take place starting June 1 will be modest, involving only 500 of the approximately 10,000 megawatts of power Con Ed can produce, with 200 megawatts reserved for smaller customers and 300 earmarked for larger users. All power in the Con Ed service area is to be deregulated by the end of 2001.
Much of the initial savings in electrical bills will be the result of avoiding taxes, executives said. Power generated by Con Ed is considered a commodity subject to a state tax of 4 percent and a New York City tax of 4.25 percent. When power is purchased outside the city or outside the state and transmitted to users, it is not subject to the sales tax, because transmission is considered a service.
"The tax piece is very big in the initial phases of deregulation," said Gerald Lieberman, the president of New Energy Ventures-East, which is a subsidiary of a California-based company, New Energy Ventures. But over time, he said, savings in the purchase of power will be more important as less efficient generators are driven from the market.
Energy service companies do not typically own their own generation facilities, but buy electrical power where surpluses exist and favorable rates can be negotiated. Unlike oil or gas, which can be stored, electrical power must be consumed as it is generated or it is lost.
"If a company has a 1,000 megawatt plant, and it is only selling 700 megawatts, that 300-megawatt capacity goes down the drain," Mr. Lieberman said. He said companies with unused capacity are eager to sell, and use attractive prices to make deals. There are physical and economic restrictions on how far power can be transmitted, but an open market for power is expected to be more price efficient than the current situation, in which companies generate much of their power within their own service territories.
Nicholas LaPorte, executive director of the Associated Builders and Owners, said it was expected that New Energy Ventures-East would concentrate on commercial accounts, while Con Ed Solutions would focus on residential customers, although both would be free to seek whatever business they could find.
"Con Ed is a known entity with an infrastructure in place and a history," Mr. LaPorte said. "There is a comfort level there that should appeal to the residential customer."
Because of the way transmission and distribution facilities were built, all of Manhattan and some other parts of the city cannot be fully supplied with imported power. In these areas, power must be generated locally, even if the plants are more costly than those located elsewhere.
Earlier, the 12 energy service companies participated in an auction to buy generating capacity from Con Ed, with New Energy Ventures-East and Con Ed Solutions both purchasing 51 megawatts.
One issue that remains uncertain is what will happen to the price of steam, which many large buildings use for both heating and cooling. Steam was originally a byproduct of the generating process, but over time profits from sales of electricity were used to subsidize the price of steam, property managers have said.
More than 2,000 high-rise buildings are connected to Con Ed steam through a 102-mile system of pipes stretching from 96th Street to the Battery. Buildings connected to the steam system do not need their own heating plant, which makes space available for storage and other uses.
"Steam is an important energy source for customers in New York, and there may be a lot of volatility in steam prices," said John E. Boyd, the president of Con Ed Solutions, which is based in White Plains. He said that steam would remain a part of the regulated Con Ed, while his company would provide financial services to moderate the impact of changing steam prices.

HEADLINE: Montana Writers' Sessions Teach Language of the Land

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
Like the old Federal Writers' Project of the Great Depression, which provided jobs for unemployed authors, Gallatin Writers Inc. of Bozeman, Mont., puts writers in harness to help uplift a depressed area.
Where the Writers' Project turned out still-useful guidebooks and local histories, the Gallatin writers examine local conflicts and try to come up with solutions. At 9 or 10 conferences a year, the organization chews over local issues, like how to cope with the depletion of natural resources. Then the writers go forth to spread their acquired knowledge, writing books or articles for a variety of Western newspapers and magazines. 
 The three- or four-day conferences are held at ranches around Bozeman, in Gallatin County in southwestern Montana, or at the Gallatin Gateway Inn, which was built in 1937 as a jumping-off point for visitors to Yellowstone National Park, a few miles south of Bozeman. If the conferees find time for trout fishing or bike-hiking in the spectacular Gallatin Range of the Rocky Mountains (and they invariably do), that only helps to sensitize them to the land.
The project was developed in 1991 when Gallatin County was in an economic decline. The local industries -- farming, mining and lumbering -- suffered from over-use of the land and had lost their competitive edge.
Along came John Baden, a retired college professor who had taught economics for 25 years, most recently at the University of Washington, where he had co-founded an M.B.A. program. Mr. Baden, 58, who has owned a sheep and horse ranch in Bozeman since 1970, retired to the ranch and came up with the idea of seeking to strengthen the literary culture and examine the local identity and conflicts.
His workshop has achieved remarkable success, receiving grants from the Ford Foundation totaling more than $300,000 since its founding. Gallatin, unlike the Depression project, is privately supported. Another important difference is that Gallatin does not ask literary artists to do utilitarian work but instead taps their creative talents. Mr. Baden recruits writers and others for the conferences, and their expenses are paid by the workshop. He selects the topics and matches writers to them, but the writers are obliged only to attend. Any writing they do afterward on issues of concern to the West is up to them.
Some contribute to the Gallatin Writers' syndicated column, which appears in The Seattle Times and at least a dozen smaller newspapers throughout the West.
Bill Wilke, editor of The Bozeman Daily Chronicle, which carries the column, said, "The Gallatin Writers can be counted on to address the key issues here -- timber, mining, ranching, agriculture and the environment -- and do so in such a way that causes people to soften their views or even adopt new ideas."
One thing writers are especially good at, Mr. Baden said, is debunking worn-out images and creating suitable new ones. For example, a view subscribed to by many old-fashioned environmental advocates, he said, holds that any land development is bad. A new concept that is helping to replace the old one argues that development can be good so long as it does not run roughshod over the values of those who are most affected by it.
The newer concept -- dreamed up for a Gallatin workshop by Donald Snow, executive director of the Northern Lights Institute, a nonprofit environmental organization in Missoula, Mont. -- has had an impact. Today, Mr. Baden said, it is discussed throughout the West.
Mr. Baden said he liked to bring together environmental advocates like Mr. Snow with the "hook and bullet" crowd, people like Datus C. Proper, a writer and editor for Field and Stream magazine who lives on a farm in Gallatin County.
Mr. Proper, who said his love for Montana centered on rainbow trout, gray partridges and white-tailed deer, likes to needle environmental absolutists at Gallatin workshops by arguing that hunters help to preserve wildlife. "Their licensing fees go to the maintenance of wildlife refuges," he said.
Has Mr. Proper ever swayed an adversary?
"Hard to tell," he said. "It usually takes a few days to sink in."
One of the sharpest -- and Mr. Baden says healthiest -- debates at a Gallatin workshop took place a year or two ago. Participants included Todd Wilkinson, a Western correspondent for The Christian Science Monitor; Ray Rasker, a resource economist interested in environmental protection; and Brett KenCairn, an anthropologist and community organizer from Ashland, Ore.
Mr. KenCairn bemoaned the influx of "modem cowboys," new arrivals in the West who have little connection with the land and make their living at computer stations in their homes. "They don't participate in the life of the community," he said.
Mr. Rasker shouted, "Bunk!" and accused Mr. KenCairn of "romanticizing the idea that people in the West are drawn together only because they all know how to sharpen a chain saw."
"What makes people form a community is much more complicated than that," he said. "It has to do with schools or with the fact that somebody plans to open a hog farm down the road and things like that."
Mr. Baden said the debate was precisely the sort of interaction he hoped to generate. "We're trying to sensitize people to the fact that there are no simple solutions to our problems -- only trade-offs," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: John Baden, a retired economics professor, at his ranch in Bozeman, Mont. Mr. Baden founded and runs the Gallatin writers workshops. (Paul Dix for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: About New York;
Wall St. Horde Gives Mongols Feel of Action

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
MONDAY, the Mongols hit Manhattan, descending first on the New York Stock Exchange. They strode past the clerks and brokers who stood on Broad Street smoking their morning cigarettes. They skipped the line of tourists waiting to enter the building, eliciting suspicious whispers before they passed through the revolving doors and metal detectors. Their progress was smooth, until an alert guard slowed them down.
"No pictures," he said to them as they entered the elevator. "If you take any pictures, I'll have to throw you out of the building." 
 That's no way to treat descendants of the Great Conqueror, Genghis Khan. Centuries ago, the Mongols did the tossing out, amassing a sprawling Asian empire. By this century, Mongolia had become a Soviet protectorate. Then, in 1990, the Mongols pulled a nonviolent twist on tradition and replaced their Communist government.
Ever since, the nation's leaders have been working to spread free markets and democratic rule. Choosing the economy over ideology, a delegation of two dozen Mongolian politicians and executives visited the city to promote both their country and its business climate. They were eager to meet American bankers and business people. They came, they saw and they conferenced.
"It is important to meet business people in New York because the city is the center of finance and business," said Radnaasumbereliin Gonchigdorj, the Speaker of the Mongolian Parliament and leader of the delegation. "When we were a satellite of the Soviet Union, we were under Communism, and capitalism was always painted black, with all the horrors of competition."
Now, competition means green, so he and his colleagues filed into the stock exchange balcony to watch as the floor jumped into action at the opening bell. A guide pointed out where trades were made in different industries, as the guests nodded. Jargalsaikhan Enkhsaikhan, the Ambassador to the United Nations, had already briefed some of them on the workings of the exchange.
"I told them how most of the trading decisions are made in 22 seconds," the Ambassador said. "I told them about the clerks, specialists and brokers. Actually, in Mongolia we have our own stock exchange. We have about 29 brokers."
The visitors were impressed by the array of monitors, tickers and computers that blinked the market's vital signs. One asked whether it was possible for Mongolian companies to be listed on the New York exchange. It was all part of their plan to continue the transition they had begun in 1990, with an emphasis on foreign investment incentives and the privatization of state-run businesses in manufacturing, food production and just about everything else.
GIVEN how city officials have done a little privatizing of their own with parks, health care and social services, the Mongols came to the right place. Mr. Gonchigdorj admitted that as a child, he knew little about the city, except for what he read in books.
"Of course, I had a certain understanding about New York, especially the sky-high buildings and the taxis," he said. "If I recall correctly, they were called 'Yellow Devils of New York.' "
The city he encountered filled him with new impressions, including one sure to hearten city officials intent on establishing the rule of order. "As a mathematician, I would like to say that this is the best city in terms of coordination," he said. "No one can be lost in this city. Everything is good. It is a square, coordinated system."
At a conference with American executives, he explained how new tax laws and incentives had combined with less bureaucracy to change his nation's economic system. The Americans seemed interested and their reaction buoyed the Mongolian delegation, which left later in the afternoon for meetings at the United Nations.
The schedule was tight, and it left Mr. Gonchigdorj with no time to do the touristy stuff that had been on his itinerary, like seeing "Cats" on Broadway. Nor could he visit the one place he had longed to see: the Statue of Liberty.
Some New Yorkers base their urban authenticity on avoiding the place, but to Mr. Gonchigdorj, it is the apex of art and independence. "There are people who are in a rush but not to see it," he said. "They do not visit it because it is always available. On the other hand, the symbolism is very important to Mongols."
