HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Nasdaq Market Index Posts Its First Close Above 1,800

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Several major stock market indexes climbed to highs yesterday as investors used the previous day's selloff as an opportunity to buy stocks at lower prices. The gains pushed the Nasdaq composite index, a leading technology barometer, to its first close above 1,800.
A retreat in crude oil prices, which buoyed the Treasury bond market by diminishing fears of higher inflation, aided stocks as well. After rising almost $2 a barrel on Monday, oil prices slipped by more than 50 cents a barrel yesterday, reflecting investors' skepticism about whether oil producers would stick to a weekend agreement to curb production. Also sliding were prices of such oil shares as Chevron, British Petroleum and Mobil. Several oil-related indexes also faltered. The Oil Service Sector index fell 1.92 percent, the Amex Natural Gas index slipped 1.84 percent and the Amex oil index fell 1.36 percent. 
 The prospect of lower fuel prices lifted the Philadelphia Airline Sector index 2.18 percent, with such airlines as the UAL Corporation, Northwest Airlines, Southwest Airlines and British Airways gaining.
In addition, many stocks that had faltered in the previous session, including Disney, General Electric and I.B.M., rose.
And financial services companies, for which continued consolidations are expected, rose, aided by a strong earnings report from Goldman, Sachs. "These companies want to buy themselves, and as investors you want to see that," Alan Bond, chief investment office at Bond Procope Capital Management in New York, said.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 88.19 points, or 1 percent, to 8,904.44, just 1.99 points away from its record closing high of 8,906.43 reached last Friday.
But other indexes posted records, including the Standard & Poor's 500 index, which gained 10.10 points, to 1,105.65, and the Russell 2000 index, which gained 2.30 points, to 476.26.
The Nasdaq composite index rose 19.93 points, or 1.11 percent, to 1,812.44.
Among smaller-company shares. the Securities and Exchange Commission took the rather severe action of temporarily suspending trading yesterday in Shopping.com, an Internet-based retailer, citing concerns about a "lack of current and accurate information" about the stock; it said that recent market activity might be a result of "manipulative conduct."
Shopping.com went public in November, selling 1.3 million shares at $9 a share, for a total of $11.7 million.
Since then, the stock reached a 52-week high of 32 1/8 on March 12 and closed at 22 1/4 on Monday, down 6 5/8. The company does not expect to make a profit for several years, and the stock traded on the National Association of Securities Dealers over-the-counter bulletin board, which has no stock listing requirements.
The 10-day suspension came after problems with the company began to appear last week. The company's sole underwriter, Waldron & Company, stopped trading the stock after its clearing broker, Wedbush Morgan Securities, told the National Association of Securities Dealers that it would no longer process stock trades for Waldron, an N.A.S.D. official said.
Last year, the company withdrew its request for listing on the Nasdaq market after it learned that its application would be denied, said a person familiar with the procedure.
Officials at Shopping.com could not be reached for comment.
Shopping.com, based in Corona del Mar, Calif., sells a variety of brand-name products and services, including computers, books, office supplies, compact disks and videotapes via the Internet.

HEADLINE: Jakarta Dissident Questions U.S. Military Aid

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 24

 BODY:
Indonesia's best-known opposition leader has challenged President Clinton to explain why United States special-operations soldiers are training members of the Indonesian military.
"Who, in the view of the U.S. government, is the target or enemy for this specialised training?" asked Megawati Sukarnoputri in a March 18 letter to Mr. Clinton. Noting that her country faces no foreign threat, she suggested that the troops' real targets were Indonesians protesting against their Government. 
 The United States has been training Indonesian soldiers despite a 1992 Congressional ban intended to end the instruction. Under a little-known $10 million Pentagon program called Joint Combined Exchange and Training, United States special forces teach the Indonesians skills that include psychological warfare and urban combat techniques.
"The U.S. military is providing training in lethal methods of social control at a time when the Indonesian people are trying to build a more democratic system," said the letter, a copy of which was given to The New York Times. "It is the explicit policy of the Indonesia security forces to meet peaceful and unarmed demonstrators with force -- and thus military training from the U.S. directly undermines the democratic movement in Indonesia."
Indonesia's military has ordered its troops to police recent political protests against the Indonesian Government.
Pentagon officials say the commando training increases the United States' ability to influence the Indonesian troops' respect for human rights. Mrs. Megawati's letter questioned that argument. "In light of the U.S. government's stated support for democracy around the world, I respectfully request an explanation of this secret training program that contradicts this noble foreign policy goal," her letter concluded.
The Indonesian military is seen by many members of the Government and some of the people as the most stable institution in a nation whipsawed by political corruption, skyrocketing inflation and social unrest.
But the military is accused of a long series of abuses, including the disappearances of political opponents, and it engineered Mrs. Megawati's ouster as chairwoman of one of the nation's three sanctioned political parties in 1996. Mrs. Megawati, the daughter of the former Indonesian ruler, Sukarno, has become the leading symbol of dissent against the 32-year reign of President Suharto.
Congress cut off funds that went to Indonesia under a program called International Military Education and Training in 1992, after Indonesian troops massacred more than 270 civilians on the island of East Timor. But the Pentagon continued its instruction in Indonesia under the Joint Combined Education and Training program.
Representative Nita Lowey, a New York Democrat, said today that she would introduce legislation to end that instruction and ban the Pentagon from "training an army that has been implicated in cases of torture, murder and disappearances."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
In California, a Distant Mirror on Korea

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 24

 BODY:
Bong Koo Cho was once one of the wealthiest industrialists and biggest landowners in South Korea. He lived in a 14,500-square-foot mansion and owned five or six cars.
But in 1984 he lost nearly everything. He abandoned his country, never to return, and has lived quietly in the Los Angeles area ever since. 
 Now, at 78, Mr. Cho is seeking to avenge his losses. He and his family have filed a lawsuit in state court here demanding the return of their fortune, which they say was illegally seized from them by the military dictatorship of Chun Doo Hwan. The assets today would be worth $2 billion, Mr. Cho estimates.
The lawsuit, while no doubt a long shot, could cast light on the corruption and political meddling in South Korea's economic system, something the nation is trying to leave behind in the wake of its recent economic collapse. The case also shows that back in the 1980's Korea was dealing with a problem that seems very familiar today -- a huge industrial expansion, backed by the Government and fueled by heavy borrowing, that left many companies on the verge of bankruptcy and banks buried under bad debts.
Mr. Cho's company, Samho Group, one of the largest conglomerates at the time, was transferred to a rival company, Daelim Group, as part of a Government program to merge, sell or liquidate companies deemed to be insolvent. But Mr. Cho denies that Samho was insolvent and said the real reason was that he and his family had failed to pay enough bribes to President Chun. The owner of Daelim, meanwhile, was the brother of the Speaker of the National Assembly and a close ally of Mr. Chun.
Several other companies were also seized at that time, and there is some evidence that failure to pay off the President did play a role. In one well-known case, a Korean court ruled in 1993 that the dismantling of the Kukje Group in 1985 was illegal. Kukje's owner contended that the Government ordered banks to cut off all financing to his company after he failed to make a big contribution to President Chun.
The Cho lawsuit could be embarrassing to some prominent Koreans who were involved in the Samho case. The Minister of Finance at the time, Kim Mahn Je, is now chairman of the giant Pohang Iron and Steel Company. Another official involved was Lim Chang Yuel, the Minister of Finance who guided Korea through its recent negotiations with the International Monetary Fund.
No present or former Government officials, however, are targets of the lawsuit, which names Daelim and Cho Hung Bank, Samho's main bank, and their American subsidiaries.
A spokesman for Pohang said Mr. Kim preferred not to comment on the matter. Spokesmen for Daelim and Cho Hung in Seoul said nobody there could talk about an incident that took place more than a decade ago. Simon Hong, a lawyer in Los Angeles for the California Cho Hung Bank, said the bank believed the suit was "groundless."
Mr. Cho, who never finished high school, started in the sewing machine business and moved into textiles, glass and construction. Along the way he accumulated real estate, becoming a major holder in the southern part of Seoul, which later boomed, and on Cheju, a resort island.
In the mid-1970's, Korea's Government urged Korean construction companies to seek contracts in the booming Middle East. But many companies ran up huge debts doing so, and by the mid-1980's the Government decided to sell, merge or liquidate insolvent companies without allowing them to declare bankruptcy, which, it was thought, would alarm the public and cast an international spotlight on the huge bad debts in Korea's banking system.
Samho had debt of about $350 million in part because the Saudi Arabian Government had failed to pay it for a housing project owing to a dispute over the contract terms. Mr. Cho, who suffered a stroke in 1979, was in the United States seeking treatment in 1984 and the company was being run by his son Yong See. The son, who now calls himself Peter Cho, said that on Aug. 24, 1984, he was summoned by Finance Minister Kim and told that the decision had been made to confiscate Samho and the family's private property.
He was then sent to see the president of Cho Hung Bank, who, he recalled, chastised him, saying: "I told you to lobby top-level guys. What have you been doing?" He said the bank president also said that since Mr. Cho was going to lose everything anyway, he might as well take care of his health, a remark Mr. Cho interpreted as a threat that he would be tortured if he resisted.
While Daelim officials waited in the next room, Mr. Cho said, he was forced to sign three blank pieces of paper, which later became documents transferring virtually all the family's assets to Daelim. The Chos say the body of Peter's older brother, who had died at a young age from cancer, had to be removed from his grave because the family burial plot was taken as well.
The Chos also say they had enough assets to cover the debts. "We were simply not even given a chance," the elder Mr. Cho said in an interview through an interpreter. "The Cho family's assets were simply handed over on a platter to the Lee family," he said, referring to the Daelim owners. The Cho family moved to the United States, except for Peter, who was detained in Korea because of a tax dispute until 1990.
Father and son seem to partly blame each other for the loss of property. Peter Cho said that when he ran Samho he dispensed $700,000 to Government officials on holidays, three times a year. But his father resisted doing even more.
"I told him to get along with Chun -- sacrifice some of your assets, give him the golf course or the hotel," Peter Cho said. "He wouldn't listen to me."
Still, enough wealth seems to have remained that Mr. Cho and his son have survived without working since then. "After you are one of the top-ranking businessmen in Korea after you come here, it's hard to start a liquor store or dry cleaner," said Peter Cho, 47, who had gone to high school and college in the United States.
As democracy came to Korea in the late 1980's and early 1990's, the Cho family tried without much luck to retrieve some of their assets. But in late 1995, former President Chun was arrested and eventually sentenced to life in prison for amassing hundreds of millions of dollars of "donations"' from businessmen. "It dawned on us that this was the chance for the family," said Sally Cho, one of Mr. Cho's four daughters.
The family filed its suit in Los Angeles County Superior Court in December. The Chos say they chose a court in the United States rather than Korea because they are all United States citizens and because American lawyers are willing to work on contingency. But the difficulty of suing foreign companies -- the defendants have not even been served with copies of the lawsuit -- and the fact that the events occurred so long ago will make the case tough.
One week after the suit was filed, Kim Dae Jung, an ardent foe of the military dictatorship, was elected President of South Korea and promised to right the wrongs of the past. But Mr. Cho was disappointed that one of the President-elect's first acts was to agree to a pardon of Mr. Chun in the name of national unity.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Donor Won New York Contract As His Gifts Soared

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
In March 1997, a construction company owned by one of the biggest financial backers of Gov. George E. Pataki and the New York Republican State Committee learned that it was on the verge of losing the competition for a contract to repair the Queens-Midtown Tunnel that was worth as much as $100 million.
When officials of the Long Island company, Silverite Construction, complained to the state agency overseeing the contract, they were allowed to revamp their bid, according to interviews and state records. Two months later, Silverite was awarded the contract, even though state officials had initially determined that the company and its partner in the venture lacked the necessary experience, the records show. 
 In the days just before and after the contract was awarded on May 30, 1997, the Republican State Committee received a spate of donations from contributors linked to Silverite's owner, Angelo J. Silveri, totaling $100,000, records show. Of that, $40,000 was contributed by a political action committee that Silverite set up just nine days before the contract was awarded. Since then, the PAC has been virtually dormant.
Among the other contributors were Mr. Silveri's wife; an executive of Silverite; the wife of another Silverite executive, and an executive of another company that Mr. Silveri controls. Each gave $10,000, received on the same day, May 28, 1997.
Before the donations last spring, Mr. Silveri, his relatives, his employees and companies he controls had given about $210,000 to the state party and the Pataki campaign, most of it in late 1994 and early 1995, according to campaign records.
In a telephone interview last week, Mr. Silveri denied that anyone connected to him had made donations around the time the contract was awarded. But then, when presented with details of the donations, he said, "I hope you're not driving a nail into something that is not there."
Tom Kelly, a spokesman for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the state agency that awarded the contract, said officials there did not know about the campaign donations. "This contract was awarded on the merits," he said.
Yet the timing of the donations underscores the success that the State Republican Party and the Pataki campaign have had at exercising an advantage of incumbency: collecting gifts from companies and others with a stake in decisions by the state government. Those gifts have helped the Republican leaders and Mr. Pataki raise money at a far more aggressive pace than any other politicians in state history. The Governor's campaign treasury now holds more than $11 million.
Silverite Construction was one of several bidders in early 1997 vying for the tunnel contract, a four-year project to replace much of the lighting, walls and ceiling.
The company, one of the largest privately owned general contractors in the state, has over the years worked for many government agencies including the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. Mr. Silveri, 60, has been active in several building trade groups on Long Island, and was a trustee of Adelphi University until last year, when state officials ousted the board of trustees, charging that it had failed to oversee the university's president.
Mr. Silveri was on Mr. Pataki's inaugural committee and said in the interview that he was a friend of Charles A. Gargano, the Governor's senior economic development adviser and former chief fund-raiser.
"I speak to him an awful lot," Mr. Silveri said of Mr. Gargano. Mr. Silveri said he might have discussed the tunnel contract with Mr. Gargano, but he said he did not ask for assistance in getting the contract.
Caroline Quartararo, a spokeswoman for Mr. Gargano, said he was no longer a political fund-raiser. She said that while "it's possible" that Mr. Gargano discussed the contract with Mr. Silveri, Mr. Gargano was not involved in the bidding.
Zenia Mucha, a spokeswoman for Mr. Pataki, said he had no role in the selection of Silverite by the transportation authority, which is controlled by gubernatorial appointees. Asked whether the Governor knew Mr. Silveri, Ms. Mucha said, "It's irrelevant whether the Governor knows him or doesn't know him."
The circumstances surrounding the Queens-Midtown Tunnel contract were pieced together from interviews, campaign finance records and court papers in lawsuits filed by two construction companies against the Metropolitan Transportation Authority that contended that the competition was biased in favor of Silverite and its partner.
Silverite bid in a joint venture with another company, Frontier-Kemper Constructors of Evansville, Ind. Together, the two companies offered to do the work for $96.96 million. That proposal turned out to be the third lowest among seven bids for the job, court records show.
But the authority was basing its decision on more than price. The tunnel project is one of the most complicated it has undertaken in recent years, requiring a contractor that will do extensive renovations while not crippling the flow of traffic. The authority told the bidders that they had to prove that they had successfully completed a similarly difficult tunnel project to get the one at the Queens-Midtown Tunnel.
On March 11, 1997, the authority sent a letter to the Silverite venture saying that it had not "met the requirements" for prior experience, according to state records.
On March 18, 1997, Silverite and its partner sent a letter to the authority saying that they were "somewhat dismayed," and over the next two months, they repeatedly lobbied authority officials, trying to convince them that they were qualified.
The Silverite venture submitted new evidence that focused on Silverite's partner, Frontier-Kemper. They said the venture had the experience because of the work of construction companies in Europe that were connected to Frontier-Kemper through complex ownership arrangements. They cited the experience of the European companies even though those companies themselves were not bidding on the Queens-Midtown Tunnel project.
In May, the authority reversed itself and accepted Silverite's position. At the same time, the low bidder dropped out, and the authority disqualified the second-lowest bidder for lacking experience. That bidder -- a joint venture of Tap Electrical Contracting Service and Loduca Associates -- had offered to do the job for $83.92 million, $13.04 million less than the Silverite venture.
With those two bidders out, the authority awarded Silverite the contract. The fourth-lowest bidder, Grow Tunneling, which had bid $97.81 million -- only $850,000 more than Silverite -- protested, saying that the authority should not have let Silverite revamp its application and use the European companies to meet the experience requirement.
"Based on the rules, they did not satisfy the requirements and should have been turned down," said Charles E. Williams 3d, a lawyer for Grow Tunneling.
Grow Tunneling and the Tap Electrical venture sued the authority separately. Grow Tunneling said it was the lowest bidder with the proper experience. Tap Electrical said it had been wrongly disqualified, charging that the authority had undertaken a "campaign to improperly award the contract to Silverite."
In June 1997, the two companies asked Justice Charles E. Ramos in State Supreme Court in Manhattan to void the contract immediately. Justice Ramos declined to do so, but said he would rule on whether the bidding had been fair. He has not issued a ruling. The four-year project began in January, and the authority says it is going smoothly.
Donations were not mentioned in the lawsuits, and lawyers for the two losing bidders said last week that they had not known of Mr. Silveri's political activities.
It does not appear that either Grow Tunneling or Tap Electrical donated to the Republicans at any time during the bidding process.
Sayward Mazur, a lawyer for the Silverite venture, said there was not "one scintilla of evidence" to support the charges by the losing bidders. Mr. Mazur said the authority did not violate any rules by letting Silverite rely on the experience of the European companies, which he said would provide expertise.
Asked about contributions linked to Mr. Silveri, Mr. Mazur said, "I am totally not aware that there were any contributions."
The largest single contribution connected to Silverite, $40,000, came from the Old Country PAC, which was established on May 21, 1997, nine days before the contract was awarded, according to state records.
The committee apparently got its name from Silverite's address, 520 Old Country Road in Hicksville, N.Y. The Republicans received the $40,000 from the PAC on June 2, 1997. In the days before that donation, $40,000 had been deposited into the PAC's account -- $10,000 from Mr. Silveri himself and a total of $30,000 from six companies that he controls, each of which gave $5,000.
The Republican State Committee also received donations of $10,000 each from five people connected to Silverite, all on May 28, 1997.
They were Constance Silveri, Mr. Silveri's wife; two executives, Frank Chiodo and Stephen Cody; the wife of a third employee, Theresa Giorgi, and William Doremus, president of the James McCullagh Company, a contractor that has often worked with Silverite and was hired by Silverite to help on the tunnel project.
Ms. Giorgi and Mr. Chiodo did not reply to phone calls seeking comment. Ms. Silveri declined to comment. Mr. Cody and Mr. Doremus said they could not recall details of their contributions.
Two other contributors were Silverite itself and another company controlled by Mr. Silveri, Ontrac Construction. Each gave $5,000, also received on May 28, 1997.
Silverite and Ontrac had previously given $5,000 each to the PAC, so the donations to the Republicans appear to put both companies over the limit. Under state law, corporations can give up to $5,000 annually to all state and local candidates and committees, with few exceptions.
Terry O'Brien, a spokesman for the Republican State Committee, acknowledged the committee's receipt of the donations, but said no one at the committee had called the authority about the contract. "The name of the company just doesn't ring a bell," Mr. O'Brien said.
Mr. Silveri also contributed $1,000 to Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's current re-election campaign on June 24, 1997.
After denying in the interview that donors connected to him had given money to the Republicans, Mr. Silveri conceded that Silverite had set up the PAC. But he declined to say why the company had done so or why it had not included its name in the PAC's title, as is customary.
"I really feel that this is something that I shouldn't be discussing with you," he said. "What's the point of that? Give me a break."
Soon after, Mr. Silveri hung up. He did not respond to three later telephone requests for further comment.

HEADLINE: U.S. and I.M.F. Delay Funds for Indonesia

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 24

 BODY:
The United States and the International Monetary Fund have agreed to delay billions of dollars in aid to Indonesia until President Suharto begins to act on a revised plan for economic reform being negotiated in Jakarta, according to American and I.M.F. officials.
But in an effort to alleviate the food riots that some Indonesians blame on the austerity measures required in the plan, the United States announced today that it would send more than $70 million in emergency food and medical aid. In recent days the United States and the fund have also agreed to allow some Indonesian subsidies on food and fuel to continue, easing the conditions imposed on Jakarta two months ago. 
 Officials said a larger emergency food and medicine program was being coordinated by the World Bank, with major contributions expected by Japan and Australia.
"We want to show that while the only long-term solution is to follow the I.M.F.'s plan, there are humanitarian issues that have to be addressed immediately," said Stuart Eizenstat, the Undersecretary of State for Economic and Business Affairs.
The carrot-and-stick strategy has emerged after lengthy debate over how to handle the potential economic disintegration of the world's fourth most populous nation.
Since the fund put together a $43 billion aid plan in October, Mr. Suharto has resisted many of the steps he had agreed to under two previous plans.
A third agreement is under negotiation that would impose strict budgetary controls and monetary policies on Indonesia and require the dismantling of many cartels.
After lengthy discussions with Mr. Suharto's new economic team, American officials say they now have some hope, in the words of one senior official, "that the Indonesians realize that if they don't commit to the reforms, they simply aren't going to get the money."
But Administration officials say it is still far from clear whether Mr. Suharto will go along with the changes the fund is demanding.
Payment of the next installment of funds has been delayed until the middle of April at the earliest, when the I.M.F. board will review both the agreement and the steps Mr. Suharto has taken to implement it, according to American and fund officials.
"We have had constructive discussions," David Lipton, a senior Treasury official, said today after returning from a week of talks with Mr. Suharto's economic advisers. "But it is a long road to economic recovery."
It is the I.M.F. that has been conducting talks with Indonesia, and it is the I.M.F. that will decide when the Indonesians have done enough to earn the next aid installment. But the United States holds a de facto veto over such decisions, and so the talks with Indonesia have been a delicate, three-way dance between Mr. Suharto, economists and top officials from the I.M.F. and American officials in Jakarta and Washington.
In the end the success or failure of the effort comes down to one man: President Suharto, who has repeatedly stated his willingness to work with the fund, and repeatedly undercut his commitments to break up monopolies run by his friends and deferred tough austerity measures.
"He is going to have to do the kinds of things that give people the sense that he is taking ownership of the reforms, the way the South Koreans, the Thais and the Mexicans did," Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said in an interview last week. "Only by doing that can he get the confidence of the markets back."
During the Administration's internal debates, Mr. Rubin has generally advocated taking a tough line with Mr. Suharto. He has argued that unless the Indonesian fulfills the reforms he has promised the I.M.F., the fund's credibility will be severely undercut, and other nations may be tempted to back out of politically unpalatable conditions set by the fund.
There is also a political calculation to Mr. Rubin's position: He is trying to convince Congress to approve $18 billion in additional funds to the I.M.F. to handle future economic crises. While the Senate appears ready to approve the money, a major fight looms in the House, where many Republicans and some Democrats have complained that the fund is not doing enough to deal with the corruption and crony capitalism that have become part of Mr. Suharto's hold on power.
There are some signs that the Indonesians are begining to act. The Government has dropped a plan for a currency board, a money-management technique to raise the value of the rupiah that the I.M.F. and the United States warned could sink the economy.
And though Indonesia announced a tax on most purchases of hard currency on Friday, the Government reversed itself on Monday after fund officials warned that the move would scare off foreign investors.
But there is mounting evidence that the country is running low on foreign currency reserves, the cushion that has allowed it to buy food abroad and keep the rupiah from falling even further. The current level of reserves is a closely guarded secret, but it appears to be less than $16 billion, and some put the figure at closer to $10 billion to $13 billion.
And hyperinflation is beginning to set in. One issue under negotiation is a move by Indonesia to stop printing money at the current furious pace to meet its obligations.
"It's conceivable they could simply run out of cash in a hurry," said Steve Radelet, an Indonesia expert at the Harvard Institute for International Development. "If they run out of reserves, if food prices continue to rise, if the drought intensifies, the pressure grows on the army to do something."
For the first time, the I.M.F. is dealing with the huge foreign debts owed by Indonesian companies, totaling more than $70 billion. Virtually all payments have halted, but the first two reform plans avoided the subject of working out a repayment plan with creditors, a prerequisite for convincing foreigners to make new loans.
American and I.M.F. officials have concluded, however, that they moved too hastily in insisting on breaking up food monopolies and ending subsidies on essentials like fuel. While the subsidies are expensive, they may be the only way to keep social unrest from seizing the country. The food monopoly also controls the distribution system.
"The trick," one I.M.F. offiical said, "is to phase them out more slowly."
Alexander Downer, Australia's Foreign Minister, who was in Washington last week to deal with the Indonesia crisis, said: "It's a very fine line we must walk. If you weaken the I.M.F. accord too much, the markets will not respond. If you press Suharto too much, he won't implement the program."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Indonesia, once a rice exporter, now must import rice, with this shipment arriving on Monday from Vietnam. Though the United States plans modest food aid for Indonesia, larger financial credits are being delayed. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Former Chief of Carpenters' Union Convicted of Stealing Funds

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB 

 BODY:
Frederick W. Devine, who campaigned against corruption to become one of the state's most powerful construction union leaders in the early 1990's, was convicted yesterday in Manhattan on charges that he stole more than $50,000 from a fund earmarked to create jobs for unemployed carpenters.
He was found guilty by a jury of siphoning the money to pay for lavish winter vacations in Florida from 1993 to 1996 for himself, his wife, his relatives, a female companion and some of his friends. He was also convicted of using the fund to cover the cost of using a private jet twice to visit another female companion in Rochester. 
 The president of the 25,000-member District Council of Carpenters and Joiners in New York City and Vicinity from 1991 to 1996, Mr. Devine showed no emotion as the jury announced that it had found him guilty of six counts of grand larceny and acquitted him of two grand larceny counts and one count of conspiring to defraud the fund.
During his five years as the head of the nation's largest regional carpenters' union, Mr. Devine -- with a salary of $410,000 a year -- was courted by political candidates who sought his union's endorsement and financial support.
Mr. Devine, 58, faces a maximum prison term of 15 years. He was freed without bail, pending motions by his lawyers to overturn the conviction.
The verdict came after a three-week trial in State Supreme Court in Manhattan and was viewed by labor experts as a major triumph for prosecutors in the Manhattan District Attorney's office, who spent two years on the case.
"This is a significant victory against labor corruption," said James F. McNamara, the research director of the Association for Union Democracy, a group that monitors union activities. "Without informing his members, Devine used their money to create a slush fund for his personal use and glorification."
Paul A. Victor, Mr. Devine's chief lawyer, said he would ask the acting State Supreme Court Justice, Colleen McMahon, who presided at the trial, to set aside the guilty verdicts on the grounds of insufficient evidence and that there was no proof of criminal intent by Mr. Devine.
A grand jury indictment in 1996 accused Mr. Devine of misappropriating more than $200,000, but yesterday's verdicts left unclear how much the jury believed he had actually stolen. The jury found him guilty of one "C" felony count of grand larceny, which specifies a theft of more than $50,000. The five other guilty verdicts were for "D" felony counts, for thefts of amounts from $3,000 to $50,000 each.
Mr. Devine began working in a carpenters' local as a teen-ager, repairing and building docks and foundations for skyscrapers. Over the next 40 years, he battled for union posts saying he would extend democratic rights to rank-and-file members. In 1991, he ran for president of the District Council of Carpenters and Joiners, portraying himself as a reform candidate who would end corrupt practices in the union. He was elected, and then re-elected in 1995.
In June 1996, Mr. Devine was abruptly ousted from his posts by officials of the national carpenters' union who cited complaints by members of excessive spending and assertions by a court-appointed monitor that he had helped mobsters and their relatives get jobs at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.
The criminal accusations stemmed from expenditures that he authorized from 1993 to 1996 as the district council's president and as the administrator of a regional Labor-Management Cooperation Trust Fund that was established to create union jobs in the city, the northern suburbs and on Long Island.
Michael Bixon, the lead prosecutor, cited the testimony of witnesses and a paper trail of financial records to argue that Mr. Devine's authorized improper payments for himself and others for hotel suites in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., limousine rentals, massages, beauty parlor visits and golf parties. Mr. Bixon said that Mr. Devine spent about $9,000 for two private plane trips in 1993 and in 1994 to Rochester to visit a female union official with whom he was having a romantic relationship.
Mr. Victor, the defense lawyer, contended that Mr. Devine and his associates went to Florida for annual conferences with other union officials. Mr. Victor said that Raymond O'Kane, a former top aide to Mr. Devine, was responsible for the misappropriations. Questioning Mr. O'Kane's credibility as the prosecution's star witness, Mr. Victor said that Mr. O'Kane brokered a lenient plea deal with prosecutors in 1996 after learning that he was being investigated for misusing union funds.
Mr. Victor, in his closing argument, said Mr. Devine's trips to Rochester were for legitimate purposes, not for romantic trysts.
"Prosecutors should stay out of the bedrooms and not prosecute sin," Mr. Victor told the jury. "That's God's jurisdiction."

HEADLINE: Piece of Penn Station's Past Is Found in Salvage

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
Maybe it was the sunflower behind her ear. Or the silky folds of her robe. Or the gentle waves in her hair.
Whatever it was, the five-foot chunk of stone that arrived on a truck at the Bronx yard of the Con-Agg Recycling Corporation four years ago didn't look like typical salvage. So the workers set it aside. 
 Not much further thought was given to the piece until last month, when a photograph appeared in The New York Times of an allegorical figure from the old Pennsylvania Station. The building was adorned with eight such figures, four of "Day" and four of "Night," by Adolph A. Weinman. Only five had been accounted for since the station was razed in the 1960's.
Although the fragment of Knoxville marble at Con-Agg was missing its face, the sunflower clearly matched that shown in The Times.
A new "Day" had dawned in a stone-crushing plant at East 149th Street and Bruckner Boulevard. And yesterday, Con-Agg called officials of the Pennsylvania Station Redevelopment Corporation to let them know.
"This is our winged victory," declared Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the corporation, when he learned of the discovery. "And it could have been someone's patio."
Mr. Gargano, who is also New York State's chief of economic development, has more than an archeological interest in the statuary. The redevelopment agency hopes to incorporate as many original architectural details as can be salvaged from the old Pennsylvania Station into a grand new passenger concourse and ticketing hall that it is planning within the General Post Office on Eighth Avenue, directly over the Amtrak passenger platforms.
Actually, "Day" was in no danger of paving a patio, or even a highway or sidewalk, for which Con-Agg provides varying grades of recycled concrete.
"They did understand that it was a statue that was appealing and attractive, and on that basis they put it aside," said Charles R. Foy of Whitman Breed Abbott & Morgan, a lawyer for Con-Agg. He said it would be extremely difficult now to trace where the piece came from.
"Their basic motivation was to insure that the statue finds its way back to the proper place," Mr. Foy said, "which will hopefully be the new Penn Station."
New York State officials also hope to incorporate in the new station one figure from a "Day" and "Night" pair that is now in Ringwood State Park in Passaic County, N.J. Another pair is in Kansas City, Mo. And a lone "Night" can be found at the Brooklyn Museum. Perhaps it is the partner of the Bronx "Day."
"It is one of the most significant finds we could hope for," said Alexandros E. Washburn, president of the redevelopment corporation, who has been known to don hip waders and slog through the bogs of the Meadowlands, where parts of Pennsylvania Station were dumped as landfill, in search of artifacts.

GRAPHIC: Photos: A sculpture of "Day," one of eight figures from the old Pennsylvania Station, was recently recognized at a Bronx salvaging company. New York officials hope to incorporate it into a new Pennsylvania Station. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times); Another "Day" sculpture from the old Pennsylvania Station was discovered 30 years ago in a New Jersey landfill. (Eddie Hausner/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN AFRICA: THE REGION;
A New Model for Africa: Good Leaders Above All

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: KAMPALA, Uganda, March 24

 BODY:
When President Clinton walks into a conference with East African leaders here on Wednesday afternoon, he will do what American Presidents usually do in the third world. He will preach the virtues of free markets, democracy and civil liberties.
But Mr. Clinton's decision to hold the conference in Uganda has already sent another strong signal: that the United States is embracing a new generation of leaders in the region who care less about establishing full-fledged democracies than they do about developing their countries. 
 The unofficial standard-bearer for this group is Yoweri K. Museveni, a former guerrilla who rescued this Central African country from political chaos and economic collapse but does not allow party politics. The others in the group include the Presidents of Eritrea, Ethiopia, Rwanda and Congo, the former Zaire.
These leaders say they want more trade and investment from the United States, but they do not want to be told how to govern. Nor do they wish to be chastised for delaying democratic reforms. And while American officials maintain they are still advocating democracy, they acknowledge that their overriding goal in the region is to support leaders who not only manage their governments well but also can somehow staunch the seemingly endless rebellions, famines, refugee crises and economic disasters that have cost the West billions to fix over the years.
From this perspective, Mr. Museveni is a model leader. His style of self-reliant government, fiscal discipline and free-market economics has made him the darling of United States diplomats, who are trying to remold America's role in Africa to replace costly and paternalistic aid programs with more trade and investment.
"You have a new type of leadership, particularly on the economy, and he has more of a regional vision," an American diplomat said. "You're looking at a group of people who find African solutions to African problems." But the American support in recent years for Mr. Museveni and the others in this generation has opened up the United States to charges of double standards from older allies, especially Kenya.
A staunch ally of America during the cold war, Kenya has a much more advanced democracy than Uganda. Still, Washington has battered President Daniel arap Moi recently because he has done a poor job managing the economy and has not cleaned up the rampant official corruption. This has put questions in the minds of some East Africans about how deep America's professed commitment to encouraging democracy runs. Indeed, most of the countries to which the United States has moved closer in recent years -- Uganda, Ethiopia, Eritrea and Rwanda -- have yet to set up bona fide pluralistic political systems.
Worse, some of these new American allies, notably Rwanda and Congo, have checkered records on human rights. The Rwandan Army has been accused of massacring Hutu civilians during counterinsurgency operations against rebel groups. Congo's new Government has jailed opposition leaders and held dozens of summary executions after military trials.
Finally, while Uganda itself has experienced its longest period of peace and economic development in decades, the region as a whole is far from peaceful. One reason for this is that Mr. Museveni and the other leaders in this group have not been shy about supporting armed rebellions in neighboring countries.
The war in southern Sudan is entering its 15th year with no sign of abating, partly because recent rebel advances have been helped along by Uganda, Ethiopia and Eritrea. In Rwanda and Burundi, civil wars between the Hutu majority and Tutsi minority, which in a sense were touched off when Uganda-backed Tutsi rebels invaded Rwanda in 1990, continue to take hundreds of lives a week.
Here in Uganda, a terrorist campaign by Christian fundamentalist rebels in the north has also persisted with heavy Sudanese support. In eastern Congo, the self-proclaimed President, Laurent Kabila, who came to power last year with Ugandan and Rwandan support, is facing new uprisings from rebel movements allied with Hutu insurgents in Rwanda and Burundi. Somalia remains a fractured mess of warring clans with no central government.
Even in Kenya political and tribal tensions have remained high since the re-election of President Moi in January.
It is against this backdrop that Mr. Clinton will meet with these heads of state at Entebbe on Wednesday afternoon. Neither the Burundi military leader, Pierre Buyoya, nor the Sudanese President, Omar el-Bashir, are invited. Nor will there be any Somali representatives. As a result, little progress on solving the region's many conflicts can be expected.
Still, most American policy-makers see Mr. Museveni and the others in the new generation as the best hope for East Africa's future. They argue that these leaders have supported insurrections in other countries only when they would create greater stability in the long run.
Also underlying the new American policy is a desire to work with leaders who will not plunder what foreign aid they do receive and will manage their governments well, taking care of basic services, diplomats said.
As long as these African leaders, like Mr. Museveni, make some headway toward democracy, or show a willingness to keep working toward it, America can live with them, American officials said.
"It's not that we have a double standard," a United States Government official said. "It's that we have varying standards based on historical context."
But there is another reason for the United States' stance. With the cold war won, Islamic fundamentalism has become the new perceived threat to American interests in the region, and the Islamic Government in Sudan has been harboring Muslim terrorists and financing rebel movements throughout the region.
By backing Uganda, Ethiopia and Eritrea, the United States has isolated the Sudan. All three countries are now receiving American military aid and are in turn helping rebels in southern Sudan.
But for better or worse, the leaders Mr. Clinton will meet with here are not likely to take orders from him. They are too independent for that, diplomats said.
"It has to be recognized that we are not dictating the shape of things out here," a Western diplomat said. "We are increasingly being forced to work with the situation on the ground."

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN AFRICA: THE OVERVIEW;
IN UGANDA, CLINTON EXPRESSES REGRET ON SLAVERY IN U.S.

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: MUKONO, Uganda, March 24

 BODY:
President Clinton expressed regret today for the role of the United States in African slavery, as he reeled off a list of errors in American policy toward this continent that included turning to ruthless dictators as allies during the cold war.
Mr. Clinton has been under some pressure at home to issue a formal apology for slavery, but he stopped well short of such an explicit statement. 
 "Going back to the time before we were even a nation, European-Americans received the fruits of the slave trade and we were wrong in that," he said in what his aides called an impromptu remark, which strayed into a political territory that the White House has been trying to avoid.
The President's remarks seemed addressed as much to his audience back home as to those who heard him speak today in Uganda. Although some slaves were taken from this region, West Africa was the real center of the slave trade in the 18th and 19th centuries.
In raising the subject of slavery on what the White House is billing as the most ambitious African tour ever undertaken by an American President, Mr. Clinton chose to elevate an issue that he has largely avoided, except when questioned by reporters.
He made his comment while speaking before more than a thousand children in a meadow by a school in this rural hamlet. Under a brilliant sun, the President and Hillary Rodham Clinton toured the school, then sat as the children danced and sang before briefly joining in the dancing themselves, bouncing and swaying to the drums, the rattles and the bright, high voices.
In his 13-minute speech, Mr. Clinton gave the children a brief history lesson. "It is as well not to dwell too much on the past," he said, "but I think it is worth pointing out that the United States has not always done the right thing by Africa."
Uganda suffered during the 1970's under the brutal regime of Idi Amin, who ruled for years unchallenged by the United States. Without referring specifically to Uganda or any other country, Mr. Clinton said today that during the cold war, "very often we dealt with countries in Africa and in other parts of the world based more on how they stood in the struggle between the United States and the Soviet Union than how they stood in the struggle for their own people's aspirations to live up to the fullest of their God-given abilities."
But in keeping with the themes of his trip, Mr. Clinton went on to say that "perhaps the worst sin America ever committed about Africa was the sin of neglect and ignorance."
While trying to encourage democracy and open markets, Mr. Clinton is also trying to alert Americans to hopeful changes in Africa and to direct more investment here. "I came here to listen and to learn," Mr. Clinton said, "to offer my help and friendship and partnership."
Administration officials criticized reporters this evening for focusing on the President's remarks about history, saying Mr. Clinton's purpose in Africa was to envision the future, not exhume the past.
Mr. Clinton, who has been trying to encourage Americans to discuss race for the last nine months, appointed a commission that has been traveling the country for a series of public discussions on the issue.
But he has tried to prevent that discussion from dwelling on slavery and its legacies, an issue that created a small political storm when Mr. Clinton created the commission.
At the time, Representative Tony P. Hall, Democrat of Ohio, called for an official Government apology to Americans whose ancestors were slaves. The idea gained some currency when Mr. Clinton did not quickly rule it out as a goal of the commission.
He later did so, after some of his political advisers argued that an official apology, while seemingly uncontroversial more than a century after slavery was outlawed in the United States, would have run the risk of reigniting tensions over the issue. In the view of some analysts, it also might have needlessly angered some centrist white voters who have been dependable supporters of Mr. Clinton.
Moreover, an official apology for slavery never received a push from the Congressional Black Caucus or from major civil rights organizations, which have considered the issue less important than other matters on their policy agenda.
Calling Mr. Clinton's comment on slavery "statement enough on that matter," the Rev. Jesse Jackson, Mr. Clinton's special envoy to Africa, said, "The question is where shall we go from here?"
But Mr. Jackson, speaking at press briefing tonight arranged by the White House, nevertheless provided a lengthy description of how slavery had operated for centuries as an African subsidy to the American economy.
On his visit here, Mr. Clinton tried today to highlight the efforts of President Yoweri K. Museveni to expand Uganda's economy and educate its people. In addition to speaking here, Mr. Clinton met with Mr. Museveni and later joined Mrs. Clinton to tour another village, Wanyange, to spotlight a lending program that provides small amounts of credit to poor women.
Mr. Clinton, who is clearly relishing the enthusiastic crowds he has encountered in Africa, posed in the village with a 2-day-old baby named Bill Clinton, the son of Betty Namugosa, a shopkeeper. "Look at all this hair!" the President said. "I was completely bald until I was 2."
The infant yawned, and Mr. Clinton pronounced him "the smartest person here."
When reporters touring the village with Mr. Clinton asked if he was invoking executive privilege in the Lewinsky matter, Mr. and Mrs. Clinton ignored the question. President Museveni called after them, saying, "They're asking a question" -- to no avail.
Mr. Clinton had no audience today like the several hundred thousand he addressed in Ghana on Monday. For this portion of the trip, the White House arranged for more intimate speeches in rural settings. The children in Mukono had rehearsed specially written songs for Mr. Clinton, in which they praised Mr. Museveni's education initiatives.
"Universal primary education benefits the majority," they sang in one song, while noting in another that Mr. Museveni's signature program was short on resources. "Mishandling funds, misinterpretation, shortage of classrooms and teachers prevent U.P.E. from flourishing," they sang.
The Kisowera Primary School, which Mr. Clinton visited, crams 760 students into 10 rooms, with 14 teachers in all. There is no electricity, and there are no panes in the windows. Several students from Kisowera and nearby schools said they had never seen a computer, but Mr. Clinton envisioned in his speech a future in which they would communicate with American students on the Internet.
Mr. Clinton announced today that he would seek to spend $120 million in the next two years to improve the quality of African education, through community resource centers, partnerships between African and American schools and programs focused on educating girls, who are often left out when officials plan for schooling.
He also announced another two-year initiative, this one for $61 million, to improve farming techniques and food distribution.
On Wednesday, Mr. Clinton plans to fly to Kigali, Rwanda, for an airport appearance to deplore the violence in that country. White House aides said Mr. Clinton would declare that the world community should have responded sooner to the Rwandan mass killings in 1994, without naming any countries, including the United States.
Then Mr. Clinton is to return here for a meeting of Central and East African leaders before flying on to South Africa on Wednesday night.

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN AFRICA: THE RWANDANS;
Why Washington and the World Largely Failed to Act to Head Off the Blood Bath

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
Nearly four years ago, Rwanda and its neighbors dissolved into genocidal violence, and today President Clinton is expected to say the world should have responded sooner to head off the killings.
Hundreds of thousands of Rwandans and others perished in the ethnic conflict. It is still not over. 
 Tragically for the people of Rwanda, both Hutu and Tutsi, their moment of greatest peril occurred too close to the United States debacle in Somalia, in which 18 American soldiers died, setting off a political storm in Washington.
At the time, the Clinton Administration was concerned that there was no clear strategy, viable goal or exit plan for a military mission in Rwanda. It was also divided over how to respond to fast-moving events, with Madeleine K. Albright, then the American representative at the United Nations, arguing for some kind of international response, and the Pentagon and White House opposing any United Nations peacekeeping force.
Ms. Albright ultimately prevailed, but the force created was a very small one of only 270 troops. She has since said repeatedly -- most recently in December on a visit to Africa as Secretary of State -- that the United States and other Western nations did too little too late in Rwanda.
A senior United Nations official said this week that Washington had been "absolutely paralyzed by Somalia." Other nations, already mired in Bosnia, were also reluctant to intervene in the small Central African country.
"The Security Council was traumatized by what had happened," a European diplomat recalled, "but Washington was more traumatized than the others."
Mr. Clinton is not expected to name any country today for a failure to act, but diplomats involved in the United Nations debate in 1994 say they now doubt, despite all the praise and promises of economic assistance for Africa now, that Washington would join or support a peacekeeping operation if a similar crisis arose.
Rwanda descended into genocide in 1994 after years of ethnic tensions. A guerrilla army, the Rwandese Patriotic Front, had been attacking from Uganda. In August 1993, an agreement between the country's minority Tutsi, represented by the front, and the Hutu majority promised to end the ethnic war and introduce a power-sharing system.
By the fall of that year, the Rwanda agreement was already in danger, and the United Nations sent a peacekeeping mission to the country. But early in 1994, the United Nations commander in Kigali warned that Hutu militias were plotting to kill large numbers of Tutsi.
The Security Council, with the United States as its most powerful member, did not act. On April 6 and in the weeks that followed, those Hutu plans were put into horrific effect. The trigger was a plane crash, which many believe to have been an act of sabotage, that killed Rwanda's Hutu President, Juvenal Habyarimana, along with the President of Burundi, Cyprien Ntaryamira.
Among those who died in the rampage that followed were 10 Belgian peacekeepers guarding the Prime Minister, Agathe Uwilingiyimana. The peacekeepers had laid down their arms only to be butchered, as she was. Belgium decided to withdraw all its troops. On April 21, the Security Council dramatically cut the peacekeeping force to a bare 270 soldiers. Meanwhile, tens of thousands of Tutsi were trying to flee the country to Tanzania as their communities -- and those of Hutu opposed to the massacres -- were decimated.
Kenneth Roth, executive director of Human Rights Watch, called the Security Council action at the time "a thin veil over another massacre."
Late in April and into May, as the toll of massacred Tutsi mounted into the hundreds of thousands, Bourtos Boutros-Ghali, the Secretary General of the United Nations, went repeatedly to the Security Council to ask for a credible force for Rwanda.
When the Council finally agreed to a force of 5,500, the United States and other Western nations balked, and Washington forced the United Nations to delay sending any soldiers until there were moves toward an end to the violence.
Mr. Boutros-Ghali, trying vainly to recruit Africans or anyone else for a force, called the situation "a scandal." Eventually, Ghana, Ethiopia and Senegal volunteered.
Events then moved beyond the Security Council. As the Tutsi-led guerrillas of the Rwandese Patriotic Front began a march of conquest across Rwanda, France decided to field a force, which established sanctuaries in southwestern Rwanda, largely for Hutu fleeing the R.P.F.
Many more Hutu chose flight. By mid-July 1.5 million refugees had entered what was then Zaire, which is now Congo.
Again the United Nations asked the Security Council for help. Although Washington was prepared to provide some relief aid, the Administration turned a deaf ear to pleas from Sadako Ogata, High Commissioner for Refugees, for a force in the camps to separate out Hutu leaders who had committed acts of genocide and who would no doubt rearm for a return to Rwanda.
"We asked for help in getting those people out of the camps," Mrs. Ogata told an audience at the Holocaust Museum in Washington last year. "No country offered to get help. My staff had to continue feeding criminals as the price for feeding hundreds of thousands of innocent women and children."
The rearming took place as predicted. By late 1996, when the pro-Tutsi forces of Laurent Kabila, now Congo's President, were emptying the camps of Hutu and forcing them back into Rwanda, a Canadian-led mission to provide security for the displaced was only reluctantly supported and then in effect undermined by the United States.
Tens of thousands of Rwandans are still missing, Mrs. Ogata said recently. She believes that they perished in the absence of a protection force. Mr. Kabila's Government, now being wooed by the United States, is blocking investigations into reports of massacres by victorious Tutsis or their supporters among his troops.
To bring the story full circle, Hutu gangs are now killing Tutsi again in remote areas of Rwanda, and Hutu in turn are being attacked by Rwandan Government troops.

Aid to Indonesia Delayed, But U.S. Sends In Food

HEADLINE: Patients' Lives on the Line In Battle Over Transplants

BYLINE: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 24

 BODY:
For two years and one month, Mindy Ervin has waited in uneasy limbo for a new liver. Too well to be ushered to the top of the transplant list, yet so sick that she has already planned her own funeral, she spends her days in bed, hoping the telephone will ring with news of an available organ.
A former nurse who suffers a rare autoimmune disease, Mrs. Ervin, of Portsmouth, R.I., lives in the region with the nation's longest wait for livers. She cannot have her transplant in Florida, where waiting times are shorter; her insurance company will not permit it. Five weeks ago, she endured a devastating false alarm. She dashed to the New England Medical Center in Boston for the long-awaited operation, only to learn that the donated organ was unsuitable. 
 "I told my husband, 'This is not living,' " said Mrs. Ervin, adding that she no longer expects to see her 37th birthday, which is in July. "I'm just existing, waiting for it to happen, and nobody can tell me if it is going to happen. Emotionally, I don't know how much longer I can hang on."
Now the Ervins must contend with an additional uncertainty: The Clinton Administration is about to dismantle the regional system for distributing donated organs and replace it with a national list in which the sickest patients would get priority. In a recent letter to 89 members of Congress, Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, sketched her proposal, saying the change would even out waiting times and insure that very sick people do not die waiting while those who are less acutely ill receive transplants.
But Dr. Shalala's plan, which is expected to be made an official Federal regulation this month, has done little to ease the minds of patients like Mrs. Ervin and even less to settle the Solomon-like debate about how organs -- and in particular livers, which are in extremely short supply -- should be distributed. Rather, it has exposed a nasty political and economic fight between large and small transplant centers, each vying for its share of the lucrative transplant business, in which an operation can cost $250,000.
Surgeons who trained side-by-side are accusing one another of putting money ahead of patients' interests. The fight is so venomous that Dr. John Fung, chief of liver transplant surgery at the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center and an outspoken opponent of the current system, complained that he has been "blackballed from administrative positions" in scientific societies by doctors who disagreed with him.
Small transplant centers, fearing that a national list could put them out of business, have argued that a national list would concentrate organs in big cities, hurting poor patients who do not have the means to travel. Big hospitals have complained that their smaller counterparts are trying to hoard organs for patients who are not desperate.
In Washington, the lobbying is intense. The Pittsburgh hospital, which pioneered liver transplants, has hired a Little Rock, Ark., lawyer who also represents President Clinton to press its case that the regional system should be scrapped. A coalition of mid-size medical centers, including Vanderbilt University and a doctors' group from the Medical University of South Carolina, is fighting back with its own lobbyists.
"I wish we were having an open-ended debate about what's fair," lamented Dr. Arthur L. Caplan, a bioethicist and the author of "Am I My Brother's Keeper" (Indiana University Press, 1998), a book about transplants. "Unfortunately, what I suspect we are seeing is a political squabble among transplant centers about what's in their interest."
Many Patients Baffled
By Proposed Changes
Caught in the middle of this fracas are patients like Mindy Ervin, who said she has no idea how the rules would affect her. With more than 10,000 people waiting for a liver and only 4,000 livers available each year, she noted, "some of us are going to die." The question that is dividing transplant surgeons and patients is what system will make the best use of organs and save the most lives.
"It's among the thorniest issues I've dealt with here," said one official at the Health and Human Services Department who is involved with the proposed rules and who spoke on condition of anonymity. "A lot of things we do involve people's lives, but changing the system of distributing organs alters who lives and who dies, or how long you live and when you die."
While a sickest-first national policy might seem to make the most sense, some experts, including Dr. Caplan, said it might not be the best use of organs. Sicker people are more likely to die after their transplants, or to need second and even third transplants. The problem is especially acute with liver patients; unlike people in kidney failure, they cannot be kept alive through dialysis or other medical means.
"It's as if we were in a lifeboat," Dr. Caplan said, "and instead of trying to figure out how many of us might survive a shortage of food and water, we said, 'Let's pick the people who are closest to dead and save them.' "
At the same time, projections of how the new policy would affect patients conflict. An analysis performed for the Pittsburgh hospital by Consad Research Corporation found that Dr. Shalala's proposal would save as many a 200 lives a year by offering organs to people who would not otherwise get them.
But a competing study by the United Network for Organ Sharing, the nonprofit organization that runs the distribution system, found that Dr. Shalala's plan would result in 761 additional repeat transplants each year, and that the overall survival rate after transplants would drop to 68 percent from 75 percent.
"Do we want to transplant the sickest patients first, or the most people possible?" asked Walter Graham, the network's director who favors the current system. "Those are two conflicting objectives. Our answer is that you want to do both, but you can't do both."
So vexing is this issue that the effort to draft new rules has languished in the bureaucracy since 1989, five years after the passage of the National Organ Transplant Act. The law spawned the organ sharing network, a collection of 63 independent organizations that procure organs in their local areas and assign them to hospitals.
The network's distribution plan works this way: Patients are given a rank of one, two or three, depending on the severity of their illness. When an organ becomes available, it is offered to people in the area, starting with the sickest. If there are no local patients, the organ is offered regionally, then nationally.
But donation patterns, as well as waiting lists, vary greatly throughout the nation's 11 regions. In New England, for instance, the wait for a liver is roughly two years, five times as long as in the Southeast.
In 1996, Dr. Shalala noted in her letter, more than half the livers used locally were given to patients who were well enough to be at home. Yet that same year, nearly 400 of the 953 patients who died while awaiting transplants died in the hospital.
With competition for organs fierce, many patients "game the system," said Dr. Caplan, the bioethicist. Some sign up at more than one transplant center, which is permitted under the network rules. Others switch to a hospital where the wait is short.
That is not an option for Mrs. Ervin, whose husband works in a boat yard painting yachts. "People tell us, 'List down in Florida, the wait is shorter,' " Michael Ervin said, "But we don't have the money, and our insurance won't pay for it."
 Mistrust among doctors and patients runs deep. Goldsby Margiotta, a Virginia woman who has been waiting three years for a liver, stopped going to a patient support group when the husband of another transplant candidate began calling her home with prying questions. "He thought I was some kind of interloper trying to get his wife's liver," she said.
To complicate matters, the lists are fluid, with patients' ranks changing constantly depending on their health. "Everybody just thinks you put your name on this big list and when your number comes up they call you," Mrs. Ervin said. "It's not like that at all. People constantly ask me, 'What number are you?' I have no idea."
 
Current Problem Is Testament to Success
The high demand is, in a sense, testimony to the success of transplant medicine, particularly liver transplants. Nearly every liver transplant surgeon in the United States has trained at the University of Pittsburgh, or trained under someone who has. Over the past decade, the Pittsburgh-trained surgeons fanned out across the United States, starting programs at local hospitals.
In 1990, there were an estimated 50 liver transplant programs in the country; today, there are 120. As the number of programs grew, the number of operations done in Pittsburgh fell by more than half, to 230 last year from 569 in 1990, said Dr. Roger Evans, a health policy analyst at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., who studies organ allocation.
"Pittsburgh created its own competition," Dr. Evans said.
In 1991, the organ sharing network made a crucial change in its distribution policy that set the stage for the current dispute. Earlier, patients facing imminent death had priority for organs, no matter where they lived. When that provision was eliminated, the number of patients dying on Pittsburgh's waiting list ballooned, said Dr. Fung, the hospital's liver transplant chief.
In 1993, after pressing unsuccessfully for the organ network to rescind the rule change, Pittsburgh officials turned to the Government, which by that time was considering setting standards for organ allocation. They enlisted David Matter, a Pittsburgh real estate developer and college friend of President Clinton, who said he wrote and talked to the President several times. And Pittsburgh hired a Little Rock lawyer, John R. Tisdale, who said last week that he was encouraged to see Dr. Shalala "leaning in our direction."
Also encouraged were transplant surgeons at the University of California at San Francisco and other large hospitals, including Mount Sinai Medical Medical Center in New York. Dr. Charles Miller, Mount Sinai's director of transplantation, said the current system was so Balkanized that a patient in his intensive care unit might be denied a liver that goes to someone waiting at home in Fort Lee, N.J., just across the Hudson River.
 
Organ Network Favors Existing Regional Plan
But officials of the organ sharing network are not going to abandon their policy without a fight. They have hired their own lobbyist and hinted at a lawsuit, saying the Government has no right to impose rules.
"Where does all this come from?" asked Mr. Graham, the executive director. "The only answer I can come up with is that it came as a result of political influence."
Mr. Graham contends the current system encourages organ donation, because donors want to know that their organs will help their neighbors, a view Dr. Miller describes as "beyond bunk."
But doctors from smaller transplant centers agree with Mr. Graham. They say liver transplant candidates are dying across the country and that replacing the regional system will simply change where people die.
"This national sharing plan is not going to bring organs to Cincinnati," said Dr. Douglas Hanto, director of the adult liver transplant program at the University of Cincinnati. "Livers will be taken from Ohio and sent to Pittsburgh. I think Pittsburgh is just flat out very interested in their own program."
To which Dr. Fung, the Pittsburgh surgeon, retorted: "Call Doug Hanto back. Ask him what I did for him three or four years ago when he had a very sick patient in Ohio. Ask him if I sent him a liver from Pittsburgh."
As the debate rages, Congress is considering jumping in. Senator Bill Frist, a Tennessee Republican and heart surgeon who practiced at Vanderbilt University, said he would consider holding hearings once the final regulations are announced.
"The Secretary cannot play doctor," Dr. Frist said.
For her part, Dr. Shalala said in her letter that she did not intend to "interfere in the practice of medicine"; she simply expects the organ sharing network to devise new rules to meet the Government's standards.
As for patients, they can do little more than wait. Mrs. Ervin's surgeon, Dr. Richard Rohrer, chief of the division of transplant surgery at New England Medical Center, is optimistic about her prospects.
But his patient is frightened and feels herself getting weaker. She is nauseated, jaundiced and rarely goes out. The weeks since her false alarm have been especially tough.
"I hope I get the call again," she said. "But I hope it comes before I'm so ill that I won't be able to survive the surgery. That's my biggest fear. Will it come soon enough?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael and Mindy Ervin of Portsmouth, R.I., are waiting to find out how a new transplant policy could affect her chances of receiving a liver. (Rick Friedman for The New York Times)(pg. A18)

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 516 words

HEADLINE: Amending Tobacco's Sweet Deal

 BODY:
The tobacco industry is waging a fierce campaign to win Congressional approval for the agreement it reached with 40 state attorneys general last summer. The industry's desperate pitch is a good indication that the settlement is good for the tobacco industry and not good for everyone else. The deal would give the industry what it desires most -- protection from future class-action lawsuits and other legal shields, with relatively little impact on future profits. Senator John McCain, chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee, now has the tough job of producing better tobacco legislation that can meet public health goals, give the states their expected payoff and persuade the industry to accept voluntary advertising controls.
A bipartisan plan sponsored by Senators Bob Graham, John Chafee and Tom Harkin has already won favorable reviews from President Clinton and public health experts such as former Surgeon General C. Everett Koop. It contains many crucial elements that must be included in any legislation that reaches the Senate floor. 
 Public health experts have long argued that raising cigarette prices is absolutely necessary to curb teen-age smoking. The Graham plan would extract roughly $25 billion a year out of the industry, or $630 billion over 25 years -- raising the price of a pack of cigarettes by $1.50 over the next two years, an amount most health economists believe would make a significant reduction in youth consumption. The agreement with the attorneys general, by contrast, would raise the per-pack price by only 62 cents, achieving very little impact on smoking rates.
The Graham proposal is also far stronger in other ways. It would preserve the Food and Drug Administration's full authority to regulate nicotine. It would not grant the industry any immunity against future lawsuits, and would impose stiffer penalties of up to $10 billion a year on the industry if youth smoking rates do not fall by 65 percent over the next 10 years. It would also end outdoor cigarette advertising, ban the use of cartoon characters and other promotional activity.
In exchange, the bill would cap the industry's financial exposure to lawsuits in any given year to $8 billion. The industry would pay $4 billion annually into a separate victims' compensation fund. Money not spent would be rolled over to the next year. This mechanism would give the industry financial predictability, but would not shield it from any liability.
The industry, faced with damaging exposure about its past efforts to sell to teen-age smokers, is on the defensive. But it is by no means an impotent force in Congress. Its power to push through legislation is substantial, particularly since both the White House and the Republican leaders are eagerly eyeing money from any tobacco settlement to pay for their favorite programs. As the Senate takes on tobacco, it must remember that this issue is not about protecting the industry or plugging holes in the Federal budget. The aim here is improving public health, and any legislation has to be measured by that yardstick alone.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
