HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
As the Panthers Lose Money, Their Fans Enrich Huizenga

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
H. Wayne Huizenga cannot make money in the sports business. Or so he has claimed.
As the owner of three of South Florida's four professional sports teams -- football's Miami Dolphins, baseball's Florida Marlins and hockey's Florida Panthers -- Huizenga has spent the last several years insisting that his baseball and hockey franchises are losing money. 
 But like many of the owners of sports franchises who plead poverty, Huizenga has found ways to turn a profit from his teams, no matter what his financial statements have to say about gate receipts and player salaries. Borrowing a page from Ted Turner, Huizenga has used his sports teams to anchor a cable television station. And like Rupert Murdoch, who bought Dodger Stadium along with the Dodgers last week, Huizenga owns Pro Player Stadium, where both the Marlins and the Dolphins play.
But Huizenga, one of America's richest businessmen, has also come up with a new twist on the familiar story of how to turn a supposedly money-losing sports franchise into a financial bonanza: sports team as investment tool.
Capitalizing on his hockey team's 1996 drive to the Stanley Cup finals, Huizenga sold stock in the Florida Panthers to the public. Public enthusiasm persuaded civic leaders in Broward County, Fla., to use public money to build a new stadium for the team. Then, Huizenga used the hockey team's stock as currency to begin building yet another diversified enterprise. The company's first move: to buy two resort hotels owned partly by Huizenga and other Panthers officials, a move that enriched Huizenga, his friends and others who have invested with him.
It has all worked out grandly for Huizenga, whose original investment in Florida Panthers Holdings has nearly tripled in value, to $150 million. But those riches have won Huizenga few fans in South Florida, some of whom rate the maneuvering as a clever but cynical manipulation of loyalty to a local team.
Investors who bought the stock in its first month of trading have done well, but many of those who bought subsequently have, at best, broken even. The Panthers, having traded away some of their top players, including Dave Lowry and Esa Tikkanen, have fallen from the Stanley Cup finals to having the second-worst record in the National Hockey League this year.
Even some profitable investors who got in early have expressed outrage, believing that Huizenga and his friends profited improperly. Three class-action lawsuits seeking damages have been filed by shareholders.
Huizenga, through a spokesman, declined to be interviewed. But J. Ronald Castell, a senior vice president at Florida Panthers Holdings, defended the company's new direction. He said the move into the resort business was not contemplated until Huizenga had come to despair over the stock's failure to rise much above its initial price in the opening days, as usually happens with an initial public offering.
The filings made as part of the stock offering said that the company could acquire other businesses or properties, including some owned by Huizenga or his affiliates. And other Panthers executives note that the purchase of the resorts was approved by "disinterested" members of the company's board of directors and was ruled fair by a Wall Street investment bank.
 
For Team Owners, An Elusive Bottom Line
Those assertions give little comfort to Bernard Kalishman, a 67-year-old Miami resident and Panthers shareholder. Kalishman said he had got caught up in the short-lived hockey mania in 1996, but he is now angry that Huizenga sold stock to hockey fans and then started buying his own hotels.
"It was not an ethical thing to do," said Kalishman, who filed one of the three suits charging that Huizenga and other insiders misled investors, enriched themselves through self-dealing and violated securities laws against insider trading. "Now, he has started to cut the Panthers' payroll, like he did with the Marlins."
Fans have long expressed skepticism when owners say they are losing money on sports teams. They read of lucrative television contracts, then get hit with higher ticket prices. They see teams bought and then resold for double what the owners paid. And this is not the first time such complaints have been voiced against Huizenga.
In fact, fan disgust with owners crying fiscal distress reached its climax last fall when, barely days after Huizenga's Marlins won their first World Series, the club dismantled the team, saying it had to trade away expensive stars -- left fielder Moises Alou and pitcher Kevin Brown among them -- because the team was losing too much money.
Huizenga is not alone in crying financial duress. For one, George Steinbrenner, the owner of the Yankees, has done his share of poor-mouthing over his club's financial performance, eager to get public financing for a new stadium and threatening to move the team otherwise.
But many economists agree that few, if any, sports teams truly lose money for their owners, who typically employ creative accounting and use their other businesses -- like stadium operations or cable television networks -- to make money off the team.
"Unless you buy the argument that a large number of people are willing to pay ever-higher prices for a depreciating asset, you're not looking at folks who are losing money," said Mark Rosentraub, director of the Center for Urban Policy and the Environment at Indiana University.
Because most sports teams are privately held, outsiders are unable to tell much about their financial situation. While a few teams have opened their books in order to sell stock to the public -- the Boston Celtics being the most famous -- none have done so with the panache, or the sense of timing, of the Panthers.
In June 1996, on the eve of the team's first appearance in the Stanley Cup finals, Huizenga announced he would sell 50 percent of the team to the public. The sale was intended in part to help raise support for a new arena: "You buy these stocks because you love the sport or want to be part of owning a team in your local community," Huizenga said in a television interview.
At the time, Wall Street was booming, and stocks of newly public companies typically soared. The buyers of those shares, though, typically would be the corporate pension funds and other institutions that do big business with the Wall Street firms that underwrite stock offerings.
Florida Panthers Holdings was an exception. "The financing was targeted at the loyal fans of the Florida Panthers, and to my knowledge it was sold exclusively to South Florida residents," said Budd Bugatch, a financial analyst at Raymond James & Associates, a Florida-based brokerage firm that led the offering.
Clearly, some of the ordinary buyers were drawn to the company by Huizenga's stunning history of success. In the 1970's, he built Waste Management into the country's largest garbage hauler, and later made Blockbuster Video the nation's biggest video outlet. Most recently, he has built Republic Industries into a giant of auto sales and rentals. Forbes Magazine said last year that Huizenga's accumulated fortune is $1.7 billion.
Panther fans snapped up 2.7 million shares at $10 each, while company insiders bought another 4.6 million at about the same price, together contributing $71.4 million to the new company. With the stock price staying near its offering price, several members of the company's board of directors soon bought an additional 345,000 shares in the open market.
"I've been watching Huizenga's progress through the companies he's owned, and when he came out and decided to build a new stadium for the Panthers, I decided to get on the bandwagon," said Paul Susser, a 76-year-old fan of the Panthers from Plantation, Fla., who bought stock in the offering. "But there was nothing in there saying Huizenga wanted to run a hotel company."
 
A Quick Change Of Direction
But that is the road Huizenga took barely a month after the stock offering, stunning Wall Street by transforming Florida Panthers Holdings into "a diversified leisure time based sports and entertainment company."
To do so, the company announced it would acquire two South Florida resorts, the Hyatt Regency Pier 66 Hotel and Marina and the Radisson Bahia Mar Beach Resort and Yachting Center, issuing 8.4 million new shares of stock, then worth $84 million, to the resorts' owners. Those owners included Huizenga and three other members of the Panthers board of directors, who received 2.4 million, or 28 percent, of the new shares.
The deals, unrelated to the hockey club, sent the price of Panthers stock soaring. But despite the sharp increase, the company did not adjust the number of shares it had offered to exchange for the resorts before the deal closed in March 1997. By ignoring a common practice when acquisitions are paid for with shares of stock, the company ended up paying $225 million for the two resorts, three times the original price.
The big winners in the deal were the Panthers insiders who owned the resorts, and the directors who bought the 345,000 shares of Panthers stock before the announcement of the deals. Three of those insiders also owned part of the resorts; the fourth is Huizenga's brother-in-law, one of the "disinterested" directors who approved the deal.
No Federal or state securities regulators have brought any charges of improper conduct against the Panthers directors. Neither the Securities and Exchange Commission nor the Florida Division of Securities would comment on whether it had been or were investigating the situation, and Panthers officials said they did not know of any inquiries by the authorities.
In the past year, Florida Panthers Holdings has continued to expand its resort business, buying two more Florida resort properties, a South Florida golf course and the Arizona Biltmore, a luxury resort near Phoenix.
Its newly purchased properties have begun to brighten the company's bottom line. In the six months ended Dec. 31, for example, the resorts earned $6.9 million. But the hockey team has continued to lose money -- $7.3 million in the six months ended Dec. 31 -- despite selling out most games.
Despite the team's losses, the market value of Florida Panthers Holdings has increased sixfold since the company went public, to $750 million. The gain is due to the millions of shares of new stock the company issued to make its resort purchases. Traded on the New York Stock Exchange, the company's stock currently trades at about $22, well below its high of $32.50, reached shortly after the first resort purchase was announced.
Perhaps the hockey team can start turning a profit after moving next season. The new arena boasts 4,385 more seats than the Miami Arena, where the Panthers now play, and plenty of the luxury boxes that Huizenga covets. The company will also reap the benefit of managing the arena, which can be used for myriad other events.
Even so, the profits from the hockey and arena-management operations, which now account for only about 10 percent of the company, will be but a blip on the company's financial screen. For Huizenga, little about Florida Panthers Holdings has to do with hockey.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Study Shows Power Savings

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
Electricity users in Connecticut would save hundreds of millions of dollars if lawmakers open the state's electric markets to competition, a study for a business group has showed.
If electric rates are cut 10 percent, the state's 1.4 million residential customers will have an additional $132 million in their pockets each year, said the study for the Connecticut Business and Industry Association, the state's largest business group. 
 The study, released yesterday, said almost all of those savings would be spent on other things, from pizzas to clothes.
There would be similar benefits for industrial and commercial customers, while a failure to pass the bill this year could hurt businesses, said Donald Klepper-Smith, president of DataCore Partners, a Middletown, Conn., market research firm that did the study.
The study estimated that Connecticut could lose 19,000 manufacturing jobs if neighboring states lower their electric rates but Connecticut's remain at their current level -- up to 72 percent higher than the national average.
The study showed that industries could save $46.5 million a year with a 10 percent electric rate cut and that industries would pump nearly half of that savings into the economy.
For commercial customers, $114.9 million could be saved, and that money could be spent to generate $54.6 million for the economy.
A bill that had been before the General Assembly proposed a guaranteed 10 percent rate cut starting in 2000 and continuing for three years. After that, the free market would determine the rates. A legislative committee had replaced the measure with a bill that would start the deregulation process but delay action for another year while the issue is studied. But legislative leaders have said that work on the original bill will continue, and that a final bill will be ready for a vote in April.

HEADLINE: Public Eye;
Sport Utility Toasting

BYLINE: By Phil Patton 

 BODY:
RUGGED, retro, British and expensive, the Dualit professional toaster has a bulldog look. Essentially unchanged for a half century, the Dualit ($359 for the four-slot model, $269 for two slots) resembles a Land Rover -- the original 1948 Land Rover, the one on which Joy Adamson's lions draped themselves. There's the same combination of curves and lines, the same rugged metal surface (though the toaster comes in colors like sea green, yellow and blue as well as chrome) and the same utilitarian shape -- the same look right down to the slotted grill.
Rough country bread is for these toasters what rough country roads are to sport utility vehicles. "I call it the S.U.T. -- the sport utility toaster," said Steve Holt of Frogdesign, a Silicon Valley company that styles toasters for Sunbeam. "You get the same exaggeration of features." 
 Why would anyone need such an appliance?
Americans have ventured beyond the regulation two thin slices of Sunbeam bread in their Sunbeam toasters. Now, American toasting has moved to three and four wide slots at a time. While couples in the 1940's and 50's used to toast at the breakfast table -- the toaster being a tamed version of the hearth -- they now park their toasters on their kitchen counters and eat breakfast there, if they eat breakfast at all. The toast itself includes not only Pop-Tarts but also thick English muffins, wide bagels and great hunks of peasant bread. And when it comes to toast slices, two are never enough.
The Dualit is only the high end of the new generation of high-testosterone, wide-slot toasters. Big chrome Cuisinart four-slicers cost $80, brag of electronic sensors, and protrude from those counter-top kitchen "appliance garages" the way Chevy Suburbans protrude from real garages. Krups offers a wide-slot model, the $50 Sensotoast Deluxe -- the equivalent of the sleek Mercedes M-Class sport utility vehicle. Brenda Cooper, a sales associate at Broadway Panhandler, says that a British model, the Russell Hobbs, $74, has sold well recently. It appeals, she said, to those who like rough-cut slices of fresh bread and bagels.
A decade ago, toaster sales fell. "A toaster oven was the hot new item to have," said Carolyn Scott, an economist and partner in McCoy, Scott & Company, a consulting firm that follows the small-appliance market. "Now," she said, "it might be the three-or-more-slot toaster."
The toasters rated best by Consumer Guide magazine -- the Krups, Cuisinart and Kitchenaid ($120) -- get points for offering seven different settings, perhaps a few more than absolutely necessary. The Krups and the Cuisinart have microprocessors to control doneness. Some toasters boast higher "pop up"; others tout the superiority of their removable crumb trays. All of them toast the toast.
The toaster emerged in the 20's as a symbol of American prosperity and modern domestic life. The design historian Russell Flinchum has said that because toaster technology was largely mature by 1930, the way to distinguish toasters is through looks. So toaster design has been fiddled with almost as much as car design -- and it's hard to come up with anything new. Frogdesign's Sunbeam toaster, which has a little window allowing a peek at the toast, echoes Henry Dreyfuss's "look while you cook" Birtman toaster of 1932.
The prestige of the Dualit is that it conveys an air of European expertise. Just as professional stoves like the Garland became status symbols in the late 70's, Dualits are (more affordable) status symbols today.
But what's the difference between a Dualit (offered exclusively in the United States by Williams-Sonoma) and, say, the $15 Proctor-Silex?
The Dualit is pure utility, and looks it. It comes with a sandwich basket for lowering complex bread constructions into the wide slots. It uses a mechanical timer, and it does not even pop the toast up automatically. Instead, the heating element switches off and the toast remains inside. To release the toast, you flip down a sturdy knob-and-rod device that lifts its toasted cargo with a solid "chunk," reminiscent of the sound of a siege catapult.
A rugged toaster like the Dualit announces that its owner has stepped beyond the vagaries of mere toaster styling. "It looks like the toaster for the ages," Mr. Flinchum said. "The implication is, This is the last toaster you'll ever buy."

HEADLINE: Workers of the World

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Help Unwanted," your March 19 and 21 front-page articles on European unemployment: Germany and France provide generous unemployment benefits, while the majority of their workers enjoy high wages, outstanding health and pension benefits, shorter workweeks and long vacations. The strongest economy in a generation leaves most Americans with stagnant wages, record debt, reduced benefits and longer workweeks. Who's better off?
 
KEITH MELCHERS
Washington, March 23, 1998

HEADLINE: Teen-Age Suicide

 BODY:

To the Editor:
During the 15 years in which suicides among black teen-agers increased dramatically, so has the availability of handguns. Your March 20 front-page article on the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention study omits this essential fact. The study says that "firearm-related suicides account for 96 percent of the increase in the suicide rate among black children and teens." 
 Your article's focus on the theory of black middle-class depression reflecting the strain some families feel in making the transition to middle-class life may hold true in general, but there is no evidence for it in the centers' study, which did not consider the economic status of victims. What we do know is that the availability of handguns in the home increases the risk of suicide fivefold. And to stem the tide of suicides, we need to regulate the availability and accessibility of handguns.
 
ELLEN FREUDENHEIM
LANNY BERMAN
Brooklyn, March 23, 1998
 
The writers are, respectively, national coordinator of Silent March, an antigun group, and executive director, American Association of Suicidology.

SECTION: Section A; Page 27; Column 5; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 712 words

HEADLINE: Essay;
You're All Fired!

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Bored? Depressed? Stumbling and coughing a lot? Fearful your public is tiring of you, but unwilling to gamble on vigorous reforms? Take the Yeltsin Cure: grab world headlines by firing your whole Cabinet, and then hire most of them back.
A week before Russia's President flexed his shake-up muscles, Gen. Alexandr Lebed was here campaigning for governor of a region in Siberia by speaking in the U.S. That may sound odd, but it's the new Russian politics: "See this cameraman?" he said to me after telling Congress that NATO expansion is no big threat. "His film goes on television back home. I'm being pragmatic." 
 He's gambling his national future on a regional race. If Lebed loses in Krasnoyarsk, he's finished; if he wins, he'll be a prospect for president in 2000. Last time out, Yeltsin pumped money into Lebed's campaign to split the large anti-Yeltsin vote, then paid him off with a short-lived appointment before dumping him.
The formerly arrogant general must be happy about Yeltsin's latest reshuffle. Lebed's archenemy in the military, Interior Minister Anatoly Kulikov -- whose botched war in Chechnya Lebed ended -- is out on his ear. And Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin, Gore's Gazprom gasbag, has also been cut adrift.
"Chernomyrdin's like a sunflower," Lebed opined through an interpreter before the P.M. got the sickle, meaning his power was purely derivative. "When Yuri Luzhkov is no longer Mayor of Moscow, he's still Luzhkov; but take Prime Minister from Chernomyrdin, and he's nothing."
He sees Luzhkov as "a serious candidate, with money, organization." What about the Communist leader, Gennadi Zyuganov? "A scarecrow -- his ceiling is 29 percent." And Boris Nemtsov, the handsome young democrat said to be Yeltsin's favorite, soon to be reappointed? "He gets the unpopular assignments, along with taking care of the bones of the last czar. Finished."
I presumed that Yeltsin won't seek a loophole in the Russian Constitution that would enable him to run again. Lebed disagreed: "Yeltsin will run again. He's running already."
Gee -- that's what Grigory Yavlinsky, the only reformer building a national political party, has been saying all along. "There's a Russian saying, 'fools agree,' " smiled Alexandr Ivanovich. (The more pompous American expression is "great minds think alike.") What about Yavlinsky?
"Intelligent man, attracts smart people around him. Controls 8 percent of the Duma. I don't know what's the matter with Yavlinsky -- he doesn't engage but doesn't resist. Still, there's an affinity between us. Everybody says he could be kingmaker, not king."
Yesterday I reached Yavlinsky on his cell phone in Moscow (Kremlinology is easier now). The putative kingmaker gives Lebed a good chance of making a comeback in Siberia. He, too, is relieved at the fall of General Kulikov, and will not miss Chernomyrdin; he's glad his reformist ally Nemtsov remains in place.
"Firing the Government is positive," says the leader of the Yabloko party. "Yeltsin did it himself, with no advice." Wasn't Boris Berezovsky, the billionaire capitalist at odds with Chernomyrdin over a gas deal, behind the shake-up, as he has hinted? "No," says Yavlinsky flatly. "This was Yeltsin being Yeltsin, wanting a tabula rasa. He showed the seven bankers their power was not absolute. Now we'll see if he follows through."
Yavlinsky, unlike most of the bears dancing to Yeltsin's game of musical chairs, has a clear direction in mind: "Gaining people's confidence with a fair and simple tax system; ending nontaxpaying monopolies like Gazprom; breaking the criminal oligarchy, and privatizing property, including land."
That would take steady, purposeful leadership at the top, but I don't see sustained vision in a fits-and-starts reformer like Boris Yeltsin.
Yeltsin is splashing around a lot, but when it comes to building a free economy he's treading water. His only policy consistency is wrongheaded, coming from Foreign Minister Yevgeny Primakov, Saddam Hussein's loyal K.G.B. friend, whose shortsighted nationalism discourages investment from abroad.
Yeltsin will serve until he drops because he needs to stay in office to stay alive. But to struggle out of its swamp, Russia needs the daring Yeltsin of a decade ago.

HEADLINE: Home Resales Soar by 8.7% As Slowdown Proves Elusive

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 25

 BODY:
Home resales rose at a record pace in February and factories continued to receive orders for big-ticket items at healthy rates, signs of strength that confounded predictions of slowing economic growth.
"What slowdown?" said John Ryding, senior economist at Bear, Stearns & Company in New York. "There's no evidence of a slowdown in the overall economy," 
 The National Association of Realtors said today that sales of existing single-family homes rose 8.7 percent last month, to a record annual rate of 4.75 million units, up from January's 4.37 million units.
In another economic report, the Commerce Department said orders for durable goods fell 1.7 percent in February. But that was chiefly because of a big drop in aircraft orders to the Boeing Company; excluding aircraft orders, which often change sharply from month to month, durable goods orders rose half a percent in February, the seventh increase in nine months. Also, February shipments, a gauge of current activity, increased.
Because of the Asian economic crisis, policy makers at the Federal Reserve had predicted that a decline in demand for American exports would cause economic growth in the United States to slow to less than 2.75 percent this year. But most private economists have now revised their estimates for first-quarter growth to well above that pace, and some say the stronger-than-expected performance will extend into the following three months.
"We're looking at a very healthy first two quarters," said Michael Englund, chief economist at Standard & Poor's MMS in Belmont, Calif. "The Fed is going to find it increasingly difficult to use Asia as a reason for assuming a slowdown this year."
Rather than holding down the American economy, Asia has been a net benefit so far, analysts say. Because investors have flocked to the safety of American Government securities, interest rates have fallen. That has caused consumers to spend more on housing and other items.
Today's housing data showed that home resales gained in all regions of the country during February. The president of the National Association of Realtors, R. Layne Morrill, said, "We had expected demand to stay strong, but this is exceptional."
Resales account for about 85 percent of all single-family home sales in this country. The figures are based on actual closings, which reflect contracts signed a month or two earlier.
With little change in mortgage rates over the last three months -- rates have remained close to 7 percent for the average 30-year fixed loan -- the housing outlook remains healthy. The Mortgage Bankers Association of America reported today that applications for mortgages rose 7 percent last week.
Rising home sales, in turn, mean growing domestic demand. "Spending on household durables is set to get even stronger as people seek to furnish and improve their new homes," said Ian Shepherdson, chief economist at HSBC Markets Inc. in New York.
Durable goods orders and shipments reflect that demand. In a sign that factories were expanding capacity, orders for nonmilitary capital goods excluding aircraft rose 1.3 percent last month. And orders of industrial machinery, a category that includes computers, rose 3.2 percent. Over the last three months, industrial machinery orders are up 33 percent.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Durable Goods Orders" tracks manufacturers' total new orders for durable goods, in billions of dollars, seasonally adjusted, from September 1996 through February 1998. (Source: Commerce Department)

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
In the economy's success, don't forget somy lucky breaks.

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle 

 BODY:
NO ONE can argue with a straight face that the American economy is damaged or even threatened by what happened to oil this week. Sure, the producing countries announced that they intended to cut production. And in response, oil prices jumped for a day. They might even go a bit higher. But oil is still remarkably cheap, clearly a break for the national economy.
Much is made of America's current economic success. While Europe and Japan wallow, the United States economy surges ahead. To many economists, politicians and executives, that demonstrates the superiority of the American model. Ever more efficient companies, these boosters say, have generated strong profits and full employment, without having to raise prices. And in such noninflationary conditions, robust economic growth can go on indefinitely. 
 But this explanation leaves out good luck, which has played a big role in the economy's success, maybe even the decisive role. "There are some real improvements," said William Dudley, director of domestic economic research at Goldman, Sachs & Company, "but we have had a lot of blind luck, and that can change."
Three items appear on nearly everyone's list of lucky breaks for the American economy since the last recession ended in 1991 and the present expansion began. In chronological order, the first was the Soviet Union's disintegration and the end of the cold war, which unleashed a much greater worldwide output of goods and services -- more, in fact, than people wanted to buy. Then came the Asian crisis, which suppressed demand in Asia without suppressing supply. And finally, there is the year-long decline in oil prices, also a case of more supply than demand.
None of the three qualifies as all good news, of course. The Asian crisis may in time bring trouble to America. What they have in common, however, is that each has held down the inflation rate in the United States. That, in turn, has kept the Federal Reserve from slowing the economy by raising interest rates. The goal of such Fed action is to prevent the inflation rate from rising, but often a recession has resulted.
The oil phenomenon promises another respite from inflation fighting. Since autumn, the decline in oil prices has probably reduced the inflation rate by 20 percent, the Labor Department estimates. Cheap oil means lower costs, and higher profits for any company that uses oil, or oil-based materials such as chemicals and plastics. That is a huge group of companies ranging from airlines and truckers to chemical plants, utilities and manufacturers. Airlines alone have seen their fuel costs drop by 23 percent in the last year, a saving of more than $1 billion.
"The airlines are keeping some of these savings as profit, and they are passing along some to passengers," said Julius Maldutis, an airline analyst for Salomon Smith Barney. "You are seeing some significant airline ticket sales right now."
The American household, through its cars, is the biggest benefactor. The average price of a gallon of gasoline has declined to $1.06 or $1.07 from $1.25 a year ago, according to Cambridge Energy Research Associates. And even if this week's jump in oil prices to $16.35 a barrel from $13.35 earlier this month is not rolled back, the average gasoline price is still unlikely to get above $1.10 a gallon. After all, just six months ago, West Texas crude sold at more than $22 a barrel.
"The downturn in Asia and the unseasonal warm weather in America have really chopped out the anticipated growth in demand for oil," said Daniel Yergin, president of Cambridge.
When gasoline and heating oil prices fall, consumers quickly shunt their savings into other spending, stimulating the economy. That helps to explain the current brisk spending seven years into an economic expansion, says Richard T. Curtin, director of the University of Michigan's Consumer Surveys. "Gasoline price fluctuations are something people notice simply by driving into a service station," he said, "and they incorporate changes right away into their budgets."
The oil price decline is not without damage, of course. Texas and Alaska, to take two examples, depend heavily on taxes derived from oil production for their state budgets, and tax revenues have declined drastically, particularly in Alaska. Still, there is serendipity in the announcement this week of production cuts to force up the price.
At less than $14 a barrel, oil industry profits were threatened. The rebound this week to more than $15 removes that pressure and preserves profitability. "There will be pain for the oil companies," said Ann-Louise Hittle, an industry analyst with Cambridge Energy Research, "but we are not going back to disaster scenarios, unless prices go lower."
Which may make this week's uptick in price yet another stroke of good luck.

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN AFRICA: THE NEXT STOP;
A Touchy South Africa Takes Pains Not to Kowtow

BYLINE: By SUZANNE DALEY 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, March 25

 BODY:
President Clinton is spending 11 days on this continent, but he is really making two different trips: one to Africa and one to South Africa.
South Africa is of Africa, but different too. It is no hardship case dependent on foreign aid. 
 Its economy dwarfs that of any other African country. In fact, its gross domestic product is nearly half that of the rest of sub-Saharan Africa's 48 countries combined. Some 300 American companies do business here. And in Nelson Mandela, South Africa has a President whose international stature rivals Mr. Clinton's.
While the United States may be able to tell Jerry Rawlings of Ghana or Paul Kagame of Rwanda what subjects will be on the agenda, the relationship with South Africa is, if not one between equals, one between a world superpower and a regional superpower.
Yet despite its status, South Africa remains a pretty touchy country. Mr. Clinton's visit will be examined carefully here for signs that the United States is showing due respect to a nation that is wary about its sovereignty, doesn't ask for much outside help -- it does not owe the World Bank a dime -- and is unwilling to kowtow to a superpower.
The new black-led Government is hypersensitive about being told what to do, especially by the Americans. The Government sees the United States as an essentially white country that repressed its own blacks for centuries and was a tacit ally of the old apartheid state and the chief foe of African liberation struggles.
All this is not to say that South Africans are indifferent to Mr. Clinton's attentions. American companies have already invested more than $2 billion here since 1994, according to Business Map, a private group that tracks business trends here. And the Government would certainly like to see more American investment.
Moreover, officials here see the Presidential visit as helpful even in their efforts to persuade businesses from other countries to invest in South Africa. While the United States is the country's largest foreign investor, Malaysia, Britain, Germany and Japan are also big players. For days officials have been urging South Africans to take in stride the inconveniences that might arise from the Clinton visit, pointing out the potential benefits of the international attention he will bring with him.
Mr. Clinton will whip through most of the six countries he is visiting, but he will spend four days here accompanied by pomp and pageantry that other African countries cannot afford. Some, like Ghana, do not even have enough hotel rooms to accommodate the nearly 1,000 diplomatic, security and communications personnel and reporters accompanying Air Force One. Here though, Mr. Clinton plans to visit Johannesburg, the country's financial hub, and Cape Town, where he will address Parliament, be a guest at a state banquet and visit Robben Island, the prison where Mr. Mandela was held for 18 of the 27 years he spent in prison. Had he wanted, he could easily have gone to Pretoria or Durban too.
Apart from the pageantry , high-level officials on both sides are planning a host of meetings during Mr. Clinton's trip. But these get-togethers do not carry the sense of urgency and one-shot opportunity of the meetings in the other countries. The United States and South Africa have a bi-national commission, led by their Vice Presidents (they are said to get along well), which regularly meets to discuss trade, economic issues, cultural and scientific exchanges.
There is one sticky issue at the moment, though: A new South African law aimed at lowering drug prices. The South Africans say it lets them import legal drugs from wherever they are least expensive. But American drug makers say it destroys their patent rights and legalizes piracy.
Indeed, if Americans ever expected an easy relationship with the new South Africa, they have by now learned otherwise. President Mandela has proved tough-minded and independent, several times loudly and clearly rejecting American suggestions.
Last October, for example, when State Department officials protested his visit to Libya, saying it violated United Nations sanctions, President Mandela made no secret of his fury. He went ahead with the trip, lashing out at America at every stop. He said it would be immoral not to acknowledge the role that countries like Libya played in the struggle against apartheid, "one of the most brutal systems in the world."
"How can they have the arrogance to dictate to us where we should go or who our friends should be?" he said at one point. "Can you imagine if I said Boris Yeltsin should not visit Albania? They would say that I am the most arrogant black."
Other American entreaties have also fallen on deaf ears.
South Africa ignored United States displeasure with its decision to import Cuban doctors to rural areas where medical help was needed and went ahead with a deal to store Iranian oil.
South Africa's cautious relationship with the United States is no doubt influenced by the shadow of United States policy during the apartheid years.
During the Reagan and Bush Presidencies, America was no friend to the African National Congress, which in those days clung to the Socialist and one-party line.
Meanwhile, the United States -- busy with cold-war strategy -- was aligned with South Africa's white-minority Government in supporting Unita guerrilla fighters in Angola.
Many African National Congress officials from that era remember the United States as the enemy and have not taken the United States to their bosom so easily.

SECTION: Section A; Page 13; Column 5; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 885 words

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN AFRICA: A SHOWCASE;
Uganda Could Be Model For 'New' Africa's Goals

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: KAMPALA, Uganda, March 25

 BODY:
Winston Churchill called this lush, landlocked country "the pearl of Africa." Idi Amin turned it into a charnel house. Now it is a display window for an African renaissance.
Of the six countries President Clinton is visiting during his 12-day African trip, Uganda has achieved the most stunning transformation. (South Africa has replaced government by a repressive minority with government by an enlightened majority -- an extraordinary achievment. But it never experienced the economic disintegration and lawlessness that once gripped Uganda.) 
 "Ours is a country that has had a long and, in the main, sad history," said a leading Kampala newspapers, The New Vision, in an editorial welcoming the President. At the nadir, in the late 1970's, Uganda was synonymous with mindless savagery.
In his book "The Africans," written only 15 years ago, David Lamb painted a grim picture. He wrote: "Uganda no longer exists as a viable nation. Its government is a collection of outcasts and misfits serving only themselves." Only its agricultural potential, he added, "holds out any hope that Uganda could, in a generation or two, forge some kind of meaningful nationhood."
Yet Uganda's economy, little noticed by most of the world, has become the fastest growing in Africa. Security has been re-established in most of the country. Kampala is again a handsome, hilly city with lovely gardens, and a framework for democracy has been created -- including a new constitution, a free press and an independent judiciary. Two years from now, Ugandans will decide in a referendum what form of government they want.
Major American investments of the kind Mr. Clinton wants to encourage are already visible. The AES Corporation, a United States power producer with worldwide interests, is the majority shareholder in Nile Independent Power, which is building a $500 million hydroelectric plant near Bujagali on the Nile. The Coca-Cola company is building a $23 million bottling plant with African partners.
All this has come at a price.
President Yoweri K. Museveni, who took power in a coup in 1986, runs what he calls a no-party state: opposition voices are muted and the police still use strong-arm methods. A rebel movement in the north kidnaps children and sends them into battle against Government forces. Corruption remains intractable.
Nor has Mr. Museveni made much headway against the old enemy, poverty: two-thirds of all Ugandans still live lives of grinding destitution. His support appears widespread, but people still worry about the future.
"When he goes, what do we get?" a shopkeeper asked this week. "The rest are corrupt and incompetent. It's hard to plan for the future."
Mr. Museveni was described by Mr. Clinton as a model, and Administration officials often cite him as the kind of leader, along with Meles Zenawi of Ethiopia and Alpha Oumar Konare of Mali, that they would like to see in other African capitals.
One reason is geopolitical. Islamic fundamentalism has replaced militant Communism as the bugbear of American diplomacy, and Ethiopia and Uganda form a bulwark against their turbulent neighbor to the north, the Sudan. Mr. Museveni has even used his troops to support animist and Christian rebels in southern Sudan who oppose the Islamic Government in Khartoum.
Another is personal. American officials are impressed by President Museveni's tireless efforts to combat AIDS, a scourge in this country. He has tripled spending on education, especially teachers' salaries, while also beefing up his military forces.
But it is more than that. With the cold war over at last, Washington is in a mood to admit past mistakes in Africa and to make amends.
"Very often we dealt with countries in Africa and other parts of the world based more on how they stood in the struggle between the United States and the Soviet Union than how they stood in the struggle for their own people's aspirations to live up to the fullest of their God-given abilities," Mr. Clinton said at Mukono.
He might have been talking about Idi Amin, the crude, hulking dictator who ruled here from 1971 to 1979. With the United States and its European allies looking the other way, almost to the end, more than 300,000 Ugandans were murdered on his orders. Mr. Amin expelled 50,000 Asians with British passports, mostly of Indian origin, who had been Uganda's shopkeepers. Coffee plantations stood idle, shops and factories closed and the tourist industry disintegrated as roads crumbled and game herds were slaughtered for meat. Not a single hospital or school was built during Idi Amin's rule. Makerere University, once known as the Harvard of East Africa, fell into intellectual ruin.
Apolo Milton Obote, who preceded and followed Mr. Amin, was not much more of a bargain. A hard-drinking tyrant, he held power through his secret police and finished the job of dismantling the economy that Mr. Amin started.
For those who know where to look, there are reminders in today's Uganda of the bad old days. Mr. Clinton stayed at the Sheraton Hotel, once the Apolo, built during the Obote regime and named for him. And part of the press corps stayed nearby at the Nile Hotel, formerly known as the Nile Gardens, an address once feared by every Ugandan: Mr. Amin's enemies were taken there to be tortured.
